On the other hand, the scenery in Tavoy and Mergui, and among the myriad islets which fringe the Tenasserim coast, is almost English in its verdure and repose. The forests of Burma abound in fine trees. Among these, teak holds a conspicuous place, some of the finest teak forests being in Pegu. Almost every description of timber known in India is produced in the forests, from which also an abundant supply is obtained of the varnish employed by the Shans and the Burmese in their manufacture of lacquered ware. Sticklac of an excellent quality is obtained in the woods, and rubber of late years has been largely exported.

Burma is rich in minerals. It produces gold, silver, copper, tin, lead, antimony, bismuth, amber, coal, petroleum, nitre, natron, salt, limestone, and marble, the jade or yu of the Chinese, sapphires, and other precious stones. Gold is found in small quantities at Shwe-gyin, in the sands of different rivers, and also towards the Shan territory on the eastern frontier; but the demand is very much greater than the native supply. There are silver mines near the Chinese frontier, but they have not been recently worked. The mountainous districts of the Shan territory contain almost all the other metals; but they are but scantily exported, and the copper and tin seen in Mandalay are mostly imported from China. Iron is found in several places, and is wrought especially at Poppa, near a mountain of that name to the eastward of the old capital Pagan, and also at Myedu, north-west of Mandalay; but, owing to ignorance and the want of proper methods, about 30 or 40 per cent. of the metal is lost in the process. Large deposits of rich magnetic oxide, as yet untouched, exist in the ridges east of the capital near the banks of the navigable river Myit-ngoe, and the same district contains lime in great abundance, and of remarkable whiteness; while statury marble, equal to the best Italian kind, is found about 15 miles north of Mandalay, and east of the Irawadi. Mines of amber are wrought, among other places, at Hukhong or Payendwen, near the sources of Kyen-dwen. Nitre, natron, and salt are found in various quarters. Sulphur also occurs in some places, as in the district of Sale-Myo, and in the neighbourhood of the petroleum wells; but the quantity is comparatively small. Coal has been discovered in various places, and seems likely to prove the most valuable mineral of Upper Burma. Petroleum is found in Kyaik-hpyu, the Boronga Islands, Thayet-myo, and Ye-nangyaung. The precious stones produced are chiefly the sapphire and the ruby. They are found about 60 or 70 miles in a north-east direction from Mandalay, over an area of about 100 square miles.

In Lower Burma, agriculture is the main employment of the people, and it may be assumed that the production and distribution of rice occupies three-fifths of the whole population. Cotton, sesamum, and tobacco are also extensively grown; gardens and orchards are found near every village; but rice covers about six-
sevenths of the total area under cultivation. The enormous foreign demand, and the large profits recently obtained, have greatly increased the cultivation of the cereal. The Burmese are content with a single annual crop, corresponding with the *aman ropa* of Bengal. It is sown in June, transplanted in September, and reaped about December or January. Their soil is lavish in its yield, requires little labour, and no artificial stimulus beyond the ash of the past year's stubble, which is burned down and worked into the land. Year after year, without a rest, the heavy rains and this primitive manure suffice to ensure an abundant harvest. The Irawadi valley and its delta furnish about three-fifths of the whole rice produce.

The commercial prosperity of Lower Burma has more than kept pace with its rapidly-increasing population. Rangoon absorbs about 90 per cent. of the whole foreign import trade, and about 60 per cent. of the foreign export trade. The chief articles exported are rice, timber, cutch, hides, petroleum, and precious stones. The chief imports are piece-goods, silk, cotton and wool, cotton twist, gunny-bags, betel-nuts, liquors, tobacco, iron, mill machinery, and sugar.

The main commercial industries are those connected with the rice and timber trade. The indigenous manufactures of the country produce little beyond what is required for home consumption. Silk, lacquered ware, and gold and silver work, are among the most justly-admired of Burmese manufactures. The characteristics of Burmese art are vigour and novelty of design, but want of delicacy and finish in execution.

The dynasty which till recently reigned in Upper Burma was founded in the year 1752 A.D., by Alaungpaya, who, in early life a hunter, then a dacoit leader, established himself on the throne and extended his authority over the whole of Burma, including Arakan, Pegu, and Tenasserim, to the sea and the borders of Siam. The early relations of the House of Alaungpaya with the Indian Government are matters of history. In the reign of Bagyidawpaya, the seventh king and fourth in descent from Alaungpaya, occurred the first war between England and Burma, terminated in 1826 by the treaty of Yandabo, whereby the provinces of Arakan and Tenasserim were ceded to the British. In the reign of Bagyidawpaya's nephew, Pagan Min, occurred the second Burmese war, at the conclusion of which, in December, 1852, Lord Dalhousie by proclamation annexed to the Indian Empire the province of Pegu, including the deltas of the Irawadi and the Sittaung, and the valleys of those rivers as far north as the parallel of latitude six miles north of the fort at Myede. Ten years later the province was organised, and a Chief Commissioner appointed. The territory which remained to the Burmese king was the country now known as Upper Burma. The pacification of the newly-acquired province of Pegu was a work of much labour, and was not satisfactorily completed till ten years after the annexation.

Almost immediately after the end of the second war, Pagan Min was deposed by his brother, thenceforward known as Mindon Min, or King Mindon. Mindon Min was an enlightened prince who, while professing no love for the British, recognised the power of the British government, was always careful to keep on friendly terms with them, and was anxious to introduce into his kingdom, as far as was compatible with the maintenance of his own autocratic power, Western ideas and Western civilisation. He sent envoys to Europe to study the arts and manufactures of European nations; and, throughout his reign, young representatives of the families of leading men about the court were sent to England, France, and Italy, to study the languages and manners of those countries. Though the king's zeal was not always tempered by discretion, he did much to increase the revenue of the crown, and to promote the commercial prosperity of his country. In 1867, a treaty was concluded at Mandalay between the British and Burmese governments, providing for the mutual extradition of criminals, the free intercourse of traders, and the establishment of permanent diplomatic relations between the two countries. So long as Mindon Min lived, though he clung to the obsolete ceremonials to which he was accustomed, and thus debarrred the British resident at Mandalay in his later years from access to his presence, there was no breach in the friendship between England and Burma.

In October, 1878, Mindon Min died, and was succeeded by his son, the Thebaw prince. Early in 1879, the execution of a number of the members of the royal family at Mandalay excited much horror in Lower Burma. Executions of this kind were the usual incidents of a change in the occupancy of the throne of Ava. But, hitherto, owing to the remoteness of the capital of the Burmese kingdom from our own territories and to difficulty of communication, these relics of barbarism had not been forcibly presented before the eyes of the civilised world. In 1879 a British resident was stationed at Mandalay, telegraphic communication was open between Upper and Lower Burma, and trading steamers passed constantly between Mandalay and Rangoon. The cruelties which marked the accession of the new monarch attracted more notice than on previous similar occasions. The British resident was instrumental in securing the escape of some members of the royal family, and was energetic in his protests against the barbarities with which the new reign was ushered in. Indignation among Englishmen at the state of affairs in Mandalay, and resentment in the minds of the courtiers of the king on account of the attitude of the resident, combined to render imminent a breach of the friendly relations between the two countries. The immediate apprehension of war passed away; but throughout the year the tension continued, and in October, 1879, in view of the passive unfriendliness of the Burmese government, and the unsatisfactory nature of the position of the British resident in Mandalay, the government of India withdrew their representative from the Burmese court, and, as long as the native government continued to exist, no fresh agent was appointed.

These occurrences were sinister omens for the reign of King Thebaw. Nor did the progress of events afford prospect of the re-settlement of the relations between the Indian and Burmese governments. Although upon two occasions—once in 1879-80 by means of an envoy who, not being accredited with full powers, was not permitted to proceed beyond Thayetmyo; and once in 1882, when an embassy visited Simla—attempts were made to re-establish cordial relations on a satisfactory footing, there was no
real restoration of confidence and good feeling between 1879 and 1886. The action of the Burmese government gave much reason for complaint. British subjects, travellers and traders from Lower Burma, were subjected to insult and violence by local officials in Upper Burma, and representations to the central administration were often fruitless in obtaining redress. In contravention of the express terms of the treaty of 1867, monopolies were created to the detriment of the trade of both England and Burma. Owing to the weakness and corruption of the Burmese government, society became thoroughly disorganised, and the elements of disorder on our frontier became a standing menace to the peace of the British provinces. At the same time, the Burmese government showed a marked and persistent anxiety to enter into alliances with foreign powers, in such a manner and to such an extent as to give ground for apprehension that grave political trouble might hereafter result.

While the Indian government was unrepresented at Mandalay, representatives of Italy and France were welcomed, and two separate embassies were sent to Europe, one under the guise of a merely commercial mission, for the purpose of contracting new and, if possible, close alliances with sundry European powers. Neither of these missions visited England, or showed any desire to win the friendship of the representatives of the British government residing at the courts to which the Burmese envoys were accredited.

Notwithstanding these grounds of complaint, though frequently and vehemently urged to interfere in the interests of the peace and commerce of British Burma—the government of India from time to time, on review of the situation, found it unsatisfactory, but not yet intolerable, and decided that interposition in the domestic administration of Upper Burma was not necessary. Such was the state of affairs at the beginning of 1885. Early in that year, the Burmese government found or made reason for complaint against the Bombay-Burma Trading Corporation, a company of merchants, chiefly British subjects, who had extensive dealings in Upper Burma. The claim which the government advanced against the corporation was for several lakhs of rupees. In view of the magnitude of the interests which the corporation had at stake, the chief commissioner addressed the Burmese government for the purpose of securing an impartial investigation of the cause of complaint. Disregarding this attempt at mediation, the Burmese council decided the case against the corporation without giving them reasonable opportunity of being heard, and condemned them to pay a fine amounting to £230,000.

Acting under the orders of the supreme government, the chief commissioner protested against this arbitrary act of the Burmese authorities, and invited them to stay proceedings against the corporation, and to refer the matter to an arbitrator appointed by His Excellency the Viceroy. The reply of the Burmese foreign minister was that on no account should proceedings against the corporation be suspended. In view of this decisive and discourteous refusal to accept the mediation of the British government in a case where the interests of British subjects were largely involved—and bearing in mind the accumulated causes of dissatisfaction with the existing state of things—the government of India decided once for all to adjust the relations between the two countries. The chief commissioner was therefore instructed to send to the King of Burma an ultimatum requiring him to suspend action in the execution of the decree against the corporation, to receive at Mandalay an envoy from the Viceroy with a view to the settlement of the matter at issue, and, hereafter, to permit the residence at the capital of an agent of the Indian government, who should be received and treated with the respect due to the government which he represented. It was further intimated that the Burmese government would in future be required to regulate the external relations of the country in accordance with the advice of the government of India, and to afford facilities for opening up British trade with China. A letter embodying these terms was despatched by special steamer to Mandalay on the 22nd October, 1885. The Burmese government were informed that a reply must be received not later than the 10th November, and that, unless the conditions laid down were accepted without reserve, the Indian government would deal with the matter as it thought fit. In view of the possible refusal by the Burmese government of the terms offered to them, preparations were made for the despatch to Rangoon of a military force of 10,000 men. On the 9th November, a reply, amounting to an unconditional refusal of the terms, was received in Rangoon. On the 7th November, three days after the date of the reply from the Burmese minister, and two days before the receipt by the chief commissioner of that reply, the King of Burma issued a proclamation calling on his subjects to rally round him, and to resist the unjust demands of the British government, and expressing his determination to efface these heretic foreigners and conquer and annex their country. In accordance with the terms of the ultimatum, and in view of the hostile tone of the king's proclamation, the expeditionary force was ordered to advance. The frontier was crossed on the 14th November, 1885. On the 17th, Minhla, on the 23rd, Pagan, and on the 25th, Myingyan, were successively occupied. Except at Minhla, scarcely any resistance was encountered. Before the expeditionary force reached Ava, an envoy from the Burmese court arrived, and, after some negotiation, the unconditional surrender of the capital and of the royal family was arranged. On the 26th and 27th November, the forts at Ava and Sagaing were surrendered; and, on the 28th, General Prendergast and his force occupied Mandalay. The king and his two queens, with their mother, were at once sent down to Rangoon, whence the former were afterwards transferred to India, the latter to Tavoy. Simultaneously with the advance on Mandalay, operations were undertaken with success on the Thayetmyo and Toungoo frontiers.

Immediately after the occupation of Mandalay a provisional administration was constituted. All the members of the Hluttaw, or great Council of State, professed themselves willing to continue to take part in the government. They were therefore retained in office, under the guidance of Colonel (now Sir E. B.) Sladen, and the control of General (now Sir Harry) Prendergast. Theoretically there was to be no breach of continuity. The state council was to continue to discharge all its functions, and all civil officers, whether British or Burmese, were to work
under its direction. The council began by issuing proclamations to this effect, and ordering Burmese officials to continue in the regular performance of their duties.

On the 15th December, 1885, the chief commissioner arrived at Mandalay, and assumed charge of the civil administration. On the 1st January, 1886, by the Viceroy's proclamation, Upper Burma was declared to be part of Her Majesty's dominions, and placed under the direct administration of the governor-general. The shape which the settlement of Upper Burma should take was not at that time finally determined; but, after the visit of the Viceroy to Mandalay, it was resolved to incorporate Upper Burma in British India, and this was effected by command of Her Majesty with reference to the statute 21 and 22 Vic., c. 106. From the 1st March, Upper Burma with the exception of the Shan States, was constituted a scheduled district under the statute 33 Vic., c. 3.

The constitution of Upper Burma into a scheduled district removed it from the operation of the statute law, which applies to the rest of the empire. It was clearly impossible that, under the conditions subject to which the administration was being carried on, the whole body of the Indian civil and criminal law should be at once introduced into Upper Burma. The condition of the law in that province between March and November, 1886, resembled that which prevailed in the Punjab for several years after its annexation, in that the civil administration of the country was being conducted under instructions issued by the Chief Commissioner. By these instructions, civil officers were enjoined to be guided, as far as possible, by the provisions of the Indian Penal and Procedure Codes, and in matters relating to marriage, succession, &c., to be guided by personal law and local custom, or, in the absence of these, by justice, equity, and good conscience. The 'Upper Burma Laws Act' passed by the Governor-General's Council, September, 1886, was the first stage in the process of suspending these provisional arrangements by laws formerly enacted. It was the necessary preliminary to the further legislation for the province which was to be effected by regulations made by the Governor-General in Council, as empowered by Statute 33 Vict. c. 3, under the operation of which Upper Burma had been brought. The Laws Act defined the province of Burma, distinguishing between its two divisions of Upper and Lower Burma; and it declared the Indian enactments which were to be in force in Upper Burma.

The administration of the province was further placed during 1886-7 upon a legal basis by the enactment of Regulations, under the Statute 33 Vict. c. 3, Sec. 1, relating to Registration, Municipalities, Forests, Revenue Stamps, and Village Officers. The Revenue Regulation provided merely for the realisation of Government dues. The large question of the revenue administration of the country is under consideration; no radical change and no permanent adoption of the existing revenue arrangements will be attempted until the fullest information is obtained. The Village Regulation gave the headmen the position and the powers which they have exercised under the ancient régime as near as may be, and it enforced with much strictness the joint responsibility of the village in criminal matters. This is in accordance with the practice of Burma.

The Regulation has strengthened the hands of the district officers, and assisted them to maintain order. Under this Regulation a great many petty criminal cases can be disposed of by the Village Officers, who are also responsible for taking immediate action, and for reporting to the nearest police station in the case of heinous crime.

The military occupation of Mandalay was effected without the smallest difficulty, and in a manner which reflected credit on all concerned. To this, as was foreseen, succeeded a period of disorder and of straggling warfare which assumed dimensions somewhat, though not materially, exceeding what was anticipated. The same difficulties, however, were encountered upon the annexation of Lower Burma, and were not finally overcome for a period of eight years after the occupation of that province, although the general pacification of the country may be said to have been effected at the end of the third year.

The province of Upper Burma has an area larger than that of France, and contains a population which has been roughly computed at 4,000,000.* A considerable portion of this vast expanse is impenetrable jungle, and even in the more thickly populated districts there are no proper roads or bridges. During the rainy season the difficulties of communication are very much increased by the sudden rise of the rivers and numerous streams which intersect the country in all directions, and often for weeks at a time large tracts remain under water. The population, though it cannot be described as warlike in the ordinary sense of the term, has a traditional and deep-rooted love of desultory fighting, raiding, gang-robbery, and similar kinds of excitement. Villages have long standing feuds with villages, and many young peasants, otherwise respectable, spend a season or two as dacoits without losing their reputation in the eyes of their fellow-villagers. If there were any under the old régime who had scruples about engaging in dacoity pure and simple, they always had plenty of opportunity for leading a very similar mode of life as partisans of one of the numerous pretenders to the throne, one or more of whom were generally in open revolt against the de facto sovereign. As the monarchy was hereditary only in the sense of being confined to the members of a particular family—the descendants of the famous Alompra—each scion of the royal line considered himself justified in raising the banner of insurrection if he imagined that he had a fair chance of success, and he could generally plead in justification of his conduct that his successful rival on the throne had endeavoured to put him and all his near male relations to death. These various elements of anarchy no King of Burma was ever able to suppress. Sometimes a sovereign of unusual energy obtained comparative tranquility for a short period by executing or imprisoning all his more formidable rivals, and by employing energetic leaders who could break up the larger gangs of dacoits; but such periods of tranquility were never of very long duration.

King Thebaw was in administrative capacity below rather than above the average of Burmese sovereigns. In his reign the authority of the Government did not extend much beyond the

* Burma Blue Book, c. 4962, p. 103.
district of Mandalay and the immediate vicinity of the main channels of communication, and even within this limited area there was always a very large amount of anarchy and maladministration. Not a few of the men who had been raised to high office by the favour of the Court of Mandalay were in league with the dacoit leaders who roamed about Thebaw's dominions and occasionally threatened the tranquility of the contiguous British districts.

These numerous difficulties, inherent in the nature of the country, in the character of the people, and in the existing political organisation, were considerably augmented by the manner in which the overthrow of Thebaw was effected. The care and completeness with which the expedition had been prepared by the departmental and local authorities, and the promptitude and accuracy with which the plan was executed by General Prendergast and his subordinates, made all serious resistance impossible, and when our troops arrived in Mandalay after an almost bloodless campaign of a few days' duration, they found that nearly the whole of the undisciplined levies called out to oppose our advance had spontaneously melted away. This easy and rapid success, though in many respects most fortunate, tended greatly to retard the work of permanent pacification. The inordinate national vanity which forms a prominent trait of their character had preserved among the Burmese a vivid recollection of the period when they were a conquering race, very formidable to Shans, Kachins, Assamese, and other neighbouring tribes, and has enabled them to forget the reverses which they have since suffered from British and Indian troops. Unable to comprehend that their country could be permanently conquered by a ten days' campaign, they naturally regarded the dethronement and deportation of Thebaw as merely one of those 'royal incidents' to which they had been long accustomed, and to which they attribute very little significance. Without some more tangible and striking proof of the power and intentions of the invaders, they were not to be convinced by declarations or proclamations that, through the folly of their rulers, the old order of things had come to an end. This national feeling, however, savours much more of childish vanity than of stern patriotism, and it rarely assumes an aggressive form. The ordinary villagers and townsfolk, that is to say the great mass of the people, when not afraid of subsequent vengeance at the hands of insurgent leaders, generally received British officers and troops in the light-hearted friendly spirit which endears the Burmese to all foreigners who come in contact with them. Even in those localities where our troops met with some show of resistance there were no symptoms of fanaticism, political or religious; and in Mandalay itself, and in all the tranquillised districts, our officers were able to move about without fear of assassination. At the same time this feeling of national vanity, or whatever else it may be called, in conjunction with the rapidity and bloodlessness of the initial campaign, enabled the gang leaders and other ambitious chiefs both to augment the number of their adherents, and to establish at various points a good many centres of resistance to our rule. If the Burmese had been from the first duly conscious of their own national weakness, or if an adequate impression of our power had been made on the popular imagination by one or two decisive battles, they might have been more capable of understanding the real situation, and more disposed to recognise that for themselves and their country immediate submission was the wisest and most patriotic course.

The subsequent history of the pacification of Upper Burma consists of the measures taken to establish order in the country and to enter into favourable relations with the Shan States. In the Autumn of 1886, a large addition was made to the military garrison, which was raised to about 24,000 men. In the Summer of the following year, however, the garrison was somewhat reduced, and certain posts were taken over by the military police. There had been little loss to our troops from the enemy, but there had been much sickness. In the cold season of 1887-88, operations were again actively carried on in the districts where large rebel bands still remained. The two Shan columns visited all the chief Shan States, and chiefs west of the Salween River. Over the whole of this vast tract the Shan political agent received the personal submission of all the principal Sawbwas, confirmed them in their positions as tributary chiefs, settled their relations with the Government and with each other, fixed the amount of tribute to be paid by each chief, and succeeded in placing the administration of the States on a satisfactory footing. The result was that the supremacy of the British Government was now cordially acknowledged throughout this vast tract of country, tribal disputes are referred to the arbitration of the superintendent, and fighting between individual States is strictly forbidden. This result was attained without a single attack on our columns, and almost without firing a shot. Before the rainy season of 1888, all the districts of Upper Burma, except two, namely, Sagaing and Minbu, had been pacified, in so far that all the notable rebel leaders had been either killed or captured, or had surrendered; that no considerable bands of guerillas were at large; that the police had taken over the posts from the military; that settled civil administration was begun; that the civil officers were gaining touch with the people, and that the people were on the side of order, and sometimes defended themselves. Small dacoities, that is gang robberies with violence, still occur on many sides; this class of crime will not disappear from Burma for a generation or two. The districts of Sagaing and Minbu have still to be pacified, though this latter district yielded in 1887-88 a revenue of Rx. 46,800. The trans-Salween Shan States have to be visited, and the wild Chin tribes have to be quieted. These tribes are a part of the wild peoples who inhabit the great mass of tangled country bounded by Manipur and Cachar on the north, by Arakan and Bengal on the west, and by Upper Burma on the south and east. After nearly 100 years' contact with the British on the west, they are still untamed, and still indulge in murderous raids into Chittagong; so their yielding to efforts from the Upper Burma side must be slow.

The military police force has been raised to a strength of 17,000 men; they are recruited in India. They are divided into 18 battalions, with complete company organisation like regiments of the native army. Each battalion has two or more European officers. The men are armed
with the Snider rifle; they are drilled and clothed like the native army. These police have now taken over nearly all the posts formerly held by the military in the interior; the minimum garrison of each post is 40 men, with a small contingent of Burmese police to keep touch with the people; no police patrol consists of less than 10 men. Each post keeps communication with its neighbours by patrols. A proportion of the military police are provided with ponies, and are employed like mounted infantry. The military police have already done excellent service, and are as efficient as the native infantry of the army in pursuing dacoits.

Upper Burma, though inferior in point of fertility to the low-lying tracts of Lower Burma, is far from unproductive. The chief crops are rice (of which the Burmese count 102 different sorts), maize, millet, wheat, various pulses, tobacco, cotton, sesamum, mustard, and indigo. The sugar-cane appears to have been long known to the Burmese; but, though the climate and soil are extremely favourable, it is not generally cultivated. A cheap and coarse sugar is obtained from the juice of the Palmyra palm, which abounds in the tract south of Mandalay. The cocoa-nut and areca palms are not common. The tea-plant, which is indigenous, is cultivated in the hills by some of the mountain tribes at the distance of about five days' journey, and by others in still greater perfection at the distance of about ten days' journey from Mandalay. It seems, however, to be another plant, probably the Elaeodendron persicum, which furnishes the principal ingredient in the halapet, or pickled tea, that forms a favourite Burmese delicacy, and is an essential accompaniment to every social or ceremonial incident. Cotton is grown in every part of the kingdom and its dependencies, but chiefly in the dry lands and climate of the upper districts. Indigo is indigenous, and is universally cultivated, but in a very rude manner; it is still more rudely manufactured, so as to be wholly unfit for exportation abroad.

One of the most urgent wants of the country is land communication. There is abundance of waterway, however, throughout the delta all the year round, but the Sittaung valley has no such advantages. There are lines of railway, from Rangoon to Prome, and from Rangoon to Toungu.

The railway from Toungu to Mandalay was sanctioned in November, 1886; the survey was pushed on and completed by the summer of 1887; work begun on each section as soon as the estimates were sanctioned; and so rapidly has the work been carried on that 50 miles were opened in the spring of 1888, and an engine ran through from Toungu to Mandalay, a distance of 220 miles, by the 1st May, 1888. The line was carried over temporary timber bridges at the outset; but permanent brick and iron bridges are being constructed, and will be completed by the spring of 1889. The line will be finished within the estimated cost; and though at the beginning the work practically lay through an enemy's country, there have been no disasters to surveying or working parties, and hardly any loss of life from rebels or dacoits to the many thousands of workmen on the line. The lengths of embanked, bridged, and partially metalled roads made, or in good progress, outside Mandalay town, aggregate 422 miles, of which the chief are the Ruby Mines road, the Shan plateau road from Hlaingdet, the Shwebo and Yeu road, the Monywa road, the Taundweingyi road, the Nape road; on the hill lengths a mule road is being made in the first instance. Many hundred miles of tracks were cleared through the jungle for the safer passage of troops and patrols. Very many roads are still wanted, more especially feeder roads to the railway; but the progress made in what at the outset was a hostile country is considerable.

NATIVE STATES.

That the territories of the Native States of India occupy no small proportion of the entire Indian peninsula and contain about one-fifth of the whole population of the country will be seen from the statistical table printed at page 152.

Many of the Feudatory States are governed almost independently by their own rulers, but they are all subject in a greater or less degree to supervision and guidance at the hands of the British Government. They may be divided into two main heads: (1) States holding direct relations with the Governor-General in Council; and (2) States holding relations primarily with the several Local Governments of India.

States Under the Direct Supervision of the Governor-General in Council.

1. Hyderabad.—The Hyderabad State is roughly co-extensive with the Deccan or central plateau of Southern India and takes its name from its capital city. With the exception of the assigned districts known as Berar, a tract of some 17,000 square miles, the whole of this province is governed by the Nizam. The total area including Berar is about 98,000 square miles, and the population is estimated to be about 124 millions, one-tenth being Muhammadans. The ruling dynasty is of Turkoman origin, the name of the first Sovereign being Chin Killich Khan, also known as Asaf Jah, who was appointed to be Viceroy of the Deccan by the Mogal Emperor Aurungzeb in the year 1713. During the dissensions in the Empire subsequent to the death of Aurungzeb, Asaf Jah succeeded in asserting his own independence. The Assigned Districts of Berar are administered by British officers in trust for the Nizam, and the Government maintains out of their revenues an auxiliary force of four cavalry regiments, four field batteries of artillery, and six regiments of infantry. The raison d'être of this force was primarily that it might be of use to the Nizam, but it is available also under treaty for general service with British troops when required. The surplus revenue derived from Berar, after paying for the cost of the administration, is paid to the Nizam's Government, and now amounts to nearly 20 lakhs of rupees per annum.

2. Mysore.—The Mysore State is situated in Southern India between 11° 40' and 15° N. lat., and between 74° 40' and 78° 30' E. long., and is surrounded on all sides by British territory. Its total area is 24,723 square miles, and it contains a population of over 4 millions. The inhabitants are almost exclusively Hindus, who constitute more than 94 per cent. of the whole population. In early times Mysore was the principal seat of the Jains, who have left many interesting memorials of their occupation. The State has always been under Hindu rulers except during the short
interval caused by the usurpation of power during the 18th century by Haidar Ali and his son, Tippu Sultan. After the defeat of the latter, at the siege of Seringapatam in 1799, A.D., the English restored a representative of the ancient line in the person of Krishna Raj, son of Chama Raj of Arakotara. His subsequent misrule, when admitted to power on attaining his majority, led to the resumption of the administrative control of the province by the British Government in the year 1831. The government, however, continued to be carried on in the name of the Native Prince, and at his death an adopted son was recognised as successor. This Chief was duly installed on coming of age in 1881. The British Chief Commissioner thereupon handed over office to the Native Diwan, and a Political Resident was appointed to represent British interests.

3. Baroda.—This State includes all the territories of his Highness the Gaekwar. Its total area is 8,570 square miles, and it contains a population of 2,185,000 souls, the majority of whom, over 80 per cent., are Hindus. The province of Guzerat was at one time included in the Mogal Empire, but, in the early part of the seventeenth century, the Mahrattas, under the leadership of Damaji Gaekwar, and afterwards of his son, Pilaji, succeeded in wresting all power out of the hands of the Mogal officers. From that time Baroda has remained continuously under the sway of the Gaekwar family, who held it in the first instance under the Mahrahta Peshwa subject to a tributary payment, but afterwards threw off their allegiance and became feudatory to the British Government under the guarantee of a treaty executed in the year 1817. The British Government is represented at the Court of the Baroda State by a Political Officer, called the Governor-General's Agent.

4. Kashmir and Jammu.—This Native State includes, in addition to the district of Kashmir proper, Jammu, Punch, and the Governorships of Ladakh and Gilgit. The area is estimated to be 80,900 square miles. There has been no census since the year 1873, but the population may be roughly stated at 1,600,000. Kashmir became part of the Mogal Empire in 1586 A.D., but it was afterwards subjugated both by the Afghans and the Sikhs. At the time of the Sikh War the State was under the government of Gulab Singh, a Sikh officer, who ruled as a feudatory of the Maharaja of the Punjab. After the victory of the British forces in 1846, the possession of the kingdom was confirmed to Gulab Singh, under certain specified conditions of alliance and subordinate co-operation, by a separate treaty executed at Amritsar in the same year. A Political Resident is permanently stationed with the head-quarters of the Kashmir State to represent the authority of the Governor-General, and to carry on the political relations between the two Governments. The Maharaja pays a small annual tribute in token of the supremacy of the British power. The ruling family is Hindu, but the greater number of the inhabitants of the country, considerably more than half, are Muhammadans, and chiefly of the Sunni sect.

5. Kalat.—The Khan of Kalat is head of the Baluchistan tribal chiefs whose territories are comprised under the following divisions:—Jhalawan, Sarawan, Makran, Las, and Kachh Gandava. These districts form what may be termed Kalati Baluchistan, and occupy an area of about 80,000 square miles. The inhabitants of the country are either Brahuis or Baluchis, both being Muhammadans of the Sunni sect. The country is sparsely populated, the total number being roughly estimated at 350,000 persons only. It derives its chief importance from its position with regard to Afghanistan on the North-Western Frontier of British India. The Khan of Kalat is under a treaty obligation of subordinate cooperation with the British Government. The Governor-General's Agent in Baluchistan is the Political Officer who conducts the relations between the Government of India and the Khan.

6. Rajputana Agency.—Rajputana is the name of a great territorial circle, situated between 23° and 30° N. lat., and between 69° 30' and 78° 15' E. long. Within these limits are twenty Native States, having each its own autonomy and separate Chief, together with the British district of Ajmere-Merwara. Of the Native States, 17 are Rajput, 2 are Jat, Bhartpur and Dholpur, and 1 only is Muhammadan, Tonk. Their combined area is about 130,000 square miles, and they contain a population of over 10 millions. The chief administrative control of the British District is vested ex officio in the Political Officer, who holds the post of Governor-General's Agent for the supervision of the relations between the several Native States of Rajputana and the Government of India.

7. **Central India Agency**.—Central India is the name given to the country occupied by the Native States grouped together under the supervision of the Political Officer in charge of the Central India Agency. These States lie between 21° 24' and 26° 32' N. lat., and between 74° 0' and 83° 0' E. long. The British Districts of Jhansi and Lalitpur divide the Agency into two main divisions—Native Bundelkhand and Baghelkhand lying to the east, and Central India proper to the west. The total area covered is not less than 75,000 square miles, and the population amounts to over 9 millions. The great majority of the people are Hindus. The principal States are 6 in Number—Gwalior, Indore, Bhopal, Rewa, Dhar, and Jaora, of which two, Bhopal and Jaora, are Muhammadan, and the rest are Hindu. Besides these there are a multitude of petty States held by their rulers under the immediate guarantee of the British Government, but having feudal relations with one or other of the larger States. The total number of States amounts to 69, and the petty Chiefships to 79—total, 148.

### STATES UNDER THE LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND ADMINISTRATIONS.

1. **Under the Government of Madras**.—The Madras Presidency includes five Native States covering an area of 9,638 square miles, with a population of 3,344,349 souls. Revenue, £921,300.

Of these States, Travancore and Cochin represent ancient Hindu dynasties. Pudukota is the inheritance of a Chieftain called Tondiman. Banganapalli and Sandur, two petty States, of which the first is ruled by a Nawab, lie in the centre of two British districts. The principal States are:

| Name | Area | Population | Revenue |
|------|------|------------|---------|
| Cochin | 1,361 | 600,278 | £161,800 |
| Travancore | 6,730 | 2,401,158 | 666,600 |
2. Under the Government of Bombay.—The Native States in this Presidency number about 370. Area, 71,935 square miles. Population, 6,976,109. Revenue, £2,996,000.

The characteristic feature of the Bombay States is the excessive number of petty principalities, governed mostly by Rajput and Bhil Chieftains. The Peninsula of Kathiawar alone contains no less than 188 separate States. The recognition of these innumerable jurisdictions is due partly to the circumstance that the early Bombay Administrators were induced to treat the de facto exercise of civil and criminal jurisdiction by a landholder as carrying with it a quasi-sovereign status, and partly to the fact that some of the minor States have at various times been partitioned amongst members of the ruling families.

3. Under the Government of Bengal there are twenty-nine States. Area, 39,234 square miles. Population, 2,853,405. Revenue, £245,900.

These States may be divided into two groups: the first consisting of the petty States attached to the Orissa and Chota Nagpur Divisions, 26 in number; and the other comprising the States of Kuch Behar and Sikkim to the north, and Hill Tipperah to the east of Bengal. The inhabitants of the first group are hillmen of Kolarian or Dravidian origin, and their condition is still very primitive. Kuch Behar is inhabited by an Indo-Chinese people, the Koch. The population of Sikkim consists of Lepchas, Bhutias and Limbus. Hill Tipperah is the home of a race, partly Indo-Burmese, and partly drawn from the Eastern Himalayas.

4. Under the Government of the N.-W.-P. and Oudh, the native territory comprises the following two States, the first being ruled by a Muhammadan, and the second by a Hindu, dynasty.

| Tehri (Garhwal) | 1,180| 199,836    | £14,200 |

Rampur is nearly equally divided between Muhammadans and Hindus. The inhabitants of Tehri are chiefly Hindus.

5. Under the Government of the Punjab there are thirty-four States, varying considerably in size and importance. Area, 35,817 square miles. Population, 3,861,683. Revenue, £1,119,100.

The Punjab States may be grouped under three main classes. The Hill States, 23 in number, lying among the Punjab Himalayas and held by some of the most ancient Rajput families in all India. Along the western half of the southern border lies the Muhammadan State of Bahawalpur. The remaining States, including the Sikh Principalities of Patiala, Jind, Nabha, Kapurthala, Faridkot and Kalsia, and the Muhammadan Chiefships of Maler Kotla, Pataudi, Loharu and Dujana, lie east of Lahore, and, with insignificant exceptions, occupy the centre of the eastern plains of the province.

6. Under the Chief Commissioner of the Central Provinces are fifteen States. None of them is of any size or importance. Their total area is 28,834 square miles, with a population of 1,709,720 persons. Revenue, £77,790. The inhabitants are chiefly Hindus and aborigines.

7. Under the Chief Commissioner of Assam there is only one State—Manipur. Its area is 8,000 square miles, and it has a population of 220,000, principally Hindus. Revenue, £9,000.

8. Under the Chief Commissioner of Burma there are some Shan States and other petty Chiefships, the population and revenue of which are at present unknown.

THE INDIA OFFICE LIST.

RECORD OF THE PUBLIC SERVICES OF OFFICERS AND OTHERS.

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICES.

ABBOTT, Henry B., Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1861; arrived in India, Nov., 1861; served with the 109th foot; served as assistant resident, Aden, 1865 to 1869; from Oct., 1869, to Feb., 1874, served as assistant agent, Rajputana, and acted as magistrate of Abu, and assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, 1872-73; officiating settlement officer, Ulwur, 1874-75; officiating political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, 1875; political assistant, Maunpoor, and deputy Bheel agent, 1875-76; on special duty at Jhallawar, 1876-77; superintendent of Jhallawar, from March, 1876; graded as additional political agent, 1st class.

ACWORTH, Harry Arbuthnot (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Brighton College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector of stamp revenue and political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, revenue, financial, and general departments, Oct., 1879; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, March, 1881; from April, 1881, served as assistant collector, deputy collector, and acting junior collector of salt revenue; member of the mixed commission at Goa, Dec., 1884; deputy municipal commissioner, July, 1885; deputy collector of salt revenue, Aug., 1885; acting junior collector and magistrate, Aug., 1887.

ADAMS, George, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1861; from April, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; deputy commissioner, Lalitpur, in the Jhansi commission, April, 1877; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, in 1878 and 1880; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1883.

ADAMSON, Charles Henry Ellison, Major M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1868; served with 5th brigade at Kirkee and Rangoon till 1870; admitted to the Madras staff corps, 1870; joined the Burma commission, Dec., 1871, and served as assistant magistrate, assistant commissioner, and officiating magistrate, and president of municipal committee, Rangoon; deputy commissioner, June, 1885; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, Bhamo.

ADAMSON, Harvey, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived at Rangoon, 17th Dec., 1877; served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; 1st grade settlement officer, June, 1886; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, April, 1888.

ADDIS, David Foulis, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Universities of Glasgow and Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, and grade, Dec., 1883; 1st grade, August, 1887.

AGNEW, William Fischer (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Burma.—Reporter for Indian law reports, high court, Calcutta, from Feb., 1877; officiated as editor in 1879, 1882, and 1883; law lecturer, Presidency College, 1879; advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1879; recorder of Rangoon, March, 1884; officiating judge, high court, Calcutta in 1885 and 1886, author of 'Law of Patent,' 'The Statute of Frauds,' 'The Law of Trusts in India,' 'The Criminal Procedure Code,' and 'Index to Indian Acts.'

AHISANUDDIN AHMAD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Appointed assistant magistrate and collector on probation under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1881; confirmed in the statutory civil service, Oct., 1887.

AIKMAN, Robert Smith, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Madras College, St. Andrew's, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1867, and serve in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine relief duty, Feb. to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1879; from March 1884 served in
the judicial department, and was appointed judge, 3rd grade, Mainpuri, Oct., 1886.

AINSLIE, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1845; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector in Cuttack; and was specially employed in 1850-51 and 1851-52 in the suppression of Meriah sacrifices in the Khond districts; magistrate of Rungpore, July, 1852; railway commissioner, East Indian railway, Jan., 1856, to March, 1857; magistrate and collector, Bhagulpore, March, 1857; railway commissioner, Eastern Bengal railway, 1858, and subsequently of the South-Eastern railway also; from Aug., 1863, served in the judicial department, and was appointed civil and sessions judge of Patna, Jan., 1864; president, tea commission, Nov., 1867, to April, 1868; officiated as judge of the high court, Calcutta, from Nov., 1870, and was confirmed in that appointment May, 1873; retired, April, 1880.

AITCHISON, Sir CHARLES UMPHERSTON, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., M.A., LL.D., D.O.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 21st Sept., 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner and magistrate; transferred to Punjab, May, 1857; personal assistant to judicial commissioner, July, 1858; officiating under secretary, government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1859; deputy-commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1865; officiating commissioner, Lahore, Aug., 1867; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1867; from April, 1868, served in the foreign department, government of India, as officiating secretary, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1870; on special duty in Thagi and Dakaiti department, Oct., 1877; chief commissioner, British Burma, 31st March, 1878; provisional member, governor-general's council, July, 1880; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 4th April, 1882, to April, 1887; member, governor-general's council, 2nd April, 1887; has published "Manual of the Criminal Law of the Punjab," 1860; "Treaties, Engagements, and Sanads relating to India and the Neighbouring Countries;" and "The Native States of India."

AITCHISON, John R., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Clapham Grammar School; supernumerary writer, 14th Feb., 1860; clerk in registry department, Oct., 1860, and employed in military department, 1867; junior clerk, Nov., 1872; funds department, 1873; military department, 1874; deputy resident clerk 1880-84; senior clerk, March, 1885.

ALCOCK, JOHN BACKHOUSE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, and railway magistrate; from Jan., 1884, served as assistant judge and sessions judge, and as acting judge and sessions judge.

ALEXANDER, ERNEST BRUCE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1874, to March, 1881, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer in Fatehpur and Moradabad, and was appointed junior secretary to the board of revenue in addition to his other duties in 1877, and was placed on special duty under the orders of the board, Feb., 1879; served subsequently as assistant magistrate, and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and acted for various periods as small cause judge, and magistrate, and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Sept., 1885; author of "Gazetteer of Gorakhpur," and "Settlement Report of Moradabad."

ALEXANDER, GEORGE, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign H.M. 70th regiment, Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 30th Jan., 1861; from April, 1869, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner; town magistrate, Akyab, Jan., 1879; appointed a deputy commissioner, Feb., 1882, and promoted to 3rd grade, March, 1885; president, Prome Municipal Committee, July, 1885; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1888.

ALEXANDER, Moses, India Office Stores Department.—Appointed 2nd class clerk, March, 1888.

ALEXANDER, NATHANIEL STUART, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 10th July, 1858; from Oct., 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; commissioner, Dacca division, Aug., 1884; commissioner of Bhagulpore, Dec., 1885; and of Burdwan, Aug., 1887.

ALISON, Sir ARCHIBALD, Bart., G.C.B., Lieutenant-General.—Member of the council of India; 1st commission ensign 72nd foot, 3rd Nov., 1846; captain, Nov. 1853; major unattached, Dec., 1856; brevet colonel, March, 1867; lieutenant-general, Nov., 1882; served in the Crimean campaign of 1855, and was present at siege of Sevastopol (medal and clasp and Turkish medal); served in the Indian mutiny, and was military secretary to the commander-in-chief, Aug., 1857, to March, 1858; was present at relief of Lucknow (wounded—arm lost), medal and clasp; brevet of lieutenant-colonel and C.B.; in staff employment adjutant general's department at headquarters, and in the south-western district, and at Aldershot, 1862 to 1873; served in the Ashantee war of 1873-4 as brigadier-general of European brigade, and was present at the battle of Amoafai, capture of Bequah, action of Ordashu, and taking of Coomassie; received thanks of both houses of parliament, medal with clasp, and K.C.B.; deputy adjutant general headquarters Ireland, Oct., 1874, to Dec., 1877; commandant staff college, Jan.-April, 1878; deputy quartermaster-general intelligence branch, May, 1878-Aug., 1882; served in the Egyptian expedition of 1882 as major-general in command of troops at Alexandria, and on the Mahmoudiyeh canal, and in command of 3rd brigade, and division, at battle of Tel-el-Kebir; received thanks of both houses of parliament, medal with clasp, bronze star, 2nd class Osmanich; promoted lieutenant-general for distinguished service; commanding division Aldershot, Aug., 1883, to Feb., 1885; and again Oct., 1885; adjutant-general to the forces, Feb., Sept., 1885; appointed member of the council of India, Jan., 1886.

ALLEN, CHARLES FRANCIS EGERTON, B.A. (Cantab), Judicial Department, Burma.—Called
to the bar (Inner Temple) 1871; admitted advocate of high court, Calcutta, Nov., 1873; law examiner, Calcutta University, Dec., 1874, and again in 1875 and 1876; acting judge of the Calcutta court of small causes, 1875-76; lecturer on English law in the Presidency College, Calcutta, Feb., 1876, and professor of law (temporary) May, 1877; from June, 1877, served as government advocate, Rangoon, and acted as recorder of Rangoon for various periods.

ALLEN, CHARLES GEORGE HILLERSDEN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Haileybury and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1886.

ALLEN, DAVID BIRD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant to director-general of statistics, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and under the director of the agricultural department, May, 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1887; has also acted as magistrate and collector.

ALLEN, PERCY UNDERHILL, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces, &c).—Educated at University College School, Cheltenham College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885.

ALLEN, THOMAS TAYLOR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Cork; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1861; from Nov., 1861, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1867; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, April, 1880; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1881, and again, Jan. to Dec., 1883, and Nov., 1886; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1883.

ALLEN, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate, acting 1st class deputy collector in Scinde, acting assistant conservator of forests, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; 1st assistant collector, Dec., 1882; acted as collector and magistrate of various districts.

ALLISON HAZLETT, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service as surgeon, Sep., 1873; arrived in India, 29th April, 1874, and served on military duty from July, 1874; acted as fort surveyor, Fort St. George, medical inspector of seamen, and professor of anatomy in medical college at various periods; surgeon-major, Sept., 1885; fort surgeon, Fort St. George, with fort and marine duties, and professor of anatomy in the medical college, and medical inspector of seamen, Jan., 1888.

AMBICA CHURN SEN, Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884, on probation; confirmed in the statutory civil service, Feb., 1886; on duty under the director of the agricultural department, May, 1885.

AMIRTO LAL CHATTERJEE, B.L.—From 10th May, 1866, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, Moorshedabad, April, 1873; subordinate judge, Nuddea, Jan., 1880; 1st grade subordinate judge, Jan., 1880.

ANDERSON, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Gordon's Hospital, New Grammar School, and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and forest settlement officer; on special duty, Jan.-May, 1878, and again, Nov., 1881, in the forest department; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Sept., 1883; 1st grade, Feb., 1887.

ANDERSON, FRANCIS CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, Oct., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Aug., 1881; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Feb., 1882; acted as secretary to chief commissioner in Oct., 1882, 1885, and March, 1888; prepared excise manual for the Central Provinces, 1885.

ANDERSON, HENRY AIKEN, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1873, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was appointed officiating under secretary to Government, Punjab, March, 1880, and assistant political officer, Kurram, under the Government of India, Aug., 1880; on special duty, camp of exercise, Delhi, Nov., 1885; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1885; officiating district judge, Peshawur, May, 1886; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1888.

ANDERSON, JAMES, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; on special duty connected with the Wahabi case, June, 1870; retired, 1888.

ANDERSON, JAMES DRUMMOND, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan.-Dec., 1882; assistant commissioner, 1st grade,
July, 1886; author of 'A Short List of Words of the Hill Tipperah Language,' 1885.

ANDERSON, JOHN ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Grammar School and University of Aberdeen, and was also a student of the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1880; officiating deputy commissioner, May, 1887; officiating divisional judge, March, 1888.

ANDERSON, J. W. M., Colonel, late Bombay S.C., Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—First commission, Jan., 1855; from Nov., 1863, served in the revenue survey department Mysore, as assistant superintendent and deputy superintendent; from April, 1881, served as superintendent of the Scinde settlement survey; 1st grade superintendent, Jan., 1885; retired, March, 1888.

ANDERSON, ROBERT HILDEBRAND, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1876; served as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

ANDERSON, W. R. L., Captain, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Oct., 1870, 63rd foot; admitted to the Bombay staff corps, Oct., 1871; aide-de-camp to Governor of Bombay, 1876; deputy accountant-general, military department, Jan., 1882; served in the Egyptian war, 1882; medal and Khedive's star.

ANDREW, DAVID CLAPHAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal S.C., Survey of India.—Ensign, Bengal Infantry, Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 7th March, 1860; joined the revenue survey department as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1862; deputy superintendent of revenue survey, 3rd grade, Jan., 1878; was in charge of Bassein District, British Burma survey, Nov., 1879, and was transferred to the South Deccan survey, Nov., 1880; and grade deputy superintendent, March, 1886.

ANDREW, JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

ANDREWS, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 30th March, 1876.

ANLEY, GEORGE AUGUSTUS D'AUVERGNE, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the government of India as executive engineer, 4th class, 25th Jan., 1861; served in the Bengal public works department, and temporarily under the municipality of Calcutta; officiating assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1876; held charge of office of chief engineer, and secretary to Government of Bengal, Dec., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1882; 2nd class, March, 1886.

ANNESLEY, ROBERT, Major, Bengal U.C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Served from 4th Jan., 1871, as assistant district superintendent of police and officiating cantonment magistrate, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, June, 1877; judge, small cause court, June, 1880.

ANSON, GEORGE WEMYSS, Major, B.S.C. (N.W. Provinces).—1st commission, 11th Jan., 1867; private secretary and A.D.C. to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, May, 1871, and Feb., 1875—June, 1878; from April, 1872, served as officiating cantonment magistrate and officiating assistant commissioner; confirmed in latter appointment, Sept., 1875, and in the former, Sept., 1877; agent, Belurampur estate, June, 1886.

ANUNDORAM BOROOAH (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Gowhatty Government School, and Presidency College, Calcutta University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1872; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1885; has also officiated as magistrate and collector; author of an English-Sanskrit dictionary.

ARBUTHNOT, SIR ALEXANDER JOHN, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Madras C.S., member of the Council of India.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury College, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, Sept., 1842; served in the revenue department as assistant collector and magistrate, and also held the posts of Malayan translator to government, secretary to the college and university boards, and deputy and acting registrar to the Sudder court; director of public instruction, March, 1855; chief secretary to government and additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Oct., 1862; member of Madras Council, Oct., 1867, to Oct., 1872; temporary governor of Madras in the absence of Lord Napier, Feb.-May, 1872; retired from the Madras civil service, Oct., 1874; member of governor-general's council, June, 1875, to 1880, and acted as president of the council, Nov., 1878, and March, 1879; vice-chancellor of the university of Madras, Oct., 1871, and of the university of Calcutta, Oct., 1878; counsellor of the Empress of India, Jan., 1877; appointed Member of the Council of India, 1 Nov., 1887; is the author of various publications on educational and other subjects in connection with India, among which are 'Reports of selected cases determined in the Court of Foudari Adawlut,' 1851; 'Compilation of papers relating to public instruction in Madras,' 1855; 'Memoir of Sir Thomas Munro,' 1881, &c.

ARBUTHNOT, SIR CHARLES GEORGE, Lieut.-General, K.C.B., R.A.—1st commission, Royal Artillery, June, 1843; served in the Crimean campaign, 1855, and was present at the siege and fall of Sevastopol (medal and clasp, brevet of major, 5th class Medjidie, Turkish medal); deputy adjutant-general, R.A., in Bengal, March, 1873, to Sept., 1877; acted as inspector-general of ordnance, Oct., 1877, to Sept., 1878; inspector-general of artillery in India, Sept., 1878, to July, 1880, during which period he served as brigadier-general in the operations in Afghanistan (medal, K.C.B.); deputy adjutant-general, R.A.; with the headquarters of the army in
England, Sept., 1880, to Aug., 1883; inspector-general of artillery in England, Sept., 1883, to April, 1885; president, ordnance committee, May, 1885, to Jan., 1886; commander-in-chief, and member of the governor's council, Bombay, 16th Feb., to Dec., 1886; commander-in-chief, and member of council, Madras, 9th Dec., 1886.

ARBUTHNOTT, John Campbell, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Bhagalpur, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner.

ARDAGH, John Charles, C.B., Col., R.E., F.R.G.S., Private Secretary to Governor-General of India.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; entered royal engineers as lieutenant, 1st April, 1859; captain, Aug., 1872; major, Nov., 1878; lieutenant-colonel, Nov., 1882; colonel, Nov., 1887; attached to the special embassy during the congress at Berlin, June, 1878, and was made a C.B. (civil), July, 1878; appointed assistant to Her Majesty's commissioner for the delimitation of the frontier of Bulgaria, Sept., 1878; appointed commissioner for the demarcation of the Greek frontier, June, 1881; was employed during the conference at Berlin on the Greek frontier in 1880, and during the conference at Constantinople on the same subject in 1881; served in the Egyptian campaign of 1882-4, including the operations at Alexandria, and the battle of Tel-el-Kebir (medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet of lieutenant-colonel and 4th class of Osmanli); served in the Soudan in 1884, commanding royal engineers and chief of the intelligence department; battles of Teb and Tamai; 2 clasps, C.B. (military), May, 1884; served in Soudan expedition, 1884-5—Nile; commandant of Basc at Cairo, and in the expedition of 1885-6 with the frontier field force; has received the 3rd class of the Medjidieh; appointed private secretary to the Right Hon. the Marquess of Lansdowne, governor-general of India, Dec., 1888.

ARGYLL (Duke of), His Grace George Douglas Campbell, K.T.—Born in 1823; succeeded to the dukedom in 1847; took an active part in the controversy in the Presbyterian Church of Scotland relating to patronage, and published various pamphlets and essays in connection therewith, 1842-1848; elected chancellor of the University of St. Andrew's, 1851; lord privy seal, 1852-1855; postmaster general, 1855; lord privy seal, 1859; in 1860 he was again appointed postmaster general, and subsequently lord privy seal; secretary of state for India, Dec., 1868, to Feb., 1874; lord privy seal, May, 1880; resigned in April, 1881; elected rector of the university of Glasgow, Nov., 1854; presided over the 25th annual meeting of the British Association, held at Glasgow, Sept., 1855; president of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, 1861; is hereditary master of the Queen's household in Scotland, a trustee of the British Museum, and hereditary sheriff and lord lieutenant of Argyllshire; published the 'Reign of Law' in 1866; 'Primeval Man' 1869; a small work on the history and antiquities of Iona, 1870; 'The Patronage Act of 1874, 1874; observations 'On the important question involved in the relation of Landlord and Tenant,' 1877; and in 1879, 'The Eastern Question from the Treaty of Paris to the Treaty of Berlin, and to the second Afghan War.'

ARMSTRONG, Francis B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham Proprietary College, and King Edward's School, Birmingham; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 30th March, 1869; senior clerk, Sept., 1883.

ARMSTRONG, John Arthur, Major, R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—1st commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, Nov. 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant engineer; served in the Hazara Campaign, 1868, as assistant engineer in charge of field telegraph; executive engineer, Sept., 1869; assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government, April, 1877; served in Kashmir on special road work, 1881-82; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1886; retired, March, 1887.

ARMSTRONG, John Scobell, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd March, 1866; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, and collector of customs, Calcutta, April, 1883; port commissioner, Calcutta, Nov., 1887.

ARNOLD, George, late Store Department, India Office.—Clerk in storekeeper's department, Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, Oct., 1855, to Dec.; 1858; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, Dec., 1858; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877, retired, 1886.

ARNOTT, James, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Glas.) Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct. 1867, and was employed under the military department till Aug. 1868, including service in the Abyssinian Expedition (medal), and subsequently as assistant-surgeon in the David Sassoon Hospital, Poona, and in the European General Hospital, Bombay, and as professor of pathology in the Grant Medical College; also acted as civil surgeon, and registrar of marriages, Poona, and in medical charge of the Deccan and civil engineering colleges, and as superintendent of the lunatic asylum and jail; acting surgeon, Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital, Bombay, Jan., 1878; also acted as presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay; surgeon, European general hospital, Bombay, March-April, 1882; professor of midwifery, Grant Medical College, and obstetric physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital from April., 1882.

ARTHUR, Sigismund Raynor, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay Civil Service after Open Competition of 1886.

ARUNDEL, Arundel Tagg, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; served in various districts of Madras from Aug., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate; private secretary to governor of Madras, July, 1875; acting deputy director, revenue settlement, April, 1878; president of the municipal commission, Madras, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; principal assistant to collector and magistrate and agent Vizagapatam Oct. 1884;
district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1884; collector and magistrate, Kistna, Dec., 1885.

ASHBURNER, Lionel R., C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1848; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Broach, Surat, and Kaira; on the outbreak of the mutiny in 1857, was appointed superintendent of police, Kaira, and organised a body of horse and foot for the protection of the eastern frontier; special commissioner for trial of rebels, 1858; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1861; revenue and police commissioner, N. division, 1872; member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1877; retired, 1883.

ASHTON, G., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 7th April, 1884; attached to financial department.

ASHUTOSH GUPTA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules; assistant magistrate and collector, Lohardugga, on probation, March, 1885; confirmed, July, 1885.

ASTON, Henry Faure (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay, C.S.—Educated at the South African College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political assistant in Kathiawar (April, 1871, to June, 1874), acting judge and sessions judge, railway magistrate and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881, to March, 1883; 1st grade assistant judge and sessions judge, Aug., 1883; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, March, 1885; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Nov., 1886; acting 1st grade judge, 1887; on special duty in connection with settlement cases, Baroda.

ATKINS, John De Courcy, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; acted as under-secretary to government, Bombay, revenue, financial, &c., departments, in April, 1886.

ATKINSON, Edwin Felix Thomas, B.A., C.I.E., F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Irish Missionary College, Ballinasloe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from July, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dün, and was placed on special duty under the forest department, July, 1870; in charge of N.W.
