Provinces' Gazetteer, for various periods, 1871-1875; officiating junior secretary to government, May, 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1874, and in 1875; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, April to Nov., 1875; judge, small cause court, Allahabad, March, 1877; from March, 1877, served under the government of India, in the financial department, as officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, and was confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1880; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, Aug., 1878; sub-pro tem. accountant-general and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Madras, Dec., 1879; officiating accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1881; accountant-general, Bengal, July, 1882; officiated as comptroller-general and head commissioner of paper currency, in 1882, 1883, and 1884; officiating financial secretary to the government of India from Aug. to Nov. and in Dec., 1887; accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1887; C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

ATKINSON, John Nathaniel, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; on special duty under the commissioner of salt revenue, April, 1885; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, Oct. to Dec., 1885.

ATLAY, Venerable B. T., M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Arrived in India, 17th Oct., 1867; chaplain of St. Paul's Cathedral and of the general hospital, Dec., 1867; senior chaplain, Oct., 1877; chaplain of Naini Tal, Feb., 1879; senior chaplain, St. Paul's Cathedral, and chaplain of the general hospital and presidency jail, Jan., 1882; commissary to the Lord Bishop, and officiating chaplain in charge of the diocese, March, 1883; Archdeacon of Calcutta, Sept., 1883.

AUCOTT, Elliott, Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, Feb., 1886.

AULAD HUSSAIN, Khan Bahadur, C.I.E., Central Provinces.—Joined the service, 29th July, 1844; served in various subordinate posts till Dec., 1864, when he was appointed extra-assistant commissioner; on special duty at the Delhi assembling, Dec., 1876; made C.I.E., Jan., 1882; acting small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, July, 1883; assistant commissioner 1st class, Sept., 1883; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Raipur, Jan., 1885.

AUSTIN, Ware Plumptre, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Gloucester School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial department from May, 1866, as assistant magistrate and collector, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; district and sessions judge, North Malabar, Oct., 1884; collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, Nov., 1886.

AYLING, William Bock, Madras C.S.—Educated at Weymouth College and Magdalene College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competition of 1886.

BADCOCK, Francis William, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1869; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant-magistrate, joint-magistrate, and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge, and was placed on special duty, as settlement officer, Bhagulpore, Monghyr, and Purneah, July, 1873, and also in the office of the board of revenue, Calcutta, Jan., 1879; officiating inspector-general of registration, March, 1879; joint magistrate and deputy col-
lector, 1st grade, Feb., 1883; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan. 1888.

BADEN, EDMUND, Auditor's Department, India Office.—Writer, 4th Jan., 1859; senior inspector, Sept., 1860.

BADEN-POWELL, BADEN HENRY, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Paul's school; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; assistant commissioner, May, 1862; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab and Scinde, Aug., 1865; from July, 1866, to April, 1869, served as small cause court judge, Lahore, and subsequently in the forest department as officiating conservator and officiating inspector-general, and was placed on special duty, Nov., 1872, and April, 1876; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, April, 1880; on special duty in Madras, Oct., 1880, to Oct., 1881; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawulpindi, Oct., 1881; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1882; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, May, 1883, and again April, 1884, and Jan., 1887; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Sept. 1886, but to continue to act as judge of chief court; has published 'Punjab Products,' 'Punjab Manufactures,' 'Manual of the Land Revenue System and Land Tenures of British India,' and 'Manual of Jurisprudence for Forest Officers.'

BADGLEY, WILLIAM FRANCIS, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, April, 1857; arrived in India, May, 1857; served during the mutiny in Central India and Oudh, and afterwards with the Lushai expedition in charge of a survey party (medals and clasp); appointed to the Topographical Survey, May, 1865, and was employed in Rewah and Bundelcund, and in the Khasi, Garo, and Naga Hills; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Dec., 1880; in charge of Guzerat survey, March, 1884; officiating assistant surveyor-general in charge of photographic and lithographic offices, March, 1886.

BADOCK, HENRY W., Accounts' Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 11th Feb., 1876.

BAGNELL, HENRY WILLIAM JAMES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eastbourne College, Keble College, Oxford, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 1st Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; forest settlement officer, Aug., 1887.

BAILEY, FREDERICK, Lieut.-Colonel, R.F., Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as a lieutenant, R.E., 12th Nov., 1864; served under the military department till July, 1867, when he was appointed assistant engineer, 1st grade, P.W. department; executive engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1871; from Aug., 1871, served in the forest department as deputy conservator and superintendent of forest surveys; conservator of forests, and director of Indian forest school, in addition to his duties as superintendent of forest surveys, Sept., 1878; promoted to 2nd grade of conservators, April, 1883.

BAILLIE, DUNCAN COLVIN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Inverness Academy, Glasgow Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; assistant settlement officer, 1st grade, April, 1888.

BAINBRIDGE, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.P., M.R.C.S., I.S.A. (London), Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Khandesh, Feb., 1871; acted as deputy sanitary commissioner; also as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and of comparative anatomy, Grant Medical College, May, 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1879; acting Presidency surgeon, Aug., 1882; acting senior surgeon of Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, and professor of surgery, Grant Medical College, Feb., 1885.

BAINES, JEROVSE ATHELSTANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent, acting educational inspector, and cantonment and railway magistrate; on special duty at Bombay as compiler of general administration report, Sept., 1878, and again Sept., 1879; acting under secretary to government revenue, financial, and general departments, March, 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations in Bombay Presidency, and under secretary to government, general department, census, April, 1880; 2nd assistant collector and forest settlement officer, Dec., 1882; on special duty to supervise the work under the Income Tax Act in the Bombay Presidency, May, 1886; also acting as director of agriculture from Dec. 1886; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Oct.-Nov., 1886; acted as junior collector and magistrate, 1887 and 1888; on special duty, June, 1888.

BAIRD, ANDREW WILSON, Major, R.E., F.R.S., A.I.C.E., F.R.G.S., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, R.E., Dec., 1861; arrived in India March, 1863; served from May, 1864, in the Bombay Public Works Department as assistant engineer, and was employed on the harbour defences and reclamations; executive engineer, Oct., 1867; served in the Abyssinian Expedition as assistant field engineer, 1868 (medal); from Dec., 1868, served in the Trigonometrical Survey as assistant surveyor, and was employed in Kattywar and Guzerat; assistant superintendent 1st grade, Oct., 1871; in July, 1877, was appointed to the general superintendence and control of tidal observations upon the Indian coasts; on deputation as commissioner, Venice Geographical Congress and Exhibition, Aug., 1881; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; officiating master of the mint, Calcutta, in 1885 and 1886; 3rd grade deputy superintendent, March, 1886; is the author of various contributions to the Bombay Gazetteer, and of papers and reports on tidal observations, including a paper read before the British Association, 1876, and an account of the spirit-levelling operations of the great Trigonometrical Survey of India, read before the British Association in 1885; joint author of the annual tide tables for Indian ports.

BAKER, EDWARD NORMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open
competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1878; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; services placed at disposal of census commissioner, March, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, May, 1882; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, in addition to his own duties, April, 1884; under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1885.

BAKER, Francis, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Berkhamstead Grammar School and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; first assistant secretary to government, Nov., 1873, and again in 1879; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, April, 1874; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1878, and officiated as secretary, Sept., 1878; officiating junior secretary to government, March, 1881; under secretary to government, May, 1881; superintendent of Dehra Dun, March, 1884; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1886; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, March, 1888; officiated as magistrate and collector in 1888.

BAKER, Montagu Bernard, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and acting judge and sessions judge; acting judicial commissioner in Scinde, and judge of the Sadar court, April, 1879; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Kandeish, May, 1882; 1st grade judge, Nasik, Jan., 1884.

BAKER, Oswald, Surgeon-Major, Medica Department, Burma.—Joined the Bengal medical service, 1873; was employed under the military department up to May, 1874, and served subsequently in Burma as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; medical officer to the mission to Siam under Major C. W. Street, Feb., 1879; surgeon-major, April, 1885; junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, and port health officer, Oct., 1885; civil surgeon, Moulmein, May, 1887.

BALFOUR, Edward Green, Surgeon-General, late Madras Medical Service.—Educated at Montrose Academy, and at the Edinburgh University and Medical Schools, and is a Licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh; joined the Madras medical service in 1836; served under the military department, 1836-1854; political agent at the Durbar of H. H. the Nawab of the Carnatic, and paymaster of Carnatic stipends, 1849-1861; formed, and was in charge of the Government Central Museum, Madras, 1850-1859, and formed the Madras zoological collection, Jan., 1856; acted as assistant assay master, Madras mint; Persian and Hindustani translator to government, and member of the board of examiners of oriental languages, 1854-1861; commissioner investigating the debts of H. H. the Nawab of the Carnatic, 1856-1861; formed the Mysore museum, Bangalore, 1865; examiner of medical accounts, military finance department, 1861-1862; from 1862 to 1870 served as deputy inspector-general of hospitals in Pegu, the Straits Settlements, the ceded districts, Mysore, and Hyderabad, successively; surgeon-general, Madras medical department, 1871-1876; was hon. secretary to the Madras central committee for the Exhibition of 1851, for the Paris Exhibition of 1855, and for the Madras Exhibitions of 1855 and 1857; is a fellow of Madras University, and corresponding member of the Imperial Royal Geological Institute, Vienna; has published works on cholera (in 1849 and 1852), on the commercial products of the Madras presidency, on the mollusca (1855) on the government central museum, on the timber, trees and woods of India (1858), and on the agricultural pests of India; also a Cyclopaedia of India and Eastern and Southern Asia, 1857, 'Selections from the Persian and Hindustani poets,' 1851, 'The Vydian and the Hakim,' 1875, 'Eminent Medical Men,' 1875, and a statistical map of the world, 1854; has translated into Hindustani 'Conquest's Outlines of Midwifery' and 'Gleig's Astronomy,' and has made frequent contributions to various journals on subjects connected with India.

BALFOUR, Sir George, General, R.A., K.C.B., F.R.G.S., M.P.—lieutenant, Madras Artillery, Dec., 1825; served with the Malacca field force, 1832-1833, in the Kurnool campaign, 1839, and throughout the China war, 1840-1842 (medal); consul at Shanghaie, March, 1844, to Oct., 1846; member of the military and marine boards, Madras, Feb., 1851-1857; C.B., 1854; inspector-general of ordnance and magazines, Fort St. George, May, 1857 to 1861; member of the military finance commission, 1859-1860, and president of that commission, 1860-1862; served on the royal commission on recruiting in 1866 and 1868-70; assistant to the comptroller in chief, war office, 1868-1872; K.C.B., June, 1870; from Dec, 1872, has sat in the House of Commons for Kincardineshire; general, Oct., 1877; retired from the army, Dec., 1879.

BALLS, Charles William, Accountant-General's Department, India Office, late Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed assistant to traffic manager, Persian Gulf Telegraph, 1863; storekeeper, 1866; chief clerk, London office, 1870; visited the Persian Gulf stations on special duty in 1870; took inventory of all government property, which was afterwards valued, and made the basis of a complete stock account of the department in the Persian Gulf; acted as accountant for six months in 1867; on abolition of London office of Indo European telegraph department, services transferred temporarily to India office, 1 Jan., 1889.

BAMBER, Henry William John, Police Department, Bengal.—From 1st Oct., 1857 to May, 1862, served as assistant superintendent, and superintendent of salt chowkies; from May, 1862, served in the Bengal police department, and was promoted to district superintendent, 1st grade, Aug., 1885.

BANNERMAN, Patrick Wilson, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bombay Army, June, 1852; assistant to the superintendent, Neemuch, July, 1859; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1860; political assistant, Bhopawar Aug., 1865; also Bheel agent and commandant, Malwa Bheel corps; political agent, Rewah, March, 1871; political agent, Bhopal, 1886; resident, Eastern States, Rajputana, Oct., 1881; resident, Gwalior, March, 1882; acted as agent,
to governor-general for Central India in 1883-1884, and again in 1887.

BANTON, WILLIAM, Accounts Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 29th Dec., 1848; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, Sept., 1858; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; also assessor of income tax, 1879.

BARBOUR, SIR DAVID MILLER, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863; served in Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1873; accountant general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Lahore circle, June, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1878; accountant-general, Madras, and commissioner of paper currency, Jan., 1880; on special duty with the government of India, May, 1881; accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Jan., 1882; Bengal legislative council, Jan., to Oct., 1882; secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, July, 1882; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; on special duty in India, Sept.–Oct., 1886, and on special duty in England to serve as member of the Royal Commission on Currency in 1886; appointed member of council of governor-general, Aug., 1887; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1889.

BARCLAY, ARTHUR, M.B., Surgeon-major, Indian Medical Department.—Arrived in India 28th March, 1875, and served on civil and military duty; officiated as resident surgeon presidency general hospital and as professor of physiology, Calcutta Medical College; secretary to the surgeon-general with the government of India, April, 1885; surgeon-major, Sept., 1886.

BARCLAY, ERNEST, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 18th Sept., 1861, as French interpreter to the supreme court, Madras, acting deputy clerk of the crown and acting assistant registrar, and was appointed government solicitor, Feb., 1876.

BARCLAY, PRINGLE DAVID, Railway Department, government of India.—Joined the department, March, 1875, as assistant traffic superintendent, Rajputana state railway; class 2, revenue establishment of state railways, Jan., 1880; traffic superintendent, Punjab Northern railway, March, 1881; Eastern Bengal railway, June, 1884.

BARING, SIR EVELYN, Major, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Lieutenant, R.A.; June, 1858; captain in 1870, and major in 1876; D.C.O. to Sir Henry Storks, in Ionian Islands, in 1861, and secretary to him in 1865, during the enquiry into the outbreak in Jamaica; private secretary to the governor-general of India (the Earl of Northbrook), 1872 to 1876; commissioner of the Egyptian public debt, 1877–9; comptroller-general in Egypt, Sept., 1879; financial member of council of governor-general of India, June, 1880; agent and consul-general in Egypt, and a minister plenipotentiary in the diplomatic service, Aug., 1883; financial assistant at the conference in London, on Egyptian finance, June to Aug., 1884.

BARKLEY, DAVID GRAHAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; officiating small cause court judge, Delhi, Sept., 1863; personal assistant to commissioner, Umballa, Nov., 1864; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the chief court, Nov., 1870, and again at Simla, June, 1871, and at Lahore, April, 1872; assistant sessions judge, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1874; additional commissioner, Delhi, May, 1876, and subsequently at Jallundar and Lahore; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1878, and again in 1880; civil and sessions judge, Nov., 1880; commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, Sept., 1881; additional judge, chief court, Jan., 1882; additional member of Governor-General's council for making laws and regulations, May, 1883, and again in 1884; judge of the chief court, Punjab, Feb., 1886; retired Jan., 1887; has published 'Directions to revenue and settlement officers, non-regulation law.'

BARLOW, RICHARD WELLESLEY, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed acting judge, small cause court, Tellicherry, Nov., 1869; acting civil and sessions judge, Chingleput, Feb., 1870; from 1871 to 1873 served as collector and magistrate of Chingleput, and subsequently as commissioner, Nilgiris, 1878–1880, and again in 1881; government member of the Lawrence Asylum committee, April, 1878; major commandant Nilgiri Volunteer Rifles, Dec., 1878, to Nov., 1879; acted as member of the Board of Revenue in 1880 with charge of the Inam department, and again in 1881, in charge of settlement department, and in 1886; collector and magistrate, and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; collector of sea customs and of the Madras district, and protector of emigrants, Madras, Jan., 1883; acting president, Travancore and Cochin, Feb. to Aug., 1884; additional member of the council, Madras, Sept., 1885; chairman of the Harbour Trust Board, May, 1886; superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1887, in addition to his other duties.

BARNES, FRANCIS CARNAC, Financial Department, Government of India.—Served in the financial department from 9th November, 1872, and was appointed assistant to accountant general, N.W. provinces, Jan. 1877; assistant comptroller-general, Calcutta, Nov. 1878; private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1882; class 4 of financial department, Aug., 1885; services retained under the government of Bengal as officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1887.

BARNES, HUGH SHAKESPEARE, Bengal C.S., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Educated at Malvern College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to financial department of government of India.
Dec., 1876, and appointed assistant to accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces; private secretary to the financial member of the governor-general's council, Dec., 1876; acted as under secretary in the home department in 1878; on special duty under the foreign department, Nov., 1879; assistant to resident, Kandahar, Nov., 1880; served in the Afghan campaign, 1881, as political officer with General Wilkinson's brigade; assistant to the governor-general's agent in Beloochistan, 1881-83; political agent in Quetta and Pishin, June, 1883; in charge of arrangements, supplies, &c., for passage of Afghan boundary commission across Belooch Desert, Aug., 1884.

BARNETT, EBENEZER M., Store Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 10th Nov., 1852; junior clerk, store department, July, 1860; senior clerk, March, 1868.

BARODA CHURN MITTRA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under native civil service rules an assistant magistrate and collector, March, 1886, on probation; confirmed, May, 1888.

BARR, D. W. K., Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Sept., 1864; served in Abyssinian expedition (medal); boundary commissioner, Rewa Kantha, and Malwa Bhel agency, 1869; political assistant and boundary officer, Bhopal, July, 1869; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1870; officiating political agent, and class, Jodhpoor, 1878-79; political agent, Bhagelkund, July, 1881; also superintendent, Rewa state; resident and class at Gwalior, May, 1887.

BARRON, WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, Dec., 1868; arrived in India Feb., 1859; served with the Peshawur mountain train battery in the Mahsood Wuzuree expedition, 1860; assistant revenue surveyor June, 1862; served as assistant surveyor with the Umbeyla expedition, Oct., 1863 (medal and clasps); assistant superintendent of survey, 1st grade, June, 1866; was employed in the Punjab and N.W. frontier districts, and also in Assam; deputy superintendent of survey, April, 1870; was subsequently in charge of the N.W. frontier revenue survey, and afterwards of the Moradabad and Budaoon surveys; deputy superintendent, and grade, Aug., 1884; author of a 'Handbook of Instructions for Cadastral Survey Parties in N.W. Provinces.'

BARROW, FRANK HUNTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bruton and Felsted Grammar Schools, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; magistrate and collector, March, 1887.

BARROW, OSCAR THEODORE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Gloucester College School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to financial department, government of India, Oct., 1882; assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Feb., 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, May, 1885; assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Sep. and Nov., 1885, and deputy accountant-general, Oct., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, Nov., 1886; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Mar., 1887; class 4 of enrolled officers, May, 1887; enrolled officer, class 3, Nov. 1887; officiating accountant-general and deputy commissioner, paper currency, N.W.P., May, 1888.

BARROW, REGINALD Pocock, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oxford University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India 13th Nov., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1886.

BARRY, WILLIAM, M.R.C.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 14th Feb., 1863; from Dec., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; employed on famine duty under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1873, to Jan., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Banda, Aug., 1877; from May, 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1882; and grade, April, 1887.

BARSTOW, HENRY CLEMENTS, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from July, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; served under the Government of India, foreign department, Jan., 1874, to Oct., 1875, as officiating political agent, 1st class, Bhopal; officiating superintendent, Dehra Dun, Feb., 1876; officiating civil and sessions judge, and grade, Banda, Jan., 1880; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Cawnpore, April, 1880; retired, Nov., 1886.

BARTER, JOSEPH FRANCIS, Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the Madras medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1860; from April, 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acted for various periods as inspector-general of jails and as sanitary commissioner; rank of surgeon-major July, 1873; sanitary commissioner, superintendent of vaccination, and inspector-general of dispensaries, Central Provinces, Dec., 1878; civil surgeon and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Nagpur, July, 1883; brigade-surgeon, March, 1886.

BARTHOLOMEW, ROBERT, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, and April, 1862; from 1st Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, and grade, Aug., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Delhi, officiating as divisional judge; deputy commissioner, July, 1886; deputy commissioner, and grade, Feb., 1887.

BARTLETT, HUBERT FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination
of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1885; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1885.

BARTON, EBENEZER JOHNSTONE, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 10th Nov., 1862; from Sept., 1863, served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1882; also served as officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, Sept., 1871, and was on special famine duty, Bhagulpore division, Dec., 1873; retired, Aug., 1887.

BATESON, ROBERT SANDER, Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1856; arrived in India, and was attached to military department as assistant surgeon, 7th Aug., 1856; placed in medical charge of the civil station and in executive charge of jail at Umballa, Nov., 1871; civil surgeon, and class, Oct., 1877; brigade-surgeon, Oct., 1882; retired Sept., 1886.

BATTEN, JOHN KAYE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College, and at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Madras, 29th November, 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BATTEY, HERBERT, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay, C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of logic and moral philosophy in the Deccan College, Poona (1872-75), assistant judge and sessions judge (1st grade, Feb., 1885), and acting judge and sessions judge; under secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, Nov., 1885; acted as district and sessions judge between 1886 and 1888; acting chief presidency magistrate, Bombay, April, 1888; acting remembrancer of legal affairs.

BAYLAY, CHARLES ALLEN, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, Dec., 1857; assistant commissioner, Berar, Jan., 1866, and subsequently in Loodianah; political assistant, Rajputana, 1868-70; assistant general superintendent for suppression of Thagi and Dakaite, Dec., 1870; political agent, Haraoti and Tonk, 1876; additional political agent, 1st class, Kotah, Dec., 1879; acted as resident, western states of Rajputana in 1884.

BAYLEY, CHARLES STUART (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Heidelberg; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, January, 1878; officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, July, 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, March, 1881, and subsequently in the financial department, Oct., 1882; member of the executive committee, Calcutta International Exhibition of 1883-84, Aug., 1883; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural departments, Feb., 1884; officiating registrar, high court, March, 1884; under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural departments, April, 1885; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Sept., 1886; political agent, Bikaniir, June, 1888.

BAYLEY, LYTTELTON HOLYOAKE (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Advocate-general, Bombay, 17th March, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1866; acting chief justice, May-Dec., 1883, and Nov., 1887, to Feb., 1888.

BAYLEY, SIR STEUART COLVIN, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India 4th March, 1856; assistant magistrate and collector, 24 Pergunnahs, Nov., 1856; junior secretary to government of Bengal, Feb., 1863; officiated as secretary to the government of Bengal in 1865, 1867, and 1871; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Monghyr, Feb., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Shahabad, May, 1867; commissioner, Dacca division, July, 1873, and subsequently of the Patna division, Sept., 1873; secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1877; additional secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1877; personal assistant to H.E. the Viceroy, for famine affairs, Sept., 1877; additional secretary, government of India, public works department, famine branch, in addition to his own duties, Dec., 1877; secretary, government of India, home department, June, 1878; officiating chief commissioner, Assam, June, 1878, also officiating lieutenant-governor of Bengal, July-Nov., 1879; chief commissioner of Assam, June, 1880; resident, 1st class, Hyderabad, March, 1881; governor-general's council, 9th May, 1882; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1887.

BAYNE, CHARLES GERWIE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Uppingham, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner; junior secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1886; under secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887, and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Feb., June, and Aug., 1888.

BEACHCROFT, FRANCIS PORTEN, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

BEADON, CECIL, Colonel, Madras Cavalry, Punjab Administration.—Arrived in India, 24th March, 1858; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, March, 1877; on special duty in connection with viceregal durbar, Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, June, 1883, and subsequently in
the Lahore division; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Feb., 1885, Simla.

BEADON, HENRY SNEYD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sherborne, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 14th November, 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, June, 1864; assistant commissioner of Darjeeling, also sub-registrar of assurances, June, 1866; officiating private secretary, lieutenant-governor of Bengal, March, 1871, to April, 1872; under secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1871; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1873; officiating senior superintendent of survey, 1875-77; 1st inspector, registration offices, July, 1876; inspector-general of registration, Bengal, Jan., 1878; magistrate and collector, and grade, Nov., 1884.

BEAMAN, FRANK CLEMENT OFFLEY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant superintendent of police; acting assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, March, 1882, to Jan., 1883, and again 1885-86; acting junior collector and magistrate and political agent, March-April, 1883; from April, 1883, served in the judicial department, and was appointed acting judicial assistant to political agent, Káthiáwar, May, 1884, and 3rd grade assistant judge, May, 1885; special settlement officer, Baroda, May, 1886, and November, 1887; acted district and sessions judge, Oct., 1887.

BEAMES, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 16th March, 1858; from March, 1859, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and from Dec., 1861, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1873; officiated as commissioner, Orissa division, Aug., 1873, and subsequently as commissioner of the Chittagong, Rajshahye, and Cooch Behar and Dacca divisions; commissioner, Burdwan division, Nov., 1881; officiating member of Board of Revenue, March, 1887; Commissioner of Bhagalpur, Aug., 1887; author of 'Outlines of Indian Philology,' 1867, 'Comparative Grammar of the Modern Aryan Languages of India,' 1872-1879; edited Sir H. M. Elliot's 'Races of the N.W. Provinces of India,' 1869.

BEARD, H. G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India store depot, 1st Feb., 1866; clerk, and class, Aug., 1878.

BEATSON, JOHN FULLARTON, Surgeon-General, M.D., C.I.E., late Bengal Medical Service.—B.A. and M.D., University of Glasgow; licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh; assistant surgeon, Bengal, 16th June, 1843; served with the army of the Sutlej, 1845-46, taking part in the defence of Ferozepore, and battle of Ferozeshah (medal and clasp); served in the Punjab Campaign, and was present at various actions (medal); surgeon, June, 1857; in charge of the Allahabad General Field Hospital during the period of the Mutiny; surgeon-major, June, 1863; garrison surgeon, Allahabad, 1865-68; medical storekeeper, Umballa, 1868-69; deputy inspector-general Meerut, May, 1869; surgeon-general, Nov., 1875; Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire, Jan., 1878; retired, March, 1880.

BEATTY, JOSEPH, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1852; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from March, 1855, as assistant engineer, and executive engineer; supervisor of the canals, Godavari, May, 1874; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Aug., 1877; promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1878.

BEATTY, THOMAS BERKELEY, Surgeon-General, M.D.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin (A.B. and M.B.); joined the Bombay medical service, May, 1851; arrived in India, 27th June, 1851; civil surgeon, Karachi, July, 1853; superintendent of vaccination, April, 1856; acting civil surgeon, Poona, 22nd May, 1866, and again in 1872; superintendent, Matheran, Dec., 1867; deputy-surgeon general, Poona, Oct., 1876; principal medical officer, Malta Expeditionary Force, May to Sept., 1878; surgeon-general with the Government of Bombay, April, 1880; retired, March, 1885; is the author of various contributions on medical subjects in the Transactions of the Medical and Physical Society, Bombay.

BEAUMONT, THOMAS, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., F.R.C.S.I., late Madras Medical Department.—Arrived in India, 13th Sept., 1857; served under the military department till Feb., 1864, when he was appointed residency surgeon, Indore; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, June, 1881; also superintendent of vaccination and superintendent of medical school; retired, Oct., 1885.

BEAUMONT, WILLIAM, late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 27th May, 1858, as assistant superintendent, and deputy superintendent; reorganisation committee, Madras, March, 1871; promoted to 1st class deputy superintendent, June, 1877; board of examiners, Nov., 1882; retired, Nov., 1887.

BECHER, ALFRED READ, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Joined the P.W. Department, July, 1868; arrived in India, 14th Oct., 1868; served in the Punjab as assistant engineer on the Sirhind canal; from April, 1873, served in the accounts branch, Punjab, as assistant controller, and deputy controller; transferred to Bombay, Nov., 1875; served subsequently in Hyderabad, Oudh, Rajputana, and Mysore; examiner of accounts, Calcutta, June, 1886; 3rd class examiner, Sept., 1886.

BECKETT, HENRY BARRON, Punjab Administration.—Served from 10th May, 1860, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating inspector of schools, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Peshawur, Aug., 1884; from Dec., 1884, officiating as divisional judge, and was appointed district judge 1st grade, Oct., 1885, and deputy commissioner, and grade, Aug., 1886.

BEGBIE, ALFRED GLYNN, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, July, 1861; arrived in India, Nov., 1870; joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer in the railway department, Central India; executive engineer, Oct., 1871; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; officiating deputy controller of accounts, Bengal, Aug., 1874; officiated as examiner;
guaranteed railway accounts, at Calcutta and Bombay, 1874-75; controller of accounts, Mysore, Aug., 1875; examiner guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, 1878; Punjab Northern railway accounts, 1880; deputy accountant-general, and ex officio under secretary to Government of India, Jan., 1886; officiating accountant-general, public works department, and deputy secretary, government of India, April, 1886, to March, 1887; examiner, 1st class, May, 1886; officiating accountant-general and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, May to Oct., 1887.

BEHARY LAL GUPTA (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Colootola Branch School, Calcutta, Calcutta University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1871; on famine relief duty, Sept., 1874; presidency magistrate, Calcutta, and coroner of Calcutta, June, 1881; officiating district and sessions judge, April, 1884, March, 1885, and Feb., 1887.

BEIGHTON, THOMAS DURANT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating small cause court judge, officiating district and sessions judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty in connection with boundary disputes on the Bhutan frontier, Jan., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, May, 1885.

BELCHAMBERS, J. H., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Deputy registrar, appellate jurisdiction, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 14th March, 1863.

BELCHAMBERS, R., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Registrar of the high court, Calcutta, from 1862; is also keeper of records, taxing officer, accountant-general, and sealer; author of 'Practice of the Civil Courts,' and other legal publications.

BELL, HORACE, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, 7th July, 1862; served in the Central Provinces and Central India, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; subsequently served on the Punjab northern state railway, and on the Rajputana state railway, as superintendent of way and works, and as acting manager, also as officiating engineer-in-chief on the Sindia and Neemuch state railways; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1881; engineer-in-chief, Dacca and Mymensingh railway surveys, Dec., 1881; while on furlough superintended assistant engineers on practical course in England; superintending engineer, and class, Jan., 1883; on special duty, Aug., 1883, on committee for considering reorganisation scheme for public works department; manager and engineer-in-chief Tirhoot state railway, Feb., 1884; held charge Nalhati railway, July-Sept., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; acting director, North-Western Railway, July to Oct., 1887; engineer-in-chief and manager Jirhoot State Railway, Oct., 1887, to March, 1888; author of 'Laws of Wealth,' a work on political economy for native readers.

BELL, JAMES GIBERNE, Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, infantry, Dec. 1851; from 17th Nov., 1855, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant resident, deputy commissioner, and officiating commissioner of West Berar; judicial commissioner, and civil appellate and sessions judge, Amraoti, April, 1877; has acted on several occasions as commissioner of the Hyderabad assigned districts.

BELL, MATTHEW DENNY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; acting senior assistant collector, Ganjam, March, 1887.

BELL, NICHOLAS DODD BEATSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton Bank, St. Andrews, Edinburgh Academy and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service, after open competition of 1886.

BELLETT, G., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Appointed to the Bengal educational service, 9th Oct., 1860; served successively as head master, and professor, Dacca College; inspector of schools, Nov., 1868; professor, Presidency College, Dec., 1873; principal, Berhampore College, May, 1875; and class, educational service, March, 1876; subsequently served as officiating principal, Patna College, inspector of schools, officiating principal, Presidency College, and officiating director of public instruction (Jan., 1883).

BELLEW, HENRY WALTER, C.S.I., Deputy Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1855; arrived in India, 24th March, 1856; served under the military department up to Jan., 1868, and subsequently as civil surgeon in the Punjab; on duty with Ameer of Kabul, March, 1869; deputed to Kashmir, April to Nov., 1869; served with the Seistan and Yarkand missions in 1871 and 1873; residency surgeon, Nepaul, Feb., 1876; on special duty under the government of India, in the foreign department, April, 1876; rank of surgeon-major, July, 1876; sanitary commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1877; served under foreign department of government of India in connection with Kabul mission and Kurram field force, 1878 and 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Nov., 1881; retired, May 1886; has published a dictionary and grammar of the Pashtu language, a report on the Eusafzais, and a political report on Seistan, also 'Journal of the Kandahar Mission,' 'Indus to Tigris,' 'Kashmir and Kashgar,' 'Afghanistan and the Afghans,' 'The Races of Afghanistan,' 'History of Cholera in India from 1862 to 1881,' and a vaccination manual.

BENNETT, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to take up land for railway purposes in Fyzabad, Feb., 1870; manager of encumbered estates, Gonda, March, 1872, to Feb., 1875; officiated as city magistrate, Lucknow, in 1878 and 1879; officiating
secretary to government, Oudh revenue department, Sept.-Nov., 1879; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1882; secretary, board of revenue, May, 1886; officiating secretary to government, Oudh revenue, and judicial departments, June, 1886; officiated as chief secretary in 1837; author of 'History of the Chief Clans of the Rae Bareli District,' the Gonda Settlement Report, and contributions to the Oudh Gazetteer.

BENGER, ALFRED, Auditor's Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 20th Nov., 1866; junior examiner, June, 1867; senior examiner, July, 1877.

BENNETT, J., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; services placed at disposal of civil department, Sept., 1870; civil surgeon, Murree, Dec., 1872; superintendent of vaccination, Punjab, July, 1877; superintendent-general of vaccination, Punjab, March, 1880; deputy sanitary commissioner, Eastern Circle, Dec., 1881, to April, 1884; civil surgeon, Mooltan, Jan., 1883; also superintendent of central jail, Dec., 1883; civil surgeon, Rawalpindi, April, 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Sept., 1884; medical adviser to his Highness the Maharaja of Patiala, Aug., 1885.

BENSLEY, EDWIN CLEMENT, Surgeon-Major, late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1859; served from 22nd July, 1863, as civil assistant surgeon at Midnapore and Rajshahye; civil surgeon, Rajshahye, Oct., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, Feb., 1871; retired, Nov., 1885.

BENSON, RALPH SILLERY, M.A., LL.B., Barrister-at-law (Middle Temple), Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate (Salem), acting head assistant collector and magistrate of Cuddapah during the famine of 1876-78, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), 1878 to 1881, and acting collector and magistrate; was specially appointed as officer for the settlement of lands in the Nilgiri districts; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, North Arcot, June, 1882; on special duty as secretary to the local self-government committee, Oct., 1882; forest settlement officer, May, 1883, and secretary to the committee for drafting new municipal and local board bills; acting under-secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, Jan., 1885, and again in Oct., 1887; acting registrar, high court, July, 1885; acting secretary to the commissioners of land revenue, Nov., 1887, to April, 1888; sub-collector and joint magistrate and acting district and sessions judge, April, 1888; author of the 'Settlement Registers and Descriptive Memoirs of the Nilgiri Districts,' and of the 'Report on the Settlement of the Nilgiri District,' 1885.

BENSON, THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tavistock Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, manager of the Awa estate under the court of wards, officiating district and session judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Oct., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1883, district and sessions judge, April, 1887.

BENTHALL, ERNEST, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India Office, 19th Dec., 1865; junior clerk, Nov., 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1877.

BENTON, ALEXANDER HAY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived in India, 20th Feb., 1864, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Aug., 1883; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Peshawur, Oct., 1885.

BERESFORD, LORD W. LESLIE DE LA POER, Lieutenant-Colonel, V.C., C.I.E., 9th Lancers.—First commission, cornet, June, 1867; served in the Zulu war of 1879, and was present at battle of Ulundi (Victoria Cross, medal, and clasp); served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, and was present at the capture of Ali Musjid (medal and clasp); A.D.C. to Viceroy of India, 1875 to 1881; military secretary on the personal staff of the viceroy and governor-general, 13th Dec., 1881.

BERKELY, JAMES CAVAN, C.I.E., Colonel, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Oct., 1857; served in civil employ from June, 1862, as assistant to the governor-general's agent in Central India; also served as boundary settlement officer, deputy opium agent in Malwa, assistant general superintendent for Thagi and Dakaiti, and sessions judge and registrar for Mhow; political agent, Haraoti and Tonk, 1873; political agent, Bhagalcund, Jan., 1879, to Nov., 1882; political agent, Jacobabad, 1882; officiating resident, Gwalior, March, 1883; on special duty, Kashmir, April-Aug., 1883; political agent, Bundelcund, 1884; officiating resident, Nipal, 1885; resident, 2nd class, and governor-general's agent at Baroda, April, 1886.

BERNARD, SIR CHARLES EDWARD, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S., Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was appointed under-secretary to government of India, financial department, Aug., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as judge of the small cause court, Nagpur; settlement officer, secretary to the chief commissioner (July, 1864), commissioner of Nagpur division (Feb., 1869), and acting judicial commissioner; from May, 1871, to Jan., 1875, served in Bengal as member of the lieutenant-governor's council, and acting secretary to the government, first in the judicial department, then in the revenue department, and lastly in the scarcity and relief department; from Nov., 1876, served as commissioner of Nagpur division; secretary to Sir Richard Temple, Bart., K.C.S.I., deputed on a special mission to the Bombay and Madras Presidencies, Jan., 1877; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; additional secretary to the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Aug., 1877, and in the financial department, Dec., 1877; served as secretary to the
government of India in the home department, May, 1878, to July, 1880; Secretary to government of India in revenue and agricultural department, July, 1881; from July, 1880, acted as chief commissioner of British Burma, and was confirmed in this appointment April, 1882; retired, March, 1883, and was appointed secretary in the revenue, statistics, and commerce department, India office.

BERNARD, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Midnapore, Jan., 1885; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, British Burma, May, 1886; services replaced at disposal of government of Bengal, Feb., 1887; officiated as joint magistrate and deputy collector and as under secretary to government of Bengal.

BERRY, FREDERICK CHARLES, B.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ushaw College, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873; from Nov., 1873, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; also held acting appointments at various times as district superintendent of police, small cause court judge and cantonment magistrate, and deputy commissioner; acting superintendent of central jail and meteorological observatory, Nagpur, Jan., 1882; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Feb., 1882; on special duty, and appointed superintendent of affairs in Kalahandi State, March, 1882; political agent, Bhowani Patna, April, 1882; C.I.E., March, 1883; political agent Chattisgarh Feudatories, April, 1887.

BEST, JAMES WILLIAM, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimborne Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate in various districts; from Jan., 1875, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, South Canara, Sept., 1877.

BETTINGTON, ALBEMARLE, late Bombay C.S.—Entered the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1830; served in the usual grades in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1843; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, 1849; inspector-general of prisons and commissioner of police, Bombay, 1855; retired 1861. Has published a work on 'The Destruction of Life by Snakes and Hydrophobia.'

BEVERIDGE, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating deputy commissioner, Cooch Behar, and magistrate and collector (2nd grade, April, 1874); on special duty in Munipore under the government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1863; from Oct., 1874, served in the judicial department as officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879; member of the central examination committee, April, 1886.

BEVERLEY, HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sedbergh School, Yorkshire, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1865, and Aug., 1867; registrar-general of assurances, March, 1867; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1870; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1870; superintended the first census of Bengal in 1872, superintended the census of Calcutta, 1876; officiating judge of Nuddea, April, 1875; officiating inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Aug., 1876; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, and additional judge, 24-Pergunnahs and Hooghly, Dec., 1877; member of the prison conference, 1877; member of the census committee, 1878; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation, March, 1880; special census officer of Calcutta and suburbs, Dec., 1880, and published a report on the census, 1881; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Nov., 1883; member, Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1884; member of sanitary commission, Calcutta, Sept., 1884; officiated as judge of the high court, Calcutta, 9th April, 1884 to 15th Sept., 1884, and again from 12th Jan., 1885, until confirmed as judge, 8th May, 1885; published 'Registration Manual' and 'Land Acquisition Act.'

BHAGWAN CHUNDER CHAKARBUTTI.—From 9th October, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, May, 1884.

BIDDULPH, JOHN, COLONEL, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Cornet, Bengal cavalry, Jan., 1883; arrived in India, 4th March, 1883; served with various cavalry regiments, and received the mutiny medal; aide-de-camp to the Viceroy, May, 1872, to Feb., 1877; on special duty as member of mission to Yarkand, &c., 1873-74; employed on a secret mission to the countries beyond Gilgit, 1876 (brevet of Major); on special duty in Gilgit, Sept., 1877; acting agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, May-Nov., 1882; political agent, Bhopawur, Dec., 1882; acted as resident and boundary settlement officer in Meywar, 1885; political agent in Harooti and Tonk, April, 1886.

BIDDULPH, THOMAS HENRY STILLINGFLEET, Financial Department, Government of India.—From July, 1860, to March, 1871, served as accountant, public works accounts, in Central India and Punjab, and as examiner of railway accounts; probationer in financial department, March, 1871; assistant to the accountant-general N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1874; on special duty at Durbanagh in Bengal, June, 1874, to May, 1875; from Jan., 1879, served as assistant accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces, and also in the Punjab, Nov., 1881, to April, 1882, and as deputy accountant-general in Madras, April-Oct., 1882; officiated for various periods as deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh; controller, Hyderabad, Dec., 1884, confirmed in class 3 of enrolled officers, June, 1888.

BIDEN, W. M., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Mark's College, Chelsea, and King's College, London; provisional
assistant, art library, South Kensington Museum, 1870; clerk, 2nd class, India Store Depot, 1st July, 1875; supervisor, 2nd grade, June, 1836; B.A., London University, 1880.

BIDIE, GEORGE, Surgeon-General, A.M., M.B., F.L.S., F.R.C.S.E., F.R.G.S., C.I.E., Madras Medical Department.—University of Aberdeen; joined the medical service as assistant surgeon, 20th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department till June, 1859; was subsequently employed as civil surgeon of Guntur, 1859-61, medical officer of the Mysore farm commissariat establishments, and medicinal garden, Hoonsoor, 1861-64, professor of botany and materia medica in the Medical College, acting principal medical storekeeper, and superintendent of the lunatic asylum, Madras, and served in Mysore and Coorg, Nov., 1867, to Feb., 1868, on special duty in the coffee districts; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department (military), March, 1870; superintendent of the government central museum, Aug., 1872, to Dec., 1884, and again Jan., 1885; on special duty at Ootacamund in connection with cinchona commission, Oct., 1873; fellow of Madras university, April, 1879; secretary to the surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, left wing, April, 1880, to Nov., 1884; brigade surgeon, Feb., 1883; board of examiners, May, 1883; served in public department, Nov.-Dec., 1883, in connection with Calcutta International Exhibition, and special committee for promotion of art and manufacture; deputy surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, British Burma division, Dec., 1884-Jan., 1885; sanitary commissioner, Madras, April, 1885; member of committee in connection with the scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885; acting surgeon-general with the government of Madras from April, 1886; confirmed in appointment, Oct., 1886; author of numerous publications connected with the botany and zoology of the Madras Presidency.

BIGGS, C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 3rd April, 1882.

BIGGS, T. HESKETH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 26th Sept., 1868, and served as assistant to accountant-general in Bombay, the Central Provinces, and Madras; assistant to comptroller-general, Dec., 1873; on special duty in Madras in connection with the inquiry into certain frauds in the stamp department, Dec., 1873, to Feb., 1874; served subsequently in the Punjab, the Central Provinces, Bengal, Bombay, and Assam, as assistant to accountant-general, officiating for various periods as deputy accountant-general; appointed comptroller, Assam, Aug., 1880; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Jan., 1883; officiating comptroller of Indian treasuries, Oct.-Nov., 1883; deputy accountant-general, Punjab, in 3rd class of the financial department, 1885; comptroller, Burma, 1887.

BIGNELL, W. K. D'O., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, Feb., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Nagpur, Jan., 1868; served in the Punjab from 1873; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1881; officiating director, construction branch, director-general's office, Nov., 1883, to Feb., 1884; officiating director, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887.

BIGNOLD, THOMAS FRANK, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1859; arrived in India, 12th May, 1859; assistant magistrate and collector June, 1860; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, May, 1860; officiating superintendent of akbari and collector of stamps, Calcutta, Sept., 1871; officiating inspector-general of registration, Oct., 1873, to Feb., 1875; also officiating inspector-general of jails, Dec., 1873; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Balasore, April, 1874; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; subsequently served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; retired, April, 1886.

BIRCH, EDWARD ALFRED, Surgeon-Major, M.D., F.R.C.S., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; Behar famine, March, 1874; civil surgeon at Hazaribagh, May, 1874, and subsequently at Darjeeling and Nuddea; from Nov., 1881, officiated as surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, and also held charge of the office of sanitary commissioner, Bengal, June-July, 1882, and acted as professor of midwifery at the Medical College, and obstetric physician, Eden Hospital, May, 1883; surgeon superintendent, Presidency Hospital, sub-protem., Dec., 1883; confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1885.

BIRCH, ERNEST G., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1849; served in the revenue and survey departments, Bengal, and was appointed superintendent of survey, northern division, 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Baraset, 1858; magistrate and collector, Burdwan, 1860; civil and sessions judge, Moorshedabad, 1864, and subsequently of Shahabad; additional judge of Chittagong, 1870; district and sessions judge of Burdwan, 1872; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1873; retired 1879.

BIRCH, FREDERICK MACDONALD, Colonel B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 15th May, 1855; from Jan., 1860, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in Cashmere, July, 1864, and again, Dec., 1878, and with the financial commissioner's office, May, 1866; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Oct., 1879, to Oct., 1880, and subsequently in the Mooltan and Hissar divisions; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Nov., 1880.

BIRCH, WILLIAM BRERETON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 30th Nov., 1858, and was posted to 32nd Native Infantry, Bengal; served with the China forces 1861-62 (medal); joined the Bengal police department, July, 1863, and served as superintendent in various districts; member of Calcutta examination committee for judicial and police officers, March, 1867; vice-chairman, Burdwan municipality, March, 1867; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and a visitor of the Presidency jail and lunatic asylums, Feb., 1869; commanded Sylhet frontier police battalion, on Looshai expedition, Sept., 1871, to March, 1872; and assistant superintendent, Andamans, April, 1873; 1st assistant superintendent, 1885; services replaced at the disposal of the military department, March, 1888; author of a report on sugar manufacture in the N.W. Provinces and Bengal (1881), a report on jail manufactures in
India (1881), and of the Andamans and Nicobar Manual, 1886.

BIRD, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from June, 1866, and was appointed principal assistant collector, May, 1881, district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Oct., 1884, and collector and magistrate in the same district, Feb., 1885; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Jan., 1886.

BIRD, CHARLES PAVIN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1886; officiating divisional judge, Feb., 1888.

BIRD, HUBERT MOORE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portarlington School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and assistant commissioner, and also acted as deputy commissioner and magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1884; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Sept., 1887.

BIRDWOOD, SIR GEORGE C. M., Kt., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., M.D., LL.D., Statistics and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at the Plymouth Grammar School, and University of Edinburgh (M.D. and M.R.C.S., 1854); Bombay Medical Service 1854; between 1855 and 1857 served under the military department, and held temporary charge of the civil station of Sholapore, including the jail; served in the Persian War of 1856-57 (medal and clasp); from April, 1857 to 1868, held successively the professorships of anatomy and physiology, botany and materia medica in the Grant Medical College, Bombay; curator of the Government Central Museum, Bombay, 1857, and with the assistance of Dr. Bhau Daji and the leading natives of Bombay founded the Victoria and Albert Museum and Victoria Gardens, Bombay; Sheriff of Bombay, 1864, and subsequently registrar of the University of Bombay; special commissioner for the government of Bombay at the Universal Exhibition at Paris, 1867; appointed to assist Dr. Forbes Watson in connection with the annual exhibitions at South Kensington commenced in 1871; special assistant in the statistics and commerce department, India Office, Jan., 1878; is also visitor to the India Museum; C.S.I., 1877; Kt., 1881; LL.D., Cambridge, 1886; author of the following publications: The Economic Vegetable Products of the Bombay Presidency; a paper 'On the Genus Boswellia (Frankincense Trees),' Linn. Trans. of 1886; 'Handbook to the British Indian Section of the Paris Universal Exhibition of 1878,' an official 'Report on the Miscellaneous Old Records of the India Office,' published in 1879; a work on 'The Industrial Arts of India,' published in 1880 by the Science and Art Department; the 'Arts of India,' a handbook to the collection of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, 1881; and of several other handbooks on Indian art published by the department in connection with Indian exhibitions held at York, Berlin, Copenhagen, Stockholm, and Amsterdam; author also of various contributions to the Quarterly Review, the Asiatic Quarterly Review, &c., &c.; was a royal commissioner for the Colonial and Indian Exhibition of 1886, and a member of the finance committee appointed to assist the Prince of Wales in connection with the exhibition; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

BIRDWOOD, HERBERT MILLS, M.A., LL.M., Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858, and afterwards transferred to the Bombay service; arrived in Bombay, 26th Jan., 1859, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the judicial department, and secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, acting political assistant in Kathiawar, senior assistant judge and session judge, and registrar of the high court; judge and session judge, Surat, March, 1875; 1st grade judge, Dec., 1877; on special duty at Oodeypore, Sept., 1880; judicial commissioner in Scinde and judge of the Sadar court, Feb., 1881; on special duty in Bombay, March, 1881; judge of the high court, Bombay, Jan., 1885; edited vols. iv. and v. and (in collaboration with Mr. H. J. Parsons), vols. vi., vii., and viii. of 'West's Code of Acts and Regulations.'

BIRDWOOD, WILLIAM ILBERT, Major-General, R.E.—Joined the Madras Engineers 1825; appointed to the public works department June, 1830; served in the grades of assistant and civil engineer; district engineer, Tanjore, Jan., 1857; superintending engineer, south circle, March, 1859; deputy chief engineer, 1859; chief engineer and secretary to government of Madras, June, 1862; retired, Sept., 1863.

BIRKS, ARTHUR RAWSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Highgate School, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner; transferred to Burma, April, 1874; served in the grade of assistant commissioner, and acted as collector of customs, Bassein, March, 1878, and as judge of Moulinmein, 1880-1882; on special duty in Rangoon, Aug., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, May, 1884.

BISHOP, EDWARD F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 15th March, 1866; senior clerk, June, 1882.

BISSET, WILLIAM SINCLAIR SMITH, C.I.E., Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Dec., 1866, as assistant engineer, Rohilcund; railway branch, Bengal, 1870; assistant consulting engineer, Bengal, July, 1870; also officiating manager, Calcutta and S. E. State Railway; superintendent Darjeeling railway survey, Oct., 1870; Holkar state railway, Nov., 1870; executive engineer, March, 1871; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, April, 1872; manager, Holkar State Railway, Dec., 1875; on special duty, Madras famine relief works, 1877; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80 (medal);
manager, Rajputana and Scindia Railway, Sept., 1879; class 1, grade 2, state railway revenue establishment, June, 1881; agent, Bombay, Baroda, and Central India Railway Company, Jan., 1885; supernumerary, class I., grade 1, Nov., 1885; C.I.E., June, 1883.

BITTLESTON, Sir Adam, Knt.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1841; was a puisne judge of the supreme court, Madras, 1858-62, and of the high court from its establishment in 1862 to 1870, when he retired.

BLACK, Charles E. D., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Harrow; writer, India office, 20th Sept., 1869; geographical department clerk, July, 1873; detached in 1880 to be assistant private secretary, and subsequently, from May, 1884, principal private secretary to H.M.'s secretary of state, home department (Rt. Hon. Sir William V. Harcourt); secretary to the royal commission on the blind, the deaf and dumb, &c., July, 1885; clerk for geographical records, India office, Sept., 1885; author of the 'Abstracts of the Reports of the Surveys, and of other Geographical Operations in India' from 1873 to 1878.

BLACK, Samuel, Major-General, C.S.I., Bengal S.C.—First commission as ensign, Bengal N.I., Dec., 1844; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49 (medal); from May, 1854, served in the public works department, Lower Provinces, embankment circle; staff officer, Punjab irregular force, Jan., 1857; medal for service in the mutiny; executive engineer, public works department, Punjab, Jan., 1860; military secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1862-83; attained colonel's allowances, Dec., 1882; services replaced at disposal of Government of India, military department; appointed governor, Aitchison College, Oct., 1886.

BLANC, Henri Jules, Surgeon-Major, M.D., F.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (Lon.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 7th Aug., 1859, and served in the military department and also as acting civil surgeon in various stations, and as superintendent of vaccination; served in the China War, 1860-62; was a member of the Abyssinian mission, 1864, and was confined in chains during 21 months by the Emperor Theodore; subsequently joined the expeditionary force, and was present at the storming of Magdala (medal); superintendent of Yerrowda central jail, April, 1875; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibho Hospital, Bombay, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical College, May, 1876, to Aug., 1882; also acted as professor of anatomy, and curator of the museum, May-June, 1879; physician, European General Hospital from Aug., 1882; retired, April, 1887.
