CROLE, Charles Stewart, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh High School and Edinburgh University.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as sub-secretary, board of revenue, July-Sept., 1869, and as collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants in 1879-80; compiled Chingleput district manual; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, Jan.-March, 1880; district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1881; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882, in the district of Kistna, and afterwards in the districts of Madura and Anantapur; district and sessions judge, North Malabar, Aug., 1886.

CROMBIE, Alexander, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1872; officiating resident surgeon, Calcutta Medical College Hospital, 25th Jan., 1873; professor of surgery, Medical College, in addition to his own duties, Oct., 1873; professor of materia medica, Sept., 1874; transferred to Burma, Feb., 1875, and appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, and health officer to the port; from April, 1877, served in Bengal as civil surgeon, also at Simla as joint medical officer, March, 1880, to Feb., 1882; civil surgeon, Dacca, with charge of the jail, March, 1882; also superintendent of the lunatic asylum, medical school and Mitford Hospital; surgeon-major, March, 1884; officiating surgeon superintendent, presidency general hospital, Calcutta, March, 1886.

CROOKE, William, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's Grammar School, Tipperary, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1886; author of a rural and agricultural glossary for the N.W. Provinces and Oudh.

CROSS (Viscount), Rt. Hon. Richard Assheton Cross, G.C.B.—Born 30th May, 1823; educated at Rugby School, and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated B.A. in 1846; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1849, and for several years went the northern circuit; represented Preston in the House of Commons, March, 1857, to March, 1862, and S.W. Lancashire from Dec., 1868; secretary of state for the home department, Feb., 1874, to 1880; bencher of the Inner Temple, 1876; hon. LL.D. of Cambridge, Oct., 1878; G.C.B. in 1880; again secretary of state for the home department, June, 1885; and was appointed president of the royal commission on the Education Acts; in Lord Salisbury's second administration, Aug., 1886, was appointed secretary of state for India, and raised to the peerage under the title of Viscount Cross; was formerly an ecclesiastical commissioner for England; is a deputy lieutenant for Lancashire, and late chairman of the Lancashire quarter sessions; author of two legal works—'The Acts relating to the Settlement and Removal of the Poor, with Notices of Cases, Indices, and Forms,' 1853; and 'The General and Quarter Sessions of the Peace; their Jurisdiction and Practice in other than Criminal Matters' (written in conjunction with Mr. H. Leaming), 1858, 2nd edition, 1876.

CROSTHOWAITE, Sir Charles Hawkes Todd, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; from Nov., 1858, to March, 1877, served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate
and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and settlement officer, and acted as secretary to the board of revenue for two years from March, 1875; from April, 1877, served in the Central Provinces as commissioner of the Nagpur and Jubbulpur divisions, and was appointed judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881, and additional member of the governor-general's council for the purpose of making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881; acting chief commissioner, British Burma, March, 1883, to April, 1884; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1885; member of the public service commission, Nov., 1886; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; chief commissioner of Burma, March, 1887; K.C.S.I., May, 1888.

CROSTHWAITE, Robert Joseph, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty on the revenue committee at Naini Tal, July, 1872; assistant superintendent, sub-judge, and registrar of Dehra Dün, Dec., 1873; small cause court judge, Allahabad, March, 1875; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1878, to Feb., 1881; acting secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March to May, 1881; district and sessions judge, Allahabad, May, 1881; additional secretary to government of India, legislative department, Jan., 1882; acted as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces in 1882 and 1883, and was confirmed in the appointment, Jan., 1885.

CROW, William, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, 23rd Oct., 1883.

CROWDY, John Henry, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; posted to Indian establishment, Sept., 1870; from Dec., 1870, served as executive engineer in the Punjab; transferred to military works, 1872, and served in the Punjab, the N.W. Provinces and Bengal; superintending engineer, 3d class, March, 1886.

CROWE, William Henry (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of mental and moral philosophy and logic at the Deccan College, Poonah, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and assistant judge and sessions judge; editor of the 'Bombay Gazetteer' Oct., 1868; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, March, 1882; on special duty at Kathiawar, Nov., 1882; appointed 2nd grade judge and session judge, Thana, Aug., 1883, and afterwards at Satara; 1st grade judge, Sept., 1885.

CROZIER, Robert G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; temporary clerk, India Office, 30th Nov., 1865; junior clerk, Jan., 1867; senior clerk, March, 1887.

CRUICKSHANK, Alexander, M.A., late Madras C.S.—University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras from Oct., 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, principal assistant collector, and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, special agent, French settlement, and political agent for Pondicherry, Sept., 1878; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Nov., 1885; district and sessions judge, of Cuddapah, Jan., 1886, and of Kurnool, Aug., 1886; retired, Nov. 1887.

CRUICKSHANK, Alexander Walmsly, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and officiating magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1878; under-secretary to government, N.W.P., Sept., 1886; settlement officer, Gorakhpur, Oct., 1886.

CRUICKSHANK, John, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Appointed to the Indian medical service, 20th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 9th April, 1856; civil surgeon, Dharwar, Jan., 1865; from March, 1866, acted as surgeon to the governor of Bombay, also as private secretary, Oct., 1866; on special duty to Egypt as surgeon to Lord Mayo, Nov., 1868; superintendent of Mahabaleshwar, Dec., 1870; from April, 1871, served as inspector-general of prisons, Bombay, and was a member of the prisons conference at Calcutta, Jan., 1877; retired, April, 1887.

CRUMP, Charles George, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces; resigned, March, 1886.

CRUMP, Henry Ashbrooke, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1885; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Wardha, Nov., 1885.

CULLEN, Peter, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department (Central Provinces).—Joined the Bengal medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1860; was employed under the military department, including service in the China War; from Feb., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; also superintendent of cotton affairs, May, 1865; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877, and of brigade-surgeon, April, 1888.

CUMINE, Alexander, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1874, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting superintendent of police, railway magistrate, and acting junior collector and forest settlement officer; acting special assistant collector and settlement officer, Ratnagiri, Nov., 1884.

CUMMING, Charles Lennox Bruce, F.R.G.S., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Chel-
tenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1867, and served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; principal assistant to collector, magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Nov., 1883; retired, March, 1888.

CUMMING, JOHN ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School, and Aberdeen University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 16th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant to magistrate and collector.

CUMMING, WILLIAM GORDON, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1860; arrived in India 7th Oct., 1862; joined the public works department, Feb., 1864, as assistant engineer, Port Blair; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to Madras, Aug., 1868; Hyderabad, May, 1870; from Feb., 1874, served in British Burma; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, May, 1881; temporary superintending engineer, Rangoon, Jan., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1884; officiating secretary to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Oct., 1884; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, April, 1887; confirmed, May, 1888; chief engineer, 3rd class, special, May, 1888.

CUNNINGHAM, JAMES MACNABB, Surgeon-general, M.D., C.S.I., late Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1851; superintendent of central prison, Bareilly, 1861, and subsequently at Meerut; officiating superintendent, government press, N.W. Provinces, 1863; surgeon, April, 1864; secretary to sanitary commissioner, 1866; professor of hygiene, Calcutta medical college, 1866; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, 1869; sanitary commissioner with the government of India, 1875; surgeon-general, March, 1880; retired, March, 1885.

CUNNINGHAM, WILLIAM JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Clapham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Aug., 1873, served in Mysore as assistant commissioner on special duty at Bangalore and Chitradurg; acting deputy commissioner, additional secretary in the famine department (Aug., 1878), and secretary to the chief commissioner, general department (Jan., 1879); political agent, assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to the chief commissioner, Coorg, April, 1881; political agent, 3rd class, and assistant to the resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1883; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, Sept., 1885.

CUNNINGHAM, SIR ALEXANDER, Major-General, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., R.E.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and Addiscombe; first commission, Bengal engineers, 1831; aide-de-camp to governor-general, 1834; sent specially to Cashmere, 1839; engineer to king of Oudh in 1840; served in the Gwalior campaign of 1843-44; and was present at the battle of Punniar (bronze star); from Feb., 1844 served as executive officer on the staff, Gwalior contingent; head of a mission to Thibet in 1846; engineer for laying down the boundaries of the N.W. frontier, Jan. 1847 to 1849; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49, including the battles of Chillianwallah and Gojearat (medal with two clasps, and brevet of major); executive engineer, Moulton, Dec., 1852; chief engineer, Pegu and Tenasserim, Oct., 1856; chief engineer, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1858; also secretary to government; archaeological surveyor to government, 1861; retired June, 1862. C.S.I., May, 1871; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; author of many articles on antiquarian subjects in the journal of the Bengal Asiatic Society, and other periodicals: 'The Bhilsa Topes, or Buddhist Monuments of Central India,' 1854; 'An Essay on the Aryan Order of Architecture,' 1846; 'Ladak: Physical, Statistical, and Historical,' 1854; and official reports on the Antiquities of Northern Hindostan.

CUNNINGHAM, ALEXANDER FREDERICK DOUGLAS, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab (civil department), Sept., 1878; on special duty as political assistant to Major Cavagnari for employment in Afghanistan, Nov., 1878; political officer, Khyber, Oct., 1879; 1st assistant to chief political officer, Afghanistan (Kabul), Feb., 1880; officiating secretary to government, April-May, 1881; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Feb., 1884; under secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1884; officiated as deputy commissioner at Dera Ismail Khan, Feb., 1885, at Hazara, 1886, and at Bannu, April, 1887; on special duty at Rawul Pindi durbar, March, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1887; officiated as divisional judge, Jhelum, Aug., 1887, and deputy commissioner and district judge, Sept., 1887.

CUNNINGHAM, DAVID DOUGLAS, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1868; from 19th Dec., 1874, served as special assistant to the sanitary commissioner with the government of India; professor of physiology, Calcutta Medical College, in addition to his own duties, from June, 1879; also acted as government quinologist, and was in charge of the cinchona plantations, Sept., 1879; officiating superintendent of botanical gardens, Aug., 1880; appointed to conduct special cholera inquiries in immediate connection with the sanitary commissioner with the government of India, Dec., 1884; rank of surgeon-major, April, 1880; honorary surgeon to H.E. the Viceroy; author of many medical and scientific treatises the result of microscopic and physiological research in relation to cholera and other subjects.

CUNNINGHAM, Sir H. S., K.C.I.E., late Calcutta High Court.—Advocate-general, high court, Madras, and additional member of the governor's council, 1872-77; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; member of the famine commission, May, 1878 to Jan., 1881; member of the finance committee, March, 1886; resigned his seat in the high court, Calcutta, July, 1888; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

CURRIE, BERTRAM WODEHOUSE, appointed
to the council of the secretary of state for India, 11th Dec., 1880.

CURRIE, FENDALL, Lieutenant-Colonel (Barrister-at-Law).—Arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1858, as cornet, 1st European light cavalry; assistant commissioner, Hazaribagh, Feb., 1863; from Sept., 1863, served in the Oudh commission, and was appointed small cause court judge, Sitapur, June, 1868, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1868; on special duty to collate laws and regulations in force in Oudh, May, 1869; on special duty for taking up lands for railway purposes, Oct., 1869; city magistrate, Lucknow, Feb., 1870; on special duty to review the Bara Banki forgery report, March, 1874; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1878; officiated as Commissioner in the Rae Bareli division, Aug., 1882; and subsequently in the Fyzabad, and Lucknow divisions; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1883, commissioner Rae Bareli, March, 1888; author of 'The Penal Code, Act XLV. of 1880,' 'The Indian Code of Criminal Procedure,' 'The Oudh Rent Act,' 'The Oudh Land Revenue Manual,' 'A Commentary on Act XXII. of 1886,' and the 'Indian Law Examination Manual.'

CURRIE, GEORGE MAINWARING, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1884, and 1st grade Aug., 1887.

CURSETJEE RUSTOMJEE (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, April, 1886.

CURTIS, GEORGE SEYMOUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1886.

CUSHING, THOMAS, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk to inspector of scientific instruments, store depot, Dec., 1867; inspector of scientific instruments, May, 1876.

CUTHERBSON, CLIVE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's, Adelaide, Glenalmond School, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived, 13th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885, officiating under secretary to government of Bengal, March, 1888.

CUTTLE, G., Store Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, India store depot, 5th April, 1882.

DALE, GEORGE SPENCE DESBOROUGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Aug., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1882.

DALLAS, A. M., Deputy Surgeon-General, C.I.E., Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India and was appointed assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, June, 1856; superintendent, central jail, Oct., 1859; inspector-general of prisons, April, 1863; surgeon, Feb., 1868; special duty, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1882; deputy surgeon-general, and surgeon-general, Punjab, Sept., 1884; inspector-general of civil hospitals, Punjab, April, 1885.

DALMAHOY, PATRICK CARFRAE, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign 1st Jan., 1857; adjutant of the Hamirpur district police, Oct., 1858, to Sept., 1860; commandant of the same, Oct., 1861; from Jan., 1862, served as district superintendent of police up to April, 1867, when he was appointed assistant inspector-general, government railway police; officiating commandant of the Mhairwara police battalion Sept., 1869, to April, 1871; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1882 to 1885.

DALTON, GODFREY JOHN BECTIVE TUTE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Columba's College, Rathfarnham, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 12th Jan., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1877, and deputy commissioner, 1st grade, March, 1886; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887.

DALY, SIR HENRY DOMINICK, Lieutenant-General, K.C.B., C.I.E.—Ensign, first European regiment, Bombay, Dec., 1840; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and was present at the siege of Mooltan, the battle of Goojerat, and the pursuit and surrender of the Sikh army (medal and two clasps); served in the campaign on the N.W. Frontier, 1850-51, including the passage of the Kotah Pass, and the expedition against the hill tribes; during the Indian mutiny served at the siege of Delhi, the siege of Lucknow, in the campaign in Oude, the action at Nawabganj, the passages of the Goomtee, Gogra, &c. (C.B., medal, brevet of lieutenant-colonel); commandant, Central India Horse, June, 1862; agent to governor-general, Central India, 1871, to Feb., 1881.

DALY, W. WATT, Bengal Police.—Served in the police department from 19th Nov., 1862; attached to Looshai expeditionary force in command of frontier police, Nov., 1871-March, 1872; district superintendent, March, 1873; with Carrow Hills expedition, 1873-4; commandant of frontier police in command of Surma Valley division, May, 1883; district superintendent of police, 1st grade, April, 1888.

DALYELL, SIR ROBERT ANSTRUTHER, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., I.L.D., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1859; served in junior offices in the revenue and magisterial departments till 1861, when he was appointed sub-secretary to the board of revenue; member of the income tax commission, 1861-65; and officiating president, 1865; officiating Inam commissioner, 1866; secretary, board of revenue, 1867; acting secretary to government in the revenue department, 1868-70; on special duty in connection with the excise, 1872; additional member of the council of the governor-general for making laws and regulations, 1873 (reappointed in 1875, and again in 1877); board of revenue, Madras, 1873; government director of
the bank of Madras, 1873-74; officiating chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, 1875-76; member of the council of the secretary of state for India, 1877; nominated a C.S.I., on retirement from the Indian civil service in 1879; vice-president of council, 1883-84; honorary LL.D. of the University of St. Andrew's, 1885; a royal commissioner for Indian and Colonial Exhibition, 1886; published a sketch of the land tenures of Madras in 1864, a revised official edition of the standing orders of the board of revenue in 1866, and in 1867 a history of the Madras famine of the previous year.

DAMES, MANSEL LONGWORTH, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant and divisional judge; on special duty with the Kabul troops, Jan., 1879; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1887; author of a Biluchi grammar and text-book.

DAMPIER, HENRY LUCUS, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, Dec., 1848; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1849; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1860; junior secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1861; and secretary, Nov., 1861; commissioner, Nuddea division, July, 1863; on special duty in the famine districts, 1866; between April, 1867, and Nov., 1874, served as secretary to the government of Bengal in the revenue and general departments, and as officiating secretary to the government of India, home department, in 1872; special member of the Bengal legislative council, Dec., 1874; board of revenue, Oct., 1877; Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1879; president of commission for amendment of rent law in Bengal, 1881; retired, 26th July, 1884.

DANCE, GEORGE WHITMORE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

DANE, LOUIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner and district judge; on special duty in the Punjab secretariat, Aug., 1879; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1879, to April, 1882; on special duty, Lahore Rakhs, 1884-85; officiating registrar, chief court, June, 1886; officiating district judge, April, 1887; settlement officer, Gurdaspur, Oct., 1887; officiating deputy commissioner, April to June, 1888, in addition to his own duties.

DANE, RICHARD MORRIS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; served under the foreign department of the government of India, July, 1878, to April, 1879; secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1880; on special duty in public works department, Feb., 1882; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March to Aug., 1882; on special duty under government of India, foreign department, as boundary settlement officer, Central India, Jan., 1883, to March, 1884, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Jan.-June, 1885; served subsequently as officiating deputy commissioner, Punjab; settlement officer, Gurdaspur, Nov., 1885; officiating deputy commissioner, May, 1888.

DANIELL, CAIRNES ANTHONY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, and Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1859, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant under the commissioner of Meerut, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1866; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1868; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, July, 1866; civil and session judge, Gorakhpur, April, 1877; commissioner, Benares division, and agent to the governor-general, March, 1881; member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1884.

DANIELL, CLARMONT JOHN, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, Aug., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, Aug., 1878; fellow of Calcutta University, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Allahabad division, Aug., 1881, and of the Agra division, Oct., 1883; 1st grade judge, April, 1885, Farakhabad; retired, Oct., 1886.

DANVERS, FREDERICK C., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and King's College, London, and, after a special training preparatory for Addiscombe, studied for two years for a civil and mechanical engineer; East India House writer, old establishment, 26th Jan., 1853; junior clerk, public and ecclesiastical department, India office, 1858; public works department, 1861; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant secretary in the public works department, Feb., 1875; assistant secretary in the revenue department, 1877; registrar and superintendent of records Jan., 1884; in 1855 designed a salt-weighing machine, of which a number were manufactured in this country for the use of the Madras government; in 1859 was deputed by the secretary of state to Liverpool and Manchester to report on traction engines, with a view to their being used in India; author of articles published in 'Engineering' relative to public works in India, 1866-75; of a design for crossing the East India Railway under the Hooghly from Howrah to Calcutta, transmitted to India by the secretary of state in 1868; of 'Statistical Papers relating to India' (printed parliamentary paper No. 308 of 1869); of memorandum on Indian coals, with reference to their employment as fuel for Indian railways and steamers, 1867; of memorandum on coal-washing and artificial fuel, 1869; of 'Coal Economy' (printed by order of the secretary of state, 1872); of 'A Century of Famines, being particulars of all the Famines
that have visited India since the year 1770, and an inquiry as to the best means of providing against them,' 1877; of 'Spon's Information for Colonial Engineers—India' (published by E. and F. Spon, London, 1877); of 'Agriculture in India,' a paper read before the Society of Arts, 1878 (Society's silver medal); of 'Famines in India,' read before the Society of Arts in 1886; of a 'Report on the Records of the India Office,' printed by order of the secretary of state for India in Council, 1887; and of 'Chiefs, Agents, and Governors of Bengal,' 1888.

DANVERS, Sir Juland, K.C.S.I., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; East India House writer, 22nd March, 1842; junior clerk, Feb., 1847; minute branch, secretary's department, 1847; private secretary to chairman and deputy, 1848-53; senior clerk, Feb., 1852; assistant minute branch, secretary's department, 1857; assistant secretary in the railway and electric telegraph department, India office, and assistant director of Indian railway companies, Feb., 1858; secretary in the railway and telegraph department, and deputy director of Indian railway companies, Sept., 1858, to July, 1861; government director of Indian railway companies, 1861; secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph departments, Aug., 1880, continuing to be director of Indian railway companies; visited India in his official capacity in 1875-76; author of the annual official reports on railways in India presented to Parliament from 1859 to 1882; K.C.S.I., 1886.

DARLINGTON, Edwin, Customs Department, Burma.—Joined the service as superintendent of the Burma secretariat, June, 1868; from March, 1872, served as collector of customs, Akyab, also in the Burma secretariat, on special duty, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1875; officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept., 1876; collector of customs, Rangoon, July, 1877; vice-chairman of the Rangoon port commissioners, March, 1882.

DARRAH, Henry Zouch, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882; acting manager of the Awa estate, March, 1883; acting director of agriculture in Assam, June, 1884; acting secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, March-April, 1886; director of land records and agriculture, Assam, Jan., 1887; author of a 'Monograph on Cotton in Assam.'

DAUKES, Frederick Clendon, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Downing College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, April, 1872; officiating under secretary to government, Sept., 1873; assistant settlement officer, 3rd grade, Banda, Nov., 1873; attaché, foreign department, government of India, 1873; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1876-77; secretary, public service commission, Sept., 1886; under secretary, government of India, home department, from Dec., 1877; officiating secretary to the chief commissioner of Assam, June, 1888.

DAVIDSON, James, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to Aug., 1878; acting first assistant collector, Nov., 1883; second assistant collector, Nov., 1886; forest settlement officer, Nasik, Aug., 1887.

DAVIDSON, James Young, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant-engineer, 9th Dec., 1869, and served in the Central Provinces; executive engineer, Oct., 1875; from Jan., 1882, served as manager, in class 2 of the state railway revenue establishment, on the Wardha coal, and Nagpur-Chhattisgarh railways; in charge of Umaria colliery, Jan., 1886; acting engineer-in-chief Nagpur-Bengal railway, Feb., 1886; class 1, revenue establishment, April, 1887.

DAVIDSON, Lionel, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886.

DAVIDSON, Robert, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1852; served as assistant to collector and magistrate in various districts; sub-judge of Cuddapah, 1860; small cause court judge, Chittoor, 1862; civil and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, 1867; district and sessions judge of Cuddapah, Aug., 1873, and subsequently of Chingleput; acted as collector and magistrate of Kurnool during the famine, 1877-78; third member, board of revenue, March, 1878; chief secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1878; legislative council of Madras, 1880 to 1883; provisional member of the executive council May-July, 1881; 1st member, board of revenue, March, 1882; member of the special committee appointed to frame a famine code for Madras, Oct., 1882; retired, June 1884.

DAVIES, Arthur Matcham, Colonel, M.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1849; served in the Madras police department from Sept., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; acting personal assistant to commissioner of police, Madras, Sept., 1866; deputy inspector-general, Nov., 1881 to 1886.

DAVIES, Charles Merson, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant locomotive superintendent, 15th Sept., 1875; superintendent, March, 1880; class 1, grade 3, Jan., 1888.

DAVIES, J., late Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk in principal storekeeper's office, Tower of London, under the board of ordnance, May, 1842; inspector of stores, 1851; sub-inspector of stores, East India House, July, 1855; senior clerk, June, 1860; assistant superintendent of the India store depot, March, 1877; superintendent, June, 1880; retired, Dec., 1888.

DAVIES, James Acworth (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Denmark
Hill Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, March, 1880; assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, April, 1880; acting under secretary in the chief secretary's department, July, 1880; member of the board of examiners, Jan., 1882; acting district and sessions judge, South Canara, June, 1882; under secretary in the revenue department, Oct., 1882; acting secretary to the board of revenue, June, 1883; from Oct., 1883, acted as registrar, high court, Madras, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Kistna, July, 1884; district and sessions judge, Tanjore, March, 1888.

DAVIES, SIR ROBERT HENRY, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the N.W. Provinces and cis-Sutlej Territory as assistant commissioner; settlement officer, Baree Doab, 1857; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Azimgurh, 1858; secretary to government of Punjab, 1859; financial commissioner, Oudh, 1864; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1866; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 1871; retired 1878; member of council of India, 3rd March, 1885.

DAVIES, SIR WILLIAM GEORGE, Colonel, K.C.S.I., B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 5th Jan., 1849; from April, 1854, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, May, 1862; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Nov., 1876, and subsequently in the Jullundur division; financial commissioner, Punjab, Dec., 1883; additional member of the governor-general's council, March, 1886; author of a report on the settlement of the Shahpur district; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, April, 1887.

DAVIS, ARTHUR WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rossall, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner.

DAVIS, JOHN SAMUEL CHAMPION, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at College School, Taunton, Rossall, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1882, and officiating superintendent in 1882-83; officiating cantonment magistrate, Chakrata, Sept.–Oct., 1885; junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1886.

DAWKINS, CLINTON E., India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in June, 1883; junior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, India office, 6th Feb., 1884; political department, 1886; assistant private secretary, and précis writer to the secretary of state, Aug., 1886.

DAWSON, WALTER HILL, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, St. Peter's, Weston-super-Mare, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886.

DAY, ARTHUR S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, Bedford Grammar School, and Clifton College; writer, India office, 26th Oct., 1874; clerk, and class, Nov., 1878.

DAYARAM GIDUMAL, B.A., LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and joined the service as assistant collector, 3rd Jan., 1885; acting small cause court judge, July, 1886; employed from May, 1885, to April, 1886, in compiling a Jaghir record for Sind; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, 3rd March, 1887; acting assistant judge and sessions judge.

DEANE, THOMAS, Major, B.S.C.—First commission, March, 1862, 1st hussars; lieutenant, Bengal staff corps, March, 1863; adjutant, governor-general's body guard, Jan., 1871; 3rd assistant secretary to the government of India, military department, Jan., 1877; and assistant secretary, April, 1884; deputy secretary, July, 1886.

DEAS, JOSEPH, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1870, and served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1885; from April, 1886, acted as district and session judge; confirmed in appointment, Aug., 1887.

DE BEAUREPAIRE, E.L., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 31st March, 1885.

DE BOURBEL, RAOUl, Colonel, R.E., Late Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 1850; joined the public works department, Nov., 1852; executive engineer, Lower Provinces, Dec., 1853; assistant to chief engineer, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1857; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1860; officiating consulting engineer and under secretary, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1862; superintending engineer, Ghowhatte, June, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Oudh, Feb., 1870; superintending engineer, 2nd grade, railway branch, Oudh, Sept., 1870; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, 1871; in temporary charge of public works department in Biluchistan, 1879-80; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, 1880; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884; retired, 1885.

DE BRETT, EDWARD ADOLPHUS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

DE FABECK, WILLIAM FREDERICK, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., Medical Department.—Entered the army medical department, June, 1855; joined the Madras medical department, June, 1857, and served under the military department from that date to May, 1871, also holding the civil surgeoncies of Kurnul, Chittur, Vellore, and Nagode (Central Provinces), during that period. From Nov., 1873, served in British
Burma as acting garrison surgeon, Rangoon, and acting civil surgeon and superintendent of Lock Hospital, Moulmein (May, 1874), and was confirmed in the latter appointment, 1877; also health officer, Moulmein, Feb., 1878, and was in medical charge of the central jail for various periods; deputy surgeon-general, Nagpore force, and Central India regiments, March, 1886.

DEIGHTON, KENNETH, B.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as professor, Agra College, 19th Feb., 1862; principal, Agra College, March, 1864; and grade of educational officers, April, 1883; officiating principal, Benares College, July, 1883; inspector of schools, Rohilkund division, April, 1885.

DENMAN, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

DENNISTON, JAMES LAWSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1885; deputy commissioner, March, 1888.

DE PALEZIEUX-FALCONNET, GRENVILLE PULTENEY, Colonel, R.E., late Military Works Department, India.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1852; joined the Madras public works department, Aug., 1854, as assistant engineer; from Dec., 1854, served in the Bengal public works department as executive engineer, Pegu; Mhow division, Rajputana, Nov., 1864; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, 1872; superintending engineer, Meerut, April, 1874, and afterwards at Moradabad and Rawal Pindi; superintending engineer, 1st grade, June, 1879; officiated as inspector-general of military works, 1883-84; retired, 1886.

DERBY (EARL OF), RIGHT HONOURABLE EDWARD HENRY SMITH-STANLEY, K.G., D.C.L.—Born 21st July, 1826; educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he took a first class in classics in 1848; contested Lancaster unsuccessfully, March, 1848, but was elected for Lyme Regis, which he represented till Oct., 1860, when he succeeded to the House of Peers; made tours to the West Indies and the East in 1850-52; under secretary of state for foreign affairs, May-Dec., 1852; secretary of state for the colonies, and sworn a privy councillor, Feb., 1858; president of the board of control, May, 1858; secretary of state for India, Sept., 1858-59; during his tenure of this office the management of the Indian empire was transferred to the Crown; was secretary of state for foreign affairs from July, 1866, to Dec., 1868, and during this period conducted the negotiations for the settlement of the Luxemburg difficulty; lord rector of the University of Glasgow, April, 1869; was again appointed foreign secretary in Feb., 1874, but resigned in March, 1878; in Dec., 1882, he joined Mr. Gladstone's administration as secretary of state for the colonies; elected lord rector of the University of Edinburgh in Nov., 1874; was a member of the royal commission on army purchase in 1856-57, of the Cambridge University commission in 1856-60, and of the commission on the organisation of the Indian army in 1858-59; chairman of the commission on the sanitary state of the Indian army in 1859-61, and of the commission on patents in 1863-64; has also served on the royal commissions on capital punishment, on railways, on city companies, and for the London Exhibition of 1886.

DE RENZY, ANNESLEY CHARLES CASTRIOT, Surgeon-General, C.B., late Bengal Medical Service.—B.A., Trinity College, Dublin; entered the Bengal medical service, 1851; served through the Burmese war, 1852-53 (medal and clasp), and in the Mutiny campaigns, 1857-8, including capture of Lucknow (medal and clasp); appointed first sanitary commissioner, Punjab, 1868; surgeon-major, July, 1871; in 1877 undertook an inquiry into the causes of the great mortality among coolies proceeding by steamer to Assam, and made recommendations which led to a great reduction in the number of deaths; deputy surgeon-general, Nov., 1877; sanitary commissioner, Assam, 1878; served in the expedition against the Nagas, 1879; clasp and C.B.; deputy surgeon-general, Punjab Frontier Force, 1880; retired, Dec., 1882; author of sanitary reports to government on the Punjab and Assam; and of a paper on the sanitary state of British troops in Northern India.

DEY, GEORGE GOODAIR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1869; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1882; also served in Assam, in 1880, as officiating judge of Sylhet and Cachar; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1887.

DHANJISHA NAVROJI PARAKH, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (London), Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, Sept., 1874; arrived in India, 5th May, 1875; was employed under the military department till 1881; served subsequently as assistant civil surgeon, Poonah, and acted as deputy sanitary commissioner in 1881, as obstetric physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, and professor of midwifery, Grant Medical College, in 1883 and 1886, as presidency surgeon in 1884, and as civil surgeon at Surat, April, 1886; surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejal native general hospital, 1886.

DIACK, ALEXANDER HENDERSON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1882, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge.

DICK, ROBERT, M.A., Educational Department, Punjab.—From 31st July, 1870, served in the Punjab as professor at the Delhi and Lahore Colleges, and inspector of schools, and was appointed principal of the Lahore Training College, Dec., 1881; on special duty, April, 1877.
promoted to 3rd grade of the educational department, Nov., 1880.

DICKENS, CRAVEN HILDESLEY, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., late R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1838; adjutant and quartermaster, 1846; captain, March, 1853; assistant to secretary, government of India, public works department, June, 1855; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, April, 1864; secretary to government of India, public works department, March, 1865, to Feb., 1877; retired 31st Dec., 1878.

DICKINSON, RICHARD, Financial Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1851; junior clerk, minuting branch, secretary's department, 1853; private secretary to chairman and deputy chairman, 1855-58; senior clerk, financial department, India office, 1858; assistant secretary in the financial department, June, 1867.

DILLON, JOHN, Postal Department.—Served in the post office department, Punjab, from 3rd Oct., 1857, as deputy postmaster, inspector, and superintendent; also served in the N.W. Provinces and in Bengal; chief inspector of post offices, Oudh, March, 1874; compiler of postal accounts of India, July, 1878, subsequently designated as accountant-general of the post office, and afterwards as comptroller, post office; also acted as deputy director-general of the post office of India, March, 1879; and as postmaster-general, Bengal, Jan., 1880, and again in 1883.

DOBIE, WILLIAM HERBERT, Financial Department.—Joined the financial department, 23rd May, 1872; on famine duty as district grain accountant, Chumparun, July, 1874, and at Purneah, Jan., 1875; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1875; from Jan., 1876, served in Bengal, as acting deputy accountant-general, and as assistant comptroller-general; served in Madras, 1878-83, and in the Punjab, Oct., 1883, to Nov., 1884; assistant accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, in 3rd class of the financial department, Dec., 1884; assistant accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1885; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1886; comptroller, Assam, April, 1887.

DODD, CHARLES ALBERT, Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 23rd Royal Welsh Fusiliers, 12th Nov., 1857; medal and clasp for service during the Mutiny; from Feb., 1860, served in the police department, and was employed on special duty at Lucknow, 1860; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, March, 1861; district superintendent, Aug., 1861; secretary to committee at Calcutta for revising forms of police statistics, Feb., 1869; from April, 1870, served as superintendent, government press, and curator of government books, N.W. Provinces; also superintendent of emigration, Jan., 1883.

DODERET, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; compiler of Bombay Administration Report, 1886-7; forest settlement officer, May, 1888.

DODGSON, CYRIL GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884; forest settlement officer, July, 1887.

DONALD, WILLIAM, Financial Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1856; from 23rd May, 1859, served in the central public works office, and the civil paymaster's office, Madras, and was appointed to 5th class of financial department, Aug., 1862; examiner of claims, July, 1865; secretary to committee for examination of assistants, June, 1868; assistant accountant-general, Madras, Aug., 1869; director of incorporated bank of Madras, March, 1871; 3rd class of financial department, Feb., 1874; appointed assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Nov., 1874, and subsequently at Madras, (June, 1875), and acted on several occasions as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; member of board of examiners, May, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Dec., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Madras (class 3) May-July, 1886, and Aug.-Nov., 1887; confirmed in class 2, March, 1887; compiled the manual of rules and regulations for the use of junior members of Madras civil service.

DONOVAN, CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1862; from Feb., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty at Cawnpore, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; served in Assam, Sept., 1879, to June, 1882, as deputy commissioner, 1st grade; judge, 3rd grade, Benares, Jan., 1885; and grade, April, 1887.

DOSABHAI FRAMJI, C.S.I., Presidency Magistrate, Bombay.—Served from 6th Oct., 1860, as income tax assessor; police magistrate, July, 1866; special officer for the Imperial licence tax, May, 1867; collector of income tax and certificate tax, May, 1869; sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1871; member of the town council, Sept., 1873; from June, 1874, served as second magistrate of police, Bombay, and also held the posts of chairman of the municipal corporation (Sept., 1875, to Dec., 1876), chairman of the justices of the peace, additional member of the governor's council for making laws and regulations (Sept., 1877), special officer to hear appeals against the licence tax assessment (Aug. 1878), special collector of licence tax, and acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery (Aug.-Sept., 1882); joint commissioner of income tax in addition to his duties as presidency magistrate, April, 1886; author of 'Moral and Miscellaneous Essays,' 'The British Raj,' 'History of the Parsees,' and 'Travels in Great Britain.'

DOUGLAS, SHOLTO JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1878; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and inspector of labourers; from April, 1885, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate, and deputy collector.

DOUIE, JAMES McCrone, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the High School, Edinburgh,
University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, secretary to the financial commissioner (1881-82), and settlement officer (and grade, April, 1884); has published a translation of the Biluchinama, with a Biloch grammar.

DOVETON, JOHN CHADWICK, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Oct., 1858; assistant conservator of forests, 1st grade, Central Provinces, 8th April, 1864; deputy conservator May, 1865; conservator, 1st grade, Sept., 1882.

DOWDEN, THOMAS FREEMAN, Colonel, R.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—1st commission, Dec., 1850; joined the Bombay public works department, Aug., 1859; under secretary to government, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, 1872; officiating manager Rajputana state railway, April, 1878; manager, Dhond and Mummad state railway, Dec., 1878; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, Oct., 1879; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal); officiating superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, April, 1880; acting senior deputy consulting engineer, and under secretary to government, Bombay, Nov., 1881; assistant to director-general of railways, 1884; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1886; deputy consulting engineer, Calcutta, April, 1886; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, Feb., 1887.

DOWNING, S. F., M.A., A.M.I.C.E., Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 15th July, 1860; assistant professor, Presidency College, 16th Sept., 1869; professor, April, 1877; principal, government engineering college, Howrah, April, 1880; and class, education department, March, 1884.

DOYLE, B., Surgeon-Major, B.A., M.B., M.C.H., Political Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the Indian Medical Department, and arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1876; served in military department to April, 1881, and afterwards as civil surgeon and deputy sanitary commissioner; served in Burma, Nov., 1886 to Feb., 1887; medical adviser to Maharaja of Jhind, 20th Sept., 1887; surgeon-major, March, 1888.

D'OLYLY, WARREN HASTINGS, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 28th May, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; inspector-general of jails, May, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1876; officiating opium agent, Behar, March-Dec., 1878; and again in Nov., 1885; officiating commissioner, Bhagulpore, 1884-85.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, EDWARD FORSTER, Surgeon-Major, F.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. (London), M.R.C.S., Madras Medical Dept.—Assistant-surgeon, 1st Oct., 1866; arrived, 23rd April, 1867, and served under the military department, Madras, and also as acting civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, and superintendent of fish liver oil factory, Calicut; was also in medical charge of lock hospital, Madras, and central cholera hospital, Vepery, 1869-70; resident assistant surgeon, general hospital, and professor of pathology in medical college, Madras, Oct., 1870, to Feb., 1875; also acting professor of medical jurisprudence, Sept., 1872; ophthalmic surgeon, general hospital, and professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology, March, 1875; surgeon-major, Oct., 1878; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, ELLIOT GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service after open competition of 1886.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, HENRY VERNON, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at the Charterhouse, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1886; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Central Provinces.

DREW, WILLIAM WILSON, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; from May, 1882, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and railway magistrate, and was permanently transferred to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; appointed inspector of factories, town of Bombay, May, 1887; acting junior collector land revenue, customs, &c., June, 1888.

DRIBERG, JOHN JAMES STREET, Assam Commission.—Joined the service as deputy magistrate, and deputy collector, in Bengal, Nov., 1861; from Dec., 1863, served in Assam as extra assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty as assistant civil and political officer with the Bhutan Duars Field Force, Oct., 1864, to June, 1865 (medal and clasp); assistant commissioner, and grade, May, 1880; deputy superintendent of census in Assam, Oct., 1880; superintendent of emigration, June, 1882; deputy commissioner, May, 1886.

DRUITT, GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Wimborne Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1868; and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate and cantonment magistrate, assistant judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; attached to political department of secretariat, Oct., 1877-Jan., 1878; and grade judge, and sessions judge, Kanara, Nov., 1886.

DRUMMOND, Hon. Sir EDMUND, K.C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1831; arrived in India, 6th March, 1833; assistant collector and magistrate, Monghyr, Jan., 1834; on special resumption and settlement duty, Dec., 1835, to Sept., 1839; officiating magistrate of Behar, Sept., 1839; collector of Burdwan, July, 1850; collector, magistrate, and salt agent, Pooree, 1852; accountant, government of Bengal, military accountant, deputy accountant-general, government of India, member of mint committee, and director of bank of Bengal, 1854; accountant-general, government of India, 1856; auditor-general, government of India, president of board of audit, government director of bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1865; financial secretary, government of India, 1862; lieutenant-governor,
N.W. Provinces, March, 1863; retired 1868; member of council of secretary of state, 1875-85, K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

DRUMMOND, JAMES RAMSAY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, University of Glasgow, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, Nov., 1874; and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner.

DRYSDALE, ALEXANDER TOVEY, late Forest Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Arrived in India, Dec., 1864; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as head master of government school and officiating inspector of schools; from June, 1868, served in the forest department, Berar, as assistant conservator, deputy conservator, and conservator (3rd grade, Sept., 1882); retired, Jan., 1887.

DRYSDALE, THEODORE, Central Provinces Commission.—Assistant master, government school, Saugor, April, 1861; served in the Central Provinces commission from 19th Jan., 1863, as assistant commissioner; superintendent of the judicial commissioner's office, June, 1864; registrar of the judicial commissioner's court May, 1869; held executive charge of the jail, Saugor, 1877; deputy superintendent of census operations in the Central Provinces, April, 1880; judge, small cause court, Nagpur, Nov., 1884; on special duty in connection with the settlement of the Sarangarh State, Jan.-Feb., 1885; deputy commissioner, 4th class, April, 1885; cantonment magistrate, Kamptee, Dec., 1885.

DUCAT, WALTER MARSDEN, Col. R.E., Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service as second lieutenant, 13 June, 1856; arrived in India, May, 1858; assistant engineer, Aug., 1859; special assistant engineer, Jan., 1860; executive engineer, Aug., 1863; captain, Feb., 1868; lieutenant-colonel, Jan., 1884; and colonel, July, 1885; superintending engineer, Nov., 1886.

DUFF, ALAN COLQUHOUN, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1881, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; acting under secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1885.

DUFFERIN AND AVA (MARQUIS OF), RIGHT HON. FREDERICK TEMPLE HAMILTON BLACKWOOD, K.P., G.C.B., G.C.S.I., G.C.M.G., G.C.I.E., D.C.L.—Educated at Eton and Christ Church, Oxford; specially attached to Lord John Russell's Mission to Vienna in 1855; in 1860 was appointed British commissioner in Syria to enquire into the massacre of Christians, and for his services on this occasion was nominated a K.C.B.; under secretary of state for India, 1864-1866; under secretary for war, in 1866; Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Dec., 1868, to April, 1872; governor-general of Canada, May, 1872, to Oct., 1878; ambassador at St. Petersburg, Feb., 1879; ambassador at Constantinople, May, 1881; from Nov., 1882 to April, 1883, he was engaged in Egypt in the settlement of the various questions, arising out of Arabi's rebellion; viceroy and governor-general of India, 13th Dec., 1884; left India to take up post of ambassador at Rome, Dec., 1888; K.P. in 1863; lord-lieutenant of the county of Down, 1864; privy councillor, Dec., 1868; earl of the United Kingdom, Nov., 1871, and Marquis, 1888, taking the style of Ava in addition to Dufferin by special command of Her Majesty; president of the Royal Geographical Society May, 1878; LL.D., Harvard University, June, 1878; LL.D., Dublin University, Jan., 1879; D.C.L. Oxford University, June, 1879; G.C.B., 1883; chancellor of the Royal University, Ireland, 1886; has published 'Narrative of a Journal from Oxford to Skibbereen during the year of the Irish Famine,' 1846-47; 'Letters from High Latitudes,' the result of a yacht voyage to Iceland in 1859; 'Irish Emigration and the Tenure of Land in Ireland'; 'Mr. Mill's plan for the Pacification of Ireland examined;' 'Contributions to an Enquiry into the State of Ireland;' is also the author of various works in light literature.

DUKE, CHARLES JOHN ASHETON, Burma Commission.—Arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1866; served in the Burma commission from March, 1867, as assistant commissioner; town magistrate, Akyab, July, 1876; superintendent of Arakan Hill Tracts, March, 1880; deputy commissioner, March, 1882.

DUKE, FREDERICK WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Arbroath High School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Hooghly, Dec., 1884.

DUMERGUE, JOHN WILLOUGHBY FRANCIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant resident and acting resident in Travancore; Malayan translator to government, March, 1884; head assistant collector and magistrate, Nilgiris, Feb., 1885; acted as collector and magistrate.

DUNCAN, DAVID, M.A., D.Sc. (Edinburgh), Education Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras education department from 20th May, 1870, as professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Presidency College, and was registrar of the Madras University from April, 1875, to March, 1879, and again 1881-86; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1877; 3rd class of the education department, April, 1880; principal and professor, Presidency College, from March, 1884; also acted as director of public instruction, and as commissioner for the unconv. civil service examinations in 1885-86; second class of the education department, Aug., 1885.

DUNCAN, HARVEY TUCKETT, Major-General, C.S.I., late Madras S.C.—Ensign, 46th regt., N.I., Madras, June, 1848; was employed in the Mofussil police, 1860; inspector-general of police, British Burma, March, 1862; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1873; political resident, Mandalay, 1875 to 1878; retired from the army, Feb., 1880.

DURAND, SIR HENRY MORTIMER, K.C.I.E., C.S.I. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1873; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, March, 1873; on famine duty, Nov., 1873;
from June, 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed officiating 1st assistant to the governor-general's agent, Rajputana, July, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, foreign department, Nov., 1877; political assistant, 1st class, Dec., 1877; political secretary to major-general Sir F. Roberts with the Kabul field force, Sept., 1879 (medal and two clasps for Afghan campaign); under secretary, government of India, foreign department, March, 1880; C.S.I., Feb., 1881; officiating private secretary to the Viceroy, June, 1880; secretary to government of India, foreign department, Feb., 1885; is secretary of the orders of the Star of India, and of the Indian Empire; published a life of Sir H. Durand, 1883; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

DURRANT, WILLIAM S., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Whitgift, and Lycée St. Omer; junior clerk, India office, 18th Sept., 1879.

DUTHOIT, WILLIAM, D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1857; served from Sept., 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed deputy superintendent, family domains, Mahárája of Benares, May, 1862; officiating inspector-general of registration and commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1875; magistrate and collector, Shahjahanpur, April, 1877; on special duty under the government of India, financial department, Dec., 1879; on special duty under the orders of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1881; officiating puisne judge, high court, June, 1881; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Aug., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Oudh, May, 1882; employed on the opium commission, under government of Bengal, March to Oct., 1883; judicial commissioner of Oudh, March, 1884; retired, Aug., 1886.

DYSON, JOHN, Oudh Commission.—Joined the service, 8th June, 1858, as deputy magistrate and deputy collector in Bengal; from Dec., 1861, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate of Lucknow, Sept., 1866; also officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, Aug.–Oct., 1867; small cause court judge, Lucknow, 1869; on special duty on committee for compiling the laws and regulations in force in Oudh previous to 1861, Jan., 1870; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sitapur, April, 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1886; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, Sept., 1886.

EADES, F. T., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

EALES, CHARLES LINDSTEDT MODELLIER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating cantonment magistrate, Fyzabad, March-Aug., 1885; joint magistrate, Nov., 1887.

EALES, HERBERT LOVELY, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1879; served in British Burma as assistant commissioner; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1888; deputy commissioner, May, 1888.

EARLE, ARCHDALE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; officiating private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb., 1886.

EAST, WILLIAM ALBERT, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 26th Nov., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar, and deputy registrar and sealer of the high court, assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; superintendent of Panchgani, Nov., 1876; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Dhárwár, June, 1881; senior collector, June, 1885.

EASTWICK, WILLIAM J.—Educated at Winchester College; arrived in India, June, 1827, and was posted as ensign to the 12th Regiment, N.I., Bombay; served with the field force in the Southern Mahárrata Country, and was appointed quarter-master and interpreter, and subsequently adjutant to his regiment; from 1838 served in the political department as first assistant to the resident in Scinde; in 1839 accompanied Sir John Keane's force as political agent to Shikarpore, and was subsequently in political charge of Upper Scinde to superintend the base of operations, and the provision of transport and supplies; acted for a short time as resident at Hyderabad; resigned the Indian service as brevet captain in 1843; in June, 1847, was elected to a seat in the East India Direction, and in 1858 was nominated deputy chairman; on the transfer of the government of India to the Crown in 1858, was appointed to the council of India; resigned in 1868.

EBDEN, EDWARD JAMES, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen Elizabeth's School, Ipswich, and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1872, served in the forest department as acting deputy conservator in the Kanara district; employed on famine duty, Dharwar, April, 1877, and in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to July, 1878; from July, 1878, served as assistant collector, railway magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, Aug., 1881; acting junior collector, magistrate, June, 1882; acting senior collector, Aug., 1887.

EDGAR, JOHN WARE, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, and Feb., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, July, 1863; served in Cachar from Dec., 1863, as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; on special duty with the Lushai expeditionary force, Oct., 1871; officiating junior secretary to the government of Bengal, June, 1872; magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Feb., 1878; officiated as commissioner in various divisions in Bengal, 1880–83; 1st grade magis-
trate and collector, Nov., 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointment departments, Sept., 1884, and subsequently in the financial department, May, 1885; commissioner of Chittagong, Dec., 1885; chief secretary to government of Bengal, Aug., 1887.

EDGE, Sir John, Knt., Q.C., B.A., LL.B., Trinity College, Dublin. Called to the bar, Middle Temple, 1866; Q.C., 1886; went the northern and north-eastern circuit, and was appointed chief justice, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1886; vice-chancellor, Allahabad University, Nov., 1887.

EDGELL, W., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; writer, India office, 31st July, 1869; temporarily employed as shipping inspector of railway stores, Jan., 1872; receiver of wharf stores, Jan., 1873; supervisor, and grade, March, 1877; 1st grade, June, 1886.

EDGERLEY, STEYNING WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and officiating cantonment magistrate; from May, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, and acting Sindi translator to government; and assistant collector in Sind, 1885 and 1886.

EDIS, FREDERICK, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India Office, 29th July, 1872; clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, March, 1877.

EDMONSTONE-MONTGOMERIE, CHARLES Waterton, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Copenhagen and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1887, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

EDWARDS, HERBERT, India Office Stores Department.—2nd class clerk, March, 1887.

EDWARDS, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1837; assistant commissioner, Cuttack, 1838; assistant registrar, Sudder court, Calcutta, 1839; deputy secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1840; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, 1842, and assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces in all departments, and in attendance on the governor-general; under secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1843, and attended the governor-general in his tour to the N.W. Provinces; superintendent of the Hill states, and magistrate and collector, Simla, 1848; civil and sessions judge, Futtehpore, 1848; judge, Sudder Dewanny and Nizamat Adawlat, N.W. Provinces 1862; judge, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1866; retired 1867; author of a book of Indian treaties (reprinted by order of the House of Lords, 1853), and of several other works relating to India.

EGERTON, Sir Robert Eyles, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and Exeter College, Oxford, and appointed to the Bengal civil service from the East India College, Haileybury, in 1850; served in the Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to the charge of the settlement of the Lahore district, 1854-58; deputy commissioner, 1856; officiating commissioner, Lahore, 1863; additional commissioner, Peshawur, Nov., 1863, to Feb., 1864; commissioner, Nagpur, Central Provinces, March, 1864; officiated as judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, at various times from 1865 to 1867; financial commissioner of the Punjab, March, 1868; additional member, governor-general's council, July, 1871, and again in 1872 and 1877; lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, April, 1877, to April, 1882, when he resigned the service.

ELIAS, NEY, Political Department.—Extra attaché, foreign department, March-Sept., 1874; second in command, Yunnan expedition, and assistant to resident in Mandalay, Sept., 1874, to May, 1875; officiating political agent, Bhamo, April-Aug., 1875, in addition to other duties; extra attaché, foreign department, Oct., 1875; from Oct., 1877, has served as joint commissioner of Ladakh; political assistant, 1st class (super-numerary), June, 1879; on special duty to Yarkand, June-Aug., 1879; on special duty to Kashgar, March-Aug., 1880; political agent with the Kashgar Mission, May, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, March, 1886.
