INCH, G. F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 9th Oct., 1879.

INGLIS, JOHN FORBES DAVID, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed junior under-secretary to the government of India, foreign department, in 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847; deputy commissioner in the Punjab, 1849; magistrate and collector of Bareilly, 1858; judge of Moradabad, 1862; commissioner of Rohilkund 1864; member of board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, 1867; additional member of governor-general's council, 1870, and was reappointed in 1873 and 1875; temporarily finance member of governor-general's council, April to Dec., 1874; officiating chief commissioner of Oudh, March-Nov., 1875, and again in July, 1876; retired, Feb., 1877.

INGLIS, THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

INNES, JAMES JOHN McLEOD, Lieutenant-General, V.C., R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—First commission in Bengal.
engineers, 1848; served under the civil engineer, Punjab, from 1852; assistant engineer, Bari Doab canal, 1854; assistant chief engineer, Oudh, Jan., 1857; during the mutiny served at the defence of Lucknow, the battle of Cawnpore, the action of Sultanpur, and the siege of Lucknow (medal and two clasps, V.C.); executive engineer, Cawnpore, Dec., 1857; garrison engineer, Presidency, April, 1858; controller and examiner of accounts, Lahore, Feb., 1861; officiating accountant-general, public works department, 1865-66, and again 1867-68; on special duty on Bank of Bombay committee, 1868-69; supervising engineer, Punjab, Oct., 1869; accountant-general and deputy secretary, public works department, June, 1870; chief engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1881, and deputy inspector-general, military works; inspector-general of military works, 1882; retired, 1886.

INNES, LEWIS CHARLES, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1844; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts till Jan., 1855, and afterwards in the judicial department, and was appointed sub-judge of Combaconum, Feb., 1856, and civil and sessions judge of Nundial, July, 1858; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, Feb., 1865, to Sept., 1883, and officiated on several occasions as chief justice; fellow of the University of Madras, 1865 to 1883; and was on the syndicate, 1873-83; vice-chancellor of the university, 1874 to 1880.

IRELAND, WILLIAM DE COURCY, B.A., LL.D., Burma Commission.—Joined the service as accountant in office of commissioner of Pegu, April, 1859; assistant superintendent of forests, Toungoo, April, 1860; collector of customs, Nov., 1860; from April, 1861, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, town magistrate, and deputy commissioner (1st grade, June, 1879); on special duty, Aug., 1878; acted as inspector-general of police in 1875, 1881-1883, and 1885, and as commissioner of Arakan, June-Sept., 1880; boundary officer, Akyab district, Sept., 1880; additional sessions judge, Tenasserim, Jan., 1886; commissioner Irrawaddy division, July, 1886.

IRVINE, GEORGE DUNCAN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs at Madras and protector of emigrants, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Kurnool, July, 1882, and afterwards in Trichinopoly.

IRVINE, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Anne's School, Brixton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty under the board of revenue, Jan. to April, 1879; magistrate and collector, and grade, Ghazipur, Dec., 1881; 1st grade, July, 1885; retired, 1888; author of 'Canal Rates versus Land Revenue,' 'The Rent Digest: or the Law Procedure relating to Landlord and Tenant, Bengal,' 'Bangash Nawabs of Farukhabad,' and settlement report of Ghazipur district.

IRVING, L. A., Surgeon-Major, Army Medical Department.—Medical officer on the personal staff of the governor of Bombay (Rt. Hon. D. J. M. Lord Reay, LL.D., C.I.E.), 31st March, 1885.

IRWIN, ALFRED MACDONALD BULTEEL, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab till June, 1877, and subsequently in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1886.

IRWIN, GEORGE ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Uppingham, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, and officiating city magistrate, Lucknow; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, Dec., 1886; officiating junior secretary, Nov., 1887, and May, 1888.

IRWIN, HENRY CROSSLY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School, St. Edmund's Hall, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Oct., 1886; author of 'The Garden of India, or Chapters on Oudh History and Affairs.'

ISAACSON, S. H. H., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 15th April, 1869; clerk, and class, Sept., 1878.

ISMAY, STANLEY (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1871; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting inspector of schools, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the Kalahandi state, Jan., 1882; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, May, 1884; officiating inspector-general of police and jails, May to Nov., 1885; deputy commissioner, May, 1888.

IZAT, ALEXANDER, M.I.C.E. Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Hyderabad; executive engineer, March, 1868; transferred to railway branch, 1870, as executive engineer, Nizam's state railway; Holkar state railway, Oct., 1874; transferred to Dhoond and Marimad railway, Bombay, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Kathiawar state railways, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Bombay Eastern Deccan state railway, Aug., 1879; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1880; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Jan., 1883; services lent to Bengal and N.W. Railway company as agent and chief engineer, Feb., 1883; 1st superintending engineer, Feb., 1887.
JACKSON, ARTHUR MASON TIPPETTS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Westminster School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885.

JACKSON, CHARLES JULIAN, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., late Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1855; served in Bengal from Sept., 1859, as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon at various stations; also officiated as sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1872; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, with medical charge of Alipore and Russa jails, and medical inspector of emigrants, Feb., 1883; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail and lunatic asylum, Moorshe-dabad, 1885; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; brigade surgeon, Jan., 1881; retired, April, 1887.

JACKSON, FREEMAN HENRY, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay Infantry, 1861; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1862; from Jan., 1867, acted in charge of office of assistant resident, Amreli, and was appointed to settle boundaries in Eastern Káthiáwar, Jan., 1868; acting assistant-resident, Dwárka, and commandant of H.H. the Gáekwár's battalion, March, 1869; assistant resident, Baroda, in charge Okhámandal, July, 1874; on special duty, Baroda, Jan., 1875; treasury officer, Baroda Residency, Feb., 1875; acting cantonment magistrate, Baroda, April, 1875; extra assistant general superintendent, thuggee and dacoity department, June, 1875; from May, 1876, served as assistant agent to the governor-general, Baroda, and from Feb., 1879, as superintendent of the Gáekwár's contingent, Káthiáwar, assistant in charge of Amreli Maháls, and superintendent for the improvement of the breed of horses in Káthiáwar.

JACKSON, SIR LOUIS S., Knight, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Castleknock, Waterford, and Enniskillen (Royal) Schools; matriculated at Trinity College, Dublin, 1839 (exhibitioner); appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1843; arrived in India, 23rd July, 1843; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; from 1847 to 1850, was employed in the Straits Settlements as under governor, Prince of Wales' Island, and officiated as superintendent of Province Wellesley, 1847-48; assistant resident and superintendent of police, Singapore, and chairman of municipal commissioners, 1848; acting collector of stamps and abkari revenue, Calcutta, 1850; magistrate of Patna, 1852; collector of Moorshedabad, 1856; civil and sessions judge, Rajshahye, 1859, and Nuddea, 1861; officiating judge of the Sudder court, May, 1862; judge of the high court, Calcutta, July, 1862 (in the English department); officiating chief justice, Aug., 1868; retired, June, 1880.

JACKSON, WILLIAM GRIERSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Feb., 1877, to Jan., 1880, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, 4th grade; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1882; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1887; also officiated as magistrate and collector and as district and sessions judge; author of Mirzapur volume of N.W. Provinces' Gazetteer.

JACOB, GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; in charge of forest settlement and demarcation officer's office, Khandesh, Oct., 1881, to Feb., 1882; from May, 1883, served as assistant judge and sessions judge, and also from Dec., 1884, to Oct., 1885, as assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; from March, 1886, served as senior assistant judge, and from Nov., 1886, as joint judge and sessions judge; acting registrar, high court, appellate side, Feb., 1888.

JACOB, HERBERT BRUCE, Colonel, Bo. S.C., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Dec., 1857; served from 26th June, 1869, in the educational department, Central Provinces, and was appointed inspector of schools, 3rd grade, April, 1871; acting inspector-general of education, 1882-84.

JACOB, STEPHEN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating registrar in the judicial commissioner's court, and officiating deputy commissioner, till Dec., 1878, when he was transferred to Bengal; on special duty, legislative department, government of India, April, 1879, and again in March, 1880; officiated as under secretary and as assistant secretary in department of finance and commerce, government of India, in 1880 and 1881; assistant comptroller-general, in class III. of the financial department, Nov., 1880; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1881, and in 1882; on special duty with the government of India in department of finance and commerce, Jan. and Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, June, 1882; under secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, July, 1882; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, July, 1883; deputy auditor-general, Dec., 1884; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oude, Feb., 1885; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1885; secretary to the finance committee, March, 1886; on special duty, financial department, Feb., 1888; accountant-general, class I., and commissioner of the department of state paper currency, Bombay, May, 1888.

JAMES, HENRY EVAN MURCHISON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Cathedral School, Carlisle, and Durham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and as acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind; from May, 1873, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1875; also acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, from Nov., 1875; and grade, postmaster-general, Bengal, March, 1882; acted as director-general of the post office in India;
JAMES, STEPHEN HARVEY, M.R.A.S., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Probus Grammar School, and Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1875, and officiated as secretary, 1877; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, and officiating junior secretary, Aug., 1877; on special duty under the orders of the high court, Feb., 1881, and under the orders of the local government in 1882-83; registrar, high court, May, 1881; legal remembrancer, N.W. Provinces, May, 1884; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March, 1885; officiating secretary to the government of India, legislative department, Dec., 1885; confirmed as secretary, Sept., 1887.

JAMESON, ROBERT, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Sanitary Department, N.W. Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service as assistant surgeon, Oct., 1865, arrived in India, 11th April, 1866, and was employed on civil and military duty; in 1868, was in medical charge at Calcutta of troops and coolies, en route to Abyssinia; served in Abyssinia with 14th Bengal cavalry; served in Bombay and Punjab, 1868 and 1869, and in the N.W. Provinces from 1870 on civil and jail duty; deputy sanitary commissioner, Nov., 1886.

JAMESON, THOMAS DUNCAN, Burma Police.—Served as inspector and assistant district superintendent from 1st Nov., 1865; district superintendent, 1875; on special duty with Karem boundary commission, Dec., 1875-March, 1876; special superintendent for the suppression of dacoity, Jan., 1883; inspector-general of police, Lower Burma, Aug., 1887.

JAQUET, ROBERT G., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 11th May, 1877.

JARDINE, JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 30th October, 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, June, 1869 to May, 1871; from May, 1871, to Oct., 1873, served in Kathiawar as political assistant, and was in charge of the agency in Sept., Oct., and Dec., 1871; also appointed judicial assistant in Kathiawar, June, 1873; acting registrar of the high court, Bombay, Oct., 1873; secretary to the Baroda commission for the trial of the Gaekwar, Feb.-May, 1875; acting judge and sessions judge at Ratnagiri, Tanna, and Khan-deish, Oct., 1875, to Feb., 1877; secretary to the delegates of the government of India in the negotiations for a commercial treaty with Portugal, March to Sept., 1877, also acting as deputy secretary to government of India, legislative department, April, 1877; acting secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Nov., 1877, to Jan., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served in British Burma as judicial commissioner, and also presided in court of recorder of Rangoon Oct.-Nov., 1881; president of the educational reformatory committee, Nov., 1881; acting chief secretary to government of Bombay, Oct., 1885; judge of the High Court, Bombay, Nov., 1885; author of 'Notes on Buddhist Law'; editor of Moung Tet Pyo's Customary Law of the Chin Tribe, also of a reprint of Dr. Tandy's translation of Father Sangermano's description of the Burman Empire, and a compilation of printed judgments of the judicial commissioner of British Burma; wrote a preface to Dr. Forchhammer's 'King Wagaru's Dhamma-Satham.'

JARDINE, WILLIAM ELLIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886.

JARRETT, HENRY SULLIVAN, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, Dec., 1856, 3rd European Infantry, Bengal; during the mutiny was present at the outbreak at Mooltan, 1858, and was engaged in the pursuit of the mutineers under Brigadier-General Farquharson (medal); also served in the Mahsud Waziri expedition, 1860 (received medal and clasp), and the Eusufzai expedition, 1863 (received clasp); secretary to board of examiners, Fort William, 1871; assistant secretary, legislative department, government of India, from Aug., 1875.

JEFFREYS, WILLIAM, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 8th June, 1854; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1856; served in the irrigation branch, Punjab, from May, 1857, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and officiating superintendent, Western Jumna canal; also officiated as assistant principal, Roorkee College; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1865; temporarily transferred to P.W. secretariat, government of India, Nov., 1864, to April, 1865; transferred to Bengal, and specially deputed to investigate a project of irrigation and navigation for the river Gandak, Oct., 1867, to April, 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1869; officiating assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1869; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; 1st class, Jan., 1880; acting chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, March, 1887; retired, Nov., 1887.

JEHANGIR, K. M. KABRAJI, Bombay C.S.—appointed in India as probationer under native civil service rules, 14th Jan., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1888.

JENKINS, JOHN LEWIS, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bristol Grammar School, and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from June, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector, and acting city magistrate, Karachi; 3rd assistant collector in Sind, June, 1885; manager of encumbered estates in Sind, and educational inspector, September, 1885.

JENKINS, ROBERT GEDOIN, Colonel, M.S.C., Madras Police.—Ensign Madras infantry, Dec., 1856; arrived in India, 8th Feb., 1857; served in the Madras police, from July, 1863, and was pro-
moted to superintendent, 1872; on special duty at Madras, July-Oct., 1874, and in the Godavari District, June-Sept., 1879; acted as assistant inspector-general in 1874 and 1879, and as deputy inspector-general in 1885; 1st grade superintendent, Feb., 1886.

JENKINS, THOMAS LOWTEN LAYTON (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial departments in Bengal, and Assam (in 1882), as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

JENKINS, THOMAS MORRIS, Major, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, March, 1866; arrived at Madras, 16th Sept., 1866, and served with the 2-19th regiment; joined the Madras staff corps, June, 1869; served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner from April, 1874; acted as port officer and collector of customs, Bassein, in July, 1881; settlement officer, 1st grade, Dec., 1884, to June, 1885; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Nov., 1885; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

JENKINSON, SIR EDWARD GEORGE, K.C.B., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow and Haileybury College; appointed to the East India company's service in 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as joint magistrate and deputy collector of Benares, and afterwards of Farukhabad; served through the Indian mutiny, for which he received medal and the thanks of the Queen and the Governor-General; served also as settlement officer, magistrate, and collector; commissioner of revenue in Jhansi, and commissioner in Oudh; retired, 1880; was private secretary to Earl Spencer when lord-lieutenant of Ireland, and assistant under secretary police and crime, 1882-5; C.B. in 1883, and K.C.B., 1888.

JENKYNS, EDWARD S., Accounts Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 25th Feb., 1846; junior clerk, audit department, India office, Sept., 1858; accountant-general's department, 1860; senior clerk, Dec., 1868.

JEROVOSE, ALAN ARTHUR CLARKE, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 23rd March, 1857, and served in various districts of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, political agent and collector of stamp revenue, and acting deputy commissioner of customs and opium; junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1877; senior collector and magistrate, March, 1879; retired, April, 1887.

JOBBINS, W.H.—Superintendent of Government School of Art, and Art Gallery, Calcutta, July, 1887.

JODU NATH ROY, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 13th July, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, Midnapore, June, 1873; judge of the court of small causes at Kooshtea, Chooadanga, and Meherpore, May, 1883; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1883.

JOHNSON, ALLEN B., Lieut.-General, C.B., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; joined the service (infantry), July, 1846; appointed to 4th Sikhs as volunteer for service in Burma; medal and clasp for Pegu; in civil employ in Punjab, 1854; Indian Mutiny in 1858; medal and clasp and brevet for Lucknow; assistant adjutant-general, 1861; military department, Calcutta, 1862; assistant secretary to government of India in the military department, 1875; deputy military secretary, 1876; secretary in the military department, India Office, from 18th Jan., 1877; temporarily employed as military secretary to the government of India, 1879-1881; C.B., 1881.

JOHNSON, Right Rev. EDWARD RALPH, D.D.—Appointed Bishop of Calcutta, 14th Dec., 1876.

JOHNSON, SIR EDWIN BEAUMONT, General, G.C.B., C.I.E., R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, June, 1842; served in the Sutlej campaign, 1845-46, including battles of Ferozeshah and Sobroa (medal and clasp), and in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and in pursuit of the Sikhs and Afghans (medal and two clasps); deputy judge advocate-general, Sirhind division, April, 1849; served in the Indian mutiny (medal and two clasps), and was assistant adjutant-general of artillery, Jan., 1856-63; assistant military secretary, Horse Guards, 1865-72; quartermaster-general, Bengal, July, 1873; adjutant-general, March, 1874; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1st Sept., 1874, to Feb., 1877; military member of council of governor-general of India, March, 1877-80; director-general of military education, War Office, Dec., 1884.

JOHNSON, EVANS CHARLES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Jan., 1868, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), acting sub-collector, and acting district and sessions judge; on special duty, Rumpa disturbances, 1870-80; sub-collector and joint magistrate, South Arcot, Jan., 1883; from Feb., 1883, acted as principal assistant in Vizagapatam, and as collector, magistrate, and agent in the same district, and afterwards in Kurnool; acting district and sessions judge, Vizagapatam, May, 1884, to April, 1885; collector and magistrate, Kurnool, May, 1886; district and sessions judge, Gangam, Oct., 1886.

JOHNSON, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1882.

JOHNSTON, CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at High School, Dublin, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

JOHNSTON, JOHN LEECH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Rathoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Akalkot, acting collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; and grade judge and sessions judge, Kanara, Jan., 1884; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Thana, Feb., 1886.

JOHNSTONE, DONALD CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877;
arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; served under the government of Bombay from May, 1882, as assistant collector and magistrate, to Feb., 1884, when he was re-transferred to Punjab; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Oct., 1887.

JOHNSTONE, FREDERICK JOHN, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Assam.—Served in the public works department, Central Provinces, from July, 1861, and was appointed executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; assistant to the chief engineer, Aug., 1873; officiating controller of public works accounts, April to Nov., 1875; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; promoted to superintending engineer, Nov., 1880; posted to British Burma, Jan., 1881; transferred to Assam as superintending engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department, Jan., 1884; 1st class superintending engineer, March, 1886; 3rd chief engineer, June, 1888.

JOHNSTONE, HUGH, Surgeon-Major, A.M., M.D., Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical service, 30th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, 2nd May, 1868, and served in Calcutta at the General Hospital and as house surgeon at the Medical College Hospital; in medical charge of the British residency, Mandalay, Upper Burma, July, 1869; civil surgeon of Akyab, March, 1877; from April, 1878, officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, and was appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, April, 1880; also port health officer and in charge of the lock hospital and meteorological observatory.

JOHNSTONE, SIR JAMES, Colonel, K.C.S.I., Assam Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, 1858; assistant superintendent of police, 1864; in charge of Keddahs in the Gurjat Mehal of Cuttack, 1868-74; assistant commissioner in Assam, 1874; political agent, Manipur, 1877; deputy commissioner, and grade, March, 1884; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887.

JOHNSTONE, JAMES WILLIAM HOPE, Colonel, B.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1853; from March, 1858, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; officiated as commissioner and superintendent, Peshawur, in 1880 and 1883, also in the Jullundur division, Sept., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Rawal Pindi, Feb., 1881; civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, Sept., 1881; 1st grade divisional judge, Nov., 1884; retired, Feb., 1886.

JOLLIFFE, E. W., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, and April, 1885.

JONES, H. H., India Office, Stores Department.—2nd class clerk Store Depot, July, 1888.

JONES, THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Department.—Assistant secretary, government of Bengal, 7th April, 1866; clerk and officiating 5th judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1873; registrar and chief ministerial officer of the court, June, 1882; officiated as 4th judge from March, 1883, and was confirmed in this appointment, Oct., 1884.

JONES, WILLIAM BRITTAIN, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 15th Sept., 1856; from March, 1857, to April, 1865, served in the N.W. Provinces, and Punjab, as assistant magistrate and assistant commissioner; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner, acting superintendent of cotton affairs, secretary to the chief commissioner, and acting commissioner in the Jubbulpore, Nerbudda, and Nagpore divisions; on special duty as commissioner for drawing up land revenue and tenancy bills for Central Provinces, Sept., 1874; on special duty in the home department, Calcutta, Nov., 1876, also in April, 1877, and at Simla, May, 1877; commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; resident, Hyderabad, June, 1882; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1st May, 1883; retired, 27th Jan., 1885.

JONES, W. R. S., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Deputy superintendent, Roorkee workshops, Nov., 1867; joined the public works department, Feb., 1873, as executive engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation; transferred to the locomotive department, Rajputana state railways, April, 1879, as deputy locomotive superintendent; carriage and wagon superintendent, Ajmere, in and class of the state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1880; class I., grade 3, revenue scale, Jan., 1886.

JONES—BATEMAN, HERBERT BURLTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1876, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Aug.-Nov., 1883; joint magistrate, Aug., 1886.

JOPP, A. ABERCROMBIE, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and Royal Indian Military College, Addiscombe; entered the Royal Engineers, 19th Dec., 1860; retired Feb., 1879; secretary, office of agent-general for government of New South Wales, London, Feb., 1874, to March, 1879; director-general of stores, India office, April, 1879.

JOPP, CHARLES HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1873; second assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1886; acted as first grade assistant judge, 1886 and 1887.

JOSEPH, HUGH GORE, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; transferred for employment as deputy-commissioner in Burma, Aug., 1886; retransferred to Madras, Oct., 1887, as head assistant to collector and magistrate.

JWALA PRASAD, Pandit, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules.

KAVASJEE JAMASJEE BADSHAH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Elphinstone High School, Bombay University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1879; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and
officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, Oct., 1882; postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1887.

KAYE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Bareilly, April, 1877, officiating civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, March, 1880, and commissioner of the Jhansi division, Dec., 1881; commissioner of the Agra division, July, 1885.

KAY-SHUTTLEWORTH, Rt. Hon. Sir UCHTRED JAMES, Bart., M.P.—Educated at Harrow, and at the London University; sat in the House of Commons as member for Hastings from Oct., 1869, till 1880; served for two years on the London School Board, and was also a member of the royal commission on reformatory and industrial schools; in 1885 was returned for the Clitheroe division of N.E. Lancashire, and was appointed under secretary of state for India in Feb., 1886, and shortly afterwards Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster; in the election of 1886 was returned for N.E. Lancashire; is vice-president of University College, London.

KEATINGE, RICHARD HARTE, Major-General, V.C., C.S.I., R.A., Bombay Staff Corps.—First commission, Bombay artillery, June, 1842; from 1847 was employed in civil duties on the N.W. frontier, and was appointed assistant superintendent, Nimar, Dec., 1851; in the Mutiny of 1857 served in Central India, and was present at the sieges of Dhar and Chandeara, and in the fighting near Mundesore (dangerously wounded, brevet of Major, medal and clasp and V.C.); also took part in pursuit of Tantia Topee, 1858-59; political agent, Nimar, 1860; political agent, Gwalior, and subsequently in Kattywar, 1862; served in Kattywar against the rebel Waghers in 1865; agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, 1868; also ex-officio chief commissioner of Ajmere; chief commissioner of Assam, 1874 to June, 1878.

KEDAR, NATH ROY, M.A., (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—From 1878 served as munshi, and on 23rd May, 1888, was appointed member of the statutory civil service; assistant magistrate and collector, June, 1888.

KEEFER, WILLIAM NAPIER, Surgeon-Major, Indian Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, Bengal Medical Establishment, 1st Oct., 1869; served under the military department up to 1884, when he was appointed senior medical officer, Port Blair and the Nicobars; served in the Looshai campaign, 1871-72 (medal and clasp), the Duffla expedition, 1874-75, the Jowaki campaign, 1877-78 (clasp), the Afghan campaign, 1878-79-80 (medal and clasp), the Zaimusht expedition, 1879, and the Egyptian campaign, 1882 (medal and clasp, Khedive's bronze star, and 4th class, Order of the Osmanieh).

KEEGAN, Dennis Francis, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Indian Medical Service.—Joined the Bengal medical service in 1866; arrived in India 13th Dec., 1866; from Nov., 1868, served with the Central India Horse, and acted as residency surgeon, Indore, 1877-78; served in the Afghan War, 1879-80, in the march from Kabul to, and action at, Kandahar (medal and clasp, bronze star); residency surgeon, Indore, and civil administrative medical officer, Central India, June, 1881.

KEELAN, BERNARD CALLAN, Surgeon-Major, L.K. and Q.C.P., M.R.C.S., L.M.K. and Q.C.P. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations; served in the Abyssinian campaign, and was present at the storming of Magdala (medal); civil surgeon, Sukkur, Jan., 1887; civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, lunatic asylum, and medical school, Hyderabad, April, 1884.

KEENE, HENRY G., C.I.E., M.R.A.S., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1847; arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1847; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; superintendent, Dehra Dun, May, 1856; magistrate and collector, April, 1860; civil and sessions judge April, 1867; officiated as commissioner of the Agra division in 1872 and 1875, and of the Allahabad division in 1874; retired, 1883; fellow of the Calcutta University; member of committee of the Muhamadan College of Aligurh; medal from the zoological society; medal and diploma from the Austrian Exhibition of 1863; author of 'Indian Administration,' 1867; 'History of Hindustan,' 1885; and numerous contributions to the periodical press.

KEESS, JAMES, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., M.R.C.P., and L.M. (London), and M.R.C.S., late Madras Medical Department.—Served in the subordinate medical department as warrant officer from 11th Sept., 1848, to May, 1855; assistant surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; arrived 11th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department up to May, 1862, and subsequently as civil surgeon and superintendent of district jail, Kurnool, and was placed on special duty experimenting on alkaloids in Gudalur and Wynnaad, June, 1866; fort surgeon, Madras, and professor of anatomy and physiology in the Medical College, April, 1867; medical inspector of seamen, Aug., 1868; acting principal medical storekeeper and inspector of emigrants, May, 1869; acting health officer and superintendent, lock hospital, Madras, April, 1880; fellow of Madras University, May, 1882; principal and professor of medicine in the Medical College, and senior physician, General Hospital, Aug., 1883; retired, Jan., 1887; author of 'Syllabus of Medicine for use of Medical Students,' 'Notes on Zoology and Comparative Anatomy,' 'History of the Madras Medical College,' a pamphlet on the 'Prevention of Cholera,' and a 'Calendar of the Medical College.'

KEITH, STANLEY, Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Lancing College; writer, India Office, 6th June, 1873; clerk, and class, April, 1879; attached to financial department.

KEITH, THOMAS W., Accountant-General, India Office.—Educated at Highgate School; East India House writer, old establishment, 20th Aug., 1845; junior clerk, Treasury, 1848; senior clerk, Sept., 1858; accountant-general's department, 1860; accountant, Jan., 1872; asses-
sor of income tax, 1872; accountant-general, Feb., 1879.

KELLAKKA COVILAGOM MANAVEDAN RAJA, B.A., Madras C.S.—Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 4th June, 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1882; acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant, Aug., 1888.

KELLEHER, JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Catholic University of Ireland; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1869; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1882; transferred to Assam as district and sessions judge of Sylhet, March, 1884; services replaced at disposal of government of Bengal, Sept., 1887; district and sessions judge, and grade, Dec., 1887.

KELLEY, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India Office, 9th Oct., 1879.

KELLNER, EDWIN WELSH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department as assistant comptroller-general, 29th April, 1870; served as deputy accountant-general, and, for a short period, as accountant-general, Bengal, 1874-76; deputy comptroller-general, Jan., 1877; assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Aug., 1878; acted as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1883, 1886, and 1887; officiating comptroller and auditor-general, Aug., 1887; officiated as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh in 1887; and Madras, 1888.

KELLY, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, June, 1868; also served as assistant-superintendent of survey, 1863-64, and officiating inspector of schools, 1869; appointed small cause court judge, Bhagulpore, Jan., 1876, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, and grade, Jan., 1879; retired, Jan., 1888.

KELSALL, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; from March, 1865, to Jan., 1867, served as probationary assistant-superintendent of police, and subsequently, in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled the Bellary District Manual; appointed district and sessions judge, Aug., 1880, in the Godavari district, and afterwards in South Malabar and Vizagapatam.

KEMBALL, SIR ARNOLD BURROWES, General, K.C.B., K.C.S.I.—Educated at Addiscombe; lieutenant, Bombay artillery, Dec., 1837; served in the Afghan war, 1838-39, and was present at the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); appointed assistant to the resident at Bushire, Feb., 1842; political resident, Persian Gulf; May, 1852; consul general, Bagdad, and political agent, Turkish Arabia, April, 1855, to 1873; served in the Persian expedition of 1857, and was present at the capture of Mohumrah (medal and clasp, C.B., and brevet of major); during the Russo-Turkish war, 1876-77, was British military attache at the headquarters of the Turkish army.

KEMBALL, CHARLES GURDON, Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1850; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, judicial assistant commissioner (in Sind), and deputy magistrate; collector and magistrate, Karachi, Nov., 1861; served as judge and sessions judge, Surat, from Jan., 1866, to June, 1870, and from the latter date acted as judge of the high court, Bombay, in which appointment he was confirmed in Aug., 1871; acted as member of council, Bombay, in 1880, and again in 1881; retired in 1885.

KEMBLE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 8th April, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Oct., 1873; inspector-general of jails, July, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; officiating opium agent, Benares, April, 1881; opium agent, Behar, May, 1884.

KEMP, FRANCIS BARING, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at foreign schools, and at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1831; served in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Bengal; collector, Tirhoot, 1851; civil and sessions judge, Backergunge and Jessore, 1855 to 1862; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1862 to 1878; retired, 1878.

KENNEDY, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1879; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, March, 1884.

KENNEDY, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty, Madras, July, 1878; transferred to Assam, Nov., 1883, as assistant commissioner, 1st class; deputy commissioner, July, 1886.

KENNEDY, SIR MICHAEL KAVANAGH, General, K.C.S.I., R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—and lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th June, 1841; arrived in India, Nov., 1842; assistant engineer, roads and tanks, June, 1843; executive engineer at Surat, Aden, and Satara, 1848-60; on special duty, Ceylon, Madras, and Calcutta, Oct., 1860, to
KENNEDY, ROBERT MUIRHEAD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1877; and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate, and railway magistrate, Bandra; appointed 2nd assistant collector, April, 1888.

KENNEDY, THOMAS JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, Balliol College, Oxford, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1880, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; transferred to Central Provinces, Oct., 1885; settlement officer, Raipur, Oct., 1885; retransferred to the Punjab, and appointed assistant commissioner, Lahore, Nov., 1887; officiating deputy commissioner, Montgomery, Feb., 1888.

KENNEY - HERBERT, ARTHUR ROBERT, Colonel, Madras Cavalry.—Cornet, Sept., 1859; arrived in India, Oct., 31, 1859; served on regimental duty with various cavalry regiments; adjutant, Governor's body guard, Sept., 1865; deputy assistant quarter-master general, 1873-76; major, Sept., 1879; military secretary to the governor of Madras, May, 1881, to April, 1884; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, military department, Dec., 1881; from April, 1884, acted as secretary to the government of Madras, military department, and was confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1885; lieutenant-colonel, September, 1885; colonel and local rank of brigadier-general, March, 1887.

KENSINGTON, ALFRED, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Marlborough, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; on special duty in civil secretariat, Oct., 1882; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1882; promoted to settlement officer, April, 1884; officiating deputy commissioner, Umballa, in addition to his own duties, Feb., 1887.

KERNAN, JAMES, M.A., Q.C., Judicial Department, Madras.—Judge of the high court, Madras, 3rd May, 1870; fellow of the Madras University, Feb., 1871; vice-chancellor of the Madras University, June, 1885; officiating chief justice, July to Nov., 1885.

KERR, T. COULTER, Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Surveyor of shipping, 1st April, 1881.

KETTLEWELL, G., B.A., Inspecting Veterinary Surgeon, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1854; served under the military department till Dec., 1881, when he was appointed principal, Veterinary School, Lahore.

KEYS, ARTHUR INNES, Registry Department, India Office.—Appointed clerk, London office, Indo-European Telegraph Department, 1880; on abolition of that office, services transferred temporarily to India office, 1st Jan., 1889.

KEYSER, ALFRED, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School, and Royal Academy, Gosport; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant-collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Surat, Dec., 1884; senior collector, &c., Thana, April, 1887.

KHARSEDJI MANEKJI KHARSEDJI, KHAN BAHADUR, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th May, 1874, as judge of the court of small causes, Ahmednagar, and subsequently at Ahmedabad; appointed 4th judge, Bombay small cause court, June, 1888.

KHARSEDJI RATANJI BAMANJI, Bombay C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant-collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882; confirmed as member of the Bombay Civil Service, Jan., 1885.

KIERNANDER, CHARLES ROBERT CAMPBELL, Financial Department, Government of India.—Assistant accountant-general, British Burma, 5th Aug., 1864; officiating deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, April, 1870; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1870; from Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1876, served as deputy accountant-general in the Punjab, and subsequently in Bombay, N.W. Provinces, British Burma, and Bengal; officiated as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1878 and 1879; inspector of local offices of account, Oct., 1878; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, Nov., 1884, to Jan., 1885; deputy auditor-general, Jan., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, April, 1885; officiating deputy comptroller-general, 1886, and in 1887 and 1888.

KILBY, G. C. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Service.—Deputy superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 28th Feb., 1876.

KILBY, SANDFORD JAMES, Bengal Preventive Service.—Assistant collector of customs, Chittagong, 30th June, 1865; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1866; from Aug., 1868, to Dec., 1876, served in the police department, and was appointed assistant superintendent, 1st grade, May, 1874; on famine relief duty, Dec., 1873, and March, 1876; on special duty in Chumparum, April, 1874; from Dec., 1876, served in the customs' preventive service, and was appointed superintendent, Jan., 1877; also in charge of the Sulkea salt gahas, April, 1880; served in Madras, Sept.-Nov., 1885, as deputy commissioner, abkari and salt department.

KIMBERLEY (EARL OF), RIGHT HON. JOHN WODEHOUSE, K.G.—Born Jan. 7, 1826; educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1847, with 1st class in classics; succeeded to title of Baron Wodehouse, May, 1846; under secretary of state for foreign affairs, Dec., 1852, to 1856; ambassador at St. Petersburg, 1856-58; under secretary for foreign affairs, June, 1859, to Aug., 1861; on a special mission to the North of Europe, in connection with the Schleswig-Holstein question, 1863; under secretary of state for India, April-Nov., 1864; Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, Nov., 1864, to July, 1866;
raised to earldom of Kimberley, May, 1866; elected governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, April, 1868; lord privy seal, Dec., 1868, to July, 1870; secretary of state for the colonies from July, 1870, to Feb., 1874; member of the royal commission to inquire into the working of the Penal Servitude Acts, Feb., 1878; secretary of state for the colonies, May, 1880; held provisionally the office of chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, on Mr. Bright's resignation, June, 1882; secretary of state for India, Dec., 1882, to June, 1885, and again Feb. to Aug., 1886; was a royal commissioner for the exhibition of 1886; has been a member of the senate of the University of London since 1859, and was for some time president of University College, London (resigned, 1887).

KINCAID, WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Madras Army, March, 1840; appointed to adjust boundaries disputes, Bhopal agency, March, 1864; assistant political agent, Bundelcund, small cause court judge and cantonment magistrate, Nowgong, 1866; second in command, Malwa Bheel corps, Nov., 1870; political agent, Bhopal, Aug., 1876; political agent, Bhopawur, and commandant, Malwa Bheel corps, Oct., 1879, political agent, Bhopal, June, 1881.

KINDERSLEY, JOHN ROBERT, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1847; served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector till 1857, when he was appointed assistant judge of Mangalore; subordinate judge, Bellary, 1859; civil and sessions judge, Rajahmundry, March, 1865, and subsequently at Bellary; officiating judicial commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1866, and again 1868; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, June, 1877; retired in 1884.

KING, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1865; house surgeon, Medical College Hospital, from 9th May to 25th Aug., 1866, when his services were placed at disposal of government of India, military department; superintendent of Royal Botanical Gardens, ex-officio professor of botany in Calcutta Medical College, and ex-officio superintendent of cinchona plantation in British Sikkim, from July, 1871; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; also officiating quinologist, Dec., 1879; author of 'Manual of Cinchona Cultivation in India.'

KING, JOSHUA, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 26th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant judge and session judge; in charge of the small cause court, Ahmedabad, April-May, 1864; acting under secretary to Government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1866; acting collector and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bombay, July, 1869, to Jan., 1870; talukdari settlement officer, Dec., 1874, to Feb., 1876, and again, Feb., 1876, to Nov., 1877; for carrying Bombay Act VI of 1862 into effect, and manager under Act XV of 1871; on special duty, Baroda, Nov., 1877, to June, 1879; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, May, 1879; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, May, 1884; retired, 1886.

KING, LUCAS BLACKER BURNET, M.A. (Barister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 11th Oct., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the Bengal revenue, survey, and judicial departments, and was appointed superintendent of survey, Aug., 1866, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1880; retired, Aug., 1885.

KING, LUCAS WHITE, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Ennis College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Sept., 1882; revenue officer, Swat River Canal, Feb.-May, 1885; transferred to foreign department as officiating political agent, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, June, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, sub-pro-tem., Oct., 1885; boundary settlement officer Meywar Tonk border, Feb., 1887; also in charge of the Dewas State.

KING, WILLIAM, D.Sc., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined the service, 4th March, 1857; served in various districts of the Madras presidency, and was appointed deputy superintendent for Madras, Nov., 1868; served subsequently in the Godavari district and the Nizam's territories, and discovered the Singareni coal-field, 1871-72; deputed to Vienna in joint charge of the survey collections at the Exhibition, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1875; fellow of the Madras University and member of the Faculty of Engineering, 1884; officiated as superintendent of the geological survey, May-Nov., 1884; designation changed to superintendent of survey; appointed director, April, 1887; author of contributions to the survey publications.

KIPLING, JOHN LOCKWOOD, C.I.E., Education Department, Punjab.—Joined the government service as architectural sculptor, Bombay, May, 1865; from April, 1875, served in the Punjab as principal of Mayo School of Industrial Art, and curator, Lahore Museum.

KIRKHAM, T. B., Barrister-at-Law, Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational department, 1st Jan., 1862; arrived in India, 21st June, 1862, and served as headmaster of the Poona High School, principal of the Elphinstone High School, Bombay, and professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College; was also a member of the first municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug., 1873; from April, 1878, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, April, 1885; on special duty in England in connection with technical education, Nov., 1886.

KIRKWOOD, TOWNSEND MOLLOY, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, and Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1876, and district and sessions judge, and grade, March, 1880; served temporarily under the public works department, Oct., 1869, to Oct., 1871, and was employed on famine duty.
Bhagulpore, March, 1874; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, April, 1886; retired, 1888.

KISCH, HERMANN MICHAEL, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Nov., 1873; on famine duty, Patna, March, 1874, and at Bellary, Feb., 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, May, 1878; under secretary, judicial and political departments, Jan., 1880; officiating secretary in the financial department, June, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Dec., 1883; postmaster-general, Bengal, Nov., 1885; postmaster-general, 1st grade, April, 1888.

KITTS, EUSTACE JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Berar, Aug., 1875, and served as assistant commissioner and also as small cause court judge of Akola; on special (famine) duty in Madras, 1877-78; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, May to Nov., 1883; from April, 1884, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed joint magistrate, and grade, May, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1887; also officiated as district and sessions judge.

KNIGHT, RAYMONT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's College, Stony Stratford, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector, April, 1885.

KNOWLYS, HENRY BOLD, Berar Commission.—Served as a writer in the Ceylon civil service, 15th Feb., 1859, to Aug., 1866; from Sept., 1866, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1873; deputy commissioner, May, 1886.

KNOX, GEORGE, Punjab Administration.—Assistant engineer, May, 1854; from June, 1856, served in the Punjab commission, and was appointed personal assistant to commissioner of Jullundur, April, 1864, assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1864, and deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1877; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Rawal Pindi, Nov., 1878, to April, 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

KNOX, GEORGE EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from June, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from March, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed small cause court judge, Allahabad, Aug., 1877; judge, 3rd grade, March, 1884; officiating legal remembrancer, Feb., 1885; member of the lieutenant-governor's council for making laws and regulations; district and sessions judge, and grade, continuing to be legal remembrancer; author of a 'Digest of the Criminal Law of the Bengal Presidency,' a 'Digest of Civil Procedure,' 'The Legal Remembrancer, 1879-82,' and 'Treatise upon the Indian Stamp Law.'

KNOX, HUBERT THOMAS, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, acting principal assistant, joint sessions judge for trying Rumpa cases, and assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); acted as district and sessions judge, Ganjam, April-Sept., 1884, and afterwards in North Arcot; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Malabar, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, Nov., 1887.

KNYVETT, WILLIAM LEYCESTER NATHANIEL, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th June, 1854; served in the Bengal police department from June, 1863, as district superintendent (1st grade, April, 1875); officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, July, 1875; deputy inspector-general, April, 1885.

KOUGH, CHARLES, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1867, and served in various districts of Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, head assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; forest settlement officer, March, 1884; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate in the districts of Madura, Cuddapah, and North Arcot; collector and magistrate, Kurnool, Nov., 1887.

KRISHNA CHUNDER CHATTERJEE, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 10th Dec., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, May, 1877; small cause court judge, Backergunge, Dec., 1877; subordinate judge, 1st grade, May, 1884.

KRISHNA MOHUN MOOKERJI, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, from 28th March, 1865, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, Dec., 1884.

KUNWAR BHARAT SINGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

KUNWAR JWÁLA PRASÁD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1884; probationary assistant magistrate, Gorakhpur; confirmed as assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1887.

LAFFAN, EDWARD SIDNEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimbledon School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, 1877-78; from June, 1882, served in the Madras secretariat, and was appointed assistant secretary in judicial and legislative departments, July, 1884; has also acted for various periods as under-secretary and as secretary in the revenue department, and as
under-secretary in the chief secretary's departments; on special duty, preparing Madras administration report, Nov., 1882; Canarese translator to government, Sept., 1885; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1885, to March, 1886; acting secretary, board of revenue, Nov.-Dec., 1885; under secretary to government in the departments under the chief secretary, Sept., 1888.

LAING, JAMES ANDERSON, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1870, and served in the Madras medical department as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acting resident surgeon at the General Hospital, Madras; deputy sanitary commissioner and inspector of vaccination, Feb., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; officiating sanitary commissioner, April, 1886; confirmed in appointment, June, 1888.

LAKSHMAN GOPAL DESHMUKH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, 16th April, 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

LAL BEHARI DE, Rev., Bengal Education Department.—Served from 3rd Sept., 1867, first as head master, and afterwards as assistant professor, in the Berhampore College; assistant professor in the Hooghly College, Jan., 1872; 3rd class of the education department, May, 1885; author of 'Govinda Samanta, or Bengal Peasant Life,' 'Folk Tales of Bengal,' 'Recollections of Alexander Duff.'

LAMB, RICHARD AMPLETT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Khandeish, March, 1885; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

LAMBE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, and grade, Nov., 1886; magistrate and collector, June, 1887.

LAMBERT, JOHN, C.I.E., Police Department, Bengal.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1863, as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and officiating personal assistant to the inspector-general; on special duty, March, 1872; visitor of the presidency jail, and of the lunatic asylums, July, 1872; deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, Feb., 1874; served under the government of India, foreign department, from March, 1882, to March, 1884, as officiating political resident, 2nd class, and general superintendent of the operations for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity; acted as commissioner, Calcutta, and president of the boiler commission, 1885-86.

LAMBERT, PARRY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—And lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1857; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, 8th Jan., 1858, and served in Oudh, and the Punjab; executive engineer, Dec., 1863; officiating controller of Punjab northern state railway accounts, Sept., 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, May, 1876; examiner, 3rd class, Oct., 1878; transferred to the office of examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1879; transferred to Bombay, as officiating examiner, public works accounts, Dec., 1879; from Dec., 1881, served in the N.W. Provinces as examiner public works accounts, and officiated in Bengal, Feb.-Dec., 1882; examiner, 1st class, May, 1886; transferred to Bombay, May, 1884; and to the Punjab, Sept., 1886.

LANE, CLAYTON TURNER, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Ensign Bengal army, 11th Dec., 1858; from March, 1863, served in the Punjab as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent of police; transferred to Berar police, Sept., 1865; inspector-general of police and jails, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; is also inspector-general of jails, and registration and stamps, and registrar of joint stock companies.

LANE, J. H., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Feb., 1857; superintendent, 1st grade, Bombay, Aug., 1870; officiating deputy director-general, March, 1872, and again Feb.-April, 1886; director of traffic, Feb., 1879; officiating deputy director-general, Feb., 1886.

LANE, J. M., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 22nd Sept., 1862; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Bengal, Oct., 1869; served subsequently in the Malabar Coast and Nagpur divisions; 1st grade superintendent, British Burma, Sept., 1883, and afterwards in Bombay.

LANE, WILGOT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 13th January, 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Aug., 1863 to March, 1866, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Moradabad, Aug., 1877; commissioner, Rae Bareli Division, Sept., 1880, and subsequently of the Agra and Meerut divisions; officiating as member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct.-Dec., 1883.

LANG, ARTHUR MOFFATT, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, N.W.P.—1st commission, June, 1852; arrived in India, July, 1854; assistant engineer, Punjab, Nov., 1855; superintendent, civil buildings, Lahore, Aug., 1856; executive engineer, March, 1857; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, the relief and capture of Lucknow, and various engagements (medal and clasps); assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, April, 1858; assistant secretary, public works department, to chief commissioner, Oudh, July, 1865; principal, Thomason Engineering College, March, 1871, to May, 1877; superintending engineer, 1st grade, deputy inspector-general military works, and secretary, defence committee, Feb., 1879; secretary to agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, public works department, Feb., 1881; chief engineer, and
secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, public works department, Jan., 1883; chief engineer and joint secretary, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1885; chief engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; retired, Nov., 1887.

LANG, GEORGE LUKIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, March, 1858; from Nov., 1858, to Nov., 1866, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; from Nov., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; appointed magistrate and collector, Aligarh, April, 1877, and was subsequently posted to Bulandshahr; officiating district and sessions judge, July-Sept., 1880; has acted for various periods as commissioner in the Agra, Rohilkund, and Fyzabad divisions.

LANG, RICHARD TICKELL MONTGOMERY, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, Mooltan, April, 1877; officiating additional civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, April-Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, March, 1881, and subsequently in the Rawal Pindi Division; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

LANGLEY, EDWARD HARTLEY RAYNSFORD, Brigade-Surgeon, B.A. (Dub.), M.R.C.S. (Lon.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1858; was employed under the military department, and as acting civil surgeon in various stations; served with 5th regiment, N.L.I., in China in 1860-62; appointed presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay, Oct., 1876; also in medical charge of the European General Hospital, May-June, 1882; brigade-surgeon, June, 1884.

LANSDOWNE (Marquess of), Rt. Hon. Henry Charles Keith FitzMaurice, G.M.S.I., G.M.I.E., G.C.M.G., Honorary D.C.L., Oxford.—Born, 1845; educated at Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; succeeded to the marquisate in 1866; a lord of the treasury, 1868 to 1872; under secretary for war, 1872 to 1874; under secretary for India, April to July, 1880; governor-general of Canada, May, 1883; appointed governor-general of India, and assumed office, 10th Dec., 1888; hon. D.C.L., Oxford, 1888.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, and Aug., 1873; retired, 1887.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM REA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 28th Dec., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; officiating commissioner, Orissa division, and superintendent of Tributary Mehals, Cuttack, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Dacca, April, 1885; commissioner, Dacca division, Oct., 1886.

LATHAM, F. L., M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Service, Bombay.—Served as acting remembrancer of legal affairs, 23rd May, 1872, to 1st Jan., 1873; also acted as advocate-general, and as judge of the high court, Bombay, for various periods between 1st Jan., 1880, and 5th March, 1884; advocate-general, Bombay, 6th March, 1884.

LA TOUCHE, CECIL D'URBAN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Ensign, 29th July, 1850; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1850, and served on military duty up to Nov., 1883, and subsequently as cantonment magistrate, Poona.

LA TOUCHE, HENRY CHRISTOPHER DIGGES, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab northern state railway; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, construction division, Nov., 1879; Bundelkund railway surveys, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Jhansi-Manikpur state railway, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Bellary-Kistna and Cuddapah-Nellore railways, March, 1886; lent to Southern Mahratta Railway Company, Jan., 1888.

LATOUCHÉ, JAMES JOHN DIGGES, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, till Dec., 1871, when he was transferred as settlement officer to Ajmere; also served as officiating assistant commissioner of Bewar and officiating deputy commissioner, Ajmere; returned to N.W. Provinces, 1875, and was appointed district superintendent of police, 1st grade, Bulandshahr, Sept., 1875; served subsequently in various districts in officiating appointments as settlement officer, magistrate and collector, and district and sessions judge, and was promoted to joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1882; settlement officer, 1st grade, Gorakhpur, Nov., 1883; from Aug., 1886, served in Burma as commissioner of the Southern division.

LATOUCHÉ, WILLIAM PAGET, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Salt Department, Bombay.—1st commission, Bombay army, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1855; was employed on military duty, and served in the Persian war, 1856, and the mutiny campaign, and was also appointed assistant magistrate, Dec., 1859 and assistant district superintendent of police, Jan., 1865; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, June-Nov., 1867; from Dec., 1867, served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent (1st grade, May, 1882), and also acted as superintendent of the Bombay, Baroda, and C. I. railway company's police, Nov., 1868, to Nov., 1869; on special duty, June, 1879, to Feb., 1880; from Feb., 1883, served as deputy collector of salt revenue.

LAUDERDALE (Earl of), Rt. Hon. FREDERICK HENRY MATTLAND, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, 4th Hussars, Feb., 1861; served in Central India on civil employ from 1869 as boundary officer, and political assistant; and assistant agent, Indore, 1877; 1st assistant agent, Indore, 1878; additional political agent and superintendent, Charkhari, 1880; retired, Jan., 1886.

LAUGHTON, DANIEL WILSON, Major-General,
M.S.C., late Berar Commission.—First commission in the army, Jan., 1854; arrived in Madras, April, 1854; from Jan., 1865, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate; acted as inspector-general of registration, Jan., 1873; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Feb., 1885; retired, May, 1886.

LAURIE, HENRY MONTAGUE, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1887, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

LAURIE, LEWIS KOSSUTH, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1873; from Nov., 1873, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting district superintendent of police; acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1880, to March, 1883, and as small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1881, 1882, and 1887; acting assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, 1883-85; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, July-Oct., 1883; and again, March, 1885; acting director of agriculture, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept.-Oct., 1884; under secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1885; assistant commissioner, and class, Oct., 1887.
