LAW, VICTOR EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, April, 1859; acted as government agent at Chepak, paymaster of Carnatic stipendiaries, and Persian and Hindustani translator to government, July, 1866; attache, foreign department, July, 1872; served in Rajputana as superintendent of railway police, 1872 to 1877; political agent, Jeypoor, 1877, and afterwards in Ulwar, 1877-1883; officiating political agent, Charkhari, 1883; assistant at Sujangarh to governor general's agent in Rajputana, Feb., 1884; agent to governor general with king of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, March, 1884; appointed to the political charge of ex-Amir Muhammad Yakub Khan of Kabul, Aug., 1884; graded as political agent, 3rd class.

LAWRENCE, ALEXANDER JOHN, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1856; served from March, 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1864, served in the Central Provinces as settlement officer of Bhandara; re-attached to N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1869, and served as settlement officer and officiating magistrate and collector; member of the commission under the military department on the Lawrence asylums, June to Nov., 1872; on special duty with the government of India, home department, Dec., 1872; officiating civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, June, 1874; magistrate and collector, Etawah, Oct., 1874, and subsequently of Agra; officiated for various periods as commissioner, Agra division; commissioner of the Allahabad division, April, 1885; C.I.E., May, 1888.

LAWRENCE, EDWARD, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; acted as assistant to the political resident at Aden, March, 1882, and as under-secretary to Government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, April, 1885; compiler of general administration report for 1884-85; acted as assistant judge and sessions judge, and as under-secretary to government, in revenue, financial, and general departments.

LAWRENCE, HENRY JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th February, 1862; from Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, and grade, Nov., 1884, Amritsar; additional divisional judge, Amritsar, Jan., 1885; officiating divisional judge, Jullundur, Jan., 1887.

LAWRENCE, RICHARD CHARLES, Lieutenant-General, C.B., Bengal C.S.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1834; served in the Sutlej campaign in 1846, and was present at the battle of Sobraon (medal); second in command, Loodanah regiment, Dec., 1847; assistant commissioner, Punjab, April, 1849; captain of police, Lahore division, Jan., 1853; served in the Indian mutiny as political officer in charge of the Cashmere contingent, under General Wilson, in 1857, and was present at the assault and capture of Delhi (brevet of major, C.B., medal with clasp); military secretary to lieutenant governor of the Punjab, 1860; deputy commissioner, Simla, April, 1862; resident, Nepaul, 1867 to 1872.

LAWRENCE, WALTER ROPER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 5th December, 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Sept., 1881, to April, 1884, served in Ajmere and Merwara as officiating political assistant and assistant commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; in charge Ajmere treasury and office of registrar of assurances, May, 1882; under-secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1886; under secretary to government of India, revenue department, Sept., 1886.

LAWRIE, EDWARD, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Indian Medical Department.—First commission, Bengal medical service, 1872; surgeon-major, March, 1884; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, April, 1885; is also superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of medical school, and surgeon to the Afzalganj hospital.

LEA, JAMES HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

LEARY, A.S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the Moravian colleges of Fulneck in Yorkshire, and Neuwied on the Rhine; temporary clerk, India Office, 15th Nov., 1860; clerk, and class, Aug., 1878.

LEBRETON, WILLIAM INGLIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined the royal artillery, Dec., 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; joined the public works department, Nov., 1866, and served as ass-
sistant engineer in the Bombay presidency till Nov., 1869, and subsequently as assistant controller and deputy controller of accounts in the Punjab, N.W. Provinces, and Bombay; controller, 3rd class, and examiner of railway accounts, Bombay, Sept., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; from Dec., 1879, served as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, and was promoted to 2nd class, May, 1886; also officiated as examiner of public works accounts, Sept.-Dec., 1883, and port storekeeper, state railways, March-June, 1884; examiner, public works accounts, Bombay, Feb., 1887.

LEE, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Yarmouth Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Oct., 1885; 1st grade, Feb., 1888; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

LEE, J., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Caius School, Cambridge; writer, India Office, 24th Aug., 1868; clerk, and class, Aug., 1878.

LEE, WILLIAM HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1887; and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

LEEDS, ROBERT JAMES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1861; served from Aug., 1862, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1879, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge; retired, April, 1887.

LEEDS, WILLIAM HENRY ARTHUR ST. JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

LEE-WARNER, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in various districts of Madras from April, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting cantonment magistrate; on special duty, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot and Salem, Jan., 1868; boundary arbitrator between the Kalastri Zemindari and Madras district, Sept., 1868; special assistant collector, Madura, for the management of the Rannad estate, Dec., 1872, to March, 1878; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1882; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, May, 1884; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Oct., 1884; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, Dec., 1884.

LEE-WARNER, WILLIAM, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th November, 1869; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1870; officiating director of public instruction, Berar, Feb., 1872; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1872, to Nov., 1874, and Jan.-Dec., 1876; on special duty in the secretariat, Nov., 1874; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and acting secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, Nov., 1874; from Dec., 1876, to Aug., 1878, served in Sind as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, acting educational inspector, and acting commissioner; acting junior collector and magistrate, Satara, March, 1881; on special duty as member of the education commission, Calcutta, 1882; on special duty at the Nira canal, April, 1882; from Jan.-Oct., 1884, acted as junior under secretary to government of India, foreign department, and as private secretary to the president in council of the governor-general (Jan.-Feb.), and was on special duty in the foreign department, March-June, 1884; acting press commissioner, Sept., 1884; acting under secretary to government of India, foreign department, Oct., 1884; first assistant collector and acting director of public instruction, Bombay, March, 1885; on special duty in the Hyderabad State, Nov., 1885; acting political agent, Kolhapur, and Southern Mahratta country, Jan., 1886; also president of the Regency Council, Kolhapur, May, 1886; secretary to government of Bombay, Aug., 1887.

LE FANU, WILLIAM JOSEPH HENRY, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School, Tipperary Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; served in Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Salem district manual; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1885; collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Jan., 1886.

LEGEYT, PHILIP HARRISON, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 27th March, 1851; was employed under the military department, including service with the Persian expeditionary force (medal and clasp); served subsequently with the Gujerat Irregular Horse, and also acted as assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha (April, 1858); from May, 1863, served in the political department as assistant political agent, Káthiáwar and Cutch, and magistrate of the district of Bhávnagar; political agent, Mahi Kántha, 1872-1880; political superintendent, Pálanpur, Sept., 1880; 1st grade, political agent, Feb., 1885.

LEGGATT, EDWARD OWEN EVERY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, and Dec., 1883; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LEITNER, GOTTLIEB WILLIAM, Dr., M.A., Ph.D., LL.D., D.C.L., Barrister-at-Law, late Education Department, Punjab.—Served in education department as principal of the Lahore
College from 12th Nov., 1864, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, Nov., 1880; in July, 1867, was deputed to Kashmir for a philological examination of the Kashmiri and Chilasi dialects; on special duty in connection with the school text-book committee at Simla, May, 1877; attended the congress of Orientalists at Florence, Oct., 1878; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, July, 1879; on special duty with education commission, May, 1882; retired in 1886.

LELY, FREDERIC STYLES PHILPIN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th December, 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting city survey and inquiry officer at Ahmedabad, acting Talukdari settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; in charge of the Sachin state, Oct., 1881; first assistant collector, Surat, Dec., 1884; administrator of the Porbandar State in Kathiawar.

LEMAN, GEORGE DOWNTON, late Madras C.S., appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed principal assistant to the collector and magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Dec., 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Guntur, July, 1867, and afterwards at Tellicherry; acted as collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, in 1868, and again in 1875 and 1881-82, and as Inam commissioner in 1869; from Feb., 1872, to Nov., 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Kistna, and subsequently in Ganjam and Coimbatore; retired, March, 1888.

LE MESSURIER, AUGUSTUS, Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st Commission, Bombay Engineers, Dec., 1856; served in the Indian Mutiny at the sieges of Forts Beyt and Dwarka; joined the Bombay public works department, as assistant engineer, May, 1860; was employed on the Karachi harbour works, on irrigation in Sind, on the Bombay harbour defences, &c.; executive engineer, March, 1863; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, Aug., 1864; served in the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal); deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind, Aug., 1871; acted as consulting engineer, Lahore, April-July, 1875; acted as secretary to the railway transport committee at Delhi, in 1875-76, and to a similar committee at Agra, 1876-77; deputed to Brussels exhibition to report on continental system of transport by railways, Aug., 1876; supervising engineer, May, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, May, 1877, to Nov., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80, (medal and brevet of lieutenant-colonel); engineer-in-chief, Mysore State railway, Nov., 1879; joint secretary to chief commissioner, Mysore, 1880; on special duty reporting on timber-cutting operations in east of France, April, 1880; manager, Mysore State railway, Feb., 1881; consulting engineer to Mysore Government, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, March, 1882; supervising engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Bangalore-Harihara railway; 3rd chief engineer, March, 1887; on special duty, military department, Dec., 1887; officiating consulting engineer, railways, Calcutta, Feb., 1888; and chief engineer, April, 1888.

LE MESURIER, HAVILLAND, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1886; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Assam, Nov., 1886.

LE MESURIER, JOHN, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; second lieutenant, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1855; served in the public works department in Sind from June, 1856, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Nara works and the Rohri canal, Hyderabad; served with the Persian expedition, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); on special duty, Karachi, Jan., 1867; acting superintending engineer for irrigation in Sind, April, 1871, to Dec. 1873, and for various periods between 1875 and 1880; superintendent of works, Western Indus, Karachi, Dec., 1873; superintending engineer, Jan., 1879; officiating chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, June-Aug., 1883; (temporary) chief engineer, 3rd class, and chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government, public works department (irrigation), March, 1884; superintending engineer in Sind, Jan., 1886; retired, March, 1887.

LETHBRIDGE, ALFRED SWAIN, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1867; served from March, 1872, as superintendent of central jail and officiating civil surgeon, Bhagalpore; officiating inspector-general of prisons, sanitary commissioner, and superintendent of vaccination, British Burma, July, 1876; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, May, 1877; inspector-general of jails, Bengal, Jan., 1878; rank of surgeon-major, Sept., 1879.

LETHENEN, S. K., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; clerk, and class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877.

LEUPOLT, JOHN CUNNINGHAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Aug., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Aug., 1882, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge.

LEVINGE, EDWARD VERA, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885.

LEVY, FRANK, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 15th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

LEWIS, E. M.—Superintendent, Bengal secretariat press, April, 1869; superintendent of government printing, Bengal, Sept., 1877.

LEWIS, THOMAS CROMPTON, M.A. (Cambridge), Punjab Educational Service.—Appointed professor government college, Lahore, 18th Oct., 1881; promoted to 3rd grade of graded staff, Feb., 1886; and grade, April, 1886; prin-
cipal of government college, Lahore, 3rd May, 1886.

LIARDET, CHARLES AYLMER, Colonel, M.S.C., late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Oct., 1855; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1855; Madras staff corps, Sept., 1866; served in the Madras revenue survey department from Oct., 1868; on famine relief works, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884; retired, April, 1888.

LIDDERDALE, ROBERT, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; superintendent of vaccination, 8th November, 1869; in medical charge, Jaliporee, in addition to his own duties, June, 1872; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, April, 1880; professor of hygiene, Medical College; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; deputy surgeon-general (local rank), Bengal, Jan., 1884.

LIGHTFOOT, J., Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed from the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi railway as deputy manager, North-Western state railway, Jan., 1886; class I, revenue establishment, state railways, July, 1886; manager, Punjab section, March, 1887; Sind section, May, 1887.

LILLINGSTON, EDWARD GORDON, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 30th Aug., 1859; from 5th Feb., 1864, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1867, officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Feb., 1874, superintendent of the central jail, and the European penitentiary at Hazaribagh, May, 1875, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1886; 1st grade, Aug., 1887.

LIMOND, DAVID, Major-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1850; assistant engineer, public works department, Bengal, Feb., 1853; during the mutiny, served at relief and defence of Lucknow (medal and clasp); executive engineer, Cawnpore, 1858; officiating superintending engineer, Allahabad, April, 1867, and in Bengal, western circle, from March, 1868; transferred to Rawal Pindee, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, military works, Rawal Pindee, April, 1872; in 1879-80 served as commanding engineer, Peshawur Valley field force (medal, C.B.); chief engineer, 3rd class, military works, April, 1881; chief engineer and secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, July, 1884; retired, 1886.

LINCOLN, FREDERICK, Judicial Department, North-Western Provinces.—From Oct., 1846, to March, 1860, served in various capacities in the offices of the commissioner of the cis-Sutlej states, the Punjab board of administration, the judicial commissioners of the Punjab and Oudh, and the secretariat at Allahabad; appointed, for special services during siege of Lucknow, extra assistant commissioner in Oudh, March, 1860; assistant civil judge, Lucknow, Jan., 1865; small cause court judge, Lucknow, March, 1866; civil judge, Lucknow, Aug., 1869; district judge, 3rd grade, Sitapur, Aug., 1879.

LINDSAY, CHARLES ROBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Woolwich, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1844; arrived in India, 1845; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Farakhabad, 1858; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, 1862; extra judge of the Sudder court, Agra, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Mynpoorie, 1865, and subsequently of Goruckpore and Moradabad; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1869; retired, 1880.

LINDSAY, JAMES GAVIN, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—Lieutenant, Madras engineers, Aug., 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Dec., 1857; during the mutiny served at the battle of Banda, (medal and clasp), served subsequently as executive engineer in Banda and Orissa; deputy consulting engineer for railways, 1863; executive engineer, 1st grade, railway survey, Mysore, April, 1870; officiating superintending engineer, and engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal railway, 1872; acted as director of state railways, N.E. system, and joint secretary to Bengal government, Nov., 1878, to March, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Harnai and Gulistan-Karez sections of Kandahar railway, Feb., 1880; served in the Afghan Campaign, 1879-80, (medal); superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Southern Maharatta railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class ( supernumerary), April, 1881; services lent to Southern Maharatta railway company, from May, 1884; engineer-in-chief, Bolan railway, April-June, 1885; 3rd chief engineer, March, 1887; and chief engineer, April, 1888.

LINDSAY, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; junior clerk, India Office, 31st Jan., 1867; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1877-82; senior clerk, Jan., 1882.

LISTER, ALLEN LINDSAY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in the grades of assistant and sub-collector, and was placed on special duty in connection with the relief of the poorer classes, South Arcot, Jan., 1868; on famine duty, Sept. to Dec., 1877; on special duty, Irrigation and Canal Company, Jan., 1878; collector and magistrate, South Canara, July, 1882; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1882, in Vizagapatam, and afterwards in the Godavari district.

LISTON, JOHN, Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 29th May, 1850; served with the Bundelcund field force in the campaign of 1850; from Aug., 1863, served in Jhansi, Kumaon, and Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Lalitpur, Dec., 1879; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, Aug. to Nov., 1882; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1887.

LITTLE, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., M.C., L.R.C.S., L.M., Madras Medical Service.—Arrived in Madras, 1st Nov., 1872, and served under the military department; civil surgeon, Akola, Jan., 1877; sanitary commissioner, inspector-general of dispensaries, superintendent of vaccination, and administrative medical officer of the Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884.

LITTLE, F. A., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Acted as government solicitor and public prosecutor, Bombay, Oct.-Nov., 1879, and May to Nov., 1883, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1884.

LIVESAY, JOHN JAMES, late Bengal C.S.—
Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, and grade, Oct., 1878; employed on famine relief duty, March to Oct., 1874; retired, March, 1888.

LLOYD, ERNEST THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Shrewsbury, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, and Feb., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1882; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1885; and served as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Dec., 1886.

LLOYD, FRANCIS, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the College School, Gloucester; appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and session judge; judicial assistant to magistrate, Satara, 1860; judge and session judge, Dharwar, 1861; judge and session judge, Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1869; retired in 1873.

LLOYD, R. A., B.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the education department, from 1st May, 1864, as professor and officiating principal, Agra College; from Oct., 1867, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to the 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1870; acted as principal of the Bareilly College, 1875-76.

LOCH, FRANCIS ADAM ELLIS, Lieutenant-General, C.B., Bombay S.C.—Educated at Edinburgh High School, and Rochester School; 1st commission as cornet, Bombay cavalry, 7th April, 1844; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and was present at the siege and capture of Mooltan (medal and clasp); served subsequently as adjutant of the Southern Mahratta horse, 1850, and of the 1st regiment Bombay light cavalry, 1850-57; in the mutiny of 1857-58 was wounded at the outbreak of the Bengal troops at Nusseerabad, May, 1857; was present at the siege and capture of Awan and Cotah, the recapture of Chandaree, the action at Kotah-ke-Seraf, the capture of Gwalior, the siege of Poirie, the pursuit of rebels under Maun Sing, and the action of Koondrye (brevet of major, medal and clasp); served in the Abyssinian expedition of 1867-68, and was present at the battle of Arogee, and the capture of Magdala (brevet of colonel, medal and clasp); C.B., May, 1875; political superintendent and commandant, Upper Sind frontier, 1873 to 1876; commanded Hyderabad contingent, 1876, and the station at Ahmednugger, 1876-77; political resident, Aden, and commanding Aden brigade, May, 1877, to March, 1882.

LOCH, JAMES HENRY, M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; served under the military department till Aug., 1859, including service with the Oudh field force in 1855, and at the relief of Azamgarh, 1858 (medal), and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in various stations, and superintendent of jail, and held medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp in 1869-70, and again, 1872 and 1873; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1884.

LOCH, WILLIAM, Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, March, 1866; served in the 10th Foot; joined the Bombay staff corps, May, 1868, and served subsequently in the Sind horse; assistant political superintendent, Sawantwari, May, 1877; assistant to general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, 1878; and assistant to governor-general's agent, Indore, 1879; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, 1880; during the Afghan war was on political duty with Major-General Sir R. Phayre's force, marching to the relief of Kandahar (medal); and assistant agent, Beloochistan, in charge of Pishin valley, Nov., 1880; assistant resident, Western Rajputana, and boundary settlement officer in Marwar, Dec., 1881; graded as additional political agent, 3rd class.

LOCH, WILLIE WALKER, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acting principal of the Raja's school, and tutor and governor of the Gaekwar, Baroda, April-Nov., 1880; first assistant collector and railway magistrate, Thana, Oct., 1882.

LOGAN, ALEXANDER COCHRANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

LOGAN, ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, and University College, London; matriculated at the London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1869; served in the Central Provinces from 1869 to 1881, in the grade of assistant commissioner, and officiated as district superintendent of police, March, 1872, inspector of schools, Dec., 1873, to March, 1874, and registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, April, 1874, to Dec., 1876; from April to Nov., 1881, served in the financial department in Bengal as deputy accountant-general and officiating accountant-general; appointed assistant comptroller-general in class III of the financial department, Sept., 1881; acted as under-secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, from Nov., 1881, and was confirmed in this appointment, July, 1883; officiated as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Aug.-Oct., 1883, and as deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1884, and again in 1885; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, March, 1885; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Dec., 1885; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1887; class 3 of enrolled officers, Nov., 1887.
LOGAN, WILLIAM, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Musselburgh Grammar School, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate of Malabar, March, 1876; on special duty, Feb., 1881, as commissioner for inquiring into certain important matters in the Moplah districts; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1881; member of Forest Draft Bill Committee, March, 1882; acting member, board of revenue, Nov., 1882; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, May, 1883 to Feb., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with Report on Land Tenures of Malabar, Feb., 1884, and again in connection with the Attipadi Valley suit, July, 1884; retired, 1888; has published a collection of treaties, engagements, &c., relating to British affairs in Malabar, 1879; and edited Mr. Gréme's glossary of Malayalam words and phrases, 1882.

LOKENDRO, NATH PALIT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

LORD, WALTER FREWEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

LOVE, HENRY DAVISON, Captain, R.E., Madras Education Department.—Educated at University College, Bath, and Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; Lieutenant, R.E., 12th September, 1872; acted as inspector of schools for science and art department, 1875-76; admitted to Madras establishment, Oct., 1876; arrived in India, 5th December, 1876; first assistant master civil engineering college, July, 1877; on special duty in connection with Madras harbour works, Dec., 1877; served subsequently in the P.W. Department, and acted as deputy consulting engineer for railways in 1878 and 1879, and as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government, irrigation branch, June-Nov., 1879; assistant examiner of accounts, Nov. 1879; principal, civil engineering college, Jan., 1880; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; member of committee in connection with scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885.

LOVETT, BERESFORD, Colonel, C.S.I., R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, Sept., 1860; joined the public works department, April, 1861, and served in the Punjab till Sept., 1866, when he was transferred to the Persian telegraph department; assistant commissioner, Seistan boundary commission, Sept., 1870; rejoined P.W. department as executive engineer, Sept., 1872; C.S.I., Feb., 1873; attached to Bori Valley field force, Nov., 1877 to Jan., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1878-79; transferred to Bengal, Feb., 1881; British consul at Astrabad, Sept., 1880 to Jan., 1883; superintending engineer, Bengal, 1885; transferred to military works, Rawal Pindi command, April, 1886.

LOVETT, SACKVILLE HALTON HARRINGTON

VERNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sherborne, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LOWIS, CECIL CHAMPAINE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Newton College, Devonshire, Government Gymnasium, Gottingen, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1885; arrived in Burma, 8th Jan., 1888, and posted to Mandalay; registrar to judicial commissioner, Burma.

LOWIS, EDMOND ELLIOT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1858; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1861; deputy commissioner, Western Dooras, Oct., 1867; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Oct., 1867; magistrate and collector, Maldah, Dec., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Aug., 1868; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1872; commissioner, Chittagong division, March, 1875; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1879; officiating opium agent, Behar, Jan. to Nov., 1879; commissioner, Dacca division, Dec., 1885, and in the Rajshahi division, Oct., 1886.

LOWNDES, THOMAS, Colonel, M.S.C., late Police Department, Burma.—Joined the Madras army, and arrived in India, Dec., 1854; served in the Burma police department from March, 1861, as superintendent; on special mission to Chiengme, March-May, 1871; political agent, Bhamo, May, 1872, to Oct., 1873; 1st grade, superintendent, May, 1875; inspector-general of police, British Burma, Jan., 1876; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; retired, Aug., 1887.

LUARD, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1857; deputy superintendent, Western Jumna canal, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1859; assistant principal, Thomason College, 1863; assistant secretary, government of India, public works department, officiating as deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, March, 1865; deputy superintendent, Ganges canal, 1865; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bengal, Oct., 1867; officiating under secretary, government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873 to 1875; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1874; officiating mint master, Calcutta, July to Oct., 1876; officiating consulting engineer, Lucknow, 1877; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1884, and subsequently at Calcutta, Dec., 1885; chief engineer, and class, May, 1886; 1st class, March, 1887; while on leave, in 1887, deputed to attend railway conference at Milan.

LUCAS, ARTHUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884; forest settlement officer, March, 1886.

LUCAS, WILLIAM HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and New College,
Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service, after open competition of 1886.

LUDLAM, JOSEPH T., late Registry Department, India Office.—Served under the India Board from 1836; registrar at India Board, 1859, and continued in charge of the records till 1867, when he was transferred to the registry department, India Office, as extra assistant to registrar; retired, May, 1888.

LUDLOW, EDMOND SAMUEL, C.I.E., Lieut.-Colonel, M.S.C., Hyderabad Administration.—Served with the Madras Native Infantry from 1858 to 1864, and with the Sangor Field Division in 1859; from Oct., 1864, served in Mysore and Coorg as assistant superintendent; judge of the small cause court, Bangalore, 1874 and 1875; assistant commissioner, June, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Secunderabad, Sept., 1881; services lent to H.H. the Nizam's government, and appointed judge of the suburban court, Hyderabad, Feb., 1884; inspector general of police to the Nizam's government, April, 1884; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, May, 1887.

LUKIN, GEORGE, India Office.—Clerk to the clerk of the works, India office, 21st June, 1860; clerk of the works, Aug., 1874; surveyor and clerk of the works, April, 1882.

LUGARD, HENRY IBBETSON, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1853; was employed under the military department till 1864, also serving in the Madras police in 1857 and 1860-61; from Jan., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry, Jubbulpore, May to Sept., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, March 1873; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1885.

LUMSDEN, JOHN JAMES FOOTE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, July, 1874; on special duty to Naini Tal, July-Sept., 1875; commissioner, Fyzabad division, Dec., 1879, and subsequently of the Benares division, and agent to the governor-general.

LUMSDEN, SIR PETER S., Major-General, G.C.B., C.S.I.—Ensign, Bengal army, Dec., 1847; assistant executive engineer, 1849; deputy assistant quartermaster-general, April, 1853; assistant political agent, Afghanistan, Jan., 1857, to June, 1858; assistant quartermaster-general, Sept., 1858; deputy quartermaster-general, April, 1863; quartermaster-general, May, 1868; officiating resident, Hyderbad, 1872; adjutant-general, Sept., 1874; chief of the staff, 1879; member of council of India, 1 Dec., 1883; Afghan boundary commissioner, 1884.

LUSHINGTON, EDWARD HARBORD, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1841; arrived in India, 22nd June, 1841; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate of Chittagong in 1847, and afterwards of Patna; deputy collector of government sea customs, Calcutta, 1855; collector, Nuddea, 1856; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, 1857; acting commissioner of the Burdwan, Manbhoom, and Singbhoom district, 1857-58; Mutiny medal; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Nuddea, 1861; secretary to government of Bengal, 1861; secretary to government of India in the financial department, government director of Bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1863; retired, 1871.

LUSON, HEWLING, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's, Southwark, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Nuddea, Jan., 1885.

LUTTMAN-JOHNSON, HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1872; acting under secretary, government of Bengal, department of scarcity and relief, Oct., 1873, to Feb., 1874; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1874, as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, and secretary to chief commissioner; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, July, 1879; judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, May, 1886.

LYALL, SIR ALFRED COMYNS, K.C.B., K.C.I.E., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, and Jan., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Central Provinces, April, 1864, and served as deputy commissioner, officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating commissioner of the Nagpur division; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1867, and appointed commissioner, West Berar, Aug., 1867; secretary to the government of India, home department, March, 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and chief commissioner of Ajmere; on special duty in England, Aug., 1876; secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1878; on special political duty in Kabul, March, 1880, and again in Sept., 1880; K.C.B., May, 1881; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, and chief commissioner of Oudh, 17th April, 1882; C.I.E., May, 1882; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; retired, Dec., 1887; appointed member of the Indian council, 17th Jan., 1888.

LYALL, CHARLES JAMES, M.A., LL.D., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's College School, King's College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiated at various times as under secretary to government, and as junior secretary, Oct., 1872; assistant under secretary to government of India, foreign department, April-June, 1872; from April, 1873, served under the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed under secretary to government, Sept., 1873, and was placed on special
duty, Sept., 1878; transferred to Assam as officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1880; officiating judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, 1883, and July, 1888; secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1883; officiating secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Feb.-Nov., 1886; author of 'Article on Hindustani literature in Encyclopaedia Britannica,' 1880; 'Sketch of the Hindustani language,' 1880; 'Translations of ancient Arabic Poetry,' 1885; and 'Guide to the transliteration of Hindu and Muhammadan names in the Bengal army, 1885.

LYALL, David Robert, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating commissioner, Dacca division, March, 1878, and Presidency division, Feb., 1882; inspector-general of police, March, 1883; officiating commissioner of Chittagong, Oct., 1884; confirmed, Aug., 1887.

LYALL, Sir James Broadwood, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1858; arrived, April 8, 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and deputy commissioner; settlement commissioner, Mooltan and Derajat, March, 1874; financial commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1879; resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1883; also judicial commissioner of Coorg; graded in the political department as resident, 1st class; lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, April, 1887.

LYLE, Henry Ward, LL.B., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1887; and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

LYNCH, Sidney S., Medical Department, Bengal.—From 16th Nov., 1858, served in Assam as civil medical officer, and inspector of landing of native labourers, and from Jan., 1866, in Bengal, as superintendent, presidency jail; superintendent of the Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1871; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, May, 1879; confirmed in this appointment, April, 1882.

LYON, George Kenneth, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1885.

LYON, Isidore Bernardette, Brigade-Surgeon, F.C.S., M.R.C.S., L.S.A., F.I.C., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 1st March, 1866; acting professor of anatomy and curator of museum, Grant Medical College, March, 1866; professor of chemistry, Grant Medical College, and chemical analyser to government, Jan., 1867; in addition to these appointments was also third physician at the Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, July, 1867, to Oct., 1872, professor of medical jurisprudence, Grant Medical College, from July, 1868, and professor of chemistry at the Elphinstone College from Dec., 1875; on special duty conducting petroleum experiments, Oct.-Nov., 1882; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1887; acting principal Grant Medical College.

LYON, Percy Comyn, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's School, Bruton, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1884; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and personal assistant to the chief commissioner.

LYTTELTON, Hon. Neville Gerald, Col., Rifle Brigade.—1st commission, ensign, Rifle Brigade, 17th Jan., 1865; Major, Feb., 1882; Col. (army), Nov., 1886; A.D.C. to lord lieutenant of Ireland, Jan., 1869, to Oct., 1873; served in the Jowaki expedition of 1877, medal with clasp; private secretary to secretary of state for war, April, 1880, to Aug., 1882; A.D.C. to chief of staff expeditionary force, Egypt, Aug.-Oct., 1882, including battle of Tel-el-Kebir, medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet lieutenant-colonel, 4th class Osmanieh; assistant military secretary to governor of Gibraltar, Jan., 1883, to March, 1885; military secretary on personal staff of governor of Bombay, 31 March, 1885.

LYTTON (Earl of), Right Hon. Edward Robert Bulwer-Lytton, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Born Nov. 8, 1812; educated at Harrow, and afterwards at Bonn; entered the diplomatic service in 1849, and served as attache successively at Washington, Florence, Paris, the Hague, St. Petersburg, and Constantinople; from Jan., 1859, to Jan., 1863, he was attached to the Vienna embassy, during which period he acted as consul-general at Belgrade (Feb.-March, 1860), and was employed on a special mission to prevent the renewal of hostilities between the Turks and Servians; 2nd secretary in the diplomatic service, Oct., 1862; secretary of legation at Copenhagen, Jan., 1863, at Athens, May, 1864, and at Lisbon, April, 1865; successfully concluded the negotiation of a commercial treaty with Austria; transferred to Madrid, Feb., 1868; secretary of embassy at Vienna, Oct., 1868, and at Paris, Oct., 1872; during the periods of his service at Copenhagen, Lisbon, Vienna, and Paris he acted on several occasions as chargé-d'affaires, and during the absence of the ambassador at Paris, was accredited there as minister plenipotentiary; ambassador at Lisbon, Nov., 1874; viceroy and governor-general of India, April 12, 1876, to April, 1880; during his tenure of office as governor-general he presided at the Delhi assembly, on the proclamation of Her Majesty the Queen as Empress of India, Jan. 1, 1877, and was the object of an attempt at assassination, Dec., 1879; G.C.B., Dec., 1877; created an earl, April, 1880; a royal commissioner for the London exhibition of 1886; was appointed ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to the French Republic, Nov., 1887; his published literary works include: 'Clytemnestra, the Earl's Return, the Artist and other Poems,' 1855; 'The Wanderer: a Collection of Poems in Many Lands,' 1859; 'Lucile,' 1860; 'Tannhauser, or the Battle of the Bards' (written in collaboration with the Hon. Julian Fane), 1861; 'Serbski Pesme,' a collection of the national
songs of Servia, 1861; 'The Ring of Amasis,' 1863; 'Poetical Works of Owen Meredith,' 1867; 'Chronicles and Characters,' 1868; 'Orval, or the Fool of Time,' 1869; 'Julian Fane, a Memoir,' 1871; 'Fables in Song,' 1874; and 'The Speeches of Edward, Lord Lytton, &c.,' 1874.

MACAULAY, COLMAN PATRICK LOUIS, M.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ratcliffe College, Loughborough, Queen's College, Galway, and at Liège; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector, in Bengal, Nov., 1870; district superintendent of police, June, 1873; on famine duty at Bankoora, July, 1874; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, April, 1875; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Oct., 1875; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, Nov., 1875, and July, 1876; officiating under secretary, government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, April, 1876; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1877; under secretary, government of Bengal, Oct., 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, judicial and political departments, Feb., 1879; junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1879; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Aug., 1879; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1882; lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1882; on special duty under the government of India, foreign department, 1885; officiating chief secretary to government of Bengal, Dec., 1886; C.I.E. Jan., 1887.

MACAULIFFE, MICHAEL, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Newcastle School (Limerick), Springfield College, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 9th Feb., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; promoted to deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1882; divisional judge, Nov., 1884 (and grade, Jan., 1887); author of 'Life of Baba Nanak,' and of articles on the Sikh religion in the 'Calcutta Review,' 1880-81.

MACAUSLAND, CAPTAIN R. C. S., Bengal S.C. (Punjab).—Lieutenant, 13th Nov., 1872; arrived in India, 9th March, 1873, and served in the military department, and in the Punjab as cantonment magistrate; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Dec., 1887.

MACCARTIE, CHARLES FALKINER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served in Bombay till Nov., 1872, and subsequently in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting principal assistant, additional sessions judge, and acting collector, magistrate, and agent, and was placed on special settlement duty, Nov., 1882; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Jan., 1882; officiating postmaster-general, Madras, April-Dec., 1883; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, May, 1884; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Feb., 1885; acting secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1885, to May, 1886.

MACDONALD, DONALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Oct., 1853; arrived in India, Dec., 1853; appointed to the survey department, revenue branch, Dec., 1860; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1865; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1866; promoted to 2nd grade, Jan., 1878, and 1st grade, Jan., 1887; in charge of the N.W. frontier survey, 1879-1884; officiating assistant surveyor-general, March, 1886; confirmed, Sept., 1887.

MACDONALD, JOHN CRAWFORD, Kumaun Commission, North-Western Provinces.—Previous to employment in India, was engaged in the railway survey department at Melbourne, 1855 to 1858; from 5th Sept., 1858, served in Kumaun as assistant to the superintendent of Kheddas, and was appointed assistant superintendent, Tarai, April, 1861; superintendent, Tarai, May, 1871.

MACDONALD, R. G., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Served in the subordinate accounts establishment, Oct., 1863, to Dec., 1867; examiner of railway accounts, Oudh, Dec., 1867; auditor, Oudh and Rohilkund railway accounts, Jan., 1870; examiner, railway accounts, Madras, 1875; W. Rajputana railway, 1876; assistant accountant-general, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; examiner of accounts, Punjab, 1881; N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1882; examiner of military works accounts, 1883; inspector of public works accounts, 1884; officiated as deputy accountant-general, and under secretary to government, Nov., 1885, to Feb., 1886, and April, 1886, to March, 1887; and again May, 1887; examiner, and class, in the accounts establishment, May, 1886; examiner, 1st class, May, 1887; officiating accountant-general, public works department, and deputy secretary to government of India, accounts branch, May, 1888.

MACDONNELL, ANTHONY PATRICK, C.S.I., M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1874; officiating magistrate and collector, 1875; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1881, and again, Jan.-April, 1882; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Sept., 1881, and again, April, 1882; confirmed as secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, July, 1884; lieutenant-governor's council, Nov., 1884; officiating secretary, government of India, home department, March, 1886; confirmed in this appointment, March, 1887; author of 'Food Grain Supply and Famine Relief in Behar and Bengal,' 1876; C.S.I., June, 1888.

MACDOUGALL, JAMES WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1858; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted at various times as cantonment magistrate of Kamptee, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur, April, 1871, to March, 1873; held charge of the model farm, Nagpur, in addition to other duties, 1873-79; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Sept., 1883.

MACEWEN, ROBERT SUTHERLAND TAYLOR (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Depart-
ment.—Sub-assistant commissioner, Sonthal commission, Sept., 1862; officiating assistant commissioner, May, 1865; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, July, 1866; served from Dec., 1870, as judge, Calcutta court of small causes, and was promoted to and judge, Oct., 1884; served temporarily as recorder of Rangoon, April-Oct., 1884, and again in 1885-86; published 'The Practice of the Presidency Courts of Small Causes under Act XV. of 1882,' June, 1883.

MACFARLAN, JOHN, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1857; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, Satara, till 1860; deputy collector and magistrate, in Sind, 1860-61; second assistant collector and magistrate at Poona and Dharwar, 1862 to 1864; acting collector and magistrate, Kanara, April, 1866; first assistant collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1869; acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, 1870-72, and from Feb., 1873, and was appointed postmaster-general, Madras, in 1875; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, April, 1877, to Dec., 1878; retired, Dec., 1878.

MACGEORGE, HENRY JOHN, Central Provinces.—Joined the service as deputy superintendent of Jhansi, 10th June, 1854; deputy collector, Betul, Nov., 1856; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Dec., 1860; in charge of settlement duties, Wardha and Chanda, Dec., 1862, to April, 1863; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877.

MACGREGOR, JAMES LISTOR LAIRD, Forest Department, Bombay.—Appointed an assistant conservator of forests, Punjab, Dec., 1871; arrived, 16th Jan., 1872; transferred to Bombay, June, 1873; deputy conservator, Aug., 1879; conservator, 3rd grade, Dec., 1886.

MACIVOR, IVAR, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, 18th Hussars, Oct., 1872; arrived in India, March, 1873; 1st regiment, Central India Horse, Aug., 1877; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, Oct., 1878; assistant to political resident, Persian Gulf, Feb., 1880; 1st assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan, Jan., 1885.

MACKAY, DUNCAN LACHLAN MACPHERSON, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Madras College, and University, St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1875, and was appointed assistant commissioner at Jubbulpore; transferred to Burma, July, 1876; 1st grade assistant commissioner, Aug., 1886.

MACKENZIE, ALEXANDER, B.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward VI.'s Grammar School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Sept., 1863; from Feb., 1866, to Dec., 1873, served as under secretary, junior secretary, and officiating secretary to government of Bengal; on famine duty, Dec., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1875, and again in 1877; magistrate and collector, and grade, Moorshedabad, July, 1876; also in charge of office of agent to governor-general; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal general and revenue departments, July, 1877; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Oct., 1877; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1879; secretary, government of India, home department, April, 1882; C.S.I., May, 1886; chief commissioner of Central Provinces, March, 1887; author of 'History of the Relations of the Government with the Hill Tribes of the N.E. Frontier of Bengal.'

MACKENZIE, GORDON THOMSON, Madras C.S.—Educated at King William's College, Isle of Man, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; assistant commissioner, Nilgiris, Aug., 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Kistna, Sept., 1881; head assistant collector, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; acting registrar, high court, July, 1883; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883, and acting secretary, Nov., 1884; president of the municipal commission, Jan., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1886; acting district and sessions judge, Nov., 1887.

MACKENZIE, KENNETH JAMES LOCH, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—Joined Madras artillery from Addiscombe, 11th June, 1858; from April, 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts, as assistant commissioner, assistant conservator of forests, and deputy commissioner (and class, Feb., 1885).

MACKENZIE, STEPHEN COULL, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; served from 15th Oct., 1869, as professor of hygiene, Calcutta Medical College, also officiating as assistant surgeon at the Presidency General Hospital; superintendent, presidency jail, in addition to his own duties, Jan., 1871; junior surgeon, Presidency General Hospital, Dec., 1873; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, Feb., 1877; superintendent of Campbell Medical School and Hospital, Sealdah, professor of medical jurisprudence, Calcutta Medical College, and police surgeon, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; also appointed, in addition to his other duties, superintendent of lock hospitals in Calcutta and its suburbs, Nov., 1879, and of lunatic asylums, Dec., 1880, and coroner's surgeon; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1878.

MACKENZIE, THOMAS DUNCAN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate; secretary, Baroda Inquiry commission, Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1875, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1877; member of civil and military examination committee, April-Oct., 1879; from Nov., 1879, served as acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty at Baroda, March-Aug., 1880, in connection with the settlement of the affairs of Mir Zulfikar Ali; acting junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Nov., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Broach, May, 1884; collector, magistrate and political agent, Khandeish, Feb., 1886; acting chief secretary to government, Bombay, May, 1886.

MACKENZIE, SIR WILLIAM, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., K.C.B., C.S.I., late Madras Medical Service.—A.M. of King's College, Aberdeen, 1830; M.R.C.S., London, 1832;
M.D., University of Aberdeen, 1856; assistant surgeon in the Madras medical service, 1835; served with the 8th light cavalry, Madras, 1837-1839, and with the army of His Highness the Nizam of Hyderabad, 1839-1862; was superintendent of the Bolarum Medical School, 1842-44; served with the Ellickpoor field force, against the insurgent Rohillas in 1841, and again in Nov., 1851, with the cavalry field force, under Brigadier W. Mayne; staff-surgeon with the Central India field force, 1857-58, and with the Berar field force, Nov., 1858, to March, 1859, and was present at numerous engagements; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Mysore Division, March, 1863; inspector-general, Aug., 1866; inspector-general and head of the medical department, March, 1867; retired, Aug., 1871; appointed honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1867; author of a treatise on the medical topography of Ellickpoor, and papers on the Indian Materia Medica, and has translated into Hindustani, 'Gregory's Practice of Physic,' and 'Thomson's Conspectus of the British Pharmacopoea.'

MACKIE, ANDREW WALLACE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Universities of Edinburgh and St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874, and again, in Nellore, March, 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1887; has also officiated as district and sessions judge.

MACKINTOSH, JAMES SIMON, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, Edinburgh University, and Oriel College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant secretary, and officiating under secretary to government; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb.-April, 1874; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Aug.-Nov., 1875; junior secretary to government, July, 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1877; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1886.

MACLAGAN, EDWARD DOUGLAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1888.

MACLEAN, ALEXANDER THOMAS, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1856; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Pooree, Oct., 1866; from July, 1869, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge and district judge in various districts of Bengal, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs in 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1880; retired, 1885.

MACLEANE, CHARLES DONALD, Mus. Doc., M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; acting inspector of schools, Oct., 1866; assistant collector, Dec., 1867; acting cantonment magistrate, Sept., 1868; acted for various periods as under secretary to Government of Madras, and sub-secretary to the Board of revenue; on special duty in preparing annual administration report, Nov., 1876, and again, Sept., 1878; on special duty revising standing orders of the board of revenue, Oct., 1877, and again in June, 1886; under secretary to government in chief secretary's department, July, 1880; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1881; Canarese translator to government, April, 1881; member of board of examiners, Jan., 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1883; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of 'Manual of Administration,' Nov., 1883, and again, Aug., 1884 and 1886; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Feb., 1884; on special duty as president of the committee on Muhamadan Educational Endowment, Aug., 1885; Tamil translator to government, Sept., 1885; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Feb., 1886; on special duty in the general record department, Feb., 1886, and also to collect information for the finance committee, June, 1886.

MACLEOD, BANNATYNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, Edinburgh University, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector; also forest settlement officer, May, 1886.

MACLEOD, DONALD GRANT, M.A., LL.M. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Burma—Trinity College, Cambridge, and Inner Temple; judge of the court of small causes, Rangoon, Sept., 1869; judge of Moulmein, March, 1876.

MACLEOD, Roderick Henry, Bengal C.S. (North-West Provinces).—Educated at University College, London, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Dec., 1886.

MACNABB, Sir Donald C., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Peshawur, 1865; commissioner, Hisar division, 1872, and subsequently in the Lahore, Rawal Pindi, and Peshawur divisions; retired, 1881; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

MACNABB, James William, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, and Jan., 1852, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Aug., 1861; commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Nov., 1875, and afterwards in the Hissar and Delhi divisions; retired, March, 1886.

MACNAGHTEN, Chester, M.A. (Cantab.),
Educational Department, Bombay.—From July, 1866, to Dec., 1870, held the appointment of tutor to the minor Mahárájah of Durbhunga under the court of wards, Bengal; joined the Bombay educational service, 19th Dec., 1870, and served from that date as principal of the Rajkumar College, Káthiáwar.

MACONACHIE, GEORGE ARCHIBALD, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Aber.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; was employed under the military department till Jan., 1872, including service in the Abyssinian campaign (medal), and subsequently as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and comparative anatomy at the Grant Medical College, Bombay; also presidency surgeon from June, 1880.

MACONACHIE, JAMES ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 9th Jan., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1880; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab, July, 1884; on special duty under the government of India, foreign department, Sept.-Oct., 1885; officiating deputy commissioner, Gurgaon; author of report on the settlement of the Delhi District.

MACONOCHIE, ALEXANDER FRANCIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Westminster, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; acting joint administrator, Rajpipla, Oct., 1886.

MACPHERSON, SIR ARTHUR GEORGE, K.C.I.E., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at the University and King's College, Aberdeen, and University of Edinburgh; called to the bar, Inner Temple, 1852; 1st judge of Calcutta small cause court, 1859; secretary to the government of Bengal, legislative department, 1862; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India in the home department (legislative), 1863, and appointed assistant secretary, Oct., 1864; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1865; acted as chief justice, 13th Feb. to 25th June, 1875; retired, 1877; legal adviser to the secretary of state, Nov., 1879; secretary in the judicial and public department, India Office, Feb., 1882; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

MACPHERSON, ANDREW KENNEDY, Major B.S.C.—First commission, 19th Dec., 1865; arrived in India, 9th March, 1866; from April, 1871, served as cantonment magistrate at various stations in the Punjab, and was promoted to the 1st class, Dec., 1879; officiating in the judge advocate-general's department, May, 1886.

MACPHERSON, CHARLES GORDON WELLAND, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and superintendent of police; supernumerary under secretary to government of Bombay in the public works department for relief purposes, Nov., 1876; on famine relief duty in Madras, as secretary to personal assistant to the governor, Sept., 1877, to Jan., 1879; from April, 1879, acted as under secretary to government of Bombay, political and judicial departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881; acting private secretary to governor of Bombay, Dec., 1880, to March, 1881; acted as secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, in 1884 and 1885; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, April-July, 1885, and again in 1886; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Nov., 1885; on special duty in the political department of the secretariat, Dec., 1885; and grade judge, May, 1887; acting district and sessions judge, Jan., 1888.

MACPHERSON, DUNCAN JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882.

MACPHERSON, GEORGE MORISON, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, small cause court judge, and judge and sessions judge in various districts; 1st grade judge, Jan., 1881; judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the sadar court, Feb., 1885.

MACPHERSON, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty under board of revenue, July, 1875; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, May, 1884; superintendent of Dehra Dun, Aug., 1886.

MACPHERSON, J. M. (Barrister-at-Law), Legislative Department, Government of India.—Educated at Westminster School; advocate of the high court, Calcutta; served from Dec., 1877, as deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department; officiated as secretary from Oct., 1887, to Jan., 1888; editor of 7th edition of 'Macpherson's Law of Mortgage in British India.'

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating civil and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1872, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 10th Jan., 1885.

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in
India, 27th Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector, Patna, Dec., 1877; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating inspector of schools; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1884; under secretary to government of Bengal, Nov., 1885; officiating under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Jan., 1888, and home department, April, 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, May, 1888; officiating magistrate and collector, June, 1888.

MACRAE, JOHN KENNETH, Burma Commission.—Joined the Burma commission as officiating assistant commissioner, 20th July, 1860; registrar to the court of the recorder, and judge of the court of small causes, Moulemein, May, 1864; deputy commissioner, July, 1869; town magistrate, Akyab, Nov., 1874; boundary officer, Nov., 1880; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883; president, Akyab municipal committee, Jan., 1885; acted as commissioner of Arakan, Nov.-Dec., 1885; of the Irrawaddy division, Feb.-April, 1887.

MACRURY, COLIN WILLIAM, Surgeon-Major, Bombay Sanitary Department.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1869, arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1869; on general duty in Sind, deputy sanitary commissioner, Feb., 1878; deputy superintendent of census in Sind, 1881; surgeon-major, April, 1881; sanitary commissioner to the government of Bombay, May, 1888.

MADDOX, STUART LOCKWOOD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885.

MADDEN, JOHN MELLISH, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay Infantry.—Ensign, Bombay army, Sept., 1859; employed on military duty, including service in Abyssinia in 1868, up to 1876; served subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate, Poona; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmedabad, January, 1880.

MAGUIRE, HUGH FITZJOHN TYREL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; member, central examination committee, April, 1886.

MAHADEV GOVIND RANADE, RAO BAHADUR, C.I.E., M.A., LL.B. (Bombay), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 28th May, 1866, in the educational department, and was appointed assistant professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, Oct., 1868; also served in the judicial department as assistant reporter to the high court, Bombay, acting magistrate of police, acting small cause court judge, and subordinate judge (June, 1879); acting presidency magistrate, Bombay, Jan.-March, 1881; appointed under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act to inspect and supervise the lower courts in districts of Poona and Satara, Aug., 1881; judge of the court of small causes, Poona, Feb., 1884; and was in charge of duties of law lecturer, Deccan College, Jan.-April, 1885; member of a committee on public expenditure; C.I.E., Feb., 1887; confirmed as special judge under Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, May, 1887.
