MOSLEY, HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bishop's Stortford Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from April, 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1884; and 1st grade, March, 1888.

MOSS, T., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, July, 1849, and served as assistant and executive engineer and as assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces; officiating controller, central office of account, Rangoon, Oct., 1869; assistant ac-
countant-general in the public works department, government of India, April, 1872; officiating controller, Madras, March, 1873; controller of accounts, Punjab northern state railway, April, 1875; transferred to Central Provinces as controller, Nagpur, Sept., 1875; examiner of accounts, Rangoon, April, 1878; transferred to Punjab, 1879; examiner, 2nd class, Sept., 1881; retired, 1886.

MOULE, HORACE FREDERICK D'OVLY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty in 1872 to conduct the prosecution of the sub-judge of Mirzapur; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1879; magistrate and collector, and grade, June, 1884; 1st grade, Dec., 1886; officiated, district and sessions judge, July and Oct., 1887, and May-Aug., 1888; secretary, board of revenue, Jan.-May, 1886.

MOUNSEY, CHARLES HERBERT, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant, Anantapur, May, 1886; compiled and edited the 'Reports of the Meriah Agents (Ganjam)', and wrote a 'History of the Ganjam Maliaks'.

MOWAT, M., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Professor, Presidency College, June, 1876; Dacca College, Jan., 1878; officiating inspector of schools, Nov., 1879; professor, Patna College, Feb., 1880; officiating principal, Patna College, May, 1883; 3rd class of the education department, July, 1883; officiating principal, Hooghly College, April, 1885.

MUHAMMAD ABBAK MIRZA, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN WAIZAR-ZADAH, C.S.I., Sirdar, Lieutenant-Colonel, 11th Bengal Lancers, Political Department, Punjab.—Appointed British agent at the court of H.H. the Amir of Kabul, March, 1882; A.D.C. to governor-general.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN, Sirdar, Khan Bahadur, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 3rd March, 1881; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1883.

MUHAMMED ALI SAHIYID, B.A. (Calcutta University), Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed to be a probationary assistant magistrate and collector under the statutory rules, 4th April, 1887.

MUHAMMAD ASLAM KHAN, Kazi, C.M.G., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Officiating extra-assistant commissioner, 10th Sept., 1881; on special duty in civil secretariat, Dec., 1881; probationer under native civil service rules, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; on special duty with Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884, to Nov., 1886; appointed Mir Munshi to Punjab government, May, 1887; native attache to Foreign Office, April, 1888.

MUHAMMAD HYAT KHAN, C.S.I.—Extra assistant commissioner, Punjab, March, 1862; promoted to assistant commissioner, Jan., 1872; C.S.I., May, 1872; served as officiating judicial assistant in the Punjab, and was employed on special duty with the camp of exercise at Hasan Abdal, 1873; also as officiating political assistant with the Kuram field force, 1878; and as political officer with the staff of Sir F. Roberts, Kabul field force, 1879-80; district judge, and grade, Punjab, Dec., 1886; officiating divisional judge, Ferozepore, April, 1888.

MUHAMMAD ISHAK KHAN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, Jan., 1884; confirmed in the civil service, Aug., 1886; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1888.

MUHAMMAD RAZA KHAN SAHIB, Madras C.S.—Served from Jan., 1874, in subordinate posts in the Madras revenue and educational departments, and in Hyderabad as attache to the resident; appointed by the government of India to be a member of the Madras civil service, 3rd Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1883, is also a forest settlement officer.

MUHAMMAD SAMI ULLA KHAN, Maulvi, C.M.G., Bengal Judicial Department (N.W. Provinces).—Joined the service as sub-judge, 1st May, 1873; district judge, sub-pro tem, April, 1885 and April, 1886, officiated as district judge in 1886 and 1887, and was confirmed in the appointment, May, 1887.

MUIR, JOHN FAIRLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1869, to April, 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting assistant secretary and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; from April, 1874, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector, May, 1880; junior collector and magistrate, April, 1887.

MUIR, JULIUS WOOD, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dumfries Academy, and Edinburgh University, called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, and grade, July, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade in Oudh, Sept., 1885; district and sessions judge, Sept., 1887.

MUIR, SIR WILLIAM, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., LL.D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kilmar-nock Grammar School, and Edinburgh and Glasgow Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1837; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1837; settlement officer in Cawnpore and Bundelkund, 1840-1843; officiating collector, Futtehpore, 1844-1845; secretary, Sudder board of revenue, 1847; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; mem-
ber, board of revenue, 1856; in charge of intelligence department at Agra during mutiny, 1857; secretary with Lord Canning at Allahabad for N.W. Provinces, 1858; reverted to board of revenue, 1859; member of legislative council of governor-general, 1864; foreign secretary, government of India, 1865; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1868-1874; financial member of governor-general's council, 1874-76; member of council of secretary of state, 1876-85; principal, Edinburgh University, 1885; honorary D.C.L. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Glasgow and Edinburgh; author of 'Life of Mahomet and History of Islam to the Era of the Hegira,' 1858; 'Annals of the Early Caliphate,' 1883, and other works on the same subject; pamphlet on indigenous education in Futtehpore, 1845; papers on revenue settlement in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, &c.

MUIR, WILLIAM JAMES WEMYSS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1858; assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Sept., 1862; assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti, June, 1864; political superintendent, Sirohi, Sept., 1865; officiated for some time as agent of Haraoti and Tonk; political agent, Moorsheadabad, 1876; cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, 1879; Haraoti and Tonk, 1880; graded as political agent, 1st class.

MUIR-MACKENZIE, JOHN WILLIAM PITTS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; on duty at Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, Oct., 1886, to Oct., 1887; and assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887; acting director of land records and agriculture, Feb., 1888.

MULLALY, CHARLES MYLNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Southampton Grammar School, Hartley Institution, Southampton, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1883; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887; acting collector and magistrate, Aug., 1888.

MULLINS, JOHN, Lieut-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—And lieutenant, Madras engineers, 8th Dec., 1848; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1850; assistant civil engineer, Feb., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in Nellore and Tanjore, 1858-64; consulting engineer for the irrigation and canal company, Madras, May, 1864, to Aug., 1869; under secretary to government, public works department, Feb., 1869; chief engineer for irrigation and joint secretary to government of Madras, public works department, Nov., 1870; acted as chief engineer and secretary to government in 1875 and 1877; president, irrigation committee, famine commission, Oct., 1878, to Jan., 1879; on special duty for drawing up the Bangalore water supply scheme, Oct., 1883; services replaced at disposal of military department, in 1884; retired, 1886.

MULOCK, FRANCIS BERRY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, and Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty as assistant private secretary to lieutenant-governor on occasion of visit of H.R.H. Prince of Wales, Dec., 1875, to March, 1876; on special duty for arrangements connected with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1886; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1887.

MULOCK, HENRY PILKINGTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; from Feb., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred temporarily to Bengal for employment on Behar famine relief works, Dec., 1873, to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; judge, 3rd grade, April, 1885.

MULOCK, WILLIAM BURY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 28th Nov., 1862, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar of the high court, and assistant collector and magistrate; from April, 1873, to Nov., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of assurances in Sind, also as inspector of education, May-Nov., 1873, and was on various occasions in charge of the office of the commissioner; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kántha, Jan., 1880; acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, June, 1884; senior collector and magistrate, Nasik, March, 1885; acting commissioner, northern division, Sept., 1888.

MUNRO, JAMES HUME, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newcastle-on-Tyne grammar school, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Madras, 21st Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to the collector and magistrate.

MUNRO, W. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1861; clerk, and 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

MURDOCH, DAVID DOIG, Madras C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived, 7th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate in Kistna and Chingleput; acting head assistant collector and magistrate, Salem.

MURRAY, ALAN, Colonel, B.S.C., late Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1857, as ensign, Bengal Fusiliers; during the mutiny served at the siege of Delhi, and was present at the relief of Lucknow, Nov., 1857; served subsequently with Sir James Outram's force, Nov., 1857 to Feb., 1858, and took part in the pursuit of the rebel Tantia Topee,
Jan., 1859 (medal and two clasps); served in the Oudh Police department as assistant superintendent from June, 1866 to April, 1867, and subsequently in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, and assistant settlement officer; junior secretary to chief commissioner, 1874-1878, and acted as director of public instruction, Jan.-March, 1874, and as personal assistant to chief commissioner, April-Aug., 1876; attache in Foreign Office, Nov., 1876 to Jan., 1877; in charge of Oudh Gazetteer, Aug., 1877 to Feb., 1878; officiated as cantonment magistrate and wasika officer Lucknow, in 1879, and in 1881-82; district judge, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, Kheri, April, 1886.

MURRAY, John, Inspector - General of Hospitals, M.D., late Bengal Medical Service.—Educated at Peterhead, and Marischal College, and University of Aberdeen; A.M., 1828; M.D., University of Edinburgh, 1831; M.R.C.S., London, 1831; assistant surgeon, Indian medical service, 1832; field surgeon at the battle of Aliwal, 1846; surgeon, 1848; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, 1858; inspector-general of hospitals, 1865; retired Jan., 1871; has written various papers on cholera and its treatment.

MURRAY, Robert, Major-General, C.S.I., R.A.—Educated at Addiscombe; and lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 14th June, 1845; served with the army of the Punjab, 1848-49, and was present at the action of Sadoolapore, and the battles of Chillianwallah and Guzerat, and in the advance to Peshawur (medal and two clasps); served on regimental duty, 1845-1857, including command of a battery in the Gwalior contingent, and in the Oudh irregular force; appointed to the telegraph department in Oct., 1857, as deputy superintendent; superintendent, 1860; major, Bengal staff corps, June, 1865; deputy director-general, Jan., 1866; lieutenant-colonel, Bengal staff corps, June, 1871; director-general of the telegraph department in India, Jan., 1878 to June, 1883; nominated C.S.I., May, 1884; major-general, May, 1886.

MUTHUSWAMI AIYAR, TIRUVARUR, B.L., C.I.E., Judicial department, Madras.—Served from 1st May, 1854, in various subordinate posts in the Madras revenue, judicial and educational departments; deputy collector, July, 1859; magistrate of police, Nov. 1868; judge of the court of small causes, Madras, May, 1871; fellow of University of Madras, April, 1872; on duty at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Jan., 1877; C.I.E., Jan. 1878; judge high court, Madras, Aug. 1883.

MYLNE, RIGHT REV. LOUIS GEORGE, M.A., D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Arrived in July, 1876; installed as Bishop of Bombay, 6th July, 1876.

NANABHAI HARIDAS, LL.B. (Madras), Judicial Department, Bombay.—From May, 1873, served in the Bombay judicial department as acting judge of the high court, and government pleader; also acted as professor of law in the government law school, July to Dec., 1880, and in Feb., 1881; confirmed as judge of the high court, June, 1882.

NANNEY, LEWIS CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., L.F.P.S., L.S.A., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1886; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1886; served under the military department, also acting as civil surgeon at various stations, and as superintendent of jail; acting presiding surgeon, Madras, 1872-73; superintendent, lunatic asylum, Madras, Oct. 1875; also professor of materia medica, medical college, July, 1876; surgeon-major, March, 1878; medical officer, Coonoor and Kotagiri, 1879-1881, and at Ootacamund, 1881-1883; special sanitary officer, Ootacamund, Aug., 1881, to July, 1883; civil surgeon, Cannanore, July, 1883; civil surgeon, Trichinopoly, June, 1884.

NAPIER AND ETTRICK (BARON), RIGHT HON. FRANCIS NAPIER, K.T.—Attaché to the embassy at Vienna in 1840, and afterwards at Constantinople; served as secretary of legation at Naples and St. Petersburg, and was appointed secretary of embassy at Constantinople in 1854; British minister at Washington, 1857, whence he was transferred to the Hague, 1858, to St. Petersburg in 1860, and to Berlin in 1864; governor of Madras, March, 1866 till Feb., 1872; on the assassination of Lord Mayo, acted temporarily as viceroy; was president of the Social Science Association at Plymouth in 1872; and presided over the education section of the Association at Glasgow, in Oct., 1874; a royal commissioner on the Highland Crofters' question, March, 1883.

NAPIER, ALAN BERTRAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rossall school, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

NAPIER, HON. GEORGE CAMPBELL, C.I.E., Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1861; from July, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; on special duty, March, 1874, in Persia, and again, Feb., 1881, at Kandahar; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1882, to Sept., 1883; judicial assistant, Feb., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; superintendent, Kapurthala State, April, 1885; retired, April, 1887.

NAPIER OF MAGDALA (BARON), RIGHT HON. SIR ROBERT CORNELIUS NAPIER, G.C.B., G.C.S.I., Field Marshal.—Born 1810; educated at the Military College, Addiscombe; 1st commission, 15th December, 1826; major, Aug., 1854; colonel, Feb., 1861; general, 1st April, 1874; served throughout the Sutlej campaign of 1845-6, and was present at the battles of Moodkee, Ferozeshah, and Sobraon; served in the Punjab campaign, and was present at the battle of Mooltan, and as commanding engineer of the right wing at the battle of Gojerat (medal with two clasps); served throughout the Indian mutiny; chief of the staff to Outram in 1857, and was present at the several actions leading to the first relief of Lucknow, in September; brigadier and chief engineer at the capture of Lucknow; defeated Tantia Topee at Joura Alipore (received thanks of parliament and K.C.B.), medal with three clasps; commanded division China expeditionary force, 1860, and was present at the surrender of Pekin (received thanks of parliament and medal with two clasps); military member of the council of the governor-general of India, 1861; commander-in-chief Bombay, Nov., 1865; commanded the Abyssinian expedition of 1868, for which he was raised to the peerage, and received the thanks of both houses of parliament; elected fellow of the Royal Society, 1869; commander-in-chief of
the forces in India, and extraordinary member of the governor-general's council in 1870; governor of Gibraltar, 1876 to 1883; field-marshal, Jan., 1883.

NARAYAN DAS RAEBAHADUR, Oudh Judicial Department.—Served in the postal department from June, 1855; temporary extra assistant commissioner, March, 1867; sub-judge, 3rd grade, Oct., 1881; judge of the small cause court, June, 1882; officiated as district judge, June, 1885, and April, 1887.

NARSINGRAO BHOLOMATH DIVATIA, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, Jan., 1849, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed in the Bombay civil service, March, 1886.

NASH, A.M., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th Jan., 1875; arrived, 31st March, 1875; served as professor, Presidency College; appointed inspector of European schools, and promoted to 2nd class of the education department, April, 1883.

NATHAN, ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885.

NAYLOR, JAMES RICHARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Kaladgi, June, 1875; remembrancer of legal affairs, July, 1876; acting chief secretary to government, judicial, educational, political, secret, and separate departments, Oct., 1879, to March, 1880, and again in May, 1887; additional member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1884; on special duty in connection with the Bombay municipal bill, June, 1885; temporary member of council, Bombay, Aug. to Oct., 1887, and again in May, 1888.

NEALE, WALTER ERSKINE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and from Nov., 1867, to April, 1880, as settlement officer; district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1881; magistrate and collector, and grade, Dec., 1881; 1st grade, April, 1895; officiated as commissioner in 1888.

NEATHAM, A.H.J., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 22nd Feb., 1879.

NEEL, EDMUND, Political Department, India Office.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; India office writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, military department, 1860; assistant précis writer to the secretary of state, 1868-1871; military department, 1871; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; funds department, 1874; assistant secretary in the military department, Aug., 1881; assistant secretary in the political and secret department, 1885.

NEILL, JOHN WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London, and Edinburgh University; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1864; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Jan., 1866; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Central Provinces, July, 1866; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, May, 1870, and acted as secretary to the chief commissioner from June, 1870, to March, 1877, when he was confirmed in the appointment; also acted as inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps and commissioner of excise in 1872, and as inspector-general of education in 1873; commissioner, Nagpur division, June, 1880; acting judicial commissioner, June, 1881, to March, 1882, and again in 1885; fellow of the University of Calcutta, June, 1883; commissioner, Jubbulpore division, Oct., 1883; officiating judicial commissioner, Sept., 1888.

NEILL, LINDSAY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at foreign schools, King's College, London, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1867; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and acted as inspector-general of education in 1874, and as assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, in 1872-74, and in 1875-6; under secretary to government of India, home department, April, 1877; inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Dec., 1877; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, June, 1880; acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, 1877 to 1882, also acting as inspector-general of police and prisons, June-Aug., 1881; acting commissioner, Nagpur division, April, 1882; additional commissioner, Jan., 1883; secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1883; acted as commissioner in the Jubbulpore division in 1883 and 1885.

NELSON, JAMES HENRY, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Madras C.S.—King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1863; acted as small cause court judge of Madura, 1865-67; acting registrar of the high court, Madras, April, 1867; small cause court judge, Kumbakonam, Dec., 1867, to June, 1872; prepared the Madura district manual; from June, 1872, served as civil and sessions judge in Tanjore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, July, 1876, to March, 1880, and afterwards in South Arcot and Chingleput; retired, Nov., 1887.

NESFIELD, JOHN C., M.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—From 2nd Jan., 1867, to May, 1872, served in Bengal as professor, Krishnagarh College, and at the Presidency College; from May, 1872, served in British Burma as director of public instruction, and inspector of schools; transferred to Oudh, March, 1874, and served in the end grade of education officers as director of public instruction; principal, Benares College, May, 1878; inspector of schools, Oudh division, Nov., 1879; author of 'An Essay on the Kanjar Tribe,' 1882, 'On the Results of Primary Education in N.W. Provinces and Oudh,' 1883, and 'On the Thari and Bagsha Tribes,' 1884; 'Brief View of the Caste System of the North-West Provinces and Oudh,' 1885, and 'A Pamphlet on the Project for Establishing a University for North-West Provinces and Oudh,' 1886.

NETHERSOLE, WILLIAM, B.A., LL.M., Bar-
rister-at-law, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Sutton Valence Grammar School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1878, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as cantonment magistrate in 1882, and as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1883; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1884; acting director of agriculture, July, 1884; acting junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept., 1884; from Dec., 1884, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer of Sambalpur, March, 1885.

NEWBERY, FRANCIS MONRO, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 58th native infantry, 13th April, 1859; served in the China campaign of 1860, and was present at Simbo, capture of Tongku and the Jaku forts, and final surrender of Pekin (medal and clasps); from February, 1867, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; city magistrate, Lucknow, March, 1874; on special duty in connection with agricultural meeting and exhibition at Lucknow, Dec., 1881; district judge, 3rd grade, sub. prom., March, 1883; sub-judge, 1st grade, April, 1883; district judge, 2nd grade, Lucknow, May, 1885.

NEWBERY, HENRY JAMES, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1885; retired, April, 1887.

NEWBOLD, BABINGTON BENNETT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford School and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition, 1885.

NEWMAN, JOHN HENRY, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Establishment.—First commission in the Indian medical service, 1867; served in civil employ, in the political agency, Joudpore, from April, 1869; civil surgeon, Ajmere, April, 1879; officiated as agency surgeon and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination, and administrative medical officer in Rajputana in 1884; is also superintendent of jail at Ajmere, and medical officer of the Mhairwarra battalion.

NEWMARCH, FRANCIS W., Military Department, India Office.—Matriculated at Balliol College, Oxford, Jan., 1873; scholar of Corpus Christi College, Oxford, 1873-8; 1st class in classics, moderations, May, 1874; and 1st class in classics, final schools, Dec., 1876; B.A., Feb., 1877; junior clerk, military department, India office, 18th May, 1877; resident clerk, 1885.

NEWMARCH, OLIVER RICHARDSON, C.S.I., Major-General, late B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, March, 1855; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, July, 1857; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, 1871; deputy accountant-general, military department, 1875; accountant-general, military department, April, 1876; also ex-officio deputy secretary to the government of India; secretary to government of India, military department, July, 1886; retired, Nov., 1887; C.S.I., Jan., 1888.

NEWTON, HENRY, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury School, and afterwards at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; judicial assistant to commissioner, Satara, 1854; joint judge and sessions judge, Poona, 1858, and afterwards of the Konkan; acting sub-treasurer, Bombay, July, 1859; acting civil auditor, Aug., 1859; registrar, court of Sudder Dewani, Nov., 1859; acting puisne judge of the Sudder Court, Jan., 1860; member of commission to frame a code of laws for the Parsees, Dec., 1861; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1863; acted as chief justice, Bombay, 1868; retired in 1871.

NEWTON, J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 9th Oct., 1879.

NICHOLL, BERNARD VINCENT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Beaumont College, Windsor, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

NICHOLLS, GEORGE JASPER, LL.B. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Exeter Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and was transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine duty, May, 1874, to May, 1875; acting secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1877; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, Dec., 1877; acting inspector-general of police, July, 1880; small cause court judge, Jubbulpur, Sept., 1880; deputy commissioner, 4th class, March, 1883; from July, 1883, served in the N.W. Provinces as officiating magistrate and collector, 1st grade, and was appointed manager of the Awa State, Oct., 1883; judge, 3rd grade, April, 1885; and grade, Aug., 1887; author of 'The Law of the Central Provinces,' 'Digest of the Circular and Standing Orders of the Chief Commissioner, Central Provinces, 1862-80,' 'An Economic Gazetteer of the Central Provinces,' and contributions to the 'Central Provinces and Imperial Gazetteer.'

NICHOLSON, FRANCIS COHAM, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1869; from March, 1873, served as civil surgeon in Bengal, and also as medical inspector of labourers, and superintendent of labour transport at Goalundo; civil surgeon, Monghyr, Nov., 1876; superintendent of the presidency jail, and resident surgeon of the general hospital, and governor of the workhouse, Jan., 1878; acted as superintendent of the Allpore and Russa jails, 1879 to 1881, and as superintendent of the Campbell medical school and hospital, professor of medical jurisprudence at the medical college, police surgeon, and superintendent of lock hospital, 1879, and again in 1882; officiating surgeon superintendent, presidency general hospital, 1881; surgeon-major, Oct., 1881; civil surgeon, Darjeeling, Feb., 1884;
civil surgeon, Chittagong, March, 1886, and Moorshedabad, March, 1887.

NICHOLSON, FREDERICK AUGUSTUS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal Medical College, Epsom, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1869, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty with the selection of forest reserves, Nov., 1879; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, July, 1883; principal assistant to the collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, Feb., 1885; acting secretary, board of revenue, Sept.–Nov., 1885; acting collector and magistrate, March, 1888.

NICHOLSON, WILLIAM GUSTAVUS, Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission as lieutenant, March, 1865; arrived in India, Dec., 1871; joined the public works department, Feb., 1872, as assistant engineer, Hyderabad, but was shortly afterwards transferred to the Punjab irrigation branch; transferred to military works branch, 1873; executive engineer, March, 1876; served in the Afghan war, 1878–80, and was present at the actions of Shutargarh and Lataband, and march from Kabul to relief of Kandahar (medal and 3 clasps, bronze star, brevet of major); secretary to defence committee, April, 1882; served in Egyptian expedition, 1882, including battle of Tel-el-Kebir (medal and clasp, bronze star, 4th class Osmanieh); ex-officio assistant adjutant-general, 1885; superintending engineer, March, 1886.

NILKANTO SIRCAR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed, under the native civil service rules, assistant magistrate and collector on probation, June, 1886; confirmed, Aug., 1887.

NISBET, ROBERT PARRY, C.I.E., Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from Aug., 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Nov., 1876; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, April, 1885, Rawal Pindi; officiated as commissioner and superintendent in the Delhi, Derajat, and Rawal Pindi divisions, 1884–86; commissioner, Rawal Pindi, Nov., 1886.

NOBLE, CHARLES SIMEON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, Bengal native infantry, 14th Nov., 1858; from April, 1862, to June, 1866, served in the police department, Oudh, as assistant district superintendent, officiating assistant inspector-general, and district superintendent; from June, 1866, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate of Fyzabad, officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, and officiating deputy commissioner; secretary to committee appointed to conduct the agricultural meeting, Lucknow, Aug., 1880; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1883; 2nd grade, April, 1886, and 1st grade, Feb., 1888.

NOLAN, PHILIP, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Stonyhurst School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; on special duty at Darjeeling, Aug., 1875, and again, in the stamp and stationery office, Nov., 1879; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Shahabad, Sept., 1884; officiating secretary, board of revenue, March, 1885; secretary, government of Bengal, general, revenue, and statistical department, March, 1887.

NORMAN, SIR HENRY WYLIE, G.C.B., G.C.M.G., C.I.E., B.S.C.—Ensign in Bengal Army, March, 1844; served throughout the Punjab campaign in 1848–49, including passage of the Chenab, action of Sordoolapore, battles of Chilianwalla and Goojerat, and pursuit of the Sikhs and Afghans; brigade major and assistant adjutant-general in various expeditions on the Peshawur frontier in the years 1850–1854; commanded a detachment in Sonthal campaign, 1855; served throughout the mutiny, 1857–8, as assistant or deputy adjutant-general, and the greater part of the time as adjutant-general to the army in the field; served at the siege of Delhi and in all the actions under Greathed and Grant, from Delhi to Lucknow; present at the relief of Lucknow, the operations at Cawnpore, the action at Khodagunge, and the re-occupation of Futtehghur; at the siege and capture of Lucknow, March, 1858; served in the campaigns in Rohilkund and in Oudh, in 1858–9, including several actions; in 1860, appointed assistant military secretary at the Horse Guards; secretary to the government of India military department, 1862–70; in 1870, appointed member of the council of the governor-general of India and member of the council of the secretary of state for India, from 1878, to Nov., 1883, when he was appointed governor of Jamaica; governor of Queensland, Nov., 1888.

NORMAN, THOMAS, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; retired, Dec., 1887.

NORRIS, JOHN FREEMAN, Calcutta High Court.—Called to the bar (Inner Temple), 17th November, 1865; appointed one of Her Majesty's counsel, January, 1882; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 16th May, 1882.

NORTHBROOK (EARL OF), RIGHT HON. THOMAS GEORGE BARING, G.C.S.I., D.C.L.—Born 1826; educated at Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated (and class in classics) in 1846; was successively private secretary to Mr. Labouchere at the board of trade, to Sir George Grey at the home office, to Sir Charles Wood at the India board, and at the admiralty till 1857; sat in the House of Commons as member for Penryn and Falmouth, 1857 to 1866; was a lord of the admiralty, May, 1857, to Feb., 1858; under-secretary of state for India, June, 1859, to Jan., 1861; under-secretary for war, Jan., 1861; again under-secretary for India, July, 1861, to April, 1864; under-secretary for home affairs, 1864 to 1866; secretary to the admiralty, 1866; succeeded as 2nd baron in the same year; again under-secretary for war, 1868 to 1872; viceroy and governor-general of India, Feb., 1872, to Feb., 1876; G.C.S.I., May, 1872; created Vis-
count Baring, and Earl of Northbrook, 1876; first lord of the admiralty, 1880, to June, 1885; high commissioner on a special mission to Egypt, Aug., 1884; a royal commissioner for the London Exhibition of 1886.

NORTON, DAVID, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, June, 1880; transferred for service in Burma as deputy commissioner, 1887.

NUGENT, JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Institution School, Liverpool, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant educational inspector; appointed under secretary to government of Bombay in the judicial, political, and educational departments, and secretary to the legislative council, Feb., 1875; also acted on several occasions as secretary in the revenue, financial, and general departments, as collector of salt revenue, July, 1878, and as secretary in the political, secret, judicial, educational, and Persian departments, Feb.-March, 1879; municipal commissioner, Bombay, Feb., 1880; acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Satara, May-June, 1881; from June, 1881, acted as secretary to government in revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Dec., 1882; also acted as chief secretary to government in 1884 and 1885; president of the central committee for vernacular departmental examinations; chief secretary to government, Aug., 1887.

NUGENT, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Stonyhurst College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1872, and served in Bengal, and from Jan., 1880, in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Aug., 1885; senior-assistant commissioner, Kumaon, Jan., 1887; acting superintendent Dehra Dun, May, 1888.

NUNDA KRISHNA BOSE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Employed in the education department from Aug., 1878; appointed under the native civil service rules, and served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, from Jan., 1880, as assistant magistrate and collector on probation, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed in his appointment in the civil service, Sept., 1881.

NURSEY, J. F., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 26th July, 1871; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878; attached to financial department.

OAKESHOTT, JONATHAN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at City of London School, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, March, 1888.

OBARD, ROBERT, Bengal C.S. (Berar Administration).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1872; from 7th Jan., 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; transferred for special famine duty in the Madras presidency, Sept., 1877, to July, 1878; acted as judge of the small cause court, and superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, Jubulpore, in 1882; special assistant commissioner, Berar administration, April, 1887.

O'BEIRNE, HUGH JAMES, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884. Arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1887, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

O'BRIEN, EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Colomba's College, Winchester College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, March-Dec., 1871; promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; 1st grade, Feb., 1887; author of a glossary of the Multani language, and a report on the settlement of the Muzaffargarh district.

O'BRIEN, PETER HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Malvern College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1882.

O'CALLAGHAN, FRANCIS L., C.S.I., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, June, 1862, as assistant engineer, Central Provinces; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to the railway branch, 1870; Nagpur and Raipur railway survey, March, 1871; engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, June, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Punjab northern railway, Pindi-Peshawur section, Nov., 1879; superintending engineer, Jan., 1880; C.I.E., 1883; appointed to superintend assistant engineers on practical training in England, Nov., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Sind Sagar railway surveys, Dec., 1884; engineer-in-chief, Bolan railway, June, 1885; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; engineer-in-chief, Kwaja-Amran railway survey, Feb., 1887; and of Sind Pishin railway, May, 1887; C.S.I., Jan., 1888.

O'CALLAGHAN, I., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1873; traffic superintendent Rajputana state railway, Dec., 1874; 1st class, traffic department, state railways, Jan., 1882; on special duty with railway conference, Calcutta, Jan.-March, 1884; general traffic manager, Rajputana-Malwa railway system; class 1, grade 2, April, 1887.

O'CONNOR, J. E., Financial Department, Government of India.—Registrar, department of agriculture and commerce, June, 1873; assistant secretary in statistical branch of department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Feb., 1875; assistant secretary, department of finance and commerce, and in 2nd class of financial department, Dec., 1879; deputed on special duty in
connection with the International Exhibition at Melbourne, July, 1880, to Feb., 1881.

O'DONNELL, CHARLES JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Ignatius' College, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Oct., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, June, 1874; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1886; on special duty under financial department of Bengal government, Nov., 1887.

O'DWYER, MICHAEL FRANCIS, Bengal, C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Stanislaus College, Tullamore, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, Nov. 19, 1885, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Punjab; officiating deputy commissioner, Shakpur, July, 1888.

O'FARRELL, HORACE HANDLEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant, acting additional sessions judge, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge.

OGILVIE, GEORGE MACARTNEY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; promoted to deputy commissioner, and class, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Nov., 1886; officiating commissioner and superintendent Deragat division, June, 1886.

O'KINEALY, JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Nov., 1862, to Sept., 1874, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of survey, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate, and deputy collector and officiating magistrate and collector; appointed additional sessions judge of Bhagulpore, in addition to his other duties, Sept., 1874, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, and grade, May, 1875; officiating secretary, government of India, home department, Dec., 1877; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Jan., 1878; lieutenant-governor's council, Feb. to Sept., 1880; officiating judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1st Jan., 1882, and judge, Feb., 1883; president of the board of examiners, April, 1885.

OLDFIELD, RICHARD CHARLES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1848; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1848; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed in charge of the office of assistant superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Nov., 1855, and appointed assistant secretary to government, and assistant accountant, N.W. Provinces, March, 1856; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, March, 1864; on special duty at Cawnpore for enquiring into the case of the Dewan of Chirkhari, Feb., 1866; on special duty under the public works department, Feb., 1866; on special duty for investigating the charges brought against Mir Badshah, Munshi of Deoband, March, 1869; from May, 1869, served in the judicial department, and was appointed civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872, and subsequently of Allahabad; additional judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1874; puisne judge, high court, Nov., 1882; retired, March, 1887.

OLDHAM, FRANCIS GEORGE, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, Dec., 1858; joined the public works department, Feb., 1873, as officiating deputy controller of accounts, Calcutta; controller of accounts, Hyderabad, April, 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, March, 1878, and subsequently at Calcutta, 1879; Central India, 1882; examiner of telegraph accounts, 1883; examiner of accounts, Allahabad, Aug., 1885; examiner, and class, in the accounts establishment, Sept., 1886; examiner of accounts, military works, Jan., 1887.

OLDHAM, WILLIAM BENJAMIN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kingstown Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1865; served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1879, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; on famine relief duty, Oct., 1866, and again March, 1874, and at Bellary, March, 1877, to Feb., 1879; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, April, 1886.

OLIPHANT, HENRY LAURENCE, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; from July, 1859, served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner; judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, April, 1877; retired, Oct., 1885.

OLIPHANT, JOHN S., Funds Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 22nd June, 1853; junior clerk, minuting branch, 1855; private secretary to chairman and deputy chairman, 1857-58; India office, secretariat department, 1859; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1863 to 1865; senior clerk, funds department, April, 1866; assistant secretary, military department, 1872, but continued doing duty in funds department; also agent to administrators-general of India, 1877; acting judicial and public secretary for four months, 1879; director of funds, 22nd July, 1879.

OLLIVANT, ALFRED, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department (North-Western Provinces).—Arrived in India as ensign, 20th April, 1857; medal for services during mutiny, 1857; appointed to Jhansi military police, July, 1858; from May, 1861, served as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, July, 1862; deputy inspector-general, June, 1865; senior deputy inspector-general, May, 1866; officiated as inspector-general, Aug.-Nov., 1867.

OLLIVANT, EDWARD CHARLES KAYLL, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College;
appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant agent in special charge of Sachin state, and was in charge of office of district superintendent of police, Sept.–Oct., 1875; acting junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Surat, April, 1878; on special duty at Baroda in connection with estate of Mir Zulfikar Ali, Jan., 1879; assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration in Sind, and Sindhi translator to government, Sept., 1880; also deputy superintendent of census in Sind, Jan., 1881; municipal commissioner for Bombay, May, 1881; on special duty in England in connection with the municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug-Nov., 1883; C.I.E., May, 1888.

OMMANNEY, EDWARD LACON, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 12th June, 1855; assistant to commissioner in charge of ex-king of Delhi and state prisoners, Sept., 1857; took ex-king of Delhi and family to Rangoon, and served in Pegu commission, Oct., 1858, to April, 1859; served subsequently in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to commissioners of Derajat and Pesha-wur, and deputy commissioner; on special duty in Bengal, March, 1871, and again, April, 1871, at Patna, to give evidence in case of Queen v. Amir Khan; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Derajat, Dec., 1883.

OMMANNEY, HENRY TRAVERS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, railway magistrate, cantonment magistrate, acting junior collector and magistrate, acting political agent, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Oct., 1882; acting under secretary to government revenue, financial and general departments, April, 1886; first assistant collector, April, 1888; acting inspector-general of police, May, 1888.

OPPERT, GUSTAV, Ph.D. (Halle), Education Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras education department from 14th Nov., 1872, as professor of Sanscrit, Presidency College, and curator of Government Oriental Manuscript Library; fellow of Madras University, April, 1873; Telugu translator to government, Sept., 1878; 3rd class of education department, March, 1882; officiating principal of Presidency College from May, 1885.

ORR, JAMES PETER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Hurstpierpoint, and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1886.

ORR, JOHN HENRY, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., C.B., late Madras Medical Service.—Educated at the University of Edinburgh; M.D. of the Royal College of Physicians, and licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh; arrived in India as assistant surgeon on the Madras establishment, May, 1837; was employed in H.H. the Nizam's service, and subsequently with Hyderabad contingent, Jan., 1842, to Oct., 1862; during this period took part in various military operations, including the siege of Darur, 1851, and various engagements with the insurgent Rohillas; served through the campaign in Malwa in 1857, under Brigadier-General Sir C. Stewart, K.C.B., and was present at various actions; was staff surgeon to the Hyderabad contingent during the campaign in Central India in 1858, under General Sir Hugh Rose, G.C.B.; medal and clasp, C.B., and hon. surgeon to the Queen; garrison surgeon of Bangalore, and Fort St. George, Oct., 1862, to Feb., 1863; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, with the Nagpore force, Feb., 1863, to March, 1865, and afterwards in Mysore and the ceded districts; retired, Feb., 1870; was president of the Bangalore cantonment and Pettah municipal boards, April, 1871, to March, 1881.

ORR, J. W., M.A. (Dublin), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 7th May, 1860, as acting deputy clerk of the crown, clerk to the chief justice, acting prothonotary and ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, commissioner for taking affidavits and sealer of the high court, registrar of joint stock companies, and clerk of insolvent court; confirmed in appointment of prothonotary and ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, from Feb., 1866.

OTTLEY, JOHN WALTER, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission as lieutenant, Jan., 1864; arrived in India, Nov., 1868; joined the public works department, Feb., 1870, as assistant engineer, Bari Doab canal; assistant to chief engineer for irrigation, Punjab, April, 1870; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; personal assistant to supervising engineer, Bari Doab Canal, April, 1872; assistant to chief engineer for irrigation, Bengal, Feb., 1874; re-transferred to Punjab, irrigation branch, June, 1875; assistant secretary, irrigation branch, Punjab, July, 1881; superintendent of works, Bari Doab circle, April, 1882; supervising engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1884; and class, March, 1886.

OWEN, E., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

OWENS, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd Aug., 1873.

OXENHAM, ROBERT G., M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1863, and served till Nov., 1874, as professor of English literature at the Deccan College, Poona, and subsequently as principal of the college, and professor of moral philosophy; also held acting appointments for various periods at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, as professor of English literature and history, as principal and professor of logic and moral philosophy, and as professor of history and political economy.

OZANNE, EDWARD CHARLES, M.R.A.C., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; on famine relief duty in Tirhoot, March–Oct., 1874, in Mysore, Oct., 1877, and in Kathiawar, March, 1879; on duty in England at the Royal Agricultural College at Cirencester, Sept., 1882; director of agriculture in the Bombay Presidency, July, 1883; acting survey and settlement commissioner, Dec., 1886.

PAGE, WILLIAM HUMPHREY, Bengal C.S.—
Educated at Nottingham Grammar School, and Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating inspector-general of registration, Aug., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; district and sessions judge, and grade, Oct., 1885; district and sessions judge, Dacca, April, 1887.

PAKEMAN, THOS. C., Accounts Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 16th Oct., 1851; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, July, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872.

PALLE CHENTSAI RAO PANTULU, C.I.E., superintendent of stamps and stationery, Madras.—Served from Feb., 1851, in various subordinate posts in the judicial and revenue departments, Madras; from July, 1859, to May, 1872, served as deputy collector, and as special assistant to the Inam commissioner, also as deputy collector of salt revenue, and was on special duty under the collector of Godavari, Aug.–Dec., 1870; sheristadar, board of revenue, May, 1872; fellow of the Madras University, Nov., 1875; superintendent of stamps and stationery, July, 1882; member of the draft tenancy bill committee, July, 1885, C.I.E., Feb., 1887; additional member of the legislative council of governor of Madras, July, 1887.

PALMER, ELWIN MITFORD, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, Nov., 1871; assistant to accountant-general, British Burma, Dec., 1873; transferred to Bombay, April, 1876; assistant to comptroller-general, Oct., 1878; served under the Egyptian government, Dec., 1878, to April, 1879; from Jan., 1880, served in Madras as officiating assistant accountant-general, and officiating deputy accountant-general; comptroller, Hyderabad, Dec., 1882; 4th class of financial department, Dec., 1882; assistant-accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, Nov., 1884; assistant comptroller-general, Dec., 1884; transferred for service under Egyptian Government, Aug., 1885.

PARGITER, FREDERICK EDEN, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at College School, Taunton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1875; served as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, settlement officer in Chittagong, and commissioner of the Sunderbunds; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, Jan., 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1887; has also acted as district and sessions judge; author of 'Revenue History of the Sunderbunds from 1765 to 1870.'

PARKER, EDWIN WOODALL, Punjab Administration.—From 20th Oct., 1863, served in the Punjab as extra assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and officiating judicial assistant; extra judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; officiated as district judge, and as divisional judge, Nov., 1885; officiating inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, &c., Jan., 1886; and again April–May, 1887; on special duty with the public service commission, Dec., 1886, to April, 1887; district judge, Simla, May, 1887, to Jan., 1888; on special duty at Lahore, in connection with 'Larpent enquiry,' and again in connection with assessment of income tax, March, 1888; author of 'Outlines of the Constitutional Law of India,' and 'Outlines of Jurisprudence.'

PARKER, GEORGE ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Uppingham School, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Madura, March, 1878, and district and sessions judge, April, 1882, in the district of Kurnool, and subsequently in South Tanjore; officiating judge of the high court, Madras, July, 1885; judge of the high court, Dec., 1886.

PARKER, JOSEPH, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College; East India House writer, old establishment, 9th July, 1851; junior clerk, marine department, Aug., 1858; store department, 1860; senior clerk, Nov., 1866.

PARKER, WILLIAM HENRY, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed as temporary assistant engineer, 24th Aug., 1860; and served in the N.W. Provinces and Central India, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, April, 1872; from Nov., 1873, served in the railway branch, and was employed on the Western Rajputana and Indus Valley state railways; transferred to Bengal, June, 1881, and employed temporarily on Central Bengal railway as superintending engineer, and subsequently on Nagpore railway surveys as engineer-in-chief; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, Bengal, railway branch, July-Oct., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Godra-Rutlam railway survey; and of Patiala Bhatinda railway survey, Oct., 1887.

PARKER, WILLIAM JACKSON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1858; from July, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty with H.H. the Raja of Sirmoor, Dec., 1875, at Calcutta, and again, Dec., 1876, at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi; district judge, and grade, Nov., 1884; officiating divisional judge, Nov., 1885; promoted to be deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Sept., 1887.

PARRATT, CHARLES, Accountant-General's Department, India Office.—Appointed to the London office, Indo-European Telegraph Department as Clerk, 1881; transferred to India office, 1 Jan., 1889.

PARROTT, BENJAMIN ALEXANDER NAPIER, Captain, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, H.M. 76th regiment, July, 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1868; served in the Lushai expedition, 1871; from April, 1872, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, assistant town magistrate, and settlement, and boundary officer; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1886; transferred to Upper Burma, June, 1886.

PARRY, R., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 14th Jan., 1865; served as head-master, Krishnaghur College, and Hooghly College, professor at Hooghly College (March, 1868), and at Presidency College (Sept., 1874); inspector of schools (temporary), and officiating principal, Dacca College; 3rd class, education
department, Aug., 1877; professor, Patna College, June, 1884.

PARSONS, FRANCIS COTTON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Amersham Hall School, Reading, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed member of the Madras civil service, after open competition of 1886.

PARSONS, HENRY JAMES (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1867, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant judge, and judge and sessions judge, and acted as judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, in 1881-82; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Thana, Jan., 1884; 1st grade judge, Dharwar, Sept., 1885; acting judicial commissioner and judge of Sadar court, Sind, April, 1887, judge of high court, Nov., 1887.

PARSONS, JAMES EDMUND BACON, Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1849; from Feb., 1856, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 1st class, May, 1876; retired, Nov., 1885.

PARTIDGE, JOHN GEORGE DENMAN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Sherborne, and at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Madras, 15th Jan., 1887, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to magistrate and collector.

PARTIDGE, WILLIAM REGINALD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, Sherborne School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1831; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1883, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade; acting under secretary to Government, Feb., 1888.

PATEKI SRINIVASA RAO, Dewan Bahadur, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in the judicial department from 16th Dec., 1844, as gumastah, Foujdarli translator, district munisif, and principal suhr amin; magistrate of police, Madras, May, 1875; fellow of Madras University, Nov., 1875; small cause court judge, Madras, April, 1880; board of examiners, 11th Jan., 1882.

PATTERSON, ALEXANDER BLEAKLEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Belfast Royal Academical Institute, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces from July, 1864, as assistant magistrate and collector; from June, 1869, to April, 1883, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1882; on special duty in the settlement department, Dec., 1882; magistrate and collector, and grade, Allahabad, Dec., 1883; 1st grade, May, 1886; acting commissioner of Northern India salt revenue, Agra, June, 1885.

PATTLE, A. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

PAUL, ALFRED WALLIS, B.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; on special settlement and survey duty, Aug., 1878, and again, Nov., 1881; services placed temporarily at the disposal of the public works department, Nov., 1883; officiating inspector-general of registration, June, 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1884; secretary to the central examination committee, Calcutta, Dec., 1884; on special duty under foreign department, government of India, in connection with the Tibet Mission, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, and grade, Aug., 1887; C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

PAUL, SIR GREGORY CHARLES, B.A., K.C.I.E.—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1862-78; advocate-general, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1878; additional member, governor-general's council, 1878-82; legislative council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, March, 1885.

PEACOCK, RIGHT HON. SIR BARNES, KNIGHT.—Was called to the bar at the Inner Temple, and practised on the Home Circuit; queen's counsel, 1850; legal member of the council of the governor-general of India, June, 1852; was also president of the Indian law commission, 1852-54; chief justice of the Supreme Court, Calcutta, and vice-president of the legislative council of India, 1859, and chief justice of the High Court of Judicature, Calcutta, on its establishment in 1862; resigned, 1870, and was sworn a privy councillor; member of the judicial committee of the privy council, June, 1872.

PEACOCK, FREDERICK BARNES (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed registrar, high court, May, 1864; president of a committee to report on the King of Oudh's affairs; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1870; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1871; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1873; commissioner, Dacca division, April, 1878, and of the Presidency division, May, 1881; president of a committee on the transport and storage of inflammable oils, July, 1879, and of committees on railway police, in 1881 and 1882; chief secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointments departments, March, 1883; officiating member, board of revenue, Sept., 1884; member of the public service commission, Dec., 1886; member of board of revenue, Aug., 1887.

PEACOCK, HENRY PHIPSON, Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal cavalry, Sept., 1856; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Lucknow (medal); served subsequently with the governor-general's body guard; acted as agent to the governor-general with King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, in 1868, and on several occasions subsequently; political agent, Moorshedabad, 1878; political agent, Ulwar, Rajputana, 1882; graded as political agent, and class; acting resident, W. Rajputana, March, 1886; resident at Jeypore and officiating agent to the governor-general in Central India, 1888.

PEARS, SIR THOMAS T., K.C.B., Major-General, Madras Engineers, retired.—Educated at Addiscombe and Chatham; 1st commission, lieutenant, Madras Engineers, 16th June, 1825;
major; 1st Aug., 1854; lieutenant-colonel, May, 1858; major-general, Aug., 1861; served as superintending engineer with the Doob field force, 1828-31, and also at Jaulna, and as civil engineer Malabar and Kanara; commandant Madras sappers and miners, 1838-43; consulting engineer for railways, 1851-57; chief engineer, Mysore, 1860; served in the Kurnool campaign in 1839, and was present at the action of Zore-pore; with the expedition to China from April, 1840, to the close of the war (medal and C.B.); at capture of Chusan, Chinbae, Ningpo, Yuyao, Tsekee, Chapoo, Woosung, Shanghai, Nankin, and Ching Keangfoo; retired, Feb., 1861; was military secretary at the India office, London, from July, 1861, to Jan., 1877; K.C.B., 1871.

PEARSE, HERBERT GEORGE (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Dec., 1886; judge small cause court, Allahabad, Dec., 1887.

PEARSON, CHARLES, M.A., late Educational Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab educational department from March, 1861, as professor and principal, Agra College; inspector of schools, Rawal Pindi circle, Nov., 1865; 2nd grade, educational department, April, 1870; officiating director of public instruction in 1873, 1876, and 1883; on special duty with education commission, 1882; retired, March, 1886.

PEARSON, FRANCIS BOYLE, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Proprietary School, Islington, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1840; attached to the N.W. Provinces; served in various districts in the grades of assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector, and civil and sessions judge; also as settlement officer, Jullundur, 1849-50; and as registrar to the court of Sudder Dewani and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, 1850-53; judge of Sudder Dewani and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, 1862-66; puisne judge, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1866-81; retired March, 1881.

PEAT, WALTER SCOTT, Lieutenant-Colonel—1st commission, Bombay cavalry, 1859; from Feb., 1883, acted as cantonment magistrate, Mhow; and assistant agent to the governor-general, Baroda, and cantonment magistrate, May, 1885; cantonment magistrate, Mhow, May, 1887.

PEDLER, A., F.I.C., F.C.S. (London and Berlin), Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed to the education department, 2nd Jan., 1873; arrived 8th May, 1873, and served in the 3rd class of the department as professor of agricultural chemistry, Presidency College; on special duty, eclipse expedition, March, 1875; officiating principal, Presidency College, Aug., 1883; also officiating meteorological reporter to government of Bengal, and officiating secretary to the central committee for management of the Economic Museum, 1884; class 2 of educational department, June, 1887.

PEET, HENRY JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Assam Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Oct., 1860; was employed under the military department till Oct., 1866, including service in the Bhutan Campaign, 1864-65; from Oct., 1866, served as assistant commissioner in Assam; assistant political officer in the Dafla expedition, 1874-75; officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1875; officiating secretary, Jan.; 1876; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1879; acting inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, and commissioner of excise, and superintendent of stamps, June, 1881, to Feb., 1882; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, May, 1888.

PEILE, Sir James Braithwaite, M.A., K.C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 8th Oct., 1856, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty, alienation department, Nov., 1858; on special duty for inquiry into claims of Thakurs of Bhavnagar on account of land and sea customs, May, 1859; especially appointed to inquire into condition of Talukdars, Ahmedabad, Jan., 1860; alienation settlement officer, Gujerat, April, 1861; assistant to revenue commissioner, Dec., 1861; under secretary to government of Bombay, revenue department, April, 1862; on special duty for carrying out provisions of bill for relief of the Talukdars, Ahmedabad, Dec., 1862; commissioner for revising subordinate civil establishments, April, 1866; registrar-general of assurances, July, 1866; director of public instruction, April, 1869; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, May-Oct., 1872; acting political agent, Kathiawar, Jan., 1873; on duty at Delhi in connection with Imperial Assemblage, Dec., 1876; acting commissioner in Sind, June, 1878; on special duty as member of famine commission, Aug., 1878, to March, 1879; acting secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, March, 1879; from April, 1879, served as secretary in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and acted as chief secretary; on special duty on famine commission in England, Oct., 1879, to July, 1880; on special duty in India, Nov.-Dec., 1880, and in June, 1881, at Simla; member of council, Bombay, Dec., 1882; acted as governor and president in council in March, 1885; temporary member of governor-general's council, October, 1886; retired, Nov., 1887; member of council of India, 13th Nov., 1887; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1888.

PELLY, Sir Lewis, Lieut.-General, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., M.P., Bombay Staff Corps.—First commission, Bombay infantry, 1840; posted to the 17th N.I.; served as assistant resident, Baroda, and prosecuted the Khutput enquiries before the commission under Sir James Outram in 1851; deputy collector in Scinde, Dec., 1853; and assistant commissioner for jaghirs, in Scinde, June, 1855; personal assistant to the commissioner, 1856; served in the Persian expedition as A.D.C. to General Jacob, and political secretary to Sir Jas. Outram (medal); brigade-major, Scinde frontier force, Dec., 1858; deputy magistrate, Kurrachee, June, 1859; secretary of legation, Persia, 1859; chargé-d' affaires, Persia, 1860; served on a special mission through Persia, Herat, Afghanistan, and Beloochistan, in 1860 and 1861; on special duty at Calcutta, with Lord Canning, 1861; on a mission to the Comoro Islands, 1861; political
agent at Zanzibar, 1861-62; political resident in the Persian gulf, with local rank of lieutenant-colonel in Persia, from 1862 to 1873, during which period he was employed on various missions and negotiations with Arab chiefs in Arabia, and on the shores of the Persian Gulf, including a visit to the capital of the Wahabeees, in 1865, and was associated with Sir Bartle Frere on an anti-slavery mission to the east coast of Africa and Arabia, in 1872 and 1873; agent to the governor-general, and chief commissioner, Rajputana, 1873 to 1878, and was deputed as special commissioner to Baroda in 1874, when he arrested the Guicowar, and took charge of the state; on special duty with the government of India in 1876; was appointed envoy extraordinary and plenipotentiary for Afghan affairs; K.C.S.I., June, 1874; K.C.B., Aug., 1877; has been a member of the council of the Royal Geographical Society, and of the Asiatic Society; author of a pamphlet on 'Our North-West Frontier,' 1858, 'Views and Opinions of General Jacob,' 'The Miracle Play of Hasan and Husein, collected from Oral Tradition,' 1879; was elected conservative member for North Hackney, Nov., 1885, and was re-elected in 1886.
