RHIND, ROBERT HUNTER, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed proba-

tioner by the secretary of state, June, 1862; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1862; served as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and officiating superintendent of works on the Upper Godavary works till Aug., 1872, when he was transferred to Bengal, and served in the Orissa, Sone, and South-Western circles; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1873; superintending engineer, 2nd class, temporary, March, 1886, permanent, Nov., 1886.

RIBBENTROP, B., Forest Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state for India as an assistant conservator of forests, Dec., 1866; conservator of forests, Burma, Oct., 1876; and grade conservator, Sept., 1882; transferred to Punjab, 1883; officiating inspector-general of forests, Feb., 1884; author of 'Hints on Arboriculture.'

RICE, WILLIAM GEORGE LEWIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oscott College, and Jesus College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; transferred to Burma, Feb., 1886, as assistant commissioner.

RICE, WILLIAM ROCHE, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service, Nov., 1856; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1857; was employed under the military department, including service during the Mutiny, at Indore (medal); civil assistant surgeon, Central Provinces, June, 1859; civil surgeon, Jubbulpore, May, 1871; acting assistant to sanitary commission, Central Provinces, July, 1872; superintendent, central jail, Jubbulpore, April, 1873; surgeon-major, Nov., 1876; civil surgeon and in medical charge of central jail, school of industry, and lunatic asylum, and superintendent, meteorological observatory, Jubbulpore, July, 1879; brigade surgeon, April, 1884; officiating inspector-general of civil hospitals, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1887.

RICHARDSON, JOHN, Brigade-Surgeon, M.B., M.A., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 23rd Feb., 1860, and was employed under the military department up to 1866, including service with the Bhootan field force (medal and clasp); from April, 1866, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and officiated as superintendent of the central and district jails at Agra, Farakhabad, and Allahabad; superintendent of vaccination, March, 1867; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, July, 1874; deputy sanitary commissioner and superintendent of vaccination, 3rd circle, Jan., 1879; sanitary commissioner, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Aug., 1886.

RICHARDSON, THOMAS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Brighton College, Cheltenham College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1886, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

RICHEY, JAMES BELLOT, C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1850; arrived 7th Dec., 1856, and served as assistant collector and
magistrate, educational inspector, assistant revenue commissioner, officiating under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, talukdari settlement officer, acting collector and magistrate, and assistant to the agent and special commissioner at Baroda; on special duty in connection with the disturbances in the Ahmednagar and Poona districts, July, 1875; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, Jan., 1879; senior collector, May, 1880; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, May, 1881; on special duty at Kharghadha, Dec., 1883, and Feb., 1884, and at Baroda, Jan., 1884; acting and grade commissioner of customs, March, 1884; acting member of council, Bombay, March, 1885, and again, Oct., 1886; chief secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, educational, and separate departments, May, 1885; confirmed as member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1887.

RICKETTS, GEORGE H. M., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1847; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and as assistant to the governor-general's agent, S.W. frontier; from 1853, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and from 1858 in the N.W. Provinces as magistrate and collector, and civil and sessions judge; C.B. for service in the Punjab in 1857, and medal for service with the troops; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1873; junior member, board of revenue, 1878; retired, 1879.

RICKETTS, MONTAGUE POYNTZ, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, 2nd March, 1855; served in the Central Provinces from Sept., 1859, as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, Aug., 1862; deputy commissioner, May, 1867; acting inspector-general of police, Nagpur, in 1876-77; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1880; acting commissioner of the Jubbulpore and Nagpur divisions successively, Dec., 1882, to Nov., 1883; additional commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov., 1883; acting commissioner for various divisions from 1884 to 1888.

RIDDELL, ROBERT VANSITTART, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Mint Department, Calcutta.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1858; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1859; arrived in India, March, 1861; from Aug., 1862, served in the topographical survey of India as military assistant, and was employed in Gwalior and Central India, and in the Khasi and Garo Hills; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1867; assistant surveyor-general with charge of the mathematical instrument department and workshops, and of the lithographic branch, Calcutta, Oct., 1876; acted as mint master at Calcutta, July-Oct., 1881, and at Bombay, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883; appointed mint master, Calcutta, Jan., 1884.

RIDGWAY, SIR JOSEPH WEST, Lieut.-Col., K.C.S.I., C.B., late Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Dec., 1860; on civil employ from May, 1868, in the Central India and Rajputana agencies; attache, foreign department, government of India, 1873; assistant agent to governor-general in Rajputana, 1875; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, Aug., 1876; political agent, 3rd class, Aug., 1876; on special political duty with the field force in Afghanistan, under General Sir F. Roberts, 1880, and was present at the action of Saidebad; accompanied General Roberts' force in the march from Kabul to Kandahar, and was present at the battle of Kandahar, Sept., 1880 (medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet lieutenant-colonel); from Sept., 1880, served in the secretariat of the foreign department, and was appointed assistant secretary, Nov., 1880, junior under-secretary, Dec., 1881; and officiated as under-secretary in 1880, 1882, and 1883; from Aug., 1884, served as assistant with the commission for the delimitation of the Afghan frontier, and was appointed her Majesty's commissioner for this purpose, Sept., 1885; returned to Europe, 1887, and was appointed under secretary for Ireland.

RIGHY, VANS, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, Feb., 1856, and served in the Central Provinces, Punjab, and Bengal; Nizam's state railway surveys, Nov., 1869; executive engineer, March, 1871; on special duty, Nalhati state railway, Oct., 1874; from Jan., 1875, was employed on Tirhoot state railway, and was appointed manager and superintendent of way and works, Tirhoot and Patna Gya state railways, March, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, Feb., 1881; transferred to superior revenue establishment, 1st class, 3rd grade, Oct., 1882; superintendent of way and works, N.W. railway, 1886.

RILEY, H. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 3rd April, 1882.

RIPON (MARQUESS OF), THE RIGHT HON. GEORGE FREDERICK SAMUEL ROBINSON, K.G., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., D.C.L.—Born 24th Oct., 1827; attached to a special mission to Brussels, 1849; sat in the House of Commons (as Viscount Goderich), as member for Hull, 1852 to 1853; for Huddersfield, 1853 to 1857, and for the West Riding of Yorkshire, 1857 to 1859, in which year he succeeded to the Upper House; under secretary for war, June, 1859; president of the royal geographical society, 1860; under-secretary for India, Jan.-July, 1861; sworn a privy councillor, April, 1863; lord high steward of Hull, Oct., 1863; secretary for war, April, 1863, to Feb., 1866; secretary of state for India, Feb.-July, 1866; lord president of the council, Dec., 1868, to Aug., 1873; K.G., 1869; chairman of the joint high commission which arranged the treaty of Washington, 1871; Viceroy and governor-general of India, 8th June, 1880, in which office he was succeeded by the Earl of Dufferin, in Dec., 1884; honorary D.C.L. of Oxford, 1870; created Marquis of Ripon, June, 1871; grand master of the Freemasons of England, 1870 to 1874; president of the Yorkshire College, Leeds, 1882; is a magistrate and deputy-lieutenant for the north and west ridings of Yorkshire, and for the county of Lincoln; was a royal commissioner for the London Exhibition of 1886; first lord of the admiralty, Feb.-Aug., 1886.

RISLEY, HERBERT HOPE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1873; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, Nov., 1876; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Oct., 1877; under secretary, revenue and
general departments, Jan., 1878; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1879; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1880; served temporarily under railway branch, public works department, on special duty, Dec., 1882; superintendent of survey of Ghatwali and other service tenures in Manbhoom, Feb., 1884; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Nov., 1884; employed on the special duty of compiling statistics relating to the castes and occupations of the people of Bengal, Jan., 1885; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, April, 1886.

RITCHIE, JOHN GERALD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1887; has also officiated as magistrate and collector and inspector-general of registration.

RITCHIE, JAMES HUTTON, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1867, and arrived in Madras, 8th Nov., 1867, and served on general and military duty; in charge of 25th regiment native infantry at Malta and Cyprus, April–Sept., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1879; in charge of jails at Trichinopoly, Cuddalore, and Tanjore; civil surgeon, Madura.

RITCHIE, RICHMOND T. W., India Office.—Educated at Eton, and Trinity College, Cambridge; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 18th May, 1877; revenue, statistics and commerce department, 1881; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1883.

RIVAZ, CHARLES MONTGOMERY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1870; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, May, 1874; under secretary to government, April, 1875; superintendent, Kapurthala state, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, and grade, April, 1885; appointed secretary to Punjab government, May, 1887; continuing to officiate as assistant commissioner and superintendent Lahore division.

RIVAZ, GEORGE WILMOT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; registrar, chief court, Punjab, 1877-1884; officiating inspector-general of registration and superintendent of stamps, Oct., 1884; district judge, 1st grade, Dec., 1886; edited the 2nd edition of the circular orders of the chief court.

RIVETT-CARNAC, CHARLES JAMES, Financial Department, Bengal.—Joined the financial department, 21st May, 1872; served in the N.W. Provinces till 1876, as assistant to the accountant-general, and officiated as personal assistant to the financial member of the governor-general’s council, June, 1874; assistant to accountant-general, Punjab, Jan., 1876; officiating deputy accountant-general, Punjab, Aug., 1876; served again in the N.W. Provinces from March, 1878; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Oct., 1882; 4th class, financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant comptroller-general (in charge of forest branch), Oct., 1884; assistant accountant-general, and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, March, 1885.

RIVETT-CARNAC, JOHN HENRY, C.I.E., F.S.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1858; assistant magistrate and collector, May, 1860; officiating secretary to income tax committee, June, 1861; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Sept., 1861; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Central Provinces, June, 1862; settlement officer, Chandah and Wardha, Aug., 1864; cotton commissioner, Central Provinces, Sept., 1866, and Berars, April, 1867; commissioner of cotton and commerce with the government of India, Dec., 1871; member and honorary secretary of central committee of international exhibitions; on duty in England, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; special commissioner of transport, Bengal famine; opium agent, Benares, March, 1875; author of ‘Reports on the Indian Cotton Cultivation and Trade, and the Cotton Trade generally and on the Interchange of Traffic on Indian Railways.’

ROBB, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Aber.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st Oct., 1868; from Nov., 1873, to July, 1882, served as civil surgeon, Zanzibar, and acted as assistant political agent, in 1874-75 and again in 1881; from July, 1882, served under the government of Bombay, as civil surgeon, and superintendent of jail at Aden, and at Surat; acting deputy sanitary commissioner, Sept.–Oct., 1883; civil surgeon, superintendent of lunatic asylum, and of the Medical School, Ahmedabad, April, 1884.

ROBERTS, ALLAN SCOTT, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, and April, 1862; from June, 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; and grade, Jan., 1887.

ROBERTS, ARTHUR WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—Cornet, Bengal cavalry, Feb., 1859; assistant to governor-general’s agent, Rajputana, 1864; acted as political superintendent of Sirohi in 1868-69, and subsequently as political agent in various states of Rajputana; cantonment magistrate, Morar, Feb., 1875; assistant commissioner, Merwara, April, 1881; political assistant, Sujangarh, Aug., 1881, in charge of Bikaniir and the Upper Rajputana Thagi and Dakaiti Agency; in 1881-82 was employed in operations against the rebellious Bikaniir Thakurs and received the surrender of the Fort of Nahargarh; assistant political agent, Banswara and Partabgarh, Aug., 1883; political agent and superintendent, Charkhari, Sept., 1884; cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Dec., 1885; political agent, Alwar, April, 1886.

ROBERTS, DAVID THOMAS, LL.B., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen’s College, Liverpool, Liverpool Institute,
and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, April, 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1886; magistrate and collector, June, 1887.

ROBERTS, SIR FREDERICK SLEIGH, Bart., Lieut.-General, V.C., G.C.B., G.C.I.E., R.A.—First commission, Bengal artillery, 1851; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, the operations connected with the relief of Lucknow, at Cawnpore, and the capture of Lucknow, and was present at numerous engagements (medal and three clasps, brevet of major, V.C.); deputy assistant quartermaster-general, Bengal, April, 1858; served in the N.W. frontier expedition, 1863 (medal and clasp); assistant quartermaster-general, Bengal, Feb., 1869; served with the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal, brevet of lieut.-colonel), and with the Looshai expedition, 1871-72; deputy quartermaster-general, Bengal, Jan., 1872; quartermaster-general, Bengal, Jan., 1875; during the operations in Afghanistan in 1878-9-80, commanded the Kuram Valley field force, and subsequently the Cabul field force at the occupation of Cabul and battle of Charasiab, and in the march to the relief of Kandahar; received thanks of both houses of parliament, and was created a baronet (medal with four clasps, bronze star, K.C.B., G.C.B.); commander-in-chief, Madras, and member of governor's council, Nov., 1881; commander-in-chief in India, and member of the governor-general's council, 28th Nov., 1885.

ROBERTS, R. P., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 2nd Aug., 1873.

ROBERTS, THOMAS, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1883; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Aug., 1884; divisional judge, Nov., 1884 (and grade, Sept., 1886).

ROBERTS, WILLIAM HOWLAND, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 23rd July, 1858; arrived 24th Sept., 1858, and served in the Central Provinces till Sept., 1864, and subsequently in Madras as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Salem; acted as Zillah surgeon, Coimbatore, July, 1866, to Jan., 1868; was also in charge of meteorological observatories at Coimbatore and Salem; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and superintendent of fish-liver oil factory, Calicut, Aug., 1869; surgeon-major, July, 1870; superintendent of lunatic asylum, Calicut, May, 1872; surgeon, and district, Madras, and health officer, and superintendent of lock hospital, April, 1881; brigade-surgeon, June, 1885.

ROBERTSON, BENJAMIN, Bombay, C.S.—Educated at the Institute, Elgin, the Grammar School and University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1885; assistant collector, June, 1886.

ROBERTSON, CHARLES, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1856; served under the military department from Dec., 1856, up to May, 1874, and also as Zillah surgeon, Masulipatnam, Jan., 1862, to March, 1865; from May, 1874, served as Zillah surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Cuddalore; retired, Dec., 1885.

ROBERTSON, DONALD, Major, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Royal Scots Fusiliers, Aug., 1865; arrived in Madras, Oct., 1865; subaltern, 4th light cavalry, Madras, March, 1868; served from Nov., 1869 as assistant commissioner in the Central Provinces; transferred to Rajputana, June, 1872; cantonment magistrate, Nusserabad, May, 1877; officiating assistant commissioner, Merwara and Ajmere, 1877-78; officiating superintendent, Jhallawur, 1879; 1st assistant agent to governor-general, Indore, 1881; political agent, Bhopawur, Feb., 1885; political agent, Bundelkund, May, 1885; assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to the chief commissioner of Coorg.

ROBERTSON, ELPHINSTONE POURTALES, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 27th March, 1851, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in Bombay to report on abkari lands, March, 1868; senior collector and magistrate, Dhawar, Jan., 1873; revenue and police commissioner, Nov., 1876; commissioner of the central division, Jan., 1878; commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1881; retired, 1886.

ROBERTSON, FREDERICK ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 15th Dec., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Feb., 1882, served in the settlement department as assistant settlement officer; promoted to settlement officer, April, 1884.

ROBERTSON, JAMES CASAMAJOR, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; from Jan., 1856, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, Oct., 1871; officiating inspector-general of registration, and commissioner of excise and stamps, July, 1876; civil and sessions judge, April, 1879; commissioner, Agra division, Jan., 1882; and subsequently of the Rohilkund division, Feb., 1883; officiated as member of the board of revenue, in 1885 and 1886.

ROBERTSON, WILLIAM, Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 27th Feb., 1886.

ROBERTSON, WILLIAM ROWNTREE, M.R.A.C., Madras Education Department.—Arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1868; superintendent, government farms, Nov., 1868; on special duty to Mysore and Bangalore, Jan., 1876; superintendent of the school of agriculture, Saidapet, Oct., 1876; fellow of Madras University, May, 1882;
superintendent, government farms and school of agriculture, and agricultural reporter to government of Madras, Nov., 1882; principal, agricultural college, Saidapet, April, 1884; member of committee in connection with scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885.

ROBINSON, ALEXANDER, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865; from Jan., 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1870; deputy commissioner, and grade, Fyzabad, Nov., 1884; magistrate and collector, April, 1887; author of 'Memoirs of the Ballia and Jaunpur District.'

ROE, CHARLES ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; deputy commissioner, and class, Sept., 1881; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawal Pindi divisions, May, 1883; divisional judge, and grade, Nov., 1884; officiating judge, chief court, March, 1885, April, 1887, and May, 1888; author of 'Reports on the Settlement of various Districts,' and of 'Customary Law of the Mooltan District.'

ROGERS, ALEXANDER, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1845; served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department, and was appointed 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Broach, Oct., 1851, and afterwards at Ahmedabad, Oct., 1852, settlement officer, Guzerat, Nov., 1852; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, March, 1860, and afterwards at Surat; revenue and police commissioner, north division, April, 1865; member of council, Bombay, June, 1872; retired in 1878.

ROGERS, ERNEST, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Bedford Grammar School and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

ROGERS, HENRY THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—And lieutenant, Dec., 1849; arrived in India, 28th Aug., 1852; served in the public works department, Bengal, from 1853 to 1859, and subsequently in Madras as assistant engineer and executive engineer; and acted as comptroller of public works accounts, 1864, and as principal of the Civil Engineering College, Feb. to Aug., 1865; acting mint master, July, 1865; officiating superintending engineer, Sept.-Oct., 1870; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1872; principal, Civil Engineering College, April, 1871, to Jan., 1880; member of the committee for the management of the school of arts, March, 1877; from Nov., 1879, served as superintendent of revenue survey, Madras; retired, July, 1886.

ROGERS, MALCOLM, W., Major, R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, Dec., 1861; arrived in India, Oct., 1865; assistant surveyor, great trigonometrical survey of India, July, 1866; served with the Quetta field force as survey officer, 1878-79 (medal, brevet of major); deputy superintendent of survey, July, 1882; assistant surveyor-general in charge of mathematical instrument office, and correspondence office, Calcutta, May, 1884; 3rd grade, deputy superintendent, Aug., 1884.

ROLLAND, ALEXANDER TULLOCH, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, April, 1856; arrived in India, 11th May, 1856; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1862, as assistant superintendent, and superintendent; deputy inspector-general of police, Feb., 1885.

ROMESH CHUNDER DUTT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Colootola Branch School, Calcutta, Presidency College, Calcutta University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1871; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Morch, 1888; has published the following works: 'Three years in Europe,' 1872; 'Peasantry of Bengal,' 1876; 'Literature of Bengal,' 1877; 'Satabarsa,' (Historical Tales), and a 'Short History of India in Bengali,' 1878; a Bengali translation of the 'Reg Veda Sanhita,' a popular account of the gods of the 'Reg Veda,' and a social novel called the 'Sansar.'

ROMESH CHUNDER MITTER, B.L.—Puiscne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 30th March, 1874; acted as chief justice in 1882.

RONSON, W. T., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 1st Sept., 1873; clerk, and class, Feb., 1879; attached to revenue, statistics, and commerce department; author of the report on sanitary measures in India annually presented to Parliament for the years 1878-79 to 1883-84 inclusive.

ROSE, EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Folkingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Oct., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1887.

ROSE, HORACE ARTHUR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

ROSS, ALEXANDER, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Academy and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1836; served in the judicial and revenue departments of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed superintendent of Dehra Dun, Jan., 1846; magistrate and collector, 1853; special commissioner, Farakhabad, Dec., 1857; civil and sessions judge, 1858; member of special commission for trial of Nawab of Farakhabad, 1859; commissioner of revenue and police, Agra division, May, 1859; judge of the Sudder court, N.W. Provinces, 1862; puiscne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, 1866; retired, Oct., 1871.
ROSS, EDWARD CHARLES, Colonel, C.S.I., Bombay S.C.—Ensign, 3rd European regiment, Bombay, May, 1855; served in Central India during the mutiny, and was present at the siege and capture of Jhansi (medal and clasp); assistant to political agent, Muscat, 1863-69; assistant political agent, Gwadar, 1869; political agent and consul, Muscat, April, 1871; local lieutenant-colonel in Persian Gulf, May, 1872; political resident, Persian Gulf, from Oct., 1872; graded as resident, and class; H.M.'s consul-general for the Province of Fars, and the coasts and islands of the Persian Gulf, Nov., 1878; officiating resident, Hyderabad, April, 1886.

ROSS, G. C., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Served from Nov., 1867, as civil surgeon in various stations in the Punjab; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; civil surgeon, 1st class, Oct., 1881.

ROSS, HENRY THOMAS, M.A., LL.B., Madras C.S.—Educated at Perth Academy, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting district and sessions judge; special assistant to the collector and magistrate, Malabar, Sept., 1884; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1885; registrar, high court, Feb., 1886; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Sept., 1888.

ROSS, HERCULES GREY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; from April, 1858, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, city magistrate at Lucknow, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; superintendent, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1869; magistrate and collector, Benares, Oct., 1882; officiating commissioner, Benares division, and agent to governor-general, March, 1883; on special duty, Dehra Dun, March, 1883; settlement officer, and grade, Dehra Dun, Oct., 1883; commissioner, Kumaon, April, 1885.

ROST, REINHOLD, C.I.E., LL.D., Ph.D., Librarian, India Office.—Educated at the Grammar School of Altenburg (1838-42), and the University of Jena (1842-46), where he graduated in 1847; came to London in the same year to continue his oriental studies; was appointed oriental lecturer at St. Augustine's Missionary College, 1851; secretary to the Royal Asiatic Society, Dec., 1863; librarian, India office, July, 1869; published in 1850 an essay on the Indian sources of the Burmese laws; edited (1862-65) Professor H. H. Wilson's selected works, H. B. Hodgson's essays (2 vols., 1880), and miscellaneous papers on Indo-China (2 vols., 1886); contributes articles on oriental philology to the 'Encyclopaedia Britannica,' and the 'Athenæum'; is honorary M.A. of Oxford and LL.D. of Edinburgh, honorary member of the Royal Asiatic Society, and of the Asiatic societies of Singapore, the Hague, and Batavia; corresponding member of the Royal Society of Munich and the German Oriental Society, and honorary fellow of St. Augustine's College, Canterbury.

ROUSE, ROBERT, Deputy Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; from May, 1869, served as civil surgeon and officiating superintendent of jail in the Punjab; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; retired, Dec., 1885.

ROWE, F. J., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 15th June, 1870, and served as professor at Krishnagurh, Dacca, and Hooghly Colleges, also as inspector of schools and officiating principal, Krishnagurh College (May, 1877); 3rd class, education department, Jan., 1878; professor, Presidency College, July, 1880.

ROWLANDS, PERCY J., Registry Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1st Sept., 1858; assistant to registrar, June, 1877.

ROYLE, JOSEPH R. E. J., C.I.E., India Office.—Educated at King's College School, London; entered Indian army from Addiscombe, 7th June, 1861; lieutenant H.M.'s 107th foot, 1862; retired, Jan., 1867; on the extra staff of the India Museum, 1st Jan., 1867; clerk to the special assistant in the statistics and commerce department, India office, Oct., 1879; assistant secretary, Indian section of the colonial and Indian exhibition, 1886; also officiating as agent of the government of India from Jan., 1885; C.I.E., 1886; author of the official report on the Indian section of the Amsterdam exhibition of 1882, and of contributions on Indian art manufactures and other subjects to various periodicals; also of a lecture before the Society of Arts, June, 1882, on the Production of Tea, Cinchona, Wild Silks, and Rhein in India.

RUDDOCK, EDWARD HARDCASTLE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Leeds Grammar School and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 2nd Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884.

RULE, EDWARD, Financial Department, Government of India.—Served in England under the board of admiralty previous to joining the financial department of government of India; arrived in India, and Nov., 1865, and served in the comptroller-general's establishment; from March, 1868, to Sept., 1869, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general and assistant commissioner of paper currency; from Sept., 1869, to March, 1875, acted as deputy accountant-general in British Burma; from March, 1875, served as deputy accountant-general, Madras, and acted for some months as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; on special duty to Port Blair, Nov.-Dec., 1877; deputy accountant-general, Burma, Dec., 1877; deputy comptroller-general (afterwards designated comptroller of Indian treasuries) in 1st class of financial department, April, 1883.

RUNDALL, FRANCIS HORNBLOW, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., R.E.—Madras engineers, 1841; assistant civil engineer, 1844; civil engineer, public works department, Ganjam, 1854; district engineer, Rajahmundry, May, 1855; consulting engineer, Madras irrigation and canal company, Oct., 1859; chief engineer of irrigation and joint secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1867; chief engineer, 1st class, Aug., 1869; officiating inspector-general and deputy secretary to government of India, irrigation branch, Jan., 1871; inspector-general of irrigation and
deputy secretary to government of India, April, 1872, to April, 1874.

RUNDALL, JAMES WILLIAM, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—Joined Madras public works department as supernumerary engineer, 2nd Aug., 1855, and served in the Godavari, Tinnevelly, and Bellary districts; executive engineer, July, 1863; on special duty under chief engineer, May, 1877; superintendent of works, Kistna, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer, Oct., 1881; member of committee for drawing up navigation rules, Nov., 1882; and class superintending engineer, April, 1884.

RUSSSELL, Sir EDWARD LECHMERE, General, K.C.S.I.—Ensign, 12th N.I., Bombay, Jan., 1838; served in the Afghan war of 1842, and the Sind campaign of 1842-43, and was adjutant of the Sind irregular horse in the battles of Meanee and Hydrabad, and the surrender of Omerkote; fort adjutant, Bombay, Jan., 1855; remount agent, May, 1857; commanding brigade, Deesa, March, 1863, and subsequently at Bombay; political resident and commanding brigade, at Aden, Dec., 1867; commanding northern division, Bombay, Dec., 1870 to 1876.

RUSSELL, SAMUEL, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Santry School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; special assistant to collector, magistrate, and agent, Ganjam, Feb., 1885.

RUTHERFORD, JOHN MURIC, Railway Department, Government of India.—Was specially trained in Europe for the telegraph department, and was appointed assistant superintendent, 4th grade, Oct., 1869; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1870, and served in the Punjab, and in Rajputana; acted as assistant manager, Rajputana state railway, in addition to his own duties, June-Nov., 1879; transferred to traffic department of state railways, March, 1880, and served as district traffic superintendent on the Rajputana state railway; Indus Valley state railway, March, 1882; class I of the state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; deputy traffic superintendent, Lahore, North-Western railway, July, 1886; acting manager Punjab section North-Western railway, May, 1887.

RYAN, PATRICK (Barrister-at-Law), F.R.L.S., F.R.G.S., Police Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 23rd Nov., 1852; from May, 1860, served as assistant secretary to government of Bombay in the political, educational, and secret departments; also acted as oriental translator to government, Aug.-Sept., 1869, and as magistrate of police, Bombay; performed duties of under secretary to government in the political and judicial departments, Feb.-March, 1879; appointed third presidency magistrate, Bombay, Nov., 1880; second presidency magistrate, Jan., 1888; author of a treatise on the law of extradition in India.

RYLAND, WILLIAM HENRY, late Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 10th Dec., 1852, served in the subordinate executive service, Bengal, and was appointed deputy magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1866; officiating collector of stamps, and superintendent of ab-karee revenue, March, 1868; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1869; from Dec., 1874, served in the judicial department, and was appointed subordinate judge 1st grade, and judge of the small cause court at Sealdah, April, 1875; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1880; retired, April, 1887.

RYVES, THOMAS JAMES, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served as a volunteer in the Bengal yeomanry cavalry from July, 1857, to Jan., 1859, and received the mutiny medal and the local rank of lieutenant for distinguished services in the field; adjutant of military police, Bijnoor, 1859; assistant inspector-general, Rohilkund, April, 1861; from Aug., 1861, served as superintendent of police in various districts, and was promoted to the 1st grade, June, 1885; assistant inspector-general railway police, June, 1888.

SABONADIÈRE, ALFRED, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces, &c.)—Educated at Charterhouse and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 19th Jan., 1885, and served as assistant commissioner.

ST. JOHN, SIR OLIVER BEAUCHAMP COVENTRY, Colonel, K.C.S.I., R.E.—2nd Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1856; served in public works department, Oudh and N.W. Provinces, July, 1859, to Oct., 1863; superintendent, Persian telegraph, Oct., 1863, to Oct., 1871; boundary commissioner, Perso-Kalat frontier, Oct., 1871, to March, 1873; employed at India office in compiling map of Persia, March, 1873, to Jan., 1875; principal of Mayo College, Ajmir, Jan., 1875, to Aug., 1878; attached to General Sir N. Chamberlain's mission to Kabul, Aug.-Sept., 1878; chief political officer, Kandahar field force, Nov., 1878, to March, 1880; resident Southern Afghanistan, April, 1880, to April, 1881; gazetted H.M.'s Consul, Mazandaran and Ghilan, Aug., 1879, but did not join; officiating agent to governor-general, Beluchistan, 1881-83, and again from May, 1886; on special duty in Kashmir, Jan., 1883; acting resident in Hyderabad, April-July, 1884; resident in Kashmir, Aug., 1884; agent to the governor-general at Baroda, December, 1887.

ST. QUINTIN, WILLIAM A., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Blackheath Proprietary School; temporary clerk, 31st Dec., 1866; junior examiner, Dec., 1868; senior examiner, Nov., 1878.

SAIYID MAHMUD (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as district judge, 3rd grade, Oudh, Aug., 1879; served temporarily under foreign department of government of India, June, 1881, to May, 1882; acting puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, May, 1882; and again in 1884 and 1886; served under education committee, Nov., 1882, to March, 1883; district judge, Rae Bareli, Nov., 1883; judge of high court, N.W. Provinces, 9th May, 1887.

SALIG RAM, RAJ BAHADUR, late Postal Department, N.W. Provinces.—Served in the postal department, N.W. Provinces, from Marth, 1847, as clerk, inspecting postmaster, and head assistant in the office of the postmaster-general; inspector, post offices, Agra division, July, 1876; superintendent, Agra division, April, 1881; postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1884; retired.
SALISBURY (MARQUESS OF) RIGHT HON.
ROBERT ARTHUR TALBOT GASCOIGNE CECIL,
K.G., D.C.L., LL.D.—Born in 1830; educated at
Eton and Christ Church, Oxford, where he gra-
duated, and was elected a fellow of All Souls' Col-
lege in 1853; represented Stamford in Parliament
from 1853 to April, 1868, when he succeeded to the
Upper House; secretary of state for India, July,
1866, to March, 1867; chancellor of the university
of Oxford, Nov., 1869; in 1871-72 he acted with
Lord Cairns in conducting the investigation into
the affairs of the London, Chatham, and Dover
Railway Company; secretary of state for India,
second time, Feb., 1874; was sent as special am-
bassador to the Sublime Porte in 1876, and acted
with Sir Henry Elliot as joint plenipotentiaries of
Great Britain at the conference of Constanti-
nople, Dec., 1876; was appointed secretary of
state for foreign affairs on the resignation of Lord
Derby, April, 1878, and afterwards accompanied
the Earl of Beaconsfield to Berlin, as represen-
tative of Great Britain at the congress held
there; invested with the Order of the Garter,
July, 1878; prime minister and again secretary
of state for foreign affairs, June, 1885, to Feb.,
1886; prime minister and first lord of the
treasury, Aug., 1886; secretary of state for
foreign affairs (3rd time), Jan., 1887; has served
on the royal commissions on historical manu-
scripts, 1882; on the housing of the working
classes, 1884; and for the Indian and Colonial
exhibitions, 1886; is honorary colonel Bedford-
shire regiment, and an elder brother of the
Trinity House.

SALMON, WILLIAM ARTHUR, Lieutenant-
Colonel, Bo. S.C., Political Department, Bom-
bay.—Arrived in India, 11th May, 1859, and
served in military duty till March, 1867, and sub-
sequently in the political department as acting
assistant resident, Baroda, acting political agent,
Rewa Kántha, and acting assistant political
agent in Káthiáwar on special duty; personal
assistant to political agent, Káthiáwar, Jan.,
1871; acting assistant superintendent for thug-
gee and dacoity, Baroda, Feb.-March, 1873;
served as political assistant in Káthiáwar up to
Jan., 1879, and was in charge of the Gondal
state and of Hála Pránt, July-Aug., 1877;
from Feb., 1879, served as assistant political
agent, Kolába, in charge Janjira state; acting
political agent, Mahi Kántha, Aug.-Nov., 1882;
assistant political agent in charge of Southern
Mahrátha country Jághirs, Aug., 1883; joint
administrator of Rajpípla, July, 1884; joint ad-
ministrator of Sángli, Feb., 1885; assistant to
the governor-general's agent in charge of the
Okhamandal district, and commandant Wagheer
corps, Nov., 1887; acting political agent, Cutch.

SAMPSON, ARTHUR BISKS, B.A., late Public
Works Department, Government of India.—
Assistant secretary, public works department,
May, 1859; under secretary to Government of
India, public works department, general branch,
Sept., 1869; retired, May, 1887.

SAMUELLS, CHARLES ARCHIBALD (Barrister-
at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's Col-
lege School, Blackheath Proprietary School,
and University College, London; appointed to
the Bengal civil service after open competitive
examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th
Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial de-
partments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate, joint
magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating
magistrate and collector, and was placed on
famine duty at Chumparun, March, 1874; joint
magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade,
March, 1883; officiating junior secretary, board
of revenue, March, 1885; officiating port com-
missioner, Calcutta, April, 1886; magistrate and
collector, 3rd grade, Oct., 1886; port commis-
sioner, Calcutta, March, 1887.

SAMUELLS, WILLIAM LEYCESTER, Lieu-
tenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, 20th
Nov., 1857; served from 18th Dec., 1864, in the
non-regulation commission, Bengal, as assistant
commissioner and deputy commissioner; special
boundary commissioner (Rewah and Chota
Nagpur), 1868-71; officiating cantonment magis-
trate and small cause court judge, Barrackpore,
April, 1873; officiating political agent, Hill
Tipperah, April, 1875; deputy commissioner,
3rd grade, Aug., 1885; and grade, Aug., 1887.

SANDEMAN, J. E., Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C.,
Survey Department.—Joined at Addiscombe,
1860; ensign, Bengal infantry, 7th June, 1861;
arrived in India, Oct., 1861; studied at Roorkee
College, and obtained certificate qualifying for
engineer, public works department, Sept., 1864;
appointed to the survey department, Oct., 1864,
and served as assistant superintendent in the
Central Provinces, Oudh, and the Punjab;
served with the Hazara expedition, 1868 (medal);
in charge of Midnapur survey, Bengal, 1873;
Goalparah survey, Assam, Dec., 1873; Behar
irrigation survey, Oct., 1874; in charge of British
Burma cadastral survey, Dec., 1878; deputy
superintendent, 3rd grade, survey of India, Jan.,
1879; in charge of Mirzapur and Gorakpur
district cadastral survey, from Nov., 1883;
deputy superintendent, and grade, Jan., 1887.

SANDEMAN, SIR ROBERT GROVES, Colonel,
K.C.S.I., B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry,
Feb., 1856; during the mutiny served at the
siege and capture of Lucknow and other opera-
tions (medal and clasp); assistant commis-
sioner, Punjab, May, 1859; deputy commissioner,
Jan., 1875; on special duty in connection with
Kalat affairs, Nov., 1875, to Feb., 1877, during
which period he conducted two missions to
Kalat; agent, governor-general, Biluchistan,
from Feb., 1877; during the Afghan war held
the chief political authority in Biluchistan,
in the Zhob Valley expedition, Sept., 1884;
resident of the 1st class, and governor-general's
agent in Biluchistan, June, 1887; K.C.S.I., July,
1879.

SANDERS, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-
Western Provinces).—Educated at the Colle-
giate School and University of Edinburgh;
appointed to the Bengal civil service after open
competitive examination of 1877; arrived in
India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W.
Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate
and collector and assistant commissioner, 3rd grade;
officiating city magistrate and wasika officer,
Lucknow, May-Aug., 1886; joint magistrate,
March, 1888.

SANDERS, RICHARD CHARLES, Surgeon-
Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commis-
sion, 1869; ophthalmic surgeon and professor of
ophthalmic surgery, Medical College, Calcutta,
April, 1886.

SANDIFORD, C. T., Railway Branch,
Government of India.—Joined the P.W. depart-
ment from Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi railway as
locomotive superintendent, North-Western state
railway, Jan., 1886; class x, state railway
revenue establishment, July, 1886; class i,
grade 1, state revenue establishment, permanent, April, 1887.

SANFORD, GEORGE EDWARD LANGLEHAM SOMERSET, Colonel, R.E., C.B., Military Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, R.E., Oct., 1856; served in the China war, 1858 (medal and clasp); served in the public works department (military works), April, 1872, to Jan., 1878, as assistant and executive engineer, and in the Jowaki campaign, 1878 (medal and clasp); assistant quartermaster-general, Bengal, Feb., 1878, to March, 1880; during this period served in the Afghan campaign, and was present at the capture of Ali Mujid (medal and clasp, brevet of lieutenant-colonel); deputy quartermaster-general, Bengal, March, 1880, to Nov., 1885; commanded Royal Engineers in Burmese expedition, 1885-86; C.B., Nov., 1886; inspector-general of military works, March, 1886; chief engineer, and class, March, 1887.

SANKEY, RICHARD HIERAM, Lieutenant-General, C.B., late R.E.—Ensign, 11th Dec., 1840; arrived in India as supernumerary second lieutenant, Madras engineers, Nov., 1848; officiating superintending engineer, Nagpore subsidiary force, Feb., 1850, to June, 1853; superintendent of the east coast canal, 1856-57; additional under secretary, government of India, public works department, March, 1857; on outbreak of mutiny proceeded with special appointment to Allahabad, acting for a time as superintending engineer and consulting engineer for railways, N.W. Provinces; acted as field engineer at Cawnpore, and was subsequently senior engineer officer with the Gurkha force under Jung Bahadur; executive engineer and superintendent of convicts, Mouline, Jan.-Nov., 1859, and subsequently garrison engineer, Fort William; assistant to chief engineer, Mysore, June, 1861; chief engineer, Mysore, 1866-1877; services placed by Lord Mayo at disposal of government of Victoria for specially reporting on the waterworks of the colony, March-Oct., 1871; deputy secretary to government of India, Sept., 1877; commanding engineer of the South Afghanistan expeditionary force under lieutenant-general D. Stewart, C.B., Oct., 1878, to Feb., 1879; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Madras, public works department, April, 1879; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; resigned the public works department in 1883; retired from the army, Jan., 1884; chairman, board of works, Dublin.

SAPTE, BRAND, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1843; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal, the Punjab, and N.W. Provinces; magistrate and collector, Bulandshahr, 1857, and subsequently at Meerut; C.B. in 1859; from 1864 to 1865 served as judge of Ghazeepur, and subsequently of Farakhabad; retired 1871.

SARGEAUNT, CHARLES CHESTER, Colonel, M.S.C., late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, 31st May, 1856; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department till Feb., 1867, and subsequently in the revenue survey department, Madras, as assistant superintendent; was on special duty in Madras, 1873, and 1875-1876, and in England, 1883; deputy-superintendent of revenue survey, Dec., 1883; on special duty at Coonoor to revise and republish the survey manual, April, 1886; colonel in the army, May, 1886; superintendent of revenue survey, June, 1886; retired, July, 1887.

SARGEAUNT, RICHARD ARTHUR, Major, R.E., railway department, government of India.—1st commission, Dec., 1861; joined the Bombay public works department, May, 1864; assistant consulting engineer, railways, Nov., 1864; examiner of railway accounts, Bombay, April, 1872; acting examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Dec., 1875; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, May, 1877; acted as consulting engineer for railways in 1878; secretary to railway conference, Jan., 1879; executive engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1880; revenue assistant, railway branch, public works secretariat, government of India, 1880; manager, Northern Bengal state railway, in class I of the state railway revenue establishment, July, 1882; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Feb., 1883; officiating manager, Punjab Northern state railway, June, 1884; officiating manager of East Bengal railway, June, 1887; officiating consulting engineer for railways, and officiating joint secretary railway department, Bombay, May, 1888.

SARGENT, SIR CHARLES, Knt., M.A. (Cantab), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Judge of the high court, Bombay, April, 1866; chief justice, Aug., 1882.

SATYANDRANATH TAGORE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Presidency College, Calcutta University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived, 13th Dec., 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judge of the small cause court, Ahmednagar, and judge and sessions judge; 1st grade judge, Sholapur-Bijapur, Aug., 1883.

SAUNDERS, ARTHUR LESLIE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at the Oratory School, Edgbaston, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to the Central Provinces, Oct., 1885; under secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1887.

SAUNDERS, LESLIE SEYMOUR, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1857; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; acted as personal assistant to the judicial commissioner; and as small cause court judge in 1863; settlement officer, Lahore, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866; and acted as settlement commissioner in 1869; on special duty to write Lahore settlement report, June, 1869; officiating deputy commissioner, 1869-1871; commissioner, Ajmir, March, 1871, to Feb., 1885; graded in the political department as resident, and class; commissioner, Berar, Feb., 1885.

SAVAGE, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Institute; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and...
deputy collector, and grade, Dec., 1885; 1st grade, Dec., 1887; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

SCHARLIEB, WILLIAM MASON, Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 25th March, 1847, in various subordinate posts, and was appointed first unconvened assistant to the board of revenue, June, 1862; resigned the service to practise at the bar, Oct., 1867; acting administrator-general, Madras, in 1867 and 1874; acting government pleader, May, 1874; assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, Dec., 1874; from April to Oct., 1879, acted as first judge of the court of small causes, Madras, and again in 1885 and 1888, and served from 1885 as presidency magistrate for the town of Madras; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; has acted as chief presidency magistrate in 1884, 1886, and 1887.

SCHLICH, W., Ph.D., late Forest Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state for India as an assistant conservator of forests, Dec., 1866; conservator of forests, Bengal, Dec., 1872; transferred to the Punjab, 1880; inspector-general of forests, April, 1883; retired, 1888, and appointed principal professor of forestry, at the Royal Indian engineering college, Cooper's Hill.

SCHNEIDER, JOHN WILLIAM, Lieutenant-General, C.B.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and afterwards at the military college at Addiscombe; ensign, and native infantry, Bombay, 20th Feb., 1841; served in the Southern Mahratta campaign, 1845-45; and was present at the capture of the Panalla and Powanghur forts; second in command and commandant of the Kolhapur infantry, and also assistant political superintendent, 1852-1859; in 1857-58, took part in the suppression of the mutiny at Kolhapur, and the recapture of the city; mutiny medal; commissioner under Act XIV. of 1857 for the summary trial and punishment of offences against the State; president of the civil and military committee at Bombay for the examination of officers in native languages, 1859-1861; commanded 2nd regiment, Bombay infantry, 1859-1866; served in the Abyssinian expedition of 1867-8, and commanded a brigade at action of Arogee, and assault and capture of Magdala; medal, and C.B., Aug., 1868; judge advocate-general, Bombay army, 1868-72; political resident at Aden, 1872-77; also commanded Aden brigade; commanded northern division, Bombay army, 1877-1881.

SCOBLE, ANDREW RICHARD, C.S.I., Q.C.—Called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, Jan., 1856; held the offices of clerk of the crown and commissioner for taking accounts and for local investigations, under the high court, Bombay, 1863-66; was an advocate of the high court, 1866-1876, and successively held the offices of sheriff, 1866-67, legal remembrancer, 1869-72, and advocate-general, 1872-77; conducted the prosecution of the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1875; was also additional member of the council of the governor of Bombay, 1870-76; Q.C., 1876; took his seat as an ordinary member of the governor-general's council, 1st Dec., 1886; C.S.I., Jan., 1889.

SCONCE, GIDEON COLQUHOUN (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bengal.—Officiating magistrate, Calcutta, 12th Nov., 1866; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, Dec., 1870; judge of the Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1874; promoted to third judge, Oct., 1884.

SCONCE, JAMES, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey Department.—Joined at Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec. 1853; arrived in India, April, 1854; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, and in the operations leading to the relief of Lucknow, also during the capture of Lucknow, March, 1858, (medal and clasps); served from Oct., 1859, as assistant revenue surveyor in the Bundelcund and Central Provinces surveys; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1862; served in Bengal from March, 1866, in the office of superintendent of revenue surveys, Calcutta, and at Hazaribagh, Midnapur, and Arrah; deputy superintendent of survey, and grade, Nov., 1868; deputy surveyor-general (revenue survey branch), Jan., 1879.

SCORGIE, JAMES, F.C.S., Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the service as head master of the Akola High School, Berar, 12th Nov., 1866; in charge of the office of director of public instruction, Berar, April-June, 1872; principal, Jeypore school of arts, Oct., 1872; from Feb., 1875, served as professor of mechanism and applied science, Civil Engineering College, Poona; 3rd grade of the education department, March, 1883.

SCOTLAND, SIR COLLEY H., Knight.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe; entered as a student at the Middle Temple in 1840, and was called to the bar in 1843; practised on the common law side of Westminster Hall, and on the Oxford circuit; appointed chief justice of the supreme court, Madras, 1861, and of the high court of judicature on its establishment in 1862; resigned, 1871; vice-chancellor of the Madras University, 1861 to 1871; contributed to the Law Journal reports of cases in the court of Queen's bench, 1848 to 1857, and is joint author of a work 'On the Crown Office Practice of the Court of Queen's Bench.'

SCOTT, ARTHUR GUILLUM, Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, and at private schools; East India House writer, old establishment, 7th Nov., 1857; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872.

SCOTT, EDWIN, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884. Arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1887, and served in the revenue and survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

SCOTT, JOHN, M.A. (Oxon), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Judge of the high court, Bombay, 18th Nov., 1882.

SCOTT, MATHEW HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 16th Dec., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Kaladgi, July, 1876; and grade judge, Khândesh, Feb., 1881; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmednagar, May, 1882; acting district judge, Khandesh, April, 1888.

SCOTT, ROSS, M.A., F.C.S. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Omagh Academy, the Royal Academical Institution and Seminary, Belfast,
and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating additional and district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, and grade, Nov., 1886; 1st grade, sub-pro tem., March, 1888.

SCOTT, THOMAS AUGUSTUS, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1857; arrived in India, 29th June, 1857; from Jan., 1862, served in the police department, Central Provinces, and was appointed district superintendent, March, 1864; from June, 1865, served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Dec., 1888.

SCOTT MONCRIEFF, Sir COLIN CAMPBELL, K.C.M.G., C.S.I., Colonel, R.E., retired—joined the service as 2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 13th June, 1856; arrived in India, 10th June, 1858; served with the Bengal sappers and miners until Feb., 1859, through the campaign in Oudh, and was present at several actions (medal); joined public works department, Feb., 1859, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the irrigation branch; principal Thomason Civil Engineering College, Roorkee, Sept., 1861; assistant to chief engineer irrigation branch, April, 1869; from Nov., 1869, served on the Ganges canal as executive and afterwards superintendent engineer; major, April, 1874; in 1877, was sent on deputation to Mysore to serve as chief engineer and famine commissioner; C.S.I., May, 1878; member of an irrigation committee under the famine commission, Aug., 1878, to Feb., 1879, when he again joined irrigation department of N.W. Provinces; officiated as chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner of British Burma, May, 1881; promoted to superintending engineer, 1st class, Feb., 1882; retired, Jan., 1883; K.C.M.G., 1887; is under secretary public works ministry, Egypt.

SCULLY, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, Indian Medical Department.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1872; served under the military department, and also as medical officer, Kashgar political agency, 1874-76; residency surgeon, Nipal, 1876-78; medical officer, Gilgit, 1878-80; acting deputy assay master, Calcutta mint, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883; from Nov., 1883, served as officiating assay master, and acting deputy assay master of the Bombay mint; confirmed in the latter appointment, May, 1884; assay master of the Calcutta mint, May, 1886.

SEABROOKE, JAMES H., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London (Jelf medallist and associate, 1871); open classical scholarship, Queen's College, Oxford, 1871-74; B.A., Dec., 1874; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 13th Jan., 1876; military department, 1877; senior clerk, June, 1887.

SEATON, WILLIAM JOHN, Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Burma.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Sept., 1855; assistant superintendent in the forest department, Dec., 1860; deputy conservator, 1st class, April, 1865; conservator, Nov., 1867; 1st grade conservator, Sept., 1882.

SECCOMBE, HENRY L., Financial Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 14th May, 1858; junior clerk, financial department, India office, Dec., 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1882.

SECCOMBE, SIR THOMAS LAWRENCE, C.B., K.C.S.I.—Entered the home service of the Honorable East India Company in Jan., 1829, as a clerk in the department of auditor of India accounts (subsequently merged in the secretary's department); on the transfer of the government of India to the Crown in 1858 was appointed assistant financial secretary; financial secretary, 1859; director of military funds, and chairman of the consulting committee, 1866; in Jan., 1869, was elected chairman of a joint India office and war office committee for adjusting the charges against Indian revenues for services of H.M.'s regiments on the India establishment, and was nominated a member of a similar committee in 1874, and again in Feb., 1879; C.B., Dec., 1869; accountant-general, in addition to his other duties, Feb., 1872; assistant under secretary of state for India, July, 1872; K.C.S.I., June, 1877; appointed one of three commissioners to represent H.M.'s Government at the International Monetary Conference at Paris, 1878; continued assistant under secretary of state until 1881, but resigned his other offices on 31st Jan., 1879; member of a joint India office and admiralty committee on financial questions connected with the India troop service, June, 1879.

SELBY, F. G., B.A. (Oxon), Education Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1877, and served from that date as professor of logic and moral philosophy in the Deccan College, Poona; also held acting appointments for various periods as principal of the college, and as principal of the Rajkumar College, Kathiawar; promoted to 3rd grade of the department, April, 1885.

SELLS, ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Muzaffarnagar, Aug., 1878, and civil and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Cawnpore, April, 1882; district and sessions judge, Meerut, Oct., 1886.

SETON-KARR, WALTER SCOTT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, where he gained honours, in 1842; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1842; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Jessore, 1847; under secretary, government of Bengal, 1847-53; member of council of education, 1853; collector of Tirhoot, 1857; civil and sessions judge, Jessore, 1858-60; president of indigo commission, 1860; secretary to government of Bengal, 1860-62; legislative council of India, 1861; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Chittagong, and member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1862; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1862, to April, 1868; foreign secretary, government of India, April, 1868; retired, 1870; vice-chancellor of the University of Calcutta in 1868 and 1869; is a member of the council of Marlborough College.

SEWELL, EBENEZER JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in
India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant collector and additional sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; on famine duty, June, 1877, to Sept., 1878; senior assistant collector and magistrate, Ganjam, June, 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Dec., 1887.

SEWELL, HENRY, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Radley, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting small cause court judge, acting under secretary to government in the revenue department, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1874, to April, 1875; from May, 1875, served as collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, and political agent, Pudukkota; district and sessions judge, North Arcot, Nov., 1886; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, Nov., 1887.

SEWELL, ROBERT, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, Oct., 1877, and on special duty in connection with the archaeological survey of the Madras presidency, Jan., 1881, and again, Jan., 1883; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Tinnevelly, Sept., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1887; acted as collector and magistrate, and in Sept., 1888, was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna; is the author of the following works, published by order of government:—'A Report on the Amaraviti Tope, and Excavations on its Site,' 1880; 'Chronological Tables for Southern India from the 6th Century, A.D.,' 1881; 'A Sketch of the Dynasties of Southern India,' 1883; volumes I. and II. of the 'Archaeological Survey Series of Southern India,' 1882 and 1884; 'Early Buddhist Symbolism,' 1886.

SHAKESPEAR, ALEXANDER MURISON WAKE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887.

SHANKER, MADHO CHITNAVIS, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Appointed a probationer for the civil service under the statutory rules, July, 1885; admitted member of the statutory service, and appointed assistant commissioner, Oct., 1887.

SHARP, F. W., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Milton College, Ullesthorpe; clerk, and class, India store depot, March, 1885.

SHARP, HENRY GRANVILLE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Horncastle Grammar School, Marlborough College, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1868; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal; on special duty at Madras on famine relief work, Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Oct., 1884; 2nd grade, Aug., 1887.

SHARPE, CHARLES FERGUSON, Colonel, B.S.C., late Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 1st Feb., 1851, and served under the military department till Sept., 1858, when he was appointed to the Oudh military police; medal for mutiny services; from Feb., 1859, served as district superintendent in the police department in Oudh, and was promoted to 1st grade, April, 1876.

SHARPE, F. R., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; writer, India office, 7th Aug., 1877; clerk, and class, Sept. 1878.

SHARPIN, VEN. FREDERICK LLOYD, M.A. (Exeter College, Oxford), Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Joined the service Aug., 1865; arrived in India, 13th Oct., 1865; served as chaplain at various stations in Bombay and Sind; senior chaplain, Oct., 1875; senior presidency chaplain, June, 1880; archdeacon and commissioner, June, 1886, also chaplain of Satara.

SHAW, ARTHUR TREVOR AMBROSE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Feb., 1886.

SHAW, CHARLES G., Store Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 17th Jan., 1855; junior clerk, store department, July, 1855; senior clerk, June, 1860; assistant to director-general, Nov., 1876.

SHAW, GEORGE WATSON, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Hertford Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1879, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, May, 1888.

SHAW-MACKENZIE, CHARLES FORBES HUDSON, Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 21st Aug., 1850, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate up to Feb., 1864, and subsequently as judge and sessions judge in various districts; retired, Sept., 1885.

SHAW-STEWART, JOHN HERON MAXWELL, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Madras Engineers, June, 1851; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1853; served in the Madras public works department from Jan., 1854, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; served in the China campaign, 1860 (medal and two clasps); deputy secretary to government, public works department, Dec., 1863; under secretary to government, Oct., 1866; controller, public works accounts, Madras, May, 1867; consulting engineer for railways, Madras, Oct., 1867; chief engineer, Oct., 1870; joint secretary to government, railway branch, Feb., 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government, public works department, Sept., 1883; additional member of council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Sept., 1883; retired, Sept., 1886.

SHEPHERD, HALE HORATIO, M.A., Bar-
rister-at-Law, Madras Judicial Department.—Professor of law at Presidency College, Madras, 1st Oct., 1873; acted as government pleader from time to time from Dec., 1874; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; appointed government pleader, June, 1881; additional member of Madras legislative council, March, 1885; advocate-general of Madras and officiating judge of high court, Jan., 1888.

SHEPPARD, GEORGE FREDERICK, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1854, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Jan., 1870; on special duty in Bombay, March, 1870; collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Dec., 1871; collector and magistrate, Kaira, Feb., 1873; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Kaira, Nov., 1875; on special duty at Poona, Oct., 1878; from Nov., 1880, acted as commissioner, and was confirmed as and grade commissioner, Oct., 1882 (Northern division); 1st grade commissioner, March, 1886.

SHEPPARD, WILLIAM DIDSBURY.—Educated at Hereford Cathedral School and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1884. Arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1887.

SHERER, JOHN WALTER, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; on special duty under board of revenue to report on reh efflorescence, Western Jumna Canal, 1856-57; magistrate and collector of Cawnpore, 1857; civil officer with General Havelock's column in 1857, in the advance on Cawnpore; special commissioner to try rebels; commissioner to enquire into claims against the former king of Oudh, 1864; member of jail committee, Calcutta, 1864; judge of Allahabad, 1871, and afterwards of Azimgurh and Mirzapore; retired 1877.

SHERIDAN, PHILIP, Post Office Department.—Served in the postal department, Punjab, from March, 1861, as postmaster, booking agent, assistant superintendent of military horse van dak, and inspector; chief superintendent, travelling post office, Allahabad, Dec., 1873; chief inspector of post offices, Assam, Dec., 1873; assistant director-general of the post office of India, July, 1880; inspector of railway and mail service, Nov., 1885; deputy director-general of the post-office of India from April, 1888.

SHEWAN, ALEXANDER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Gymnasium, Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and acting forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; on special forest duty in connection with the dahli cultivation settlement in Ahmednagar, March, 1881, and Feb., 1882; from Jan., 1885, served as assistant judge and sessions judge; acting under secretary to government, Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the legislative council, March, 1886; administrator of the Rajpipla state, Nov., 1887.

SHIPLEY, REGINALD HEBER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1883; and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

SHIRRES, LESLIE PITTEDRIGH, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; served in the revenue and judicial department of Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiated as under secretary to government of Bengal, Feb., 1887, and was confirmed, Jan., 1888; officiated as under secretary to the government of India, department of finance and commerce, in Nov., 1887, and again from April, 1888.

SHORTREDE, ROBERT, Audit Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 1st Feb., 1864; junior examiner, Sept., 1866; senior examiner, July, 1873.

SHRIPAD BABAJI THAKUR, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bombay University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; from June, 1882, served in the judicial department, and was promoted to 1st grade assistant judge and sessions judge, Nov., 1885; acted as district and sessions judge, 1887 and 1888.
