SHIRRAM BHIKAJI JATAR, B.A., Education Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Served in the Bombay education department from Jan., 1859, in the Marathi translator's office, and as assistant master in the high schools at Bombay and Belgaum, and head master of the Carwar English school; from July, 1867, served in Berar as deputy educational inspector, and acting head master, high school, Amraoti; educational inspector, Aug., 1876; director of public instruction, Hyderabad assigned districts, Aug., 1884.

SHUJAAT ALI KHAN MIR, Madras C.S.—Served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Aug., 1876, in various subordinate posts, and was appointed by the government of India, as probationer for the civil service from 15th Dec., 1881; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

SHURLOCK, H. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India store depot, Aug., 1886.

SHUTTLEWORTH, ALLEN THORNTON, Forest Department, Bombay.—Appointed to the Indian marine, Nov., 1855; arrived in India, 1st April, 1856; served in the Persian War, including the bombardment of Bushire and Mohumerah (medal), and in the operations against the Wagheers in Okhamandal; from Nov., 1863, served in the Bombay forest department as assistant conservator, and deputy conservator, and was appointed conservator of forests and superintendent of botanical gardens, Sept., 1869; 1st grade conservator, Nov., 1871; while stationed at Alibag as deputy conservator of forests was instrumental in saving upwards
of a hundred lives from different wrecks; these services were acknowledged in different ways by the government of Bombay, the Bombay Harbour Board, and the merchants of Bombay; Albert medal of the 1st class; medals of the Royal Humane Society, the Shipwrecked Mariners' Company, and Lloyds, &c.

SHUTTLEWORTH, EDWARD INGLIS, Police Department, Bengal.—From 20th March, 1856, to June, 1862, served as superintendent of salt chowkies; from June, 1862, served in the police department, and was appointed district superintendent, 1st grade, Feb., 1880.

SIBTHORPE, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.S., F.K., and Q.C.P. (Dublin), Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1870; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Banda, July, 1874; from May, 1875, to Nov., 1880, served as resident surgeon, General Hospital, Madras, and Professor of pathology and materia medica in the Medical College, and acted for various periods as surgeon, General Hospital, and professor of surgery, and as ophthalmic surgeon, and professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology; also served in the Afghan war, 1878-79 (medal); surgeon-major, April, 1882; from Oct., 1882, served as fort surgeon, inspector of seamen at Madras, and professor of anatomy at the Medical College, also acting as secretary and statistical officer to the surgeon-general, Her Majesty's forces, April-Aug., 1883, and as principal medical storekeeper, Madras, Sept., 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; surgeon, general hospital, and professor of surgery, &c., medical college, Jan., 1888.

SILCOCK, HENRY FOSTER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Drogheda Grammar School and Kingstown School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, acting district superintendent of police, acting cantonment magistrate, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; and assistant collector, April, 1887; acting 1st assistant collector.

SILCOCK, JAMES GREER, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Armagh Royal School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived, 16th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty at Peshawur, Feb., 1881; officiated as district judge, Oct., 1885, to Jan., 1886, and as divisional judge, April, 1886 and again April, 1888.

SIM, HENRY ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate and acting collector and magistrate; from Jan., 1883, served as deputy conservator of forests, Kurnool, and forest settlement officer; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Malabar, Feb., 1886; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, March, 1886; employed under government of India as officiating deputy accountant-general, Aug.-Nov., 1887; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Jan., 1888; acting secretary to the commissioners of land revenue, Feb., 1888.

SIME, JOHN, B.A., Education Department, Punjab.—Professor, Government College, Agra, April, 1869; from Sept., 1870, served in the Punjab in the 3rd grade of the education department as principal, Delhi College, till 1877, and subsequently as professor, and officiating principal, Lahore College; inspector of schools, Nov., 1880; on special duty at Naini Tal, educational commission, April-May, 1885; tutor to H.H. the Maharaja of Patiala, May, 1885; promoted to 2nd grade of the department, March, 1886.

SIMPSON, SIR BENJAMIN, Surgeon-General, K.C.I.E., M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1853; served in civil employ from 1860, as assistant surgeon in Bengal, and was in medical charge of the Bhootan mission in 1863; on special duty on north-eastern frontier, 1867-68; civil surgeon, Darjeeling, April, 1868; from Jan., 1871, served as civil surgeon of Patna with charge of the Metapore jail; on special duty to the cinchona commission, Feb., 1871; surgeon-major, Oct., 1873; guardian to the Maharajah of Cooch Behar during his visit to Europe, March, 1878; deputy surgeon-general, southern Afghanistan field force, 1881; principal medical officer, Quetta, 1881; deputy surgeon-general, March, 1882; sanitary commissioner, Central Provinces, 1882; surgeon-general in the Punjab, 1883-84; surgeon-general, Bengal, 1884-85; sanitary commissioner, and surgeon-general with the government of India, March, 1885; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

SIMSON, D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Grammar School and Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, in 1845; arrived in India, 5th April, 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces, and in the Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner; commissioner in Oudh, June, 1859; extra judge, court of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, April, 1864; judge, chief court, Punjab, April, 1868; retired 1872.

SINCLAIR, DAVID, Surgeon-Major, M.B., C.M., Jail Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st Oct., 1869; arrived in Madras, 14th May, 1870; from 1871, served in British Burma, and was employed in the analysis of potable waters in cantonments, April, 1871, to Dec., 1872; served subsequently as superintendent of the central jail at Moulmein, with occasional charge of the central jail at Rangoon; also officiated as civil surgeon and superintendent of lock hospital at Moulmein in 1874, and was in medical charge of the general hospital in that year; officiating inspector-general of prisons, British Burma, May-Oct., 1875, and again July, 1882; appointed superintendent of the central jail at Rangoon, Feb., 1883; inspector-general of jails, sanitary commissioner, superintendent of vaccination, and in charge of civil medical department, Burma, Jan., 1884.

SINCLAIR, D. E., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster School, King's College School, and Merton College, Oxford; writer in post office, British museum, and admiralty, 1873-80; supervisor, and grade, India store depot, Aug., 1880.
SINCLAIR, WILLIAM FREDERICK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Armagh Royal School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting railway magistrate, and was on special duty for demarcation of forests in Khândesh, April, 1873, and in Alibág, Jan., 1874; on special duty, Poona, Nov., 1875; forest demarcating officer, Thána, Jan., 1876; on famine duty, April-Aug., 1877; first assistant collector and forest settlement officer, Feb., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Kolaba, May, 1885; author of 'Notes on Arboriculture in the Bombay Presidency.'

SINKINSON, EDWARD JAMES, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Windermere College and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1873, to Feb., 1877, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner, junior secretary to chief commissioner (March, 1876), inspector-general of prisons, sanitary commissioner and superintendent of vaccination (Sept., 1876), and member of the prison conference (Jan.-Feb., 1877); from Feb., 1877, served in the financial department of the government of India, and was appointed under secretary to government, June, 1877; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner of state paper currency, April-July, 1880; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1881; deputy-accountant-general, Madras, July, 1882; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884; acted as deputy accountant-general, Punjab, Feb.-March, 1884, and as accountant-general from Nov., 1885; officiating accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1887; and officiating financial secretary to government of India, Dec., 1887.

SKINNER, JOHN ALLAN CLEVELAND, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1885; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Khandwa, Nov., 1885.

SKINNER, RUSSELL MORLAND, Lieutenant-Col., B.S.C., late Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 7th Dec., 1855; joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, 1st grade, April, 1862; district superintendent, Aug., 1863; on special duty, June, 1873; 1st grade district superintendent, Aug., 1876; retired, April, 1888.

SKIPWITH, GRAY TOWNSEND, Lieutenant-Colonel.—Public works department government of India; 1st commission, 11th June, 1858; joined public works department, Oct., 1860; 1st assistant engineer, Nov., 1863; executive engineer, April, 1865; assistant secretary to chief commissioner central provinces, and assistant to chief engineer, Feb., 1870; assistant secretary to government of India public works department, Feb., 1872; 3rd superintending engineer, Feb., 1880; and superintending engineer, March, 1887.

SKRINE, FRANCIS HENRY BENNET, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; on famine relief duty, May, 1874, and Oct., 1877, to April, 1878 (in Madras); superintendent of Salem central jail, Jan., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1884; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Aug., 1887.

SLACK, FRANCIS ALEXANDER, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Taunton College School, University College, Oxford, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1874; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1876; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; settlement officer of wards and attached estates in Chota Nagpur; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Jan., 1888.

SLADEN, Sir EDWARD BOSC, Knt., Colonel, M.S.C.—Appointed to the Madras army, April, 1849; arrived in India, July, 1849; served as assistant commissioner in the Tenasserim and Martaban provinces from Dec., 1855; on military duty, 1857-59; rejoined the Tenasserim commission, 1859, and served as assistant commissioner and town magistrate of Moulmein, and afterwards of Rangoon (Aug., 1863); agent to the chief commissioner of Burma at the court of Mandalay, Jan., 1865; political agent at Mandalay, 1867; appointed to conduct an expedition overland through Burma to South-Western China, 1868; on special duty with the King of Siam in India, Dec., 1871; rejoined the Burma commission as deputy commissioner, March, 1872, and acted as commissioner of Tenasserim from May, 1873; from March, 1876 to 1886, served as commissioner of Arakan.

SLADEN, JOSEPH, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, Nov., 1888.

SLATER, J. S., Educational Service, Bengal.—From Sept., 1870, to Nov., 1875, served in the public works department, Punjab, as engineer apprentice and assistant engineer, on the Bari Doab and Indus canals; from Nov., 1875, served in the Bengal education department as professor, civil engineering department, Presidency College, and, from April, 1880, as professor of the Howrah Engineering College; officiating principal, Howrah College, Feb., 1881; 3rd class of the education department, March, 1881.

SLY, FRANK GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1887; and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

SMEATON, DONALD MACKENZIE, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at the Abbey Park Institution, St. Andrew's, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from May, 1870, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Feb., 1877; transferred to British Burma as settle-
ment secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1879; on special duty in India, April, 1882; secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, in the land revenue and agricultural department, and director of agriculture, May, 1882; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Aug., 1884, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1886; officiating chief secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, April, 1887; commissioner, central division, Upper Burma, May, 1888; author of an annotated edition of the N.W. Provinces Revenue Act of 1873, and of 'The Karens of Burma.'

SMEATON, ROBERT, M.A. (Class. and Phil.), LL.D., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Abbey Park Institution and University of St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; first assistant secretary to government, July, 1876; under secretary, May, 1877; junior secretary, Aug., 1877; officiated for various periods as secretary to government in the Oudh revenue department; secretary to government, financial department, May, 1884.

SMITH, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; from Dec., 1857, served as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector, and was appointed senior superintendent of survey, Aug., 1872, magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and commissioner, of the Orissa division, and superintendent of tributary Mehals, Cuttack, Oct., 1879; commissioner, Presidency division, July, 1884.

SMITH, A. CREMER, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 23rd June, 1865; junior clerk, store department, Nov., 1866; senior clerk, Nov., 1876.

SMITH, CHARLES JOHN, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—1st commission, Madras engineers, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857; assistant engineer in the Madras public works department, Jan., 1858; executive engineer, Nov., 1865; appointed to carry out certain investigations in connection with the flood waters of the Cauvery, Dec., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, and deputy consulting engineer for railways, Oct., 1870 to 1883; under secretary to government, public works department, May, 1872; superintending engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1883; consulting engineer and joint secretary to government, railway branch, 1883; chief engineer, 3rd class (supernumerary), Dec., 1885; 2nd class, May, 1888.

SMITH, F. WHITMORE, Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Bedford School and Cheltenham College; temporary clerk, India office, 23rd Jan., 1864; junior clerk, military department, July, 1866; senior clerk, Jan., 1880.

SMITH, GEORGE, Surgeon-General, M.D., late Madras Medical Department.—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh (gold medals for medical jurisprudence and midwifery, M.D. in 1843, and prize for anatomy); appointed to the Madras medical service, 1844; was on field service in Goomsoor, 1847-48; appointed professor of anatomy and physiology, Dec., 1850; secretary, medical college, Madras, 1851; garrison assistant-surgeon, Fort St. George, Oct., 1854; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, Dec., 1854 to 1860, with charge of medical school; was present at the defence of the Hyderabad residency, July 1857; professor of midwifery and superintendent of eye infirmary, March, 1863; fellow of Madras University; principal of Madras medical college, 1868; deputy surgeon-general, Mysore division, March, 1875; surgeon-general, Aug., 1876, to April, 1880; has published a practical treatise of percussion, translated from the French; edited the Hyderabad Medical Journal in Hindustani; author of various contributions to Madras and other journals of medical science; good service pension in 1879, and Indian war medal.

SMITH, GILBERT LESLIE, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Twyford School and St. Andrew's University; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; employed under the public works department in taking up land for the Punjab northern state railway, Aug., 1877, to Feb., 1878; officiating divisional judge, April, 1886, May, 1887, and June, 1888; district judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1887.

SMITH, HENRY SCOTT, Bengal S.C. (Punjab).—Educated at Trinity College, Stratford-on-Avon, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

SMITH, JOHN, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 22nd Jan., 1875; retired, May, 1886.

SMITH, JOHN MACDONALD, Colonel, M.S.C., Chief Presidency Magistrate, Madras.—First commission, Madras infantry, 29th April, 1855; served in the China expedition with the 12th regiment N.I.; staff corps, Nov., 1861; assistant to the agent in Vizagapatam, Dec., 1861 to 1868; junior assistant collector, Ganjam, 1870-1878; wrote a hand-book in the Khond language; superintendent of central and district jails, Rajahmundry, April, 1880, to April, 1882, and was on special duty in 1881 as secretary to the special commissioner on his tour to the northern districts; from June, 1882, to Dec., 1885, served as paymaster of pensioners, Bangalore, and also acted as district magistrate and president of the municipality of that place, 1883-84, and in 1885; board of examiners, May, 1883; chief presidency magistrate, Madras, Dec., 1885.

SMITH, JOSEPH, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Etah, Aug., 1881, and afterwards at Etawah and at Banda; officiating district and sessions judge, July, 1886; retired, April, 1887.

SMITH, Sir Robert Murdoch, K.C.M.G.,
Colonel, R.E., late Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, Aug., 1863; director of the Persian section from June, 1865; director in chief, Indo-European telegraph department, March, 1887; retired, Feb., 1888.

SMITH, SAMUEL G., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 6th Jan., 1883.

SMITH, THOMAS, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner; appointed district and sessions judge, Tipperah, Dec., 1877, and served subsequently in the judicial department; 1st grade district and sessions judge, Nov., 1881; retired, Jan., 1888.

SMITH, TURTON, Police Department, Punjab.—From 26th March, 1863, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, May, 1881; between Dec., 1871, and Sept., 1878, also served in the postal department as officiating assistant director-general of post offices, and as officiating postmaster-general at Bombay, Aug., 1876, and at Madras, May, 1878; officiating deputy inspector-general of police, Feb., 1885.

SMITH, J. W., India Office Store Department.—Appointed 2nd class clerk store Depot, 23rd May, 1888.

SMITH, VINCENT ARTHUR, B.A., M.R.A.S., M.A.S.B., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, and Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1874, to Nov., 1880, served in the settlement department in Hamirpur, and was appointed assistant settlement officer, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; on special duty in the Allahabad district, Nov., 1880; served subsequently as assistant magistrate, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was also settlement officer of Basti, 1883-84; joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1885; author of 'The Settlement Officer's Manual,' and of contributions to the journal of the Asiatic society in 1881 and 1884.

SMYTH, GEORGE, B.A., C.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, and Dec., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating registrar of the chief court, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, March, 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Oct., 1883; deputy commissioner, and grade, Oct., 1885.

SMYTH, JOHN WATT (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857, and was appointed assistant magistrate and collector, Agra, Nov., 1858; transferred to Punjab, May, 1859, and served as assistant commissioner, and as personal assistant to the financial commissioner, and to the judicial commissioner; registrar of the chief court, Feb., 1866; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1860; officiated as commissioner and superintendent of the Lahore division in 1869, 1872, and 1879, and as additional commissioner of Amritsar, 1874-77; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, April, 1877; judge, chief court, March, 1880; retired, 1885.

SMYTH, RALPH GRAHAM, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Burma.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 7th Dec., 1855; from 6th Nov., 1857, served in the public works department in the Central and N.W. Provinces as assistant engineer; served in the field force at Lucknow, and at the final capture of Lucknow, 1858 (medal and clasp); officiating garrison engineer, Lucknow, June, 1859; on military duty, May, 1861; reappointed to public works department, April, 1862; and served in Bengal as assistant engineer and executive engineer (Jan., 1864); on special duty in investigations connected with river Selye, and with reservoirs in the Purulia and Palamow districts, Nov., 1867, to May, 1869; served in the Ramghur and Burbee divisions and on the Grand Trunk Road, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1870; superintending engineer, July, 1876; transferred to Hyderabad, Dec., 1881, as secretary to resident in the public works department; 1st class superintending engineer, Sept., 1882; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, Aug., 1885, to Dec., 1885.

SMYTH, THOMAS WATT, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, and Feb., 1862, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and small cause court judge; registrar of the chief court, 1867-70; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; on special duty in the civil secretariat, Feb. and Oct., 1882; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Aug., 1882; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Umballa, and Amritsur divisions, April, 1883; divisional judge, and grade, Nov., 1884; officiating judge, chief court, March, 1886; confirmed as judge of the chief court, Jan., 1887; author of 'Acts and Regulations applicable to the Punjab.'

SNYD, JOHN ALEXANDER PARSONS (Madras Salt, &c., Department).—Served in the police department, Bengal, from 28th June, 1869, to Aug., 1876, as officiating assistant superintendent; confirmed 3rd grade assistant superintendent, Jan., 1876; assistant commissioner, salt revenue, Madras, Jan., 1886; deputy commissioner of salt and abkari revenue, Feb., 1887.

SNOW, PHILIP CHICHELEY HYDE (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Haileybury and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, Delhi, Nov., 1876; from March, 1877, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, assistant cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; from Nov., 1881, served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate and district registrar, and was permanently transferred to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; forest settlement officer, Dec., 1885; acting under secretary to government political, judicial,
and educational departments, Sept., 1886; 2nd assistant collector, Nov., 1887.

SORABJI PADAMJI PESTANJI, Bombay C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, 14th Jan., 1880; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, March, 1882; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

SPANKIE, ROBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury; entered the Honourable East India company's service in 1844, and was attached to the N.W. Provinces; magistrate and collector, 1853; district judge, 1859; extra judge, Sudder Dewanii and Nizamut Adawlut, Agra, 1864, and officiated as judge in that court in 1865 and 1866; officiated as puisne judge of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, on its establishment in 1866, and in 1867 was confirmed in this appointment, which he held till his retirement on 31st May, 1881.

SPEARMAN, HORACE RALPH, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 1st Highlanders, 8th Dec., 1857; probationary assistant engineer, public works department, 1862; from Dec., 1862, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and assistant secretary to the chief commissioner (Feb., 1868); also officiated as secretary to the chief commissioner, and as director of public instruction; officiating assistant political agent, Bhamo, March, 1871; appointed a deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877, and was promoted to 1st grade, Aug., 1886; on special duty in Rangoon, Feb., 1879, and Feb., 1883; president, Rangoon municipal committee, May, 1883, and again, Jan., 1886, and of the Akyab municipal committee, Jan., 1884; member of the education syndicate, Feb., 1886; author of 'British Burma Gazetteer'; officiating commissioner Pegu and Irrawaddy division, Feb., 1888.

SPEDDING, ROBERT DECY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; served from Aug., 1862, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; deputed to conduct demarcation of boundary between districts of Banda and Hamirpur and the native states of Bundelkhand, Oct., 1870; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, April, 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Gorakpur, Dec., 1879, and subsequently in Moradabad; officiated as commissioner in the Agra division in 1884, and in the Benares division in 1886.

SPENCE, JAMES KNOX, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from May, 1878, to Oct., 1880, served in the postal department, as acting postmaster-general, Bombay, also in the Punjab and Bengal; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Kolaba, June, 1885.

SPENCER, HUGH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bristol grammar school, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

SPENCER, L. D., Surgeon-Major, M.D., Indian Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, March, 1865; served under the civil department in the Central Provinces, and with the Central India horse; from Oct., 1871, served as agency surgeon, Eastern States, Rajputana; on special famine duty, Oct., 1877, and acted as political agent, Karauli, in 1877, and in Bharatpur, 1878; in 1879 was in medical charge of the Marwar and Jaisalmer agency; from March, 1881, served as agency surgeon, Rajputana, and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination.

SPRY, ARTHUR HUME, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 22nd Oct., 1857, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, special officer of income tax, acting collector and magistrate, assistant political agent, and acting talukdari settlement officer; junior collector and magistrate, Dhawar, Dec., 1878; senior collector, Kalra, Oct., 1882; on special duty in the Cambay state, Feb., 1883; retired, 1886.

STACE, EDWARD VINCENT, Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1862; from June, 1871, served in the Bombay revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, and as boundary settlement commissioner (July, 1872); between May, 1873, and March, 1875, acted as assistant political resident, Aden, and also as cantonment magistrate; from April, 1875, acted as assistant political agent, Kathiawar, and was on special duty with the son of H.H. the Jam of Navanagar, May, 1877; also acted as assistant political agent of Kolhapur and Southern Maharatta country, and as superintendent of surveys under the Rajasthani court, Kathiawar; second assistant resident at Aden, Sept., 1880; assistant political agent, Kathiawar, Dec., 1881; joint administrator, Rajpipla, Feb., 1885.

STACK, G. A., Bengal Education Department.—Served in the educational department from 1st Jan., 1868, as professor at the Agra, Bareilly, and Dacca Colleges, and acted at different times as principal of the Bareilly College, inspector of schools and principal of the Krishnagur College; professor, Patna College, Jan., 1883; 3rd class of the education department, July, 1886; professor in the Presidency College, Feb., 1888.

STACK, OLIVER STOKES, Police Department, Bengal.—From 8th June, 1859, to May, 1862, served as deputy magistrate and deputy collector; from May, 1862, served in the police department, and was appointed district superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1878; deputy inspector-general, July, 1885; officiating inspector-general, June, 1886.

STALEY, ALFRED EVELYN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, Concord, U.S.A., and St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1875; attached to N.W. Provinces; served in revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Bengal, Jan., 1880; officiating under secretary, Government of Bengal, March, 1884; and again in 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1886; 1st grade, March, 1888.

STANDEN, BERTRAM PRIOR, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Uppingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal
civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886.

STANHOPE, RIGHT HON. EDWARD, M.P.—Born 1840; educated at Harrow and at Christchurch, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1862; M.A., 1865; elected fellow of All Souls' College, 1862; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1865, and joined the home circuit; was one of the assistant commissioners on the employment of women and children in agriculture, 1867; sat in the House of Commons for Mid-Lincolnshire from Feb., 1874, till the general election of 1885, when he was returned for the Horncastle division of that county; parliamentary secretary to the board of trade, Nov., 1875, to April, 1878; under-secretary of state for India, April, 1878, to April, 1880; vice-president of the committee of council on education, June to Aug., 1885; president of the board of trade, Aug., 1885, to Jan., 1886; secretary of state for the colonies, Aug., 1886; secretary of state for war, Jan., 1887.

STANFELD, RIGHT HON. JAMES, M.P.—Born in 1820; educated at University College, London, where he took the degree of LL.B.; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1849; was returned to parliament for Halifax, April, 1859; appointed a lord of the admiralty in April, 1863; resigned in April, 1864; under-secretary of state for India, Feb. to June, 1866; third lord of the treasury, Dec., 1868; joint secretary to the treasury, Oct., 1866; president of the poor law board, March, 1871; was first president of the new local government board, Aug., 1871, to Jan., 1874, and again March-Aug., 1886.

STANTALL, W., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 25th Sept., 1882; attached to the public works department.

STANTON, FREDERICK SMITH, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—Date of commission, 10th Dec., 1850; arrived in India, June, 1853; assistant engineer, public works department, Bengal, Nov., 1853; executive engineer, grand trunk road, July, 1857; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Jan., 1860; executive engineer, 1st grade, Dec., 1863; was employed on special duties in 1863-64, and also as executive engineer in the circular and eastern canal, and Darjeeling divisions, and served under the military department with the Dooar field force; officiating consulting engineer and joint secretary in the railway branch, government of Bengal, Aug., 1867, to March, 1868, when he was transferred to Oudh in the same capacity; deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1869; superintending engineer on the Rajputana state railway, Feb., 1871; temporarily in charge of Tirhoot famine line, Feb., 1874; superintending engineer, 1st grade, April, 1874; extra deputy consulting engineer to government of India for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, Oct., 1875; engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, Feb., 1876; officiating director of state railways, north-eastern system, and officiating joint secretary to government of Bengal, May, 1877; chief engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1880; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, P.W. Department, Feb., 1880-March, 1883; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, Feb., 1882, to Feb., 1887; chief engineer, 1st class, Feb., 1887; retired, Feb., 1887.

STAVELEY, SIR CHARLES WILLIAM DUNBAR, General, G.C.B.—Educated at the Scottish Naval and Military Academy, Edinburgh; 2nd lieutenant, 87th Foot, March, 1835; assistant military secretary to Col. W. Staveley, in Mauritius, Feb.-Nov., 1842, and at Hong Kong, June, 1847-Dec., 1850; A.D.C. to Lieutenant-General Earl Cathcart, in Canada, March, 1845, to May, 1847; served the Eastern campaign of 1854-55, including the battles of Alma and Balaklava, and the siege of Sebastopol (medal, C.B., Sardinian and Turkish medals, and 5th class of the Medjidie); brigadier-general in North China, 1860-1862 (medal); from Feb., 1862, to June, 1863, was in command of the troops during the operations against the Taepings, in the vicinity of Shanghai, resulting in the capture of the entrenched camp of Onkatz, and the towns of Kadin, Tsinpoo Cholim, Najow, and Tserpoo; K.C.B., March, 1865; from March, 1865, to Sept., 1867, served as brigadier-general in the Bombay presidency, and was in command of the northern division and the Poona brigade successively; was second in command in the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, and was present at the action of Arrogee, and capture of Magdala; received the thanks of parliament, and was promoted to a major-general, 1868 (medal); major-general on the staff, western division, Devonport, Jan.-March, 1869; commander-in-chief, Bombay, and member of the governor's council, Oct., 1874, to Oct., 1878; G.C.B., 24th May, 1884.

STEAD, VEN. SAMUEL, M.A. (Oxon), late Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, March, 1863; arrived in India, 24th April, 1863, and served as chaplain at Karachi, Sholapur, cantonment of Belgaum, and Poona; senior chaplain, April, 1873; archdeacon and commissary, Nov., 1878; also held charge of the diocese of Bombay, Oct., 1877, to Nov., 1878, and Oct., 1883, to June, 1884; retired, June, 1886.

STEANE, W.C., Registry Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 9th Nov., 1860; clerk, and class, Aug., 1878.

STEAVENSON, JOSEPH, B.A., Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 25th Feb., 1878, as acting registrar of the high court (original side), Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1880.

STEEDMAN, EDWARD, C.B., Brigadier-General, B.S.C., Burma Police.—1st commission, 19th Dec., 1860; major, Dec., 1880; and lieutenant-colonel, Dec., 1885; served in the Hazara campaign, 1868 (medal with clasp), and in the Afghan war of 1878-80; with Sir Frederick Roberts in the march to Candahar; and present at the battle of Candahar (medal with clasp and bronze decoration); served in the Burma expedition of 1886-7, and commanded the operations in the Shan states; inspector-general of police, Upper Burma, May, 1887.

STEEDMAN, EDWARD BRITAIN, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Shrewsbury; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; officiating director of settlements and revenue records, March, 1887; confirmed, May, 1887; designation changed to land records and agriculture; author of 'Report on the Settlement of the Jhang District.'

STEEL, CHARLES DENTON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the
Wesleyan Connexional School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Oct., 1886; author of 'Allahabad Gazetteer.'

STEEL, HENRY WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1862, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; services placed temporarily at disposal of public works department in connection with Punjab northern state railway, July, 1874; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1878; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; 1st grade, Jan., 1887.

STEEL, JOHN PHILIP, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; joined the public works department, March, 1860, as assistant engineer, Bengal; executive engineer, April, 1868; officiating assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1871; officiating under secretary, government of India, public works department, March, 1873, to 1875, and again Feb., 1877; superintending engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, May, 1879; superintending engineer, 1st class, May, 1886; officiating chief engineer and secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1887; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Oct., 1887; chief engineer and joint secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1888; 3rd chief engineer, April, 1888.

STEINBELT, JEAN MARI CONRAD, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Mirzapur, Sept., 1878; from April, 1881, served as civil and sessions judge in Banda, and afterwards at Azamgarh; retired, April, 1887.

STEINBERG, ALFRED FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Dulwich College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1881, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and assistant inspector of labourers.

STEPHEN, ARTHUR, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1867; served under the military department in the Punjab as assistant surgeon and surgeon; Lahore medical school, 1874; superintendent of jail, Lahore, 1876; surgeon-major, Sept., 1879; statistical officer to government of India, sanitary and medical department, 1880; officiated as sanitary commissioner, Punjab, in 1880 and 1886.

STEPHEN, CARR (Barrister-at-Law).—Served in the Punjab from 11th June, 1856, as extra assistant commissioner and small cause court judge; extra judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1875; officiating divisional judge, Nov., 1885, to Jan., 1886; has published 'Indian Registration Act,' 4th edition, 'Handbook for Delhi,' and 'Archaeology of Delhi.'

STEPHEN, SIR JAMES FITZJAMES, K.C.S.I., M.A., an Honorary Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge, D.C.L., Oxford, LL.D., Edinburgh, and LL.B., London.—Educated at Eton, King's College, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated B.A. in 1852; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, Jan., 1854; went the Midland Circuit, and became recorder of Newark-on-Trent (1859-69); legal member of the council of the governor-general of India, Dec., 1860-1872; appointed by the Inns of Court professor of common law, Dec., 1875, and a member of the councils of legal education and law reporting; K.C.S.I., 1877; a member of the royal commission appointed to enquire into the provisions of a draft code relating to indictable offences, 1878; judge of the high court of Justice (Queen's bench division), Jan., 1879; president of the ordnance inquiry commission, 1886-7; has published 'General View of the Criminal Law of England,' 1863; 'Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity,' 1873; 'History of the Criminal Law,' 3 vols., 1883; 'The Digest of the Law of Evidence;' 'Digest of the Criminal Law,' 4th Edition, 1887.

STERNDALE, R. A., Financial Department, Government of India.—Served during the mutiny as a volunteer, 1857, and took part in the operations in Central India (medal); lieutenant, Behar station guards, Jan., 1885; from Aug., 1859, served in the Central Provinces as deputy collector and assistant settlement officer; from June, 1864, served in the financial department in Nagpore, Calcutta, and the Punjab, as assistant commissioner of paper currency, acting assistant accountant-general, acting deputy accountant-general, and acting assistant comptroller-general; 3rd class of financial department (new scheme), Aug., 1880; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Jan., 1884, and Madras, Nov., 1887; is a fellow of the Royal Geographical and Zoological Societies; author of 'Mammalia of British India and Ceylon,' 'Denizens of the Jungles, Seoni;' or Camp Life on the Satpura Range,' a 'Topographical and Historical Account of the District of Seoni,' 'Turkey and India; or Our Indian Moslems,' 'The Afghan Knife,' and other works; joint editor of the 'Journal of the Bombay Natural History Society.'

STEVENS, CHARLES CECIL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at University of Melbourne; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, and Feb., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1882; commissioner, Chota Nagpur division, April, 1885.

STEVENS, JOHN FOSTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Birmingham Grammar School, at Versailles, and at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 16th Oct., 1865; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy
collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; district and sessions judge, and grade, Mymensingh, Sept., 1884.

STEVENSON, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's College, Aberdeen, and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Sylhet, Jan., 1885, and grade, May, 1886.

STEVENSON-MOORE, CHARLES JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Felsted School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

STEWARD, ARTHUR BENNET, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, acting junior collector and magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Dec., 1882; acting postmaster-general, Bombay, Aug., 1884; to May, 1885; acting assistant judge, Poona, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, Oct., 1885; judicial assistant to political agent, Kathiawar, Nov., 1887.

STEWART, SIR DONALD MARTIN, Bart., General, G.C.B., G.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Ensign, Bengal army (infantry), 12th Oct., 1840; adjutant, 9th Bengal native infantry, 1845; interpreter and quartermaster, 9th N.I., 1852; deputy assistant adjutant-general, Delhi field force, June, 1857; assistant adjutant-general of army, Dec., 1857; deputy adjutant-general in India, Feb., 1863; brigadier-general, Abyssinian expeditionary force, 1868; in command of Pesawur district, July, 1869; chief commissioner of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, 1871; in command of Lahore Division, April, 1876; commanding Kandahar and Southern Afghanistan force, 1878-80; commanding at Kabul and in Northern Afghanistan, 1880, till withdrawal from that country; military member of governor-general's council, 1880; commander-in-chief in India, and extraordinary member of the governor-general's council, 1881; member of council of India, 16th Dec., 1885.

STEWART, ROBERT BARTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1886; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1887.

STEWART, THEODORE HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to inquire into land alienations in the Panch Mahals, Sept., 1865; boundary settlement officer, May, 1866; on special duty to inquire into titles of land in Surat, Aug., 1867; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Sholapur, Oct., 1879; survey and settlement commissioner, June, 1881; on special duty as member of the public service commission, Dec., 1886.

STEWART, WILLIAM DAY, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; from May, 1874, officiated as civil surgeon of Cuttack, and was confirmed in this appointment, June, 1876; also superintendent of the jail, lunatic asylum, and Medical School; surgeon-major, Oct., 1878.

STEWART-WILSON, CHARLES, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh High School, and University College, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1886; served in the N.P. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector.

STIFFE, A. W., Captain, I.M.—From 24th Feb., 1849, served in the Indian marine as midshipman, lieutenant, and senior lieutenant, and assistant surveyor; on special survey for telegraph cable in Persian Gulf, Nov., 1862; on special duty in Turkish Arabia, Feb., 1863; engineer, Persian Gulf telegraphs, and commanding "Amberwitch," Oct., 1863; officiating director, Persian Gulf telegraphs, April-Aug., 1866, and Sept., 1869, to Jan., 1871; also electrician, Aug., 1871; on special duty in England, May, 1875, and May, 1878; in command of cable steamer "Patrick Stewart," May-July, 1879; port officer, Calcutta, Aug., 1879; officiating superintendent of marine, July, 1880; ex-officio shipping master of Calcutta, Feb., 1882; is also president of board of examiners in seamanship, registrar of shipping and wrecks, and presidency magistrate; has brought out new charts and pilots of the Persian gulf and Makran coast; also a new chart of Maskat, and a description of the Hooghly.

STIMPSON, E. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 21st May, 1873; resigned, 24th June, 1879; reappointed, 10th July, 1880.

STOGDON, ABRAHAM WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; services placed temporarily at disposal of government of India, military department, Feb., 1881; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Aug., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

STOKER, THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rathmines School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1878; 1st assistant secretary to government, April, 1884; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1884; officiated as secretary to government in the financial department in 1885 and 1886; settlement officer, Bulandshahr, Sept., 1886.

STOKES, GABRIEL, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kilkenny College, Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; ap-
pointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served in Bombay till Dec., 1872, and afterwards in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; acting additional under secretary to government of Madras in the revenue (famine) department, May, 1877, to April, 1879; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Sept., 1878; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1879; acting Canarese translator to government, Feb., 1880; acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, July, 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations, Sept., 1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, South Arcot, May, 1886.

STOKES, HENRY EDWARD, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Minehead Diocesan School, Kilkenny College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; under secretary to government of Madras in the departments under the chief secretary, Aug., 1869; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, Jan., 1871; fellow of the University of Madras, Feb., 1875; sub-secretary, board of revenue, July 1875; on special duty under government of India, with the Madras salt commission, Jan.-Sept., 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1877, to Feb., 1878; and additional secretary on famine duties, Feb., 1877; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, Oct., 1879; collector and magistrate, Salem, June, 1881; member of forest draft bill committee, April, 1882; member of local self-government committee, June, 1882; secretary to government of Madras in the revenue department, Jan., 1884; acting chief secretary to government, Oct., 1886; additional member of council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Oct., 1886; chief secretary to government, Oct., 1887; temporary member of governor's council, July, 1888; appointed ordinary member and assumed office, 9th Nov., 1888.

STOKES, HENRY JOHN, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Columba College, Rathfarnham, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1863; served in Bombay from Oct., 1864, to Jan., 1870, and subsequently in Madras, and was appointed principal assistant, July, 1871, district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1877, and collector and magistrate, Madura, June, 1879; on special famine duty, Madura, Aug., 1877; district and sessions judge, Madura, Jan., 1882; collector and magistrate, North Arcot, Oct., 1884; member of draft tenancy bill committee, July, 1885; district and sessions judge, Coimbatore, May, 1886; on deputation as a member of the public service commission, Nov., 1886; on special duty in connection with rent recovery bill commission.

STOKES, WHITLEY, C.S.I., C.I.E., D.C.L., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law.—Late of legislative department of the government of India; reporter to the high court and acting administrator-general, Madras, 1863-4; served subsequently as assistant secretary to government of India legislative branch of home department, secretary to the governor-general's legislative council and to the government of India in the legislative department, and law member of the council of the governor-general, May, 1877, to May, 1882; in 1868, framed the scheme for collecting, copying, and cataloguing the Sanskrit MSS. preserved in India, in recognition of which he was made honorary member of the German Oriental Society; is an honorary member of the Deutsche Morgenländische Gesellschaft; correspondent of the Institut de France (Académie des Inscriptions et Belles Lettres), and honorary fellow of Jesus College, Oxford; author of 'A Treatise on the liens of legal Practitioners,' Bythewood and Jarman's Conveyancing,' vol. VIII., part I.; Hindu Law Books, Madras, 1865; the 'Indian Succession Act, with a Commentary,' Calcutta, 1865; the 'Indian Companies Act, 1866, with Notes'; the 'Older Statutes in force in India, with Notes,' 1874; the 'Unrepealed General Acts of the Governor-General of India, with Chronological Tables,' &c., 3 vols., Calcutta, 1875 and 1876; the 'Anglo-Indian Codes,' vol. I., 1887, and vol. II., 1888 (Clarendon Press, Oxford); the 'Tripartite life of Patrick, with other documents relating to that Saint,' 1887; and various philological works published in Germany, France, and England.

STOREY, HENRY FRANCIS, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer on the Punjab northern state railway; transferred to the Neemuch-Nasirabad railway surveys, 1878, and subsequently to the Indus Valley railway; engineer-in-chief, Kandahar state railway, March, 1880; engineer-in-chief, Indus Valley and Kandahar railways, Oct., 1881; superintendent of way and works, Sukkur, 1883; officiating manager, Indus Valley railway, Nov., 1885; superintending engineer, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886; superintending engineer, 3rd class, May, 1886; and class, Feb., 1888; officiating secretary to resident, Hyderabad, June, 1888.

STORY, ROBERT H., late Jhansi Commission.—Served in the Jhansi commission from 11th March, 1868, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty at Naogaon, in Bundelkhand, at the political agent's court, July-Nov., 1876; deputy commissioner, Jalaun, Sept., 1885.

STRACHAN, RIGHT REV. JOHN MILLER, M.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Burma.—Appointed Bishop of Rangoon, 30th June, 1882.

STRACHEY, SIR JOHN, G.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1842; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner and assistant magistrate, and collector; senior assistant, Kumaon, 1843; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1854; officiating commissioner of Kumaon, 1861; president of commission to inquire into cholera epidemic of 1861; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, 1862; president of the sanitary commission with government of India, 1864; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1866; member of governor-general's council, 7th March, 1868; acting viceroy and governor-general on death of Earl of Mayo, 1872; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1874; retired from the civil service, 1876; financial member of the governor-general's council, 23rd Dec., 1876, to 1880; left India, Dec., 1880; member of council of India, 14th July, 1885;
joint author with Lieutenant-General R. Strachey of 'The Finances and Public Works of India,' 1882; 'India,' Nov., 1888.

STRACHEY, RICHARD, Lieutenant-General, R.E., C.S.I., F.R.S.—and lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1836; was employed on irrigation works in the N.W. Provinces from 1840, and appointed executive engineer, Ganges canal, July, 1843; under secretary to government of India, public works department, 1857; secretary to government, Central Provinces, 1857; consulting engineer, railway department, Sept., 1858; secretary to government of India, public works department, 1862; inspector-general of irrigation, and chief engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1866; additional member of governor-general's council, 1866; inspecting engineer of machinery and stores for state railways, India office, 1871; member of council of India, 1875, to 12th July, 1878; special duty in India, 1878; officiating financial member of council of governor-general, 1879; officiating member of council of governor-general, 1880; president of the famine commission, 1880; reappointed member of council of India, 1879; president, royal geographical society, 1887.

STRAFFORD (Earl of), Right Hon. GEORGE HENRY CHARLES BYNG.—Born in 1830; educated at Eton and Oxford; sat in the House of Commons for Tavistock, 1854-1857, and for Middlesex, 1857, to Jan., 1874, when he succeeded to the upper house, as Viscount Enfield; attached to Earl Russell's special mission to Vienna, 1855; parliamentary secretary to the poor law board, 1865, till July, 1866; under secretary for foreign affairs, Dec., 1870; under secretary of state for India, Sept., 1880, to Dec., 1882; succeeded to the earldom of Strafford in 1886.

STRAHAN, CHARLES, Major, R.E., Survey of India.—First commission, Bengal engineers, June, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1862; joined the survey department as military second assistant, Sept., 1863; served with the Bhutan field force in charge of reconnoitring party, Oct., 1865, to July, 1866 (medal and clasp); surveyor, 3rd grade, Dec., 1867; served with the Peshawur field force in Afghanistan, 1879 (medal, brevet of major); deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Jan., 1884; assistant surveyor-general in charge of cartographic and engraving branches, May, 1884.

STRAHAN, GEORGE, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., (Bengal), Survey of India.—Obtained commission from Addiscombe, Dec., 1858; arrived in India, Nov., 1860; served under the military department, and also in the irrigation branch, public works department, till July, 1862, when he was appointed to the survey department; served as assistant in the Gwalior and Central India survey, and afterwards held charges in the Rajputana, Mysore, and Khandesh surveys; deputy superintendent, Nov., 1867; officiating assistant surveyor-general, in charge of engraving and cartographic branches, Calcutta, April-July, 1883; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

STRAIGHT, DOUGLAS (Barrister-at-Law).—Called to the bar at the Middle Temple, Nov., 1865; counsel to London banks association from 1868; junior counsel, treasury prosecution, from 1877; sat in House of Commons as member for Shrewsbury, 1870 to 1874; appointed one of the royal commissioners to inquire into corrupt election practices at Boston, 1875; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, June, 1879; fellow of Calcutta University, June, 1883, and of the Allahabad University, Nov., 1887; officiated as chief justice of the N.W. Provinces high court in 1883, 1884, and 1886.

STRATTON, JOHN PROUDFOOT, Surgeon-Major, M.D., late Bombay Medical Establishment.—Assistant surgeon, Bombay medical service, Oct., 1852; between 1854 and 1859 was employed as residency surgeon, Baroda, also serving as assistant resident, 1857-59; from Sept., 1859, served as assistant resident in Bundelcund; political agent, Bundelcund, June, 1864; surgeon-major, Oct., 1872; political agent, Meywar, 1881; resident, Western states, Rajputana, July, 1881, and in the Eastern Rajputana states, 1882, till Dec., 1885, when his services were replaced at disposal of military department; retired, Dec., 1886.

STREATFIELD, HENRY CUTHBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885. Arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

STREET, B. H. G., Store Department, India Office.—Writer, 30th June, 1874; clerk, and class, Sept., 1878; supervisor, and grade, India store depot, Oct., 1883.

STREET, CHARLES WALKER, Colonel, M.S.C.—Arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1853; ensign in Madras army, Dec., 1853; from March, 1859, served in Burma as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; magistrate of Moulmein, May, 1866; officiating superintendent of jail, Moulmein, April, 1867; officiating director of public instruction, May to Dec., 1867; from May, 1875, to Jan., 1879, served as secretary to chief commissioner, and also as officer in charge of state prisoners; employed on a mission to Siam, Jan.-June, 1879; from June, 1881, served as commissioner of the Pegu division, and was appointed a commissioner for the port of Rangoon, Oct., 1884.

STREET, HENRY ALFRED, Captain (Indian Marine), Port Officer, Madras.—Commander of 'Tenasserim,' Dec., 1876-June, 1880; assistant secretary to government of India military (marine) department, June, 1880-March, 1882; on duty in Bombay, 1882-84; assistant director Indian marine, April, 1884; 1st grade commander, Dec., 1886; port officer, Madras, Dec., 1887.

STROVER, GEORGE AUGUSTUS, Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the service as ensign, Jan., 1857; arrived at Madras, Feb., 1857; served in the Burma commission from 14th April, 1862, as assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate; officiating magistrate and small cause court judge of Rangoon, 1866; superintendent of hill tribes, North Arakan, Sept., 1868; from Aug., 1869, to Sept., 1875, served in the political department as assistant political agent at Bhamo, and political agent at Mandalay (Jan., 1872); from Nov., 1877, served as deputy commissioner of Toungoo, and acted as commissioner of Arakan, Aug. to Nov., 1883; 1st grade deputy commissioner, July, 1881; deputy commissioner and president of the municipal committee, Pegu, Dec., 1883; officiating commissioner, Pegu, April, 1886; Irrawaddy, Feb., 1888; N. division, June, 1888.

STUART, ANDREW EDMUND CASTLE-STUART,
F.G.S., F.L.S., F.R.G.S., Madras C.S.—Educated at Wellington College and Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived, 27th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; special assistant to the collectors of Nilgiris and Malabar for settlement purposes, Aug., 1886.

STUART, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Postal Department, Bombay.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1855, as postmaster in Mysore, Madras, and Hyderabad; presidency postmaster, Madras, Jan., 1864; from March, 1865, served in Bombay as presidency postmaster, and also officiated for various periods as postmaster-general, Bombay.

STUART, CHARLES JOSEPH, Colonel, M.S.C.—Arrived in India, 21st Aug., 1852; served in the Madras revenue settlement department from April, 1861, as assistant director and deputy director; special assistant to collector of Kurnool for survey and settlement purposes, April, 1871, to Nov., 1873, and again in Chingleput, Dec., 1873, and in Madura, April, 1882; 1st grade of deputy directors, June, 1883.

STUART, HAROLD ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at High School, Bishop's Stortford, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments (Dec., 1884); acting under secretary to government, revenue department, Jan., 1886; sub, pro tem, under secretary in the chief secretary's department, Oct., 1886; under secretary to government revenue department, Sept., 1888.

STUART, SIR ROBERT, Knt., Q.C.—Educated at Perth, and afterwards at the University of Edinburgh; called to the Scotch bar, July, 1840; and to the English bar at Lincoln's Inn, June, 1856; practised at the chancery bar as an equity draughtsman and conveyancer, and as an advising counsel; practised also in the House of Lords and privy council, and before parliamentary committees of both houses until 1868, when he was appointed Q.C.; and soon after elected a bencher of his inn; appointed chief justice of the north-west provinces, India, and knighted, August, 1871; retired, March, 1884; is a member of the general council of the University of Edinburgh, and has been a frequent contributor to periodical literature, especially on legal subjects; author of many legal pamphlets.

STUART, R. G., Political Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 19th Feb., 1873; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, Feb., 1876.

STULPNAGEL, CHARLES REISCH, Dr., Ph.D., M.A., Education Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab education department from 25th April, 1867, in the Zillah schools at Peshawur, Delhi and Lahore, and in the government college, Lahore; assistant professor, government college, Lahore, Jan., 1875; was appointed professor, July, 1875, and officiated for various periods as principal of the college; inspector of schools, Lahore circle, May, 1885; and grade of the education department, Feb., 1886; principal, Government College, April, 1886; inspector of schools, May, 1886.

STURROCK, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at the High School, Dundee; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting secretary to government in the revenue department, Nov., 1873; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873, and again in 1880-81; Canarese translator to government, Jan., 1874; under secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, July, 1875; additional sub-secretary, board of revenue, for special duty with famine commission, Nov., 1878, also acting as secretary, Jan., 1879; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1879; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1883; acting 4th member of board of revenue and commissioner of salt revenue, &c., July, 1888.

STURT, W. NEVILLE, Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Repton; temporary clerk, 1st May, 1862; junior clerk, store department, 1862; accountant-general's department, 1863; military department, 1863; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1863-64, and 1868-77; senior clerk, revenue department, April, 1877.

SULLIVAN, HENRY EDWARD, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Cuddalore, Sept., 1866; civil and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Dec., 1866; collector and magistrate, Bellary, March, 1868, and subsequently of Trichinopoly; officiating director of revenue settlement, Feb., 1874; acting member, board of revenue, and president of the committee for examination of assistants, April, 1876; in charge of the Inam department, May, 1876; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, March, 1877, to Feb., 1878; board of revenue, April, 1878; famine commission, Jan., 1879; 1st member, board of revenue, and commissioner, unencumbered civil service examinations, Jan., 1879; on duty studying records of famine commission, April, 1879; on special duty in Godaveri district, investigating causes of the disturbances in Rampa country, July, 1879; on duty to England as member of famine commission, Oct., 1879, to July, 1880; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Jan., 1881; in charge of settlement department, Feb., 1881; ordinary member of council, June, 1882; president of local self-government committee, June, 1882; retired, Dec., 1886.

SURYA KUMAR AGASTI, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules; assistant magistrate and collector, Purneah, on probation, March, 1885; confirmed in the statutory civil service, April, 1887.

SWAIN, W. H., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 4th June, 1881; attached to military department.

SWETENHAM, EDMUND, Colonel, B.S.C., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined public works department from Roorkee college, Nov., 1853, and served in the Punjab; resigned on obtaining commission in the army, March, 1857; served in the N.W. frontier campaign, 1858 (medal); reappointed to public works department, Feb., 1859, and served in N.W. Provinces, buildings...
and roads branch; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1869; transferred to British Burma, May, 1872; transferred to Central India, and served from Sept., 1874, to Aug., 1880, as executive engineer, Mhow division, and acted for various periods as chief engineer, and secretary to governor-general's agent; transferred to N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch, Aug., 1880, and promoted to superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1880; and class, July, 1884; 1st class, permanent, April, 1888.

SYAD ALAY MAHOMED, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Acting extra assistant commissioner, 4th class, 28th Jan., 1881; probationer for the native civil service, Dec., 1882; appointed member of the civil service, and acting assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Raipur, Dec., 1883.

SYAD NUR-UD-DIN KHAN, Bombay C.S.—Served in Hyderabad from May, 1879, as attache to Resident, judge of small causes, &c.; assistant commissioner, Jan., 1883; under secretary to Hyderabad state, Jan., 1885; appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, March, 1886; assistant collector, Jan., 1888.

SYAD NURUL HUDA, B.A., LL.B. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Officiating munisif, March, 1886; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1886.

SYKES, ROBERT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Giggleswick Grammar School and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885.

SYMES, EDWARD SPENCE, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1876; served as assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the secretariat, July and Nov., 1878; on special forest demarcation duty, Feb., 1879; personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1879; junior secretary to chief commissioner, June, 1881; also officiated as secretary to the chief commissioner for various periods, and as settlement secretary, March–May, 1882; secretary to chief commissioner and officer in charge of Delhi state prisoners, Apr., 1886; C.I.E., May, 1886; chief secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887.

SYMNS, ROBERT CORSER MONTFORT, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Westminster, King's College School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886.

SYMonds, WILLIAM POWELL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Hereford Cathedral School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; member of the central committee for departmental examinations, April, 1884; acting under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, 1884; forest settlement officer, March, 1887; and assistant collector, and acting director of land records and agriculture, Aug., 1887; acting first assistant collector and magistrate, Poona, Nov., 1887.

SZCZEPANSKI, Henry Charles Anthony, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1857; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1857; was employed under the military department up to 1860, including service during the mutiny (medal); assistant commissioner, Punjab, July, 1860; on special famine duty, Nov., 1861; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, Nov., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (1st class, Feb., 1885); officiating judicial commissioner, Feb.–May, 1883, appointed commissioner, sub-pro tem., May, 1888.

TALBOT, Adelbert Cecil, Major, C.I.E., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1867; joined the Bengal staff corps, 1869, and served with 4th cavalry, Hyderabad contingent; on special duty with the Afghan commissioner, Seistan Arbitration, 1872–73; officiating assistant agent, Rajputana, 1873; attache, secretariat, foreign department, 1874; officiating assistant secretary to the government of India, legislative department, and officiating secretary to board of examiners, Calcutta, 1875–76; acting assistant resident, and assistant-general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, Hyderabad, 1878; 1st assistant agent, Rajputana, Feb., 1878; fellow of Calcutta University, March, 1879; additional political agent, Eastern Rajputana states, 1881; political agent, Bhurtpore and Kerowlee, 1882; political agent, Bikaniir, 1883; graded as additional political agent, 1st class; officiating resident in Turkish Arabia.

TALBOT, Gerald H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; supervisor, 1st grade, India store depot, 19th June, 1877.

TANNER, Henry Charles Baskerville, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, Bombay artillery, June, 1854; accompanied the Persian expeditionary force of 1856 (medal and clasp); joined the survey department as assistant in the Sind revenue survey, Oct., 1862; was afterwards employed in the Central Provinces revenue survey, and was in charge of the Bombay city survey, Dec., 1860; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1870; was subsequently employed in the Bhawalpur revenue survey, and the Deccan survey, and accompanied the Lushai expedition in 1871–72, and the Khyber column in the Afghan campaign, 1878–79; was afterwards in charge of the Darjeeling and Nepal boundary parties, Nov., 1882; deputy superintendent, and grade, Oct., 1884; employed with the Tibet mission from May, 1886.

TATE, Alexander Chambers, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant, Sept., 1888.

TATE, William Jacob, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magis-
trate, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector, Salem, Jan., 1883.

TAUNTON, A. G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Jesuits' College, Tournay; writer, India store depot, 29th July, 1868; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

TAWNEY, C. H., C.I.E., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the department, Nov., 1864, and served as professor, Presidency College, up to Feb., 1877, when he was appointed principal of the college, and promoted to 1st class of the educational service; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1879, and again in 1885; is also registrar of the Calcutta University.

TAWNEY, JAMES WALTER, Bengal C.S.
