(Central Provinces).—Educated at Repton School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1865; served as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner, Bhootan, till Oct., 1865, and subsequently in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; also acted as small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, in 1873, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur in 1876; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Oct., 1881.

TAYLER, SKIPWITH HENRY CHURCHILL, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, and March, 1853; between July, 1854, and Sept., 1872, served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade; from Sept., 1872, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1875; retired, April, 1887.

TAYLER, WILLIAM VANSITTART GRAHAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 6th Nov., 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector 1st grade, Pubna, Oct., 1866.

TAYLOR, FRANKLIN EDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886; and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

TAYLOR, SIR ALEXANDER, K.C.B., General R.E.—Educated at Hofuzl, Switzerland, and Addiscombe military college; 1st commission, 9th June, 1843; major, Jan., 1858; colonel, March, 1864; lieutenant-general, Oct., 1877; and general (honorary rank), Dec., 1878; entered the Indian public works department, 26th Dec., 1846, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, Jan., 1848; superintendent of the Lahore and Peshawur road, Dec., 1849; superintending engineer, Nov., 1856; officiating secretary to the government of the Punjab, public works department, Jan., 1865, to Jan., 1867, and Feb., 1871, to Feb., 1872; chief engineer, April, 1872; deputy inspector-general of military works, 1870-1878; president of the defence committee of India, 1876, 1877, 1878; president of the royal Indian engineering college, Cooper's Hill, from Nov., 1880; served throughout the Sutlej campaign (medal with clasps for Ferozeshah and Sobraon), and throughout the Punjab campaign, 1848-9, being present at the action of Sooruj Khoond, the capture of Mooltan, and the battle of Goojerat (medal with 2 clasps); served throughout the Indian mutiny of 1857-8; present at the operations before, and at the siege and capture of Delhi; commanded the Bengal engineers at siege and capture of Lucknow (medal with 2 clasps); served during the Umbeyla campaign, 1863; C.B. in 1858, and K.C.B. in 1877.

TAYLOR, FREDERICK BEATSON, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Apr., 1886; 1st grade, Jan., 1888, has also officiated as district and sessions judge.

TAYLOR, GEORGE NOBLE, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, in 1840; served in the grades of assistant and head assistant collector and magistrate, and was appointed secretary to the college and university boards, and assistant collector of customs at Madras in special charge of the salt department, 1849; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Rajamundry, 1851; acted as collector and magistrate of Nellore in 1857, and of South Arcot in 1858; Inam commissioner, 1858; special commissioner for railways, Calcutta, to report upon the affairs of the East Indian railway, May, 1863, and subsequently held a similar post at Bombay; provisional member of governor-general's council, 1864; ordinary member of council, March, 1865; retired, March, 1870.

TAYLOR, HERBERT DOUGLAS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1833; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886.

TAYLOR, JAMES, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 1st Sept., 1865, and served in Bengal as assistant to the accountant-general, and deputy accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general, June, 1879.

TAYLOR, JOHN HENRY, Lieutenant, R.N.R., late Marine Department, Madras.—Served from 21st April, 1874, as acting master attendant and registrar of shipping for the port of Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1876; on special duty in the military department, May, 1878, and in England, Aug.-Sept., 1884; sheriff of Madras for the years 1885 and 1886; port officer, Madras, April, 1886; nominee trustee of the harbour trust board, May, 1886; published 'A Compendium of the Law of Storms,' prepared for the Bay of Bengal, 1874.

TAYLOR, S. A., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Epsom College; junior clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1867.

TEAGUE, GEORGE F., Funds Department, India Office.—Senior book-keeper, funds department, India office, 28th Sept., 1866; head book-keeper, March, 1873.

TEMPLE, HENRY MARTINDALE, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, 41st regiment, June, 1872; arrived in India, Sept., 1872; extra aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor, Bengal, Dec.,
1875; junior attaché, foreign department, government of India, March, 1876; senior attaché, June, 1877; cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Feb., 1878; assistant to resident, Hyderabad, and assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti, Oct., 1880; officiating judicial superintendent of railways, Nizam's Dominions, June, 1881; assistant to governor-general's agent, Baroda, Nov., 1882; boundary settlement officer, Bundelkund, Nov., 1884; political agent, Kalat, May, 1885; political assistant, 1st class, March, 1886; political agent, South Eastern Baluchistan, May, 1887.

TEMPLE, JAMES HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Burnley Grammar School, Repton School, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed member of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886.

TEMPLE, JOHN ALEXANDER, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, 12th Aug., 1861; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted at various times as cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jubbulpore, and Kamptee; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, May, 1873-74, and again, 1877; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Nov., 1884; and class, sub-pro tem., Feb., 1888.

TEMPLE, SIR RICHARD, Bart., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab in the grades of assistant commissioner and assistant magistrate and collector; settlement officer, trans-Sutlej division, 1852; secretary to chief commissioner, Punjab, 1854; commissioner, Lahore, 1859; chief commissioner of currency and chief assistant to financial member of council, 1860; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1865; resident, Hyderabad, 1867; member of governor-general's council, 25th April, 1868; president of the statistical committee, 1868; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1874; governor of Bombay, 20th April, 1877, to 1880; retired from the civil service in 1877; chairman of the board of visitors, Royal Indian Engineering College, Cooper's Hill, 1880; in the general election of Nov., 1885, was returned for Evesham, and again in the election of July, 1886; author of 'Men and Events of my Time in India,' 1882, and 'Oriental Experience,' 1883.

TEMPLE, RICHARD CARNAC, Major, B.S.C.—First commission, 4th Jan., 1871; from 11th Aug., 1879, served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, and cantonment magistrate, and was promoted to 1st class magistrate, Oct., 1884; transferred to Burma as cantonment magistrate, Mandalay, March, 1887; assistant commissioner, April, 1887.

TENNANT, JAMES FRANCIS, Lieutenant-General, C.I.E., R.E.—and lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1847; arrived in India, 7th March, 1849; assistant engineer, Ganges canal, 1849 to 1851; assistant in the great trigonometrical survey of India, 1851 to 1859; was garrison engineer to the Delhi field force, and served at the siege and assault of Delhi, and at the siege and capture of Lucknow (medal with two clasps, and brevet of major); government astronomer at Madras, Oct. 1859, to Oct., 1860; commandant, sappers and miners, Oct., 1860, to Sept., 1863; served in the public works department, Sept., 1863, to July, 1871, as executive engineer in Burma, and in the Punjab and Bengal; while on leave was appointed to observe eclipse of the sun, 1867-68, and was deputed for a similar duty in 1871; served as mint master, Calcutta, from July, 1871, to Jan., 1884; on special duty in England, Feb.–April, 1872; superintended the observations of the transit of Venus at Roorkee and Lahore, 1876; C.I.E., Jan., 1879; retired from military service and civil duties on 10th Jan., 1884; is a fellow of the Royal Society, and of the Royal Astronomical Society.

TEUNON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1888.

THOM, WILLIAM, Surgeon-General, F.R.C.S., late Bombay Medical Service.—Educated at Marischal College, and University of Aberdeen, and at University College, London, and in Paris; F.R.C.S., England; fellow of university of Bombay; assistant surgeon on the Bombay establishment, 1841; served under the military department, first, with the artillery, and then with the 3rd regiment native infantry, the 2nd Belooch battalion, the Bombay fusiliers, and the 17th native infantry at Baroda; surgeon, 1854; served subsequently at Belgaum and Poonah; in medical charge, marine battalion, Bombay, May, 1860; garrison surgeon, and surgeon to the European general hospital, 1861; served on the medical board of the India office, 1866-67; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, March, 1867; surgeon-general, Feb., 1874; retired, Sept., 1877.

THOMAS, GEORGE EBENEZER, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed from the East India railway as assistant engineer, 28th Aug., 1867, and posted to the Central Provinces; transferred to the Punjab northern state railway, March, 1868; locomotive superintendent, Punjab northern state railway, April, 1875; executive engineer, April, 1876; transferred to Indus Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; and class, revenue establishment, July, 1879; transferred to British Burma, Nov., 1881; class 1, grade 3, revenue scale, Jan., 1887.

THOMAS, HENRY SULLIVAN, F.L.S., F.Z.S., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs, member of the board of examiners, and acting civil and sessions judge; from May, 1867, to Sept., 1874, served as collector and magistrate of South Canara, and subsequently at Tanjore, and as political agent for French settlement at Karikal; from April, 1878, served on the board of revenue, Madras, and acted as secretary to government in the revenue department in 1878-79; in charge of the Inam department, Jan.–April, 1879; president, board of examiners, Oct., 1881; on special duty as a member of the local self-government committee, Sept., 1882; on duty to Calcutta as an additional member of the governor-general's council for laws and regulations, Dec., 1882, and again, Dec., 1883; on special duty in connection with the pearl fisheries at Tuticorin, and deputed to study system of management in force in Ceylon, March–May, 1884; 1st member,
board of revenue, July, 1884; on deputation to Tanjore district to report on necessity for granting remissions, April, 1885; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; on special duty to Madura, March to Sept., 1886, and to Delhi, to attend conference on agricultural and veterinary questions, March, 1888; on special duty drawing Fisheries Bill, April, 1888; retired, Jan., 1889; has published 'A Report on Pisciculture in South Canara,' 1870; 'The Rod in India,' 1881; and 'A Report on Pearl Fisheries and Chauk Fisheries,' 1884.

THOMAS, ROBERT MOSLEY BRYCE, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission as ensign, 6th Jan., 1859; arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1859; from Oct., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting small cause court judge, and was appointed cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1876, and subsequently at Kamptee; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1885.

THOMAS, WILLIAM CHARLES, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as officiating adjutant of military police, Mainpuri, Dec., 1858, having previously served as a volunteer in General Havelock's cavalry, 1857-58; adjutant of military police, Oct., 1859; inspector of district police, Jan., 1861; district superintendent of police, May, 1861; officiated as assistant inspector-general of the government railway police, July-Oct., 1868; on special duty with the camp of the lieutenant-governor, Dec., 1876, and again in March, 1878, with the governor-general's camp; 1st grade superintendent, Lucknow, April, 1885; deputy inspector-general of police, May, 1886.

THOMASON, CHARLES SIMON, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1852; joined the public works department, July, 1855, as deputy superintendent, Ganges canal; during the mutiny served at the battle of Budlekeserai and the siege of Delhi (medal and clasp); executive engineer, Oct., 1858; superintendent Rohilkund canals, Dec., 1864; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary, public works department, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1873; on special duty to Madras, in connection with harbours work, 1877-79; superintending engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Central India, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1882; retired, May, 1888.

THOMPSON, ARTHUR, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Cuthbert's, Ushaw, and University of London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector, and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector, Cuddapah, Nov., 1884.

THOMPSON, SIR AUGUSTUS RIVERS, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, June, 1850; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1850; served in the revenue and judicial departments, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; junior assistant to the governor-general's agent, south-west frontier, Sept., 1853; superintendent of survey, Jan., 1859; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1859; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1859; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Rajshahiye, April, 1861; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1861; officiating collector of customs, Nov., 1861; civil and sessions judge, Nuddea, Aug., 1865; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1868; officiating commissioner of revenue and circuit, presidency division, Jan., 1869; officiating secretary to the government of Bengal in the revenue and general departments, Sept., 1869, and in the judicial and political departments, Nov., 1871; secretary to the government of Bengal, Dec., 1873; chief commissioner of British Burma, 1st May, 1877; governor-general's council, 18th April, 1878; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 24th April, 1882; retired, April, 1887.

THOMPSON, C. T., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th March, 1883.

THOMPSON, DANIEL ROBERT, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.I.E., M.R.C.S., and L.M., late Madras Medical Service.—Acting civil surgeon, Tellicherry, April, 1865, to Sept., 1866; joined the Indian medical service as assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1867; and served under the military department, also acting as Zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail at Chingleput, April, 1868; and at Tinnevelly, April, 1869, to Sept., 1870; in medical charge of garrison, lock hospital, and meteorological observatories, Bellary, Dec., 1873; resident surgeon, general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology and materia medica in Medical College, March, 1875; from May, 1875, served as surgeon, 1st district, Madras, and medical inspector of emigrants; also superintendent of auxiliary provincial medical school, and native infirmary, Royapooram; C.I.E. for special famine services in 1876-78, 1st Jan., 1879; surgeon major, April, 1879; retired, May, 1883.

THOMPSON, DAVID WILLIAM, Educational Department, Punjab.—Served in the education department from Jan., 1863, as master in the Zillah Schools at Lahore and Amritsar; inspector of schools, May, 1870; 3rd grade of the department, Nov., 1883.

THOMPSON, FREDERICK C., Public Works Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, accounts branch, 9th March, 1872; public works department, Aug., 1875; senior clerk, 1887.

THOMPSON, GEORGE, B.A., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Head master, Saugor high school, Sept., 1869, to Oct., 1875; served from Oct., 1875, as inspector of schools, Central Provinces; was deputed to attend educational conferences at Naini Tal in 1885 and 1886.

THOMSON, A., Education Department, N.W. Provinces.—Served in Oudh, Aug., 1866, to April, 1877, as inspector of schools, and acted as director of public instruction in 1866 and 1868; from April, 1877, served as professor of English literature in the Agra College, and acted for various periods as principal; 3rd grade, educational department, May, 1886.

THOMSON, ANDREW, Bengal, C.S., Burma.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, Dec., 1885; served in Burma as assistant commissioner; transferred to Upper Burma
on special duty, March, 1886; personal assistant to chief commissioner, March, 1887; officiated as under secretary to chief commissioner, Feb. to April, 1888.

THOMSON, JAMES, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Grammar School, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; sub-collector, joint magistrate and principal assistant to collector, magistrate and agent, Godavari, June, 1885.

THOMSON, JOHN BROWN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Academy, and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, and grade, Feb., 1882; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Nov., 1882; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, May, 1884.

THOMSON, ROBERT GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Islington Proprietary School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; junior secretary to financial commissioner, Dec., 1882; officiating under secretary (revenue department) to government, Punjab, June, 1883; officiating junior secretary to government, Jan., 1884, and again in 1885 and 1886; senior secretary to financial commissioner, May, 1886; on special duty revising rules under the Punjab land revenue bill; postmaster-general, Punjab, Feb., 1888.

THORBURN, SEPTIMUS SMET, F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Feb., 1885; author of 'Bannu, or Our Afghan Frontier,' David Leslie,' and a report on the settlement of the Bannu district.

THORBURN, WALTER MILLER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dalhousie College, and University, Halifax, University of Edinburgh, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nellore, Oct., 1884.

THORNHILL, EDMUND BENSLEY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 16th Aug., 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Feb. to Sept., 1865; served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Fyzabad; magistrate and collector, Banda, March, 1872; civil and sessions judge, Banda, Nov., 1877; retired in 1885.

THORNHILL, GEORGE, C.S.I., late Madras Civil Service.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, 7th April, 1843; served as assistant to collector and magistrate in various districts, and was employed as civil officer in connection with the construction of the Godavari and Kistna anicuts; principal assistant to collector and magistrate, Ganjam, 1856; collector and magistrate, Kistna, 1861; member of board of revenue, 1870-78, during which period he was frequently employed by government on special duties of various kinds; was also appointed director of bank of Madras, and commissioner for uncovenanted civil service examinations, 1875; retired, 1878.

THORNHILL, HENRY BEAUFOPY, Captain, Andaman and Nicobar Islands administration.—1st commission, 23rd April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873; on field service, Afghanistan, Oct., 1878, to April, 1879 (medal); cantonment magistrate, Feb., 1887; appointed deputy superintendent, Port Blair, May, 1888.

THORNTON, ARTHUR PARRY, Major, B.S.C.—Ensign, 14th foot, 14th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, Jan., 1868; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Sept., 1871; served under government of Bengal in Purneah and Burdwan as relief circle officer during famine, March-Dec., 1874; served under the foreign department of the government of India from Jan., 1875, and acted as assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and as magistrate, Mount Abu, and assistant general superintendent for suppression of thuggee and dacoity; in charge of office of political agent, Marwar, Jan.-March, 1877; attached to foreign office during Delhi durbar, 1876-77; on military duty, 1878-79; from March, 1879, served under foreign department as cantonment magistrate at Morar, and at Nasirabad; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Jan., 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Secunderabad, Feb., 1884; political agent, Bhopawur, May, 1886.

THORNTON, EDWARD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and at Haileybury College, where he obtained honours, and from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1849; arrived in India, Feb., 1850; served in the N.W. Provinces, first as settlement officer, and afterwards as magistrate and collector; commissioner in the Punjab, Jhelum division, 1849-58; made C.B. for his services during the mutiny; judicial commissioner of the Punjab, 1858; retired, 1860.

THORNTON, JAMES HOWARD, Deputy Surgeon-General, C.B., B.A. and M.D. (London), Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1856; from 9th Nov., 1861, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon, besides service under the military department; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1868, and brigade surgeon, March, 1882; principal medical officer with the Indian forces, Egypt, 1885; C.B., Aug., 1885; deputy surgeon-general, Punjab frontier force, June, 1886.

THORNTON, LESLIE MELVILLE, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough, and University College,
Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1883; under secretary to government, Oct., 1886.

THORNTON, THOMAS HENRY, C.S.I., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors School, and St. John's College, Oxford (1st class moderations; Pusey and Ellerton Hebrew scholar; 2nd class, final schools); appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition, 1855; assistant commissioner, Punjab, 1857-59; personal assistant to financial commissioner, Punjab, 1859-60; personal assistant to judicial commissioner, 1860-62; small cause court judge, Lahore, 1862-63; deputy commissioner, Delhi, 1863-64; secretary to the government of the Punjab, 1864-78, and was on two occasions temporarily in charge of the administration of the province; acted as foreign secretary to the government of India, 1876-77; additional member of governor-general's council, 1877-79; judge, chief court, Punjab, 1878-81; retired, 1881; fellow of University of Calcutta, 1875; vice-president, University College, Lahore, 1879.

THUILLIER, SIR HENRY EDWARD LANDOR, General, Kt., C.S.I., R.A., F.R.S.—Educated at Addiscombe, 1837-38; first commission, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1838; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1833; served in the survey department, from Dec., 1836, and conducted the surveys of Jynteah, the Pooore division of Cuttack, and the district of Cachar, and part of Sylhet; while on furlough to England, 1844-46, was orderly officer of Warley barracks for a year; deputy surveyor-general of India, Jan., 1847, to March, 1861, when he was appointed surveyor-general of India; retired Dec., 1877; lieutenant-colonel, 1861; companion of the Star of India, May, 1870; knighted in 1879; major-general in 1870; lieutenant-general, July, 1879; general, July, 1881; colonel commandant, R.A., Jan., 1883; joint author of the Manual of Survey for India.

THUILLIER, HENRY RAVENSHAW, Colonel, R.E., Survey of India.—Addiscombe, Aug., 1855, to June, 1857; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1857; arrived in India, 29th April, 1859; appointed to the survey department as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey, May, 1859; deputy superintendent, Sept., 1869; officiating superintendent, great trigonometrical survey, April-Oct., 1876; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1878; deputy surveyor-general in charge of the revenue survey branch, Oct., 1884; acting surveyor-general from Feb., 1886; was confirmed, Feb., 1887.

TIDY, WILLIAM MEYMOPT, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1860; served in the N.W. Provinces from Aug., 1862, as assistant magistrate and collector; and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Sept., 1878; retired, 1886.

TINNEY, G. F., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 4th July, 1882.

TIRUVARUR MUTTUSWAMI AIYAR, SWAMINATHA AIYAR, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Madras University; appointed probationer for the civil service, Nov., 1883; confirmed as a member of the Madras civil service, Jan., 1886; acting head assistant collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly.

TODD, JAMES HENTHORN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting district superintendent of police, and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1886.

TODD-NAYLOR, HENRY PAUL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, March, 1886; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, April, 1886; officiating deputy commissioner.

TOMKINS, WILLIAM PERCIVAL, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Assam; transferred to Rangoon, British Burma, Jan., 1865; acted as assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan.-Aug., 1865; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; transferred to military works branch, Nov., 1873; assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, April, 1880; superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Aug., 1884; and class, Nov., 1887.

TOMLINSON, THOMAS ARMSTRONG, Madras Revenue Survey Department.—Appointed 10th Aug., 1859, and served as assistant superintendent and acting deputy superintendent on special duty, Pudukota boundary, Feb., 1887; deputy superintendent, 1st class, Nov., 1887.

TOTENHAM, LOFTUS RICHARD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 11th July, 1856; served as assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also as superintendent of stamps and stationery, Jan., 1866, and registrar of the high court, Dec., 1866; from Jan., 1874, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1878; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 16th July, 1879.

TOWERS, ROBERT MASON, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1863; from July, 1867, served in the judicial department as small cause court judge and district and sessions judge; judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nuddea and Jessore, Feb., 1879; from Jan., 1878, to Feb., 1880, served as officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur; served subsequently as district and sessions judge, and was promoted to 1st grade, May, 1885.

TOWNSEND, STEPHEN CHAPMAN, Surgeon-General, C.B., late Bengal Medical Service.—Educated at the Grammar School, Ottery St. Mary, Devon, and the London Hospital Medical School; assistant-surgeon in the Indian medical
service, June, 1852; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1852; employed in regimental and other military duty to Feb., 1862, and served in the Burma campaign, 1854-53; civil surgeon, Nagpur, Jan., 1865 to March, 1868; sanitary commissioner, Central Provinces, March, 1868, to Oct., 1878, and officiated as sanitary commissioner with the government of India, Feb., 1877 to March, 1878; rank of deputy surgeon-general, Dec., 1878; principal medical officer with the Kuram field force under General Sir F. Roberts, April, 1879; and was wounded in action, Sept., 1879; surgeon-general with the Punjab government, April, 1880; Companion of the Bath, Feb., 1881; retired, Dec., 1883.

TOYNBEE, GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 27th Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; superintendent canal revenue, Oct., 1871; on famine relief duty, Nov., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, lower provinces, Dec., 1874; second inspector of registration offices, April, 1877; on special duty connected with compulsory irrigation rate, May, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1878; special duty at the Bengal secretariat, July, 1878; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1885; author of 'Sketch of the History of Orissa from 1803 to 1828,' and 'A Chowkidari Manual.'

TOZER, H. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Jan., 1882.

TRACY, THOMAS BUROWES, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; served in the N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1858, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Muttra, April, 1877; from Feb., 1883, served as civil and sessions judge, and acted as judicial commissioner in Oudh, 1884-85; retired, Sept., 1887.

TRAFFORD, RICHARD WYME, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, judicial assistant, 1st grade, Sept., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Dec., 1886.

TRAIL, DAVID HENRY, Colonel, R.E., Bengal Public Works Department, Accounts Branch.—1st commission Madras engineers, 1856; from Sept., 1859, served in the Madras public works department; served in the China war, 1860, and was present at the battle of Sinho, and capture of Tangku and Taku forts (medal and clasp); employed in the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862; assistant engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1865; from Jan., 1866, was employed in the accounts branch of the public works department, and served as controller of accounts in Mysore, Madras, Punjab, and Central Provinces; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1882; examiner of public works accounts, 1st class, Feb., 1884; officiating accountant-general, and deputy secretary, government of India, P.W. department, April-June, 1885; examiner, public works accounts, Bengal, Dec., 1887.

TREASURE, HENRY, Legal Department, India Office.—Solicitor of the supreme court, admitted, 1859; principal clerk to legal adviser to the secretary of state, May, 1877; retired, 1887.

TREASURE, W. H., Legal Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state; solicitor of the supreme court, 1887.

TREMENHEERE, CHARLES WILLIAM, Lieutenant-General, C.B., R.E.—Educated at Adsccombe; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th Dec., 1829; served as civil engineer in Darwar, 1833-40, and as executive engineer Surat and Broach, and acting superintending engineer, Guzerat, 1843-46; assistant executive engineer, Aden, Jan., 1846, to Feb., 1847; from Dec., 1848 to March, 1850, served in Scinde as executive engineer, Kurrachee, and acting superintending engineer; dock yard, Bombay, March, 1850, to May, 1853; acting secretary, military board, May, 1853, to Jan., 1854; on special duty, Bombay, designing reclamations, docks, and fortifications, Jan., 1854, to Jan., 1855; major, Sept., 1855; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Jan., 1855, to Aug., 1856; garrison engineer, Bombay, and acted as superintending engineer, Poona circle, 1856-57; was commanding engineer to the forces under Sir Hugh Rose, and General Roberts, 1857-58, and was present at the sieges of Awhah and Kotah, and the engagements of Sanganeer and Kotaree; Indian mutiny medal and clasp for Central India; military C.B., March, 1861; superintending engineer, southern provinces, Feb., 1860; chief engineer, Scinde, May, 1862; chief engineer, presidency, Nov., 1866; major-general, March, 1867; political resident, Aden, with command of the brigade, Dec., 1870; retired with hon. rank of lieutenant-general, July, 1874.

TREMENHEERE, JAMES HENRY APPERLEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Lancing, and Cheltenham Colleges; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); from May to Aug., 1883, served in Mysore as acting civil and sessions judge; served subsequently in Madras as head assistant collector, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and was appointed acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, June, 1884; officiating private secretary to the governor of Madras, May to Aug., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Aug., 1888; also acted as collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge.

TREMLETT, JAMES DYER, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Hissar, Aug., 1878; additional commissioner, Umballa and Jullundur, Nov., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, April, 1883; additional judge, chief court, April, 1884;
divisional judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; judge, chief court, Punjab, Sept., 1886.

TRETHEWY, ANTHONY WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1885; served in the N.W. provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector.

TREVELYN, ERNEST JOHN.—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1875-83; officiating secretary, board of examiners for pleaders, &c., 1875-82; officiating magistrate, Calcutta, N. division, 1876; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1885; president, board of examiners for pleaders and mookhtars, 1886.

TREVOR, ARTHUR CHARLES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1861, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector of stamp revenue and political agent, acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, acting municipal commissioner, and deputy commissioner of customs and opium (June, 1877); collector of customs, Bombay, April, 1879; acting commissioner of customs, and collector of salt revenue, May, 1884; senior collector, Dec., 1884; collector of salt revenue, Oct., 1885.

TREVOR, CHARLES BINNY, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, 12th June, 1832; served in Bengal, in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate, and deputy collector; magistrate of Backergunge, June, 1840; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 1849; judge of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, presidency, 1859; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1863; retired in 1867.

TREVOR, EDWARD WALTER, Colonel, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Infantry, April, 1855; arrived in India, 8th May, 1855; appointed acting superintendent of bazaars and cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, March, 1864; from Nov., 1864, served in Sind, as deputy collector and magistrate, acting district superintendent of police, and acting collector and magistrate; on military duty, Oct., 1879, to Jan., 1881, as general transport officer, Khyber line, and director, Kuram transport; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Jan., 1881; on special duty to Calcutta, in connection with the prosecution of commissariat frauds, Nov., 1881; collector and magistrate, Hyderabad, Dec., 1884.

TREVOR, FREDERICK G. B., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Marlborough College; East India House writer, old establishment, 10th March, 1858; junior clerk, public, educational, and ecclesiastical departments, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, July, 1875; judicial and public department, 1877; assistant secretary in that department, June, 1887.

TREVOR, GEORGE HERBERT, Colonel, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Joined the Madras artillery, 5th April, 1858; from June, 1862 served in the central provinces as inspector of schools, and was secretary to the Jabalpur exhibition committee in 1866; subsequently acted as cantonment magistrate, assistant secretary to chief commissioner, and assistant commissioner; from Oct., 1867 acted as assistant resident, Hyderabad; secretary for Berar, April, 1877; deputed to accompany Sir Salar Jung on his tour to Europe in 1867 as political officer; 1st assistant resident and secretary for Berar, and political agent, 1st class, July, 1881; officiated as resident at Hyderabad May-June, 1882; officiating resident and class and commissioner, Ajmeré-Merwara, Nov., 1885, and confirmed in those appointments, Nov., 1887.

TREVOR, JOHN SALUSBURY, Major-General, C.S.I., late R.E.—Passed out of Addiscombe, June, 1847; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, April, 1848; assistant superintendent of roads and tanks, 1849-55; transferred to railway department in Aug., 1855, as deputy consulting engineer; municipal commissioner, Bombay, 1861; resigned appointment in railway department, 1864; rejoined the public works department in Nov., 1866, as executive engineer, 1st grade, Tapti irrigation; consulting engineer and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, Nov., 1868; chief engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1870; acting deputy secretary to government of India in railway branch, 1871-72; resigned appointment in Bombay railway department, 1874; in England, 1874-78; officiating deputy secretary to government of India, railway branch, June, 1878; resigned the army, 1879, continuing in the public works department; director-general of railways, and deputy secretary, railway branch, 1880; retired in 1881; chairman of the Bombay, Baroda, and Central India, and the Rohilkund and Kumaon railway companies, and a director in several other Indian railway companies.

TREVOR, SALUSBURY THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—1st commission, Dec., 1852; arrived in India, and Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1855, to Oct., 1863, served in British Burma as assistant engineer, executive engineer, assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1863; served as garrison engineer, Fort William, and superintending engineer, 3rd class, and was appointed secretary to chief commissioner, Assam, public works department, July, 1869; chief engineer, and joint secretary public works department, Bengal, March, 1881; on deputation in connection with International Exhibition buildings at Calcutta, July, 1883; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, railways and roads and buildings, Jan., 1884; chief engineer, 1st class, July, 1885.

TREVOR, WILLIAM SPOTTISWOODE, Colonel, V.C., R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—and lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1849; arrived in India, 5th Feb., 1852; served in the Burmese war, 1852-53 (medal with clasps); employed on the Pegu survey, 1854; executive engineer, Bassein, Nov., 1855; was subsequently posted to Darjeeling and Dinagepur; garrison engineer, Fort William, 1861; controller and examiner of accounts, Bengal, May, 1865; served the Bhutan campaign, 1865 (medal and V.C.); superintending engineer, Calcutta, Jan., 1867; consulting engineer to government of Bengal, irrigation, Jan., 1868; superintending engineer, military works, Calcutta, 1872; additional chief engineer for famine relief works, Bengal, 1874; officiating chief engineer and
secretary to governor-general's agent, Indore, April-Dec., 1875; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1876; chief engineer and secretary, British Burma, Dec., 1878; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, March, 1881; secretary to government of India in the public works department, Feb., 1882; retired, 1887.

TRIMNELL, DAVID WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, late Central Provinces, Medical Service.—Joined the Madras medical service in 1856; served in the Saugor field division in 1857-58, and was present at the battle of Banda and other engagements; civil surgeon, Narsinghpur, Central Provinces, 4th April, 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Raipur, June, 1867; surgeon-major, Feb., 1876; brigade-surgeon, Aug., 1882; retired, Aug., 1887.

TROTTER, E. W., Stamp and Registration Department, Punjab.—Appointed overseer of Studs, N.W. Provinces, 17th Dec., 1844; from Nov., 1847, served in the public works department as accountant, draughtsmen, head clerk, and superintendent; also in the office of the chief commissioner, Punjab (1857); deputy superintendent, Punjab government secretariat, Jan., 1863; assistant secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1868; inspector-general of registration and superintendent of stamps, Punjab, Aug., 1877; author of 'Punjab Registration Manual.'

TROWARD, THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1886; officiating divisional judge, May, 1887.

TRUEMAN, THOMAS, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1856, and served on military duty up to June, 1872, including the mutiny campaign under Sir Hugh Rose (medal and clasp), and subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate at Poona and Kirkee, and cantonment magistrate, and city magistrate, Káráchi; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmedabad, April, 1877, and subsequently at Belgaum; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877; retired, Nov., 1888.

TUCKER, ALEXANDER LAUZUN PENDOCK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; forest settlement office, Bijapur, Feb., 1886; services placed at disposal of government of India, foreign department, April, 1888; assistant to resident at Hyderabad, and assistant secretary for Berar.

TUCKER, HENRY ST. GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; appointed commissioner in Burma, May, 1886; author of 'Reports on the Settlement of the Dera Ismail Khan and Kohat Districts.'

TUCKER, HENRY PENDOCK ST. GEORGE, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, in 1842; arrived in India, 14th April, 1843; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge in various districts in the Bombay presidency, and acted as deputy registrar of the Sudder court in Bombay, in 1845-46, and as judge and sessions judge, in 1853, and in 1856-57; acting first assistant accountant-general, Bombay, July, 1858; acting civil auditor, Bombay, Dec., 1858 to March, 1859; collector and magistrate, North Canara, July, 1862; judge and sessions judge, Konkan, Aug., 1862; appointed to report on the measures necessary for a redistribution of judicial jurisdiction and modification of judicial establishments, Feb., 1863; officiating judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1863; member of council, Bombay, 7th April, 1866; retired in 1876.

TUCKER, LOUIS HENRY EMILLE, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1860; arrived in India, 11th April, 1861; from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty with Major Cavagnari in connection with Kabul war, Nov., 1878, and again with the staff of Major-General Bright, Sept., 1879; promoted to 1st grade, district superintendent, Sept., 1880; officiating deputy inspector-general, and grade, March, 1885; confirmed in appointment, March, 1888.

TUDBALL, WILLIAM, Bengal (N.W. Provinces, &c.).—Educated at Bedford Modern School and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

TUPP, ALFRED COTTERELL, B.A., F.S.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1862; from Oct., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty for the conduct of the case of the Munsi of Mahoba, Dec., 1867, and again, July, 1869, for the preparation of a statistical memoir of Futehpur; assistant superintendent of Dehra Dún, April, 1871; also subordinate judge from March, 1873; held charge of Provincial Gazetteer of N.W. Provinces, March, 1876, to Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Azimgarh, Aug., 1877; transferred to the financial department, government of India, Nov., 1878, and served in Madras, till 1881, as deputy accountant-general, deputy controller-general, and accountant-general, and commissioner of state paper currency; officiated as accountant-general in Bombay, Dec., 1881, to Dec., 1882, and in Bengal from the latter date; officiating comptroller-general, Sept.-Oct., 1883; from Nov., 1883, served as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency; accountant-general, class I., Nov., 1887; accountant-general of Bombay and commissioner of the department of state paper currency, Bombay, Dec., 1887; author of 'The
Indian Civil Service and the Competition System,' 1875; 'The Statistics of the North-West Provinces of India,' 1876; 'The Imperial Gazetteer of India—N.W.P. portion,' 1877; 'The Indian Civil Service List, and Record of Services,' 1880; 'The Paris International Monetary Conference of 1881, and Bimetallism,' 1881; 'The Competitive Civil Service of India, from 1856 to 1882,' 1882.

TUPPER, CHARLES LEWIS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Harrow, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating under secretary to government, and was placed on special duty in office of financial commissioner, Sept., 1874, and with H.H. the Maharaja of Patiala, Nov., 1875; appointed under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Sept., 1878; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880; from Feb., 1880, served under the government of India as acting under secretary and acting secretary in the revenue and agricultural department, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1881 (in connection with the Bengal Rent Bill), and again, Feb., 1882; junior secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1882; on special duty in connection with scheme of local self-government, June-Oct., 1883; acted as secretary to government, April, 1884, to Feb., 1886, and was on special duty in connection with the frontier crime commission, Feb.-March, 1886; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1887; author of 'Customary Law of the Punjab.'

TURNER, SIR CHARLES ARTHUR, Kt., C.I.E., late Judicial Department, Madras.—Appointed judge of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, and arrived in India, May, 1866; acted as chief justice in 1870, 1875, and 1878; chief justice of the high court of judicature, Madras, Jan., 1879; fellow of the University of Madras, Jan., 1879; member of the Indian law commission, Bengal, Feb.-Sept., 1879; vice-chancellor of Madras University, April, 1880, and May, 1882; retired, 1st July, 1885; appointed member of the public service commission, 1885-6; member of the council of India, and Feb., 1888.

TURNER, EDWARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in various districts of Madras from May, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, and was employed on state famine relief operations, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1882; collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Jan., 1885; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Feb., 1885; collector and magistrate, Madura, Jan., 1886.

TURNER, HENRY GRIBBLE, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1866; from Aug., 1866, to Dec., 1867, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty, Madras, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, Jan., 1868; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, March, 1875; postmaster-general, Madras, March, 1875, to June, 1881; from June, 1881, acted as collector, magistrate, and political agent, Vizagapatam; appointed district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1884, but continued to act as collector, &c., at Vizagapatam, and was confirmed in this post, Nov., 1885.

TUTE, ARTHUR CLIFFORD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, in Bengal, April, 1872; on famine relief duty, Salem, March, 1877, and at Trichinopoly, Sept., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1885; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, March, 1888.

TWEEDIE, JOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 13th Dec., 1860; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, July, 1861; officiating superintendent, Chittagong hill tracts, June, 1863; deputy commissioner, Bhutan Dooras, Dec., 1864; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, Aug., 1870, to March, 1873; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dinapore relief works, March, 1874; from June, 1874, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge of the small cause courts, Krishnagur, Ranaghat, and Meherpore, Oct., 1876; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Jan., 1881.

TWEEDIE, MAURICE, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, N.W. Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 23rd Oct., 1856; during the mutiny served with the field force in Central India, and subsequently with the mounted police in Oudh, and on the Nepal frontier (medal and clasp); from June, 1860, served as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, May, 1886; officiating junior deputy inspector-general, April, 1888; author of 'A Chapter on the Fauna of the Province of Oudh,' for incorporation in the 'Oudh Gazetteer.'

TWEEDIE, WILLIAM, Colonel, C.S.I., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Jan., 1857; during the mutiny served in Oudh, and was present at the siege and capture of Lucknow, and afterwards took part in the pursuit of Tantia Tope in Central India (medal and clasps); adjutant, 1st cavalry, Hyderabad Contingent, March, 1859; acted as assistant to resident, Hyderabad, from 1863; served in the Abyssinian Expedition, 1868 (medal and brevet of major); 1st assistant resident, Hyderabad, and general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, Oct., 1868; agent to governor-general, Moorshedabad, 1876-77; political agent, Gwalior, 1878-79; during the Afghan war was senior political officer with Major-General Bright, during advance on Kabul, and was in charge of Jalalabad division, March, 1880 (medal, C.S.I.); officiating political agent, Western Rajputana states, 1880-81; acted subsequently as resident in Western Rajputana, in Gwalior, and Turkish Arabia; officiating commissioner, Ajmere, March-June, 1885; resident in Turkish Arabia, July, 1885, and consul-general, Baghdad.
TWEEDY, GEORGE ALFRED, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, Nov., 1887.

TWIGG, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlements officer; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1887; and acting sub-collector and magistrate, Feb., 1888.

TWIGG, JOHN HILL, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was deputed on special duty under the commissioner of cotton and commerce for the organisation of carriage and supply of fodder for Bengal, Feb. to Sept., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1880; magistrate and collector, and grade, Hamirpur, April, 1882; 1st grade, Aug., 1885.

TWISADAY, CHARLES EDWARD JAMES, Public Works Department, India Office.—Appointed to the London offices of the Indo-European telegraph department on the 29th July, 1869; accompanied director-in-chief to Constantinople in 1880, as personal assistant; and to the Persian Gulf in 1885 with the third Persian Gulf cable expedition, and afterwards to India; on abolition of London office of the Indo-European telegraph company, his services were transferred temporarily to India office, 1st Jan., 1889.

TWOMEY, DANIEL HAROLD RYAN, Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at St. Stanislaus College, Tullamore, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1882; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1884.

TYRRELL, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived in India, 12th May, 1859; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating under secretary to government, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; registrar, high court, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1870; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1878; civil and sessions judge, and grade, Jan., 1882; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882.

UMESH CHUNDER BATABYAL, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Master in the Sanskrit College, Calcutta, Aug., 1873; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1883; appointed member of the statutory civil service, May, 1888; assistant magistrate and collector, June, 1888.

UDNY, RICHARD, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Sylhet, Dec., 1867; assistant

Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1885.

UNDERWOOD, WALTER GREGORY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Chester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to the Laccadives, Nov., 1881; sub collector and joint magistrate, Tanjore, Dec., 1885; acting district and sessions judge, June, 1886, and acting collector and magistrate, March, 1888.

UNWIN, ARTHUR HAMILTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's School, Sherborne, and Tonbridge Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1873, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, inspector of schools, acting judge of the small cause court, and acting director of public instruction; from Jan., 1880, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; 1st grade assistant judge, Oct., 1883; assistant judge and joint sessions judge, for Kaira and Panch Mehals, May, 1885; 3rd grade judge, and sessions judge, May, 1887.

UPTON, JOHN G., Registry Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 16th April, 1845; assistant to registrar, July, 1860; despatch clerk, 10th July, 1877.

UPTON, R. L.—Government solicitor, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1881.

URQUHART, GEORGE MOORE, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1885; forest settlement officer, Feb., 1887.

VAN SOMEREN, GODLIB JAMES, Lieutenant-Colonel, Madras Infantry, Forest Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Sept., 1859; appointed to the forest department, May, 1864; conservator of forests, Mysore and Coorg, Jan., 1869; transferred to Punjab, 1881; assistant comptroller-general of forest accounts under the financial department, Jan., 1883; conservator of forests, Berar, 1885.

VARADA RAOT, B.A., B.L., Madras C.S.—Madras University; probationer for the civil service, July, 1885; assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1886; confirmed in civil service, Aug., 1887.

VAUGHAN, ERNEST LLEWELLYN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Blackheath School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 10th Jan., 1888, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

VEASEY, JOHN CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Sylhet, Dec., 1867; assistant
settlement officer, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1880; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Aug., 1884; officiating inspector-general of police, Bengal, Oct., 1884; magistrate and collector, and grade, April, 1886; confirmed as inspector-general of police, Aug., 1887.

VENKATA JAGA RAO CHENDIKA, B.A., Madras C.S.—Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 2nd Dec., 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; forest settlement officer, Oct., 1883; acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1885.

VENNING, FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864; served from Aug., 1865, to Nov., 1868, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Nov., 1868, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted as small cause court judge of Jubbulpore in 1874, and as secretary to the chief commissioner in 1878; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, June, 1880; commissioner of the Jubbulpore division, Aug., 1881, and of the Nagpur division, Nov., 1883.

VENTRIS, HENRY, Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Highgate School, and Brighton College; supernumerary writer, and Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1860; clerk in registry department, Feb., 1864; junior clerk, revenue department, Jan., 1873; employed in records branch, 1879-1880; senior clerk, June, 1885.

VERNER, WILLIAM HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived and Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed officiating assistant secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1867, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1877, and district and sessions judge, Nov., 1879; also served as inspector of schools, April, 1866, and officiated as under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1871, and as postmaster-general, Bengal, in 1871, 1872, and 1875; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1885.

VERTANNE, JOHN CARAPIET, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the government of Bengal as apprentice engineer, 8th May, 1855, and served in the public works department in that province, and temporarily in the Central Provinces in 1862; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1874; on famine relief works, Nov., 1873; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; south-western circle, Jan., 1887.

VERTUE, WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Jan., 1857; from and Dec., 1862, to May, 1865, served in the police department of the Central Provinces as acting district superintendent, and personal assistant to the inspector-general; from May, 1865, served as assistant commissioner, and acted as inspector of schools, and superintendent of the school of industry at Jubbulpore, 1867; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jan., 1877; small cause court judge, Nagpur, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Sept., 1883.

VIBART, HENRY MEREDITH, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1859; assistant engineer in the Madras public works department, Sept., 1861; executive engineer, Dec., 1866; on special duty in Bangalore, Nov., 1877, to Feb., 1878; in special charge of the restoration of Tiroomal Naick's palace, Madura, Feb., 1878; acting deputy chief engineer for irrigation, and under secretary to government, public works department, March, 1879; superintendent of works, Presidency, April, 1880; superintending engineer, April, 1884.

VIDAL, GEORGE WILLIAM, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty connected with the Jath state, March, 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1878; on special duty as a British member of the mixed commission at Goa, March-May, 1880, and Jan., 1885; president of the Bombay forest commission, Dec., 1885; junior collector and magistrate, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kanta, Sept., 1886.

VINCENT, WILLIAM HENRY HOARE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ College, Brecon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal.

VOWELL, CHRISTOPHER HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1879; magistrate and collector, and grade, Dec., 1885.

WACE, ALFRED AUGUSTUS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1881; also served as officiating inspector-general of registration, March, 1879; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; and grade, Dec., 1887.

WACE, EDWARD GEORGE, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1857; officiating cantonment magistrate, Peshawur, May, 1860, to July, 1861; assistant commissioner in the Punjab, Feb., 1863; officiating superintendent of Chamba, June, 1866; on special duty in the financial commissioner's office, Feb., 1867; settlement officer, Hazara, Nov., 1869; transferred to the Jhelum settlement, Jan., 1875; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; officiating settlement commissioner in the Mooltan and Derajat divisions, June-Dec., 1877; settlement commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1879; settlement and agriculture commissioner, Sept., 1882; second financial commissioner, Nov., 1884; 1st financial commissioner, April, 1887; additional member governor-general's council,
May, 1887; author of 'Reports on the Settlement of Hazara and Simla District.'

WADDINGTON, GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Dec., 1878; senior collector, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, district registrar, and political agent, Sholapur, Oct., 1882; collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Ahmednagar, Nov., 1886.

WADE, EDWARD J., M.A.—Educated at Rugby, and Dublin; scholar and exhibitioner; first senior classical moderator and gold medallist; assistant librarian, India office, 23rd May, 1881; late editor 'Allen's Indian Mail.'

WAKE, HERWALD CRAUFURD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1857; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Shahabad, 1858; C.B., May, 1860; magistrate and collector, Patna, 1861; superintendent, Darjeeling, 1862; retired on invalid pension, 1868.

WALCH, GEORGE TURNER, M.I.C.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Appointed assistant engineer, 31st March, 1866; executive engineer, April, 1873; acted as deputy chief engineer, and under secretary to government, Feb., 1877; on special duty, Madras irrigation company's canal, July, 1882; had charge of Kurnool canal, and other works; superintending engineer, March, 1887; author of 'Notes on some of the Navigable Rivers and Canals of United States and Canada,' 1876.

WAKEFIELD, GEORGE EDWARD, late Punjab Administration.—From 25th Aug., 1853, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; promoted to 1st class deputy commissioner, Feb., 1881; retired, Feb., 1887.

WALKER, FRANCIS BLENNERHASSETT, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Appointed to the Bombay public works department, Sept., 1869; executive engineer, July, 1868; transferred to Punjab, January, 1870, and was employed on Punjab Northern state railway; served subsequently on the Neemuch and Western Rajputana state railways; transferred to Bombay railway branch, March, 1881, and subsequently to Bengal; engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal and Tirhoot railway extensions, March, 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; acting engineer-in-chief and manager, Tirhoot state railway, July to Oct., 1887.

WALKER, GEORGE CASSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty, Lahore, in connection with Viceregal durbar, Oct., 1880; from April, 1883, served in the financial department of the government of India, and was appointed assistant accountant-general, Punjab; transferred to office of accountant-general, Bengal, Dec., 1883; from Feb., 1884, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge.

WALKER, GEORGE HERBERT DACRES, B.A., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant secretary to government N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1st May, 1874; officiating under secretary to government of India, public works department, Nov., 1882 and 1886; examiner in accounts branch, April, 1884.

WALKER, GEORGE WARREN, General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—Second lieutenant, Madras engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; assistant civil engineer, 1847; district engineer, Canara, Sept., 1859; superintending engineer, Coimbatore, May, 1863; chief engineer, and secretary to government of Madras, public works department, May, 1872; retired from the public works department in 1876.

WALKER, H. B., Store Department, India Office.—Matriculated at London University, 1875; clerk, and class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877; 2nd grade, supervisor, July, 1888.

WALKER, JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in Madras, 1st Dec., 1886, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

WALKER, JAMES THOMAS, General, R.E., C.B.—Appointed to the Bombay Engineers from Addiscombe, 9th Dec., 1844; assistant chief engineer, Bombay, May-Sept., 1845; executive engineer, Upper Sind, May, 1847, to Oct., 1848; served throughout the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and was present at siege of Multan, and battle of Goojerat (medal and clasps); from 1849 to 1853 served as military surveyor of the Trans-Indus frontier from Peshawur to Dera Ismail Khan, and was present at numerous frontier engagements; from Dec., 1853, to March, 1861, served as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey; during the mutiny of 1857 served with the Punjab moveable column, and subsequently as field engineer at Delhi (brevet of major, medal and clasp); in 1860 accompanied the Mahsud Waziri expedition; medal and clasps for frontier service; from March, 1861, to Feb., 1883, served as superintendent of the great trigonometrical survey, and from Jan., 1878, to Feb., 1883 also held the appointments of surveyor-general of India, and superintendent of topographical surveys, and carried out the amalgamation of the three survey departments; fellow of the Royal Society, 1865; C.B., 1877; hon. LL.D. of Cambridge, 1885; superintended the preparation and publication of the first nine volumes of the account of operations of the great trigonometrical survey; author of occasional papers for the Royal Geographical Society and United Service Institution, presidential address to the geographical section, British Association, in 1885, and contributions to the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

WALKER, JAMES WILLIAM, LL.B., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1868, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; on special duty in connection with the Baroda commission, Feb.-March, 1875; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, Jan.-March, 1880;
and grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Feb., 1885; 1st grade judge, Nov., 1887.

WALKER, THOMAS GORDON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was settlement officer of Ludhiana from May, 1878 to 1884; attached to civil secretariat on special duty in April, 1883; officiating under secretary to government, revenue department, Punjab, April, 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, Sept. to Dec., 1883; registrar of the chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1884; and again, April, 1887; officiating junior secretary to government, Aug., 1886, to Feb., 1887; on special duty Punjab civil secretariat, Feb.—April, 1887; senior secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1888.

WALKER, THORNTON, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1885; assistant collector, Jan., 1886.

WALKER, WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.A., M.D., LL.D., F.R.C.S. (Ed.), Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855, and held various military medical charges in Bengal and N.W. Provinces, including service in the mutiny campaign, 1857; superintendent, central prison, Agra, March, 1858; superintendent, government press, and curator, government books, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1862; also chemical examiner, Dec., 1864; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1867; honorary magistrate, Allahabad Aug., 1867; inspector-general of prisons and dispensaries, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1871; also for Oudh, March, 1877, to April, 1879; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general and inspector-general of civil hospitals, with local rank of surgeon-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1882; officiating surgeon-general with the government of India, May, 1887; officiating in same appointment and as sanitary commissioner with the government of India, April, 1888.

WALL, RICHARD, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Benares, Feb., 1877; officiating civil and sessions judge, May, 1877, and in 1858; commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1882.
