WALLACE, A. C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

WALLACE, SIR DONALD MACKENZIE, K.C.I.E.—Educated at the Universities of Edinburgh, M.A., Heidelberg, LL.D., and Berlin, and the Ecole de droit, Paris; was "Times" correspondent in Russia, Austria, and the East, 1878-84; private secretary to the Marquess of Dufferin and Ava, when governor-general of India, 1884-8; was member of mission to Kabul, 1888; author of 'Russia,' 'Egypt and the Egyptian Question.'

WALLACE, SIR ROBERT, Major-General, K.C.S.I.—Educated at Cheam School; first commission, 1827; interpreter and quartermaster, 18th regiment, N.I., Oct., 1831; adjutant, July, 1833; superintendent, Guicowar's Contingent of Horse, Mahi Kanta, Dec., 1834; also assistant political agent, Jan., 1836; assistant to resident in Lower Scinde, Sept., 1840; volunteered for political service in Upper Scinde and Beloochistan, and was appointed assistant to the envoy there, 1840-41, and was for a time in charge of the agency; political agent, Mahi Kanta, Sept., 1846; under secretary to government of Bombay for the purpose of reorganising the police of the Presidency, Aug., 1852; political agent, Rewa Kanta, Nov., 1853; commanded a field force in suppressing the Naikra rebellion in Guzerat, Jan.-March, 1858; resident at Baroda, Aug., 1859, to 1865; retired from the army, Aug., 1867.

WALLACE, WILLIAM ARTHUR JAMES, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—1st commission, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, April, 1864; assistant engineer, public works department, April, 1864; officiating deputy consulting engineer, railway branch, Bengal, Jan., 1869; assistant consulting engineer, Feb., 1870; executive engineer, 3rd grade, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, Oct., 1871; acted as consulting engineer, Lucknow, and at Calcutta; on special duty in connection with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, acting as under secretary to government of India, Oct., 1876, to Feb., 1877; on deputation to England in connection with Paris Exhibition, 1878; secretary to railway conference at Calcutta, Oct., 1878; acting under secretary to government of India, railway branch, 1878-79; served in the Afghan war, 1879 (medal); engineer-in-chief, and manager, Northern Bengal state railway, Nov., 1879; 1st class state railway revenue establishment, Nov., 1879; served in the Egyptian campaign, 1882 (medal and clasp, and bronze star, 4th class, Osmanieh); officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, Oct., 1884; class 1, grade 1, revenue establishment, Oct., 1885; director North-Western railway, May, 1887; deputed to Switzerland to examine the Alt system of railways, July—Oct., 1887.

WALLER, HARDRESS EDMOND, Major-General, B.S.C., late Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th Aug., 1852; joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, June, 1862; district superintendent, March, 1863; 1st grade, district superintendent, March, 1884; retired, June, 1886.

WALLER, RICHARD MAUNSELL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1868; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1878; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1879; magistrate and collector, Noakhali, Oct., 1885; 2nd grade, Oct., 1886.

WALLERSTEIN, PHILIP HERMAN, Major, B.S.C. (N.W. Provinces).—1st commission, 13th July 1867; served with the 6th foot and
WALPOLE, HORACE G., C.B., Assistant Under Secretary of State, India Office.—Educated at Eton; temporary clerk, India office, 12th Dec., 1862; junior clerk, June, 1863; store department, 1863; accountant-general's department, 1863-64; public works department, 1864; resident clerk, 1870-77; senior clerk, April, 1877; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state, 1865-74 (Mr. Herman Merivale, C.B.), and to the secretary of state, 1874-80 (the Marquis of Salisbury, 1874-78, and subsequently, to Viscount Cranbrook); C.B., 1880; also served as clerk of the council from 1877, and was appointed assistant to the under secretaries of state in addition to his other duties, Sept., 1881; assistant under secretary of state, Nov., 1883, continuing to be clerk of the council; royal commissioner of the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, 1886; secretary to the royal commission on civil establishments, 1886.

WALSH, ERNEST HERBERT COOPER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trent College and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884.

WALTER, CHARLES KENNETH MACKENZIE, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 23rd native infantry, Bengal, Nov., 1852; assistant to commissioner, Ajmere, Jan., 1857; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Feb., 1858; political agent, Bhurtpore, Dec., 1862; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, June, 1866; political agent, Márwar, Jan., 1873; resident, 3rd class, in the political department, 1876; officiated as agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and chief commissioner, Ajmere, in 1876, and 1881-82; resident, and class, and political agent, Meywar, 1880; officiating agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and sub-pro tem. resident, 1st class, Meywar.

WARBURTON, HARRIS GRANT, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces, &c.).—Educated at Dover College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885. Arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WARBURTON, ROBERT, Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1862; from Sept., 1869, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special political duty in Khyber, July, 1879; employed with Cabul force, Oct., 1879; officiating judicial assistant commissioner, Peshawar, Nov., 1881; political officer, Khyber, Feb., 1882.

WARBURTON, WILLIAM PLEACE, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1866; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1866; assistant surgeon, Jullundur, Sept., 1867; surgeon to H.H. the Raja of Kapurthala, June, 1874; surgeon-major, March, 1878.

WARD, GEORGE ERNEST, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Jaunpur, July, 1879; on special duty on the education commission under the government of India, 1882; commissioner, Jhansi division, July, 1885.

WARD, HENRY CONSTANTINE EVELYN, C.I.E., Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, as ensign, April, 1855; was employed under the military department up to 1864, including service at the siege and assault of Delhi, 1857 (medal and clasp), and at the battle of Narnoul, Nov., 1857; served also with Eusufye expedition, 1858, and in the campaign against the Mahsood Waziris, 1859-60 (frontier medal); assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Nagpur, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, May, 1870; acting inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Nov., 1873; additional commissioner for the administration of affairs in Kalahandi, June, 1882; acting commissioner, Chattisgarh division, March-Nov., 1883, and again in 1884; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1885; on special duty as special commissioner for the repression of dacoity in Nerbudda division, Feb., 1886; from June, 1886, served under the government of India, as minister of the Bhopal state.

WARD, WILLIAM ERSKINE, C.S.I., M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1861, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866, and again in 1867, and in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March, 1873; officiating magistrate of police, Calcutta, April, 1873; from Oct., 1873, served in judicial department as acting district and sessions judge, and was transferred to Assam, March, 1876, and served as judge and commissioner of Assam Valley districts; officiated temporarily as judicial commissioner of Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; fellow of University of Calcutta; officiating chief commissioner of Assam, July-Oct., 1883, and from Feb., 1885, to 1887; president of provincial committee for collecting exhibits of Assam for Calcutta Exhibition, 1883; judicial commissioner, Burma, May, 1886; C.S.I., Jan., 1888.

WARDEN, AUGUSTUS BROOKE, Late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Kensington Grammar School, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1842; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, March, 1856; judge and sessions judge, and agent for governor, Surat, 1861; acting judge of the high court, May, 1863; judge and sessions judge of Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, Sept., 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1865; was also president of the departmental examinations committee for junior civilians for five years retired, 1871.

WARDEN, CHARLES JAMES HISLOP, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commis...
sion, 1874; from 18th March, 1876, acted as civil surgeon of Bhagulpore, with medical charge of the central jail; on special duty in the excise department, board of revenue, Dec., 1876; officiating principal assistant to the opium agent, Behar, April-Oct., 1878; officiating superintendent, central jail, Bhagulpore, Nov.-Dec., 1879; professor of chemistry, Medical College, and chemical and opium examiner to government, Dec., 1879; member of opium committee, Oct., 1880; surgeon-major, March, 1885.

WARDEN, FREDERICK, Captain, Marine Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian navy, 2nd March, 1852; from Dec., 1865, served as port-master of Canning, and, in addition (from Jan., 1867), as assistant collector customs and ex-officio superintendent of customs; from Dec., 1866, acted as assistant master attendant, and agent for government consignments, Calcutta, and from March, 1870, as agent for transports; also government prosecutor for trial of pilots, May, 1873, to March, 1876; officiating deputy master attendant, Aug., 1875; officiated as port officer, March, 1876, to Aug., 1879, and performed duties of superintendent of dockyard, from March, 1876, to Nov., 1877; assistant port officer, Aug., 1879; examiner in navigation, Nov., 1879; transferred to Rangoon as port officer, March, 1882; also superintendent of lighthouses, superintendent of mercantile marine, and transport agent.

WARDEN, JOHN LODWICK, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 8th March, 1852, and served in the Bombay covenanted civil service as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and deputy magistrate in charge of the Adalat, Hyderabadd; resigned the covenanted civil service, May, 1858; appointed extra assistant secretary to government of Bombay, in the judicial department, Dec., 1866; assistant judge and sessions judge, April, 1867, to June, 1868; acting magistrate of police, July-Oct., 1868; from Jan., 1869, served as small cause court judge, and was appointed 3rd judge, at Bombay, Dec., 1874, and second judge, May, 1888.

WARRE, SIR HENRY JAMES, General, K.C.B.,—Obtained commission from Sandhurst, 1836; ensign, 54th foot, 3rd Feb., 1837; from 1839 served as aide-de-camp to commander of the forces in British North America (Sir R. Downes Jackson, K.C.B.); during 1845 and 1846 was employed by colonial office in exploring a route for transport of troops from Canada to the Red River settlement, by Ottawa, and in surveying and reporting on the various settlements in the Oregon Territory, and on various islands on the coast of the Pacific; served in the Crimea from March, 1855, and succeeded to the command of the 57th regiment; present at the siege and fall of Sebastopol, the assaults on the Redan, and the surrender of Kinburn (medal with clasp, C.B., 5th class of the Medjidie and Turkish medal); in 1858 was in command of a mixed force on the Tapte River in co-operation with the Central India field force, and was subsequently appointed brigadier at Mhow; military secretary to the commander-in-chief in India (Lieutenant-General Sir Hugh Rose, K.C.B.), June, 1860; served in the Maori war in New Zealand, 1861, and acted for a short time as governor of the province of Auckland; was subsequently in command of the troops on the west coast, and in the province of Taranaki (under martial law), 1863-66 (medal); from 1870-74 was stationed in Ireland as brigadier-general; commander-in-chief, and member of governor's council, Bombay, Nov., 1878 to 1881.

WATERFIELD, HENRY, C.B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; junior clerk, 1st Sept., 1853; India board, financial and railway department, 1853; political and secret department, 1856; private secretary to president of the India board, 1858; India office, financial department, 1858; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1860; financial department, 1863; senior clerk, April, 1863; assistant secretary in the military department, 1867; public works department, 1871; secretary in the statistics and commerce department, 1874; secretary, financial department, 1879; C.B., Dec., 1885; author of the first report on the moral and material progress of India, 1866, and of a memorandum on the census of British India of 1871-72, both of which were presented to Parliament.

WATERFIELD, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Bengal C.S. from Haileybury in 1852; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1852; served in Bengal in the revenue and survey departments till 1859, when he was transferred to the financial department as 1st assistant to the accountant-general for India; acted as sub-treasurer, Madras, and as civil auditor and superintendent of stamps, Madras, Calcutta, and Bombay; from 1864 to 1877 served successively as civil paymaster, deputy accountant-general, and accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh; comptroller-general, 1877-80; retired, 1881.

WATERFIELD, WILLIAM GARROW, C.S.I., Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1852; from Sept., 1857, served in the Punjab as personal assistant to commissioner of Delhi, and assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1863, to Nov., 1865; assistant settlement officer, Gujarat, Nov., 1865; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1867; on special duty for reporting on the Gujarat settlement, July, 1868; commissioner and sessions judge, Peshawur, Feb., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Sept., 1878; on special duty, Nov., 1878 (with the Kurram field force); served under the foreign department of the government of India, 1881-82; author of a report on the settlement of the Gujarat district.

WATERHOUSE, JAMES, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1859; assistant revenue surveyor, Lower Provinces, June, 1866; assistant surveyor with superintendence of the photoincographic operations in the office of the surveyor-general of India, July, 1866; assistant superintendent of survey, 1st grade, June, 1870; on special duty with the Indian eclipse expedition, Nov., 1871, to Jan., 1872, and for observing the transit of Venus, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; in charge of Indian eclipse expedition to Nicobar Islands, March, 1875; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Jan., 1884; author of a pamphlet on "The Application of Photography to the Reproduction of Maps and Plans."

WATERS, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. (Ed.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st Oct., 1863; arrived in India, 27th May, 1870, and
served in the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, Bombay, and civil surgeon at Bushire (1871-75); on special duty under the government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March-April, 1877; surgeon to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; from Oct., 1881, served as third physician and registrar, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, curator of the pathological museum, and professor of pathology, Grant Medical College; also acted as first physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of medicine, clinical medicine and hygiene.

WATKINS, Lawrence Augustus, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1863; served in the Bombay judicial department from Jan., 1865, as deputy registrar of the high court, clerk to the high court judges, and commissioner for taking affidavits; also acted as assistant commissioner for taking accounts, and assistant taxing master, Aug.-Oct., 1878.

WATSON, H. E., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 29th June, 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, June, 1879; in charge of the special duty of the salt department in Sind, July-Oct., 1880; on special duty in the military department, June, 1881; head assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, June, 1885.

WATSON, Sir John, Major-General, K.C.B., V.C., Bombay S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, 1848; from Sept., 1871, served as commandant, Central India Horse and political agent; resident, and class, and agent to the governor-general at Gwalior April, 1877, also acting as agent for Central India; brigadier-general commanding cavalry brigade, Malta expeditionary force, 1878; commanding Punjab chiefs' contingent in Afghanistan, 1878-79; in political charge of the district of Kuram, Nov., 1879, to Nov., 1880; resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general, Baroda, Jan., 1882; retired from the political department, March, 1886.

WATSON, John Whaley, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 6th Oct., 1854, and served under the military department till Feb., 1863, and subsequently in the political department as political assistant and acting political agent, Kathiawar; also acted as assistant resident, Baroda, and superintendent of Gaekwar's contingent, Oct., 1863; special assistant, Gondal, March, 1872; acting political superintendent of Palanpur, March, 1873, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, March, to Nov., 1876; appointed joint administrator of Bavnagar, March, 1877; president of the Rajasthani court, Kathiawar, July, 1878; acting political agent, Kolhapur and Southern Maharatta country, May, 1885; political agent, Kathiawar, Jan., 1886.

WATT, G., M.D., C.I.E., Educational Service, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th July, 1873; arrived, 4th Nov., 1873; served in the 3rd class of the Bengal education department as professor, Presidency, Hooghly, and Patna Colleges, and as officiating principal, Krishnagar College, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Burma-Munipore boundary expedition, Oct., 1881; services placed at disposal of executive committee of the Calcutta International Exhibition, Feb., 1883; served under government of India, revenue and agricultural department, from May, 1884; C.I.E., June, 1886; reporter of economic products, April, 1887.

WEBB, W. T., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 6th April, 1875; professor, Dacca College, May, 1875; officiated as inspector of schools, Feb., 1877; professor, Presidency College, from Jan., 1878; officiating principal, Calcutta Madrassa, in addition to other duties, Oct., 1880; 3rd class, education department, Dec., 1880; has published 'Hints on the Study of English,' 'Indian Lyrics,' and translations.

WEBSTER, Edmund Forster, C.I.E. (Barrister-at-Law), late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Madura, May, 1867, and afterwards at Cuddalore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, June, 1873, and at Trichinopoly, Aug., 1873; collector and magistrate and agent, Tanjore, April, 1878; on special duty in connection with the famine commission, Oct., 1878, and again, Aug., 1881, as secretary to the famine code committee; member of the forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1882; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, July, 1883, and again, July, 1885, and March, 1886; chief secretary to government of Madras, Jan., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; member of the committee in connection with the draft tenancy bill, July, 1885; retired, Oct., 1887; C.I.E., May, 1888.

WEBSTER, Henry Binny, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 17th June, 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Nov., 1867, and subsequently at Gorakhpur and Meerut; commissioner, Jhansi division, Jan., 1878; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1880; retired, 1886.

WEDDERBURN, Francis Edward Keir, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; officiating political agent and assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner of Coorg.

WEDDERBURN, Sir William, Bart., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 25th Nov., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judicial assistant to the commissioner in Sind, and small cause court judge; acting under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations; June, 1866; acting registrar-general of assur-
ances, Oct., 1866; acting secretary to government in the judicial, political, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Dec., 1866, and again in 1870 and 1874; under secretary to government, judicial and political departments, May, 1867; acting registrar, high court, Jan., 1869; acting judicial commissioner in Sind and judge of the sadar court, May, 1874, to Feb., 1875; and grade judge and sessions judge, June, 1875; on special duty in Bombay, Nov., 1876; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, May, 1882; on special duty under government of India, April-May, 1884; acting judge, high court, Bombay, Jan., 1885; acting chief secretary to government, Oct., 1886; retired, May, 1887.

WEEKES, ARTHUR, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, and Feb., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; on famine relief duty at Madras, Feb., 1877; retired, March, 1883.

WEIDEMANN, GEORGE LEVER, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1870, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner (3rd grade, May, 1884); on special duty in Rangoon, July, 1879.

WEIR, CHARLES JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Royal Belfast Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; from May, 1884, served in Coorg as officiating first assistant commissioner and district magistrate; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Oct., 1886; officiating under secretary to government of India finance department, May, 1887-April, 1888; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1888; officiating principal assistant to collector and magistrate, Aug., 1888.

WEIR, JOHN WILLIAM ALLEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin School, Hammersmith, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

WEIR, PATRICK ALEXANDER, Surgeon, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service 1875; officiating and resident surgeon, presidency general hospital, 2nd Aug., 1876; on special duty with lieutenant-governor on tour in cyclone districts, Nov., 1876; superintendent of vaccination, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, March, 1882; principal assistant to opium agent, Benares, May, 1882.

WEIR, THOMAS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1867, and served in Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate; deputy registrar, high court, Jan., 1870, to June, 1872; acted as registrar, high court, Feb., 1874, to Feb., 1880; Tamil translator to government, Jan., 1879; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Godavari, March, 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; confirmed as registrar, high court, April, 1882; published the law of offences and criminal procedure, and the civil digest of rules and standing orders of the high court; from July, 1883, acted as district and sessions judge in the districts of Coimbatore, North Tanjore, and Madura, and was placed on special duty in connection with the reorganization of the subordinate judicial service, Nov., 1883; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1886; district and sessions judge, Madura, Nov., 1887.

WEIR, T. S., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1870; health officer, Bombay, from 1874; surgeon-major, April, 1882.

WELD, MATTHEW RICHARD, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dublin University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as district and sessions judge, Kistna, Jan.-March, 1885, and as collector and magistrate in the same district from April, 1885; appointed district and sessions judge, Ganjam, Sept., 1888.

WELDON, THOMAS, C.I.E., Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Joined Addiscombe, Jan., 1852; ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 12th April, 1854; from July, 1860, served in the Madras police department as assistant superintendent and superintendent; senior magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1867; on special duty, in connection with the note forgery case, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; chief magistrate of police, Madras, April, 1877, on special duty in Burma in connection with the commissariat case, Nov., 1879; chief presidency magistrate, Madras, Dec., 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; commissioner of police for town of Madras, Dec., 1885; C.I.E., May, 1888.

WELLS, WALTER FOX WILLIAMSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1875, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; city magistrate, Lucknow, Oct., 1885.

WELSH, WILLIAM HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, assistant sessions judge, and acting principal assistant collector and magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, Jan., 1885; senior assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1887; acting district and sessions judge, Aug., 1888.

WEST, SIR RAYMOND, K.C.I.E., M.A., Barrister-at-Law, F.R.G.S., LL.D., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1856, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector...
and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, officiating under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and acting judge and sessions judge; registrar, high court, Bombay, June, 1863; judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, June, 1872; judge of the high court, Bombay, Sept., 1873; on special duty as member of the law commission, Calcutta, April-Nov., 1879; vice-chancellor of the University of Bombay, Oct., 1886; member of council of governor of Bombay, 12th Nov., 1887, K.C.I.E., June, 1888.

WESTERN, JAMES HALLIFAX, C.M.G., Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1862; assistant engineer public works department, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1863; Eastern Jumna canal, Jan., 1864; executive engineer, Ganges canal, June, 1868; superintendent of works, Betwa canal, Nov., 1881; transferred to Punjab as temporary superintending engineer, Sirhind canal, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1882; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, Nov., 1884; services lent to Egyptian government; retired, Jan., 1887.

WESTLAKE, SIDNEY ST. JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated in Germany, and at Cheltenham, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1886.

WESTLAND, JAMES, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen, and Wimbledon School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 10th Oct., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1867, officiating magistrate and collector, Jessore, Aug., 1868, officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1869, and officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1870; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Dec., 1870; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1873; accountant-general, Central Provinces, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Nagpore circle, Dec., 1873; on special duty in the home department, Nov., 1875; inspector of local offices of accounts, Nov., 1877; accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878; acting comptroller-general and head commissioner, department of issue of state paper currency, April, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884, Nov., 1886, and again Nov., 1887; to England on special duty, April-Sept., 1884; member of finance committee, March, 1886; officiating member governor-general's council, Aug., 1887; temporary member, Nov., 1887; C.S.I., June, 1888.

WESTMACOTT, EDWARD VESEY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 8th Jan., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was on famine relief duty, Jan., 1874; officiating commissioner Dacca division, Aug., 1885; on special duty for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system, Nov., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1883; services placed temporarily at disposal of financial department, Oct., 1883; officiating inspector-general of jails, March, 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, April, 1887, and again March, 1888; port commissioner, Calcutta, April, 1887; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1887.

WESTROPP, GEORGE RALPH COLLIER, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1851; was employed under the military department, including service in Khandeish against the rebel leader Tantia Tope, 1858; adjutant, Savantvadi local corps, Feb., 1859; acting assistant magistrate in Ratnagiri, May, 1860; assistant to political superintendent, Savantvadi, Nov., 1862; assistant political agent, Kolhapur, 1865-1866; in charge Southern Mahatta Jhagir states, 1866-1877; political superintendent, Savantvadi, and commandant of the local corps, Aug., 1877; deputed on special duty in the Savanur state in 1880.

WESTROPP, SIR MICHAEL ROBERT, Knight.—B.A., Trinity College, Dublin, 1838; called to the bar of Ireland, 1840, and to the bar of Bombay, 1854; authorised reporter, court of common pleas, Ireland, 1847-1850, and in the court of chancery, Ireland, 1850-1853; acting advocate-general, Bombay, 1856-57, and again, 1861-1862; remembrancer of legal affairs, Bombay, April, 1860, to Aug., 1863; member of the legislative council, Bombay, 1861-62, and again in 1863; puisne judge of the high court, Bombay, Aug., 1863, to April, 1870; chief justice, Bombay, April, 1870, to April, 1882.

WETHERILL, JAMES FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dulwich, and at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Madras, 19th Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue and survey department, and as assistant to magistrate and collector.

WHALLEY, PAUL, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating junior secretary, and under secretary to government; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Dec., 1871, to Feb., 1872; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1877; deputy commissioner, and grade, in Oudh, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, Pilibhit, Nov., 1879; 1st grade magistrate and collector, Oct., 1883; author of 'A Collection of the Laws and Rules of the Non-Regulation Provinces.'

WHEELER, PERCY COTTERILL (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant settlement officer, Jaunpur, Nov., 1882, assistant commissioner, and grade, April, 1887; author of 'Settlement Report of the Recent Revision of Records (1878 to 1886) in the Jaunpur districts.'
WHISH, Charles William, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tonbridge School, and Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1887.

WHISHAW, John Charles, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived, 3rd Sept., 1858, and held various military medical charges up to 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, April, 1860; superintendent, central prison and district jail, Lucknow, Nov., 1867; also civil surgeon, Feb., 1868; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Oct., 1870, also ex-officio inspector-general of prisons, March, 1871; civil surgeon, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Lucknow, Oct., 1873, also in charge of meteorological observatory, Lucknow, Dec., 1877; retired, Feb., 1886.

WHITE, Edmund, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, Feb., 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, April, 1880; also under secretary to government in the census department; on special duty in connection with census, Sept., 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1882; director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, June, 1885; author of 'Report on the Census, N.W. Provinces and Oudh,' 1881.

WHITE, Henry Frederick, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 19th Dec., 1859; assistant engineer, Dec., 1860; 1st civil divisional engineer, April, 1865; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; charge of Rohilkund roads division; in charge of Mhow military works division, 1872, 1878, 1880; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, July, 1885; superintending engineer, May, 1888.

WHITE, H. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 4th Dec., 1872; graduated B.A., London University, with French honours, in 1882.

WHITE, Herbert Thirkell, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1878, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; on special duty, Rangoon, April, 1880; officiating deputy commissioner, Thayetmyo, April, 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, April–Sept., 1883; and again in 1883; officiated for various periods between 1880 and 1886 as assistant secretary, junior secretary, and secretary to the chief commissioner; also as director of agriculture, Aug.–Nov., 1884; secretary to the chief commissioner for Upper Burma, March, 1886; secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1887; officiating commissioner, Northern division, Upper Burma, Feb.–June, 1888; officiating chief secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1888.

WHITE, James, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Dec., 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Rajputana under the foreign department of the government of India as officiating political assistant, 3rd class, and acted as superintendent, Rajputana state railway police, and also held charge of the office of political agent, Jaipur; served again under the foreign department of the government of India, May, 1876, to Dec., 1881, in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and political agent, 3rd class, and officiated as resident (3rd class) and commissioner of Ajmere, May–Aug., 1878; also acted as general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggery and dacoity, Nov., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Gonda, July, 1883; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1887.

WHITE, John Hubbard, Colonel, R.E., Mint-Master, Bombay.—Second lieutenant, Bombay engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, Nov., 1855; from June, 1856, served in the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer and executive engineer (for irrigation); from May, 1865, to Feb., 1874, served as deputy consulting engineer and acting consulting engineer for railways, Bombay; acting superintending engineer, Feb., 1874; acting chief engineer, and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, June–Dec., 1874; transferred to financial department of government of India as acting mint-master, Bombay, June, 1876; rejoined the railway department, Feb., 1878; from March, 1879, served as mint-master and mint-engineer, Bombay; senior mint-master from Jan., 1884.

WHITE, Philip James, North-Western Provinces.—Signaller in telegraph department, July, 1854; was employed in various capacities in several government offices till outbreak of mutiny, when he served with a body or volunteer horse and was present at various engagements; mutiny medal; deputy collector and deputy magistrate, Gorakhpur, Sept., 1858; assistant settlement officer, Nov., 1859; from March, 1863, served in the Jhansi commission as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jalna, Dec., 1879; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1885.

WHITESIDE, William Southey, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in May dras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy secretary to government, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting civil and sessions judge, small cause court judge of Cuddalore, 1866–67, and acting collector and magistrate; collector and magistrate of North Arcot, Feb., 1873, and subsequently at Tanjore; on special duty as member of the forest draft bill committee in Ootacamund, May, 1882; served on the board of revenue from Aug., 1882, in charge of the Inam department; acting president of the board of
examiners, Nov., 1882; acted as director of revenue settlement and agriculture, and Inam commissioner, April-July, 1884; on deputation in the southern districts for reporting on working of Licence Tax Act, Dec., 1884; additional member of the governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, Nov., 1886; acting and member, board of revenue, March, 1888.

WHITEWAY, RICHARD STEPHEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of London, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting assistant secretary to government, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Oct., 1879; settlement officer, 3rd grade, on special duty at Aligarh, Nov., 1881; settlement officer, Ajmere and Merwara, Jan., 1883; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, March, 1888.

WHITMORE, JOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, Dec., 1881; district and sessions judge, and grade, Sept., 1885; district and sessions judge, Fureedapore, Sept., 1886.

WHITTEN, RICHARD JOHN, Salt Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service in Feb., 1862, as assistant patrol; deputy inspector, internal branch, Jan., 1867; on deputation to inquire into illicit manufacture of salt in Behar, 1869; personal assistant to commissioner of inland customs, Oct., 1869; collector of customs, Sept., 1871; on deputation to report on salt taxation in Sind, July-Aug., 1872; 1st grade collector, July, 1876; on deputation in Rajputana to report on salt sources in connection with proposed abolition of inland customs line, July-Oct., 1877; employed temporarily under government of Bombay in salt inquiries in Kutch and Kathiawar; deputy commissioner of inland customs, Dec., 1879; officiated as commissioner of Northern India salt revenue, May-June, 1885.

WHITWORTH, GEORGE CLIFFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sandicroft School, Northwich, and Queen's College, Liverpool; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council, Jan., 1876; (pro tem.) under secretary to government in the public works department for relief purposes, Sept., 1877, to March, 1878; second assistant collector, Feb., 1881; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Nov., 1886; and grade, judge and sessions judge, Nov., 1887; author of 'The Theory of Relevancy for the purpose of Judicial Evidence,' an 'Anglo-Indian Dictionary,' 1885, and the 'Rajkumar Law Lectures,' 1888.

WICKES, THOMAS HAINES, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by government of India as special assistant engineer, April, 1861; engineer to the suburban municipality, Calcutta, Jan., 1865; re-appointed as executive engineer, public works department, Bengal, Nov., 1865; on special duty in the famine districts, May, 1874, and in connection with the Eastern Bengal railway, April, 1875, also with the secretary to the government of Bengal, March, 1878; assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; 1st superintending engineer, temporary, April, 1888; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1888.

WIGHT, JOHN KNOX, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Queen's Collegiate School, Trinidad, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1872, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, April, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; deputy commissioner, Sept. 1885; 2nd grade, May, 1888.

WIGNER, JOHN M., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's Lynn Grammar School; B.A. and B.Sc., London University; temporary clerk, India office, 17th July, 1862; junior clerk, Jan., 1867; senior clerk, July, 1885.

WILKINS, CECIL ASDELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating registrar, high court, April, 1880, and again from 1881 to 1884; on special duty in the high court, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1884; officiating registrar, high court, March, 1885; district and sessions judge, and grade, Beerbhoom, April, 1886; compiled revised editions of the High Court's Rules and Orders, in 1881 and 1883.

WILKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined the Bengal artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, Jan., 1858; served with the Cawnpur field force, Feb.-March, 1858; studied at Thomason College, Roorkee, March, 1861, to Aug., 1862; served in the revenue survey from April, 1863, as assistant surveyor, and was employed in the Central Provinces, Punjab, Midnapur, Dearah, and British Burma surveys; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1878; and grade, Jan., 1887.

WILKINSON, ALFRED REGINALD, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal infantry.—First commission, 1860; from 10th July, 1863, served in the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; attached to the special police levy for service in Bhutan, Oct., 1864; on special duty at the presidency, June, 1866; personal assistant to the inspector-general of police, 1869 to 1881; promoted to 1st grade district superintendent, June, 1886; has also acted as deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and as deputy inspector-general.

WILKINSON, FRANCIS HENRY, Madras C.S.
—Educated at Milton Abbas School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in Madras from Feb., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as under secretary to government in the revenue department, Aug.-Nov., 1867; on special duty as arbitrator of boundary disputes, June, 1870; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Salem, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, June, 1882; judge of the high court, Madras, Nov., 1887.

WILKINSON, THOMAS ORMEROD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Chudleigh Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; officiated as registrar of the chief court in 1878, 1879, and 1880; judicial assistant, and grade, Dec., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Jan., 1887.

WILLIAMS, ALBERT, Bengal C. S. (Punjab).—Educated at Uppingham, Clifton, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1886, and was appointed assistant-commissioner, Punjab.

WILLIAMS, EDWARD C. S., Major-General, C.I.E., R.E., India Office.—Commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; arrived in India, 1850; adjutant of engineers, Fort William, and studying machinery in Calcutta mint, 1850; extra assistant secretary, military board, 1851; superintendent, iron bridge yard, Calcutta, 1851-52; served with the Pegu expedition, 1852-53, as adjutant of engineers and in charge of engineer park (medal and clasp); superintendent, Pegu topographical survey, 1854-56; principal, Civil Engineering College, Calcutta, 1856-60; member of senate, Calcutta University; acted as under secretary to government of India, public works department, for one year, during mutiny; principal, Thomason College, Roorkee, 1861-62; under secretary, government of India, public works department, 1863-69; member of Bengal sanitary commission; in charge of office of inspector-general of forests for one year; acting mint-master and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, 1867; deputy secretary, government of India, public works department (railway branch), 1869-74, and again, 1877-78; director of state railways, 1874-77; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; deputy government director of Indian railway companies, India office, March, 1880.

WILLIAMS, FLEETWOOD, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1829; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1831; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating political agent, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1841; magistrate and collector, Bareilly, 1845; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Meerut division, 1857; retired in 1870.

WILLIAMS, GEORGE ROBERT CARLISLE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, acting deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; deputy commissioner, and class, Jhansi, March, 1883; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1886; author of 'An Historical and Statistical Memoir of Dehra Dun.'

WILLIAMS, HENRY CLISSOLD, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; from Nov., 1878, served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Jan., 1883; inspector-general of police and jails, superintendent of stamps and commissioner of excise, Assam, Sept., 1885; deputy commissioner, and grade, March, 1886.

WILLIAMS, JOHN CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, London, and Uppingham School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1863; from Jan., 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was specially deputed to Lucknow for the purpose of compiling and reporting on census, March, 1869; from May, 1875, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1880.

WILLIAMS, RALPH KING, Public Works Department, Central Provinces.—From Nov., 1869, to Feb., 1873, served in the office of the consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, as accountant and deputy controller, and was appointed assistant examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in 1872; served in Madras from Feb., 1873, to March, 1878, and was appointed deputy examiner, May, 1876; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in Calcutta, March to May, 1878, and subsequently in Madras, and at Lahore, March, 1880; examiner, 4th class, Indus valley state railway accounts, Aug., 1880; transferred to Nagpur, Central Provinces, March, 1885; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, April, 1885; examiner, North-Western railway accounts, Lahore, Jan., 1886; and class examiner, Dec., 1886; 1st class, temporary, May, 1888.

WILLIS, JOHN, Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 3rd Nov., 1862; junior book-keeper, Nov., 1868; assistant book-keeper, Dec., 1881.

WILLOCK, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin, and Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th March, 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting principal assistant collector; on special duty, Jan., 1876, as secretary to the salt commission; from March, 1879, served in the salt department as deputy commissioner, and acting commissioner.
WILLOUGHBY, MICHAEL WEEKES, Brigadier-General, C.S.I., Bo. S.C.—First commission, Bombay army, June, 1849; acted as secretary to government of Bombay in the military, marine, and ecclesiastical departments, from 1st May, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881.

WILLSON, J., M.A., Bengal Educational Service (Assam).—Arrived in India, and Jan., 1870; Professor, Cathedral Mission College, Calcutta, Jan., 1870; assistant, geological survey of India, Sept., 1871, to Feb., 1873; professor, Hooghly College, March, 1873; Dacca College, Jan., 1874; Patna College, May, 1875; 3rd class of the education department, Aug., 1878; from Jan., 1879, served in Assam as inspector of schools.

WILSON, ARTHUR.—Puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1878.

WILSON, DAVID, M.A., Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at Hutcheson's Grammar School, Glasgow; University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1886; served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

WILSON, FREDERICK ALEXANDER, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal S.C., Political Department of Government of India.—1st commission, Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 8th June, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1860; admitted to the staff corps, April, 1860; extra A.D.C. to viceroy, Dec., 1860; from Nov., 1870, served under the foreign department of the government of India as guardian and tutor to the Nawab of Jaora, and from 1874, as additional political assistant and political assistant in Jaora, in Central India, and at Tehri; tutor to the Maharaja of Mysore, June, 1876; 1st assistant resident, Hyderabad, Oct., 1870; political agent, 3rd class, Oct., 1881; agent to the governor-general with the King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, March, 1882; boundary settlement officer and assistant to political agent, Bundelkhand, Jan., 1883; political agent, and class, Jan., 1884; officiated as resident, and class, in Nipal, and political agent, Bharatpur and Karauli; political agent, Bundelkhand, Oct., 1886; served in the Bhutan campaign of 1864-65 (medal and clasp), the Hazara campaign of 1868, the Black Mountain (clasp).

WILSON, GEORGE HERBERT DASHWOOD, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Magdalen College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 26th Nov., 1863, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, May, 1880; senior collector, Broach, May, 1885; retired, Aug., 1887.

WILSON, JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Perth Academy, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty, April, 1879, and again, Oct., 1880, in the civil secretariat; officiating under-secretary to government, July, 1881, and again in 1884; on special duty at Simla for the purpose of writing the final report on the Sirsa settlement, Aug., 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, April-May, 1886; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Sept., 1886; officiating deputy commissioner, Oct., 1886; author of 'A Code of Tribal Customs in the Gurgaon and Sirsa Districts.'

WILSON, JOHN HATTON, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Probationary assistant engineer, 5th March, 1856; served in the public works department in the Central Provinces, and temporarily in Oudh, 1865-67, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; temporarily transferred to military works branch, July, to Sept., 1879; in charge of the Nagpore and Chattisgarh railway reconnaissance survey division, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, and transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1881; superintending engineer, and class, Dec., 1885; 1st superintending engineer, temporary, March, 1886.

WILSON, ROBERT HENRY, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, and Feb., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating registrar-general of assurances, Sept., 1870; also officiating marriage registrar, Calcutta; officiating under-secretary to the government of Bengal, Dec., 1870; inspector of registration offices, July, 1872; officiating inspector-general of registration, Sept., 1872; officiating secretary, board of revenue, July, 1877, and again in 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, Aug., 1884; employed under the public works department on the commission in connection with the Orissa canals, Nov., 1884; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Feb., 1886; on special duty with the finance committee, 1886; retired, Sept., 1887.

WILSON, THOMAS CORBY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, Central Provinces; acting district superintendent of police, Hoshangabad, Sept.-Nov., 1884; assistant settlement officer, June, 1886.

WILSON, WILLIAM, M.A., Madras C.S.—Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna, Feb., 1874, and collector and magistrate, June, 1877; on special duty for compiling irrigation accounts, Nov., 1875, and again, Oct., 1879, and Aug., 1881; acting director of revenue settlement, April, 1878, to Sept., 1879; collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Oct., 1879, to Aug., 1881; collector, magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1882; acted as member of the board of revenue in 1882, 1883, 1884; director of revenue settlement, and agriculture, Nov., 1882; in charge of the Inam department, March, 1883; also an additional member, board of revenue, April, 1883; permitted to visit on duty agricul-
tural institutions in N.W. Provinces, and Bombay, Nov., 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885; acting secretary to government of Madras in the revenue department, April, 1885; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Sept., 1885; acting chief secretary to government of Madras, Oct., 1885; 3rd member of board of revenue, April, 1887; has acted as 2nd and 1st member of board.

WILSON, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd Jan., 1857, and was employed on military duties till April, 1864, when he was appointed acting assistant political agent, Sádra; from Nov., 1864, served as assistant superintendent of police, subordinate magistrate, superintendent of railway police on Bombay, Baroda, and Central India railway, and district superintendent; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, June, 1883; acted as commissioner of police for city of Bombay, Oct., 1885 to June, 1886; colonel, Dec., 1886; appointed commissioner of police, Bombay, July, 1888.

WILSON, WILLIAM HERBERT, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.G.S. (Heidelberg), Education Department, Madras.—Served from 4th Feb., 1875, as professor of physical science, Presidency College; fellow of Madras University, March, 1880; 3rd class, education department, June, 1882; registrar of Madras University, March, 1886.

WILTSHIRE, CHARLES PALMER BLUETT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Proprietary School, Islington, City of London School, King's College, London University, and Middle Temple; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting port officer at Karwar, and superintendent, timber depot, Canara; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873; on famine duty, Dharwar, in 1876 and 1877; in charge of Hazur treasury in 1880 and 1881; 1st assistant collector, Sept., 1886; acting collector and magistrate, Belgaum, 1888.

WIMBERLEY, REGINALD JUSTUS, Lieutenant-Col., late B.S.C.—Ensign, 3rd Bengal European regiment, 1859; served in the Punjab police force, Dec., 1861–67; commissariat department, March–Aug., 1867; from Aug., 1867, to 1872, served in Bengal as district superintendent of police; in command of police force to quell insurrection in the tributary Mehals, May, 1868; 1st assistant superintendent, Port Blair and Nicobars, April, 1872; called to the bar, Inner Temple, Nov., 1877; deputy superintendent, Dec., 1884; retired, Dec., 1887.

WINCHESTER, CHARLES BLAKE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting forest settlement officer, and acting junior collector and political agent; on famine duty, Sept., 1877; and assistant collector, Nov., 1886.

WINCHESTER, E. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 16th Dec., 1872; clerk, and class, Nov., 1878.

WINDSOR, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Old Trafford School, Manchester, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884. Arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1887; served as assistant magistrate and collector.

WINGATE, ANDREW, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, Kensington Grammar School, University of London, and University of Heidelberg; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Bombay administration report for 1874–75, and for 1875–76; in political charge of the Jath state, Feb.–Sept., 1876; additional secretary in the famine department under chief commissioner of Mysore, Aug., 1877; assistant secretary to famine commission, Aug., 1878; settlement officer in Oodeypore state, Aug., 1879; officiating resident, Meywar, Feb., 1887.

WINGFIELD, SIR CHARLES JOHN, K.C.S.I., C.B.—Educated at Westminster School, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1839; arrived in India, March, 1840; served in the revenue and judicial departments of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1854; on the annexation of the kingdom of Oudh in 1856, was appointed commissioner of the trans-Gogra division, and was actively engaged in the suppression of the mutiny, 1857–59; chief commissioner of Oudh, March, 1859; C.B., 1860, and K.C.S.I., 1866; retired, 1866; sat in parliament for the borough of Gravesend, 1868 to 1874.

WINNY, THOMAS H.—Appointed assistant to the surveyor and clerk of the works, India Office, Aug., 1885.

WINTER, EDGAR FRANCIS LATIMER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity Hall, Cambridge, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WINTER, HENRY EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and King's School, Canterbury; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement and demarcation officer, Poona districts, Jan., 1883.

WINTERBOTHAM, HENRY MARTIN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting Malayalam translator to government, March–Dec., 1877; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, June–July, 1883; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate, and as district and sessions judge in various districts; and was appointed collector and magistrate, Malabar, Aug., 1888.

WISE, FRANCIS JOHN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd May, 1857; employed on military duties till Oct., 1863, including service in the Deccan against the rebel Bills in 1857; and in Khandaish and Nimar against the rebel army
under Tantia Topee in 1858-59; served subsequently in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; also served as boundary commissioner, and assistant political agent, Khandaesh; member of committee to report to government on system of rural administration, July, 1873; on special duty on western frontier of Karachi district, Feb., 1875; on special duty in attendance on H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Nov., 1875; member of the railway robberies inquiry committee, Bombay, March-Aug., 1878; superintendent of Great Indian Peninsula railway police, June, 1878; on special duty, June, 1879, to June, 1880; 1st grade superintendent, May, 1882; acting inspector-general of prisons, May-Aug., 1884; inspector-general of police for the Bombay presidency, Jan., 1885; colonel, June, 1887.

WODEHOUSE, CHARLES, C.I.E., Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, March, 1857; arrived in India, 6th April, 1857, and was employed under the military department, including service in the mutiny campaign, 1857-58 (medal and clasp for Central India); from March, 1867, served as boundary settlement commissioner, Baroda; from Sept., 1868, acted in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, director of public instruction, and small cause court judge; acting assistant resident, Hyderabad, April to Nov., 1870; acting cantonment magistrate and judge, Secunderabad, Dec., 1870; acting assistant resident, Baroda, Jan., 1873; acting political agent, Rewa Kantha, Feb., 1873; from March, 1873, served in Kathiawar as political assistant, acting judicial assistant, and acting political agent, and was placed on special duty for the settlement of boundary disputes in the Gheer forest, July, 1874; also acted as private secretary to the governor of Bombay from May, 1876, to April, 1877; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Sept., 1881; and, grade, political agent, Feb., 1885; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, April, 1885, and in Kathiawar, July, 1886; C.I.E., Aug., 1887; on duty in England in connection with the Jubilee, 1887; acting political agent, Kolhapur, &c., June, 1883.

WODEHOUSE, SIR PHILIP EDMUND, K.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Writer, Ceylon civil service, May, 1828; assistant colonial secretary, and clerk of the executive and legislative councils, Oct., 1833; district judge of Kandy, 1840; government agent for the Western Province, 1843; superintendent of Honduras, 1851; governor of British Guiana, 9th Feb., 1854; employed on a special mission to Venezuela, Feb.-May, 1858; C.B., May, 1860; governor and commander-in-chief of the Cape of Good Hope and its dependencies, and Her Majesty's high commissioner for the settling of the affairs of the territories adjacent to the eastern frontier of that colony, 28th Oct., 1861; K.C.B., July, 1862; governor of Bombay, 6th May, 1872, to 30th April, 1877; G.C.S.I., June, 1876.

WOLFE-MURRAY, FRANCIS D'ARCY OSBORNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, acting principal assistant collector, assistant sessions judge, forest settlement officer, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and collector and district magistrate and agent.

WOLLASTON, ARTHUR N., C.I.E., Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Stockwell Grammar School; entered the India office by open competition as writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, political and secret department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1873; assistant secretary, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Jan., 1884; in 1877 published a translation of the 'Anvar-i-Suhaili' or Fables of Bidpai; in 1879 edited Sir Lewis Pelly's miracle play of 'Hasan and Husain'; appointed to succeed Sir F. J. Goldsmid as examiner in Persian at the Royal Staff College, Sandhurst, 1880; selected in 1881 by the science and art department to superintend the translation of the oriental inscriptions in the South Kensington Museum; in 1882 published an English-Persian dictionary (the first of its kind); C.I.E., 1st Jan., 1886.

WOMACK, ARTHUR SHAW, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; transferred to the Central Provinces, July, 1885, and served as assistant commissioner, and registrar of the judicial commissioners' court.

WOOD, EDWARD SEPTIMUS, Captain, Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland highlanders, 20th Sept., 1857; from Dec., 1859, served in the public works department on irrigation works, N.W. Provinces; officiated as conservator of forests, 1864-66; reverted to his regiment, Feb., 1866; appointed executive engineer, 4th grade, March, 1867; from April, 1867, served in the forest department, Oudh, and was appointed conservator, Oct., 1868; promoted to 2nd grade, Sept., 1882.

WOOD, G. P., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Marlborough, and Addiscombe; writer, India office, 25th Jan., 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

WOOD, HENRY MACKENZIE MACDONALD, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; and grade, May, 1887; also district judge; officiating divisional judge, April, 1887.

WOODBURN, ARCHIBALD FRANCIS, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Ayr Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; also acted as forest settlement officer, and as junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, June, 1885; on special duty in judicial department in connection with Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, July, 1888.

WOODBURN, JOHN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Ayr Academy, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant.
magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Feb., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating personal assistant, and officiating secretary to chief commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, in the Oudh revenue department and forest branch, Jan., 1882; also in the Oudh political department, March, 1882; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, judicial department, May, 1884; acted as chief secretary in 1884-86, and in 1887; member of the lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1886.

WOODCOCK, ELBOROUGH MARTIN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 9th March, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); appointed to Oudh military police, 27th Nov., 1858; from March, 1860, served in the police department as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1860.

WOODWARD, HILLERSDEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Birmingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting railway magistrate; on special duty in connection with the Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, Dec., 1882, and again, Aug., 1883; forest settlement officer, Sholapur, Nov., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1884; second assistant collector, May, 1885.

WOODWARD, WILLOUGHBY, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1863, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting magistrate of police at Bombay, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kántha, Aug., 1881; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, March, 1885.

WOOTTON, J. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 20th Feb., 1872.

WORDSWORTH, WILLIAM, C.I.E., M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational service, May, 1861; arrived in India, 10th July, 1861, and served as head-master of the Elphinstone Institution, Bombay, acting professor of history in the Elphinstone College, and assistant inspector of schools; from May, 1862, served as principal of the Deccan College, Poona, and also acted as professor of English literature; from June, 1872, acted as principal of the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and was also appointed to select the government records at the secretariat; confirmed as principal of Elphinstone College, and professor of logic and moral philosophy, Nov., 1874; principal, and professor of history and political economy, from June, 1878; also sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1885; C.I.E., Feb. 1887.

WORGAN, JOHN BERNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; from May, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879.

WORSLEY, CHARLES FORTESCUE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884; on special duty, Dec., 1873 (famine), and in Nov., 1882, for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system; additional commissioner of Patna, Dec., 1884; officiating commissioner, Orissa, July, 1887, and Feb., 1888.

WORSLEY, F., Political Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, savings bank department, general post-office, April-Dec., 1868; writer, marine department, board of trade, July, 1870, to July, 1874; writer, India office, 13th July, 1874; clerk specially attached to political and secret department, Feb., 1876.

WRIGHT, FRANCIS NELSON, B.A., Bengal C.S.
